It felt like they actually had cameras back in the day of Romian empire.  The scenery was too real looking.  I didn't for once think I was looking at a digital city.

title: Sheer idiocy.
review:
The acting is atrocious (Joaquin Phoenix is a particularly egregious offender). The dialogue is idiotic. The plot is laughable.

On top of which, this is yet another Hollywood extravaganza with exactly one female role among many, many male roles. (I suppose it could be worse; at least she's not a damsel in distress.)

The only positive thing I can say is that the special effects are pretty cool.

title: I expected it to be much better, disappointing
review: When I first saw the previews for Gladiator during the Super Bowl, I couldn't wait to go see it. I was very disappointed. The first fighting scene was very good, but the movie drags on at some points after that. The dramatic scenes were sooo boring that I even fell asleep a few times. I did enjoy the action scenes, but the poorly done dramatic scenes made this movie too long and too boring. Save it for a Blockbuster night, dont waste $7.50 on Gladiator.

title: My Dinner With Maximus
review: This is the talkiest bloody gladiator film I've ever seen! Yes, the first battle scene is awesome -- and there are a couple of good action scenes in the coloseum. But the rest of the film is just talk, talk, talk. It feels as though we are watching Maximus and Commodus, sitting at restaurant, talking away into the night, as the waiters stand around wanting to close up and go home. Remember when Riddley Scott made *action* films?

title: The first classic of this millennium.
review: If I have to sum it up in one line, I'll say this movie is Spartacus with better effects and, forgive me, better acting. I don't know if the movie is correct as far as history is concern, but taking in account the effort put in, I would rank this movie a classic. The first classic of this millennium. It's refreshing, it's timely,as I am sure there are many who are beginning to feel that the movies of today have little to go by if not for sound and effects.  I want to say, "Well Done!" to Mr Scott, Mr Crowe and to all involved in making Gladiator a gem. So, who said they don't make movies like they used to? They do, and (forgive me again), they're beginning to do it better.

title: Powerful
review: Not since "Braveheart" have I seen such a powerful movie.  I can't even find the words that would give due credit to Russell Crowe's strong performance. The cast (especially Joaquin Phoenix and Connie Nielsen) also deserve much praise in the portrayal of their roles.  Despite the gore of the battle scenes, the story was beautifully written -- it has a potent mixture of power, anger, fear, desperation and a dose of human savagery.

title: Disappointed by this 'Epic', but liked the human interest.
review:
I went expecting this movie to 'bring back the epic' to the cinemas. I was disappointed.

Am I along in thinking the CGI work was poor. The CGI snow looked like soap flakes poured down in front of the screen. Why didn't any settle on the actors? The 'long shots' and 'aerial fly-bys' of the city seem straight out of the remade Star Wars movies. The CGI tigers in the Coliseum seemed blurred.

The plot is so clichéd it's breathtaking! We've all seen Ben Hur, we want something different! And the number of times the emperor could have killed Maximus off, it was like a 60's Batman episode when the baddy always want's Batman to die in an interesting way.

I won't list the continuity errors.

However I did like the highly stylised fight scenes. The portrayed the violence without too much gore.

I also liked the explosive tension in the relationships between the three main characters. Portraying a mad emperor is hard, but Joaquin Phoenix managed astonishingly it well.

title: Not terrible.
review:
(implied spoilers ahoy if you haven't seen it!)

Good acting, but mismatched. Phoenix's (Caesar's heir) didn't compare to Russell Crowe (Maximus).

Characters a bit weak. What's Maximus' feelings? Is he unwilling to fight anymore? Why does he fight so hard when he has nothing to live for? Does he care or not? How could Caesar not anticipate his son's rage at being passed over? And if the sister was so cunning how is it she didn't find a way to assainate her brother who paraded around defenseless in front of her every day for 5 years? Or that she would allow her secret plans to be heard by her son? How could a former gladiator slave then go on to enslave more gladiators yet have a self-sacrificing loyalty?

The cinematics were a cut above most movies but a cut below Scott's. There were too many different filming styles; in the beginning we have the slow motion blurred battle scenes (yuck). Then CGI-peppered panorama shots (sorry, those CGI falling rose petals, birds and people still don't look quite right). Then (my favorite, the most Ridley-like) lush dream sequences with wind swept European countryside. Compare that to how much more coherent a vision we saw in Blade Runner, and those guys had to make little plastic models and matte paintings.

Worth seeing, and the Roman trivia scattered in the skit was neat, but we're not talking Blade Runner or Alien quality stuff.

title: expensive production, realistic details, but not the story
review: well, these movies are all the same. super expensive production, huge cast, stunning tricks and lot of ketchup spilled to arrange the bloody details. the production is awesome, acting not bad, but the story is not realistic at all. it seems to me that there is new wave of such movies, which were most popular in sixties coming on right now. the new ones are much more graphic, but often lack the atmosphere in comparison to the old ones. but i have to admit, gladiator is not that bad all in all. i like the opening scene especially, that is a masterpiece.

title: Give me 3 hours of Russell Crowe in a skirt, I'm a happy camper!
review:
I was ready to loathe this movie and I found myself enjoying it immensely. It has craters in the story the size of the Colisseum, but Russell Crowe makes it all work. He is totally believable as a hero, as a gladiator, as anything. He is a rare combination of star power and awesome acting skills, and he grounds and dignifies this movie even when it gets manipulative, cheesy and vulgar. Also, the writing was surprisingly mature. I loved the way the Colisseum looked, I loved seeing Oliver Reed again, and Richard Harris. Joaquin Phoenix was fantastic too. The music sucked big time. If Gustav Holst was alive he would sue the composers for stealing unashamedly from his symphonic poem, "The Planets". Gladiator is the best film Ridley Scott has done in a looooong time, but that doesn't mean much, does it?

It is well worth seeing. Hugely entertaining and not too dumb.

title: If you didn't like this film...
review: ...then you probably were expecting to see another "Ben-Hur", just as I was the first time I saw it. I felt extremely disappointed. I thought it was dark, boring and I wasn't even impressed with the F/X. Then I saw it again...And it was a revelation. Once you let the film speak to you in its own language (and not the one of the old Hollywood films) then you begin to savor it. Of course there are some ludicrous scenes ( the final confrontation between Commodus and Maximus, for example) that don't change even if you see it 10 times, but one must credit Ridley Scott for having the courage of giving us a new, more authentic look of that era, even though it was much darker and bloody than other representations we were used to see in film. Russell Crowe is perhaps the key to the film's success. His performance is outstanding. I just hope Crowe is not going to become the next Nicolas Cage. I'd like to see him taking more risks as an actor, as he has done in the past.

title: A 'modern' Roman Epic
review:
Ridley Scott has done to Roman Epics what Steven Spielberg did for WW II movies: destroy all the traditional cliches and bring a more realistic approach to the subject.

What most impressed me was the realistic portrayal of the fights making us realize that violence is not an entertainment.

The high quality of the production is reflected in every single detail: from the shining face mask of the gladiator to the giant coliseum, passing by a bird's-eye view of Rome that the Romans themselves couldn't even see, to the splendid illustrations of the atrocities of the arenas and the battlefields.

The plot is just like what one would expect from such movies. The message is simple: Loyalty and honor are worth fighting for.

Everyone should see Gladiator and enjoy the wonderful acting and the marvelous special effects.

title: Gladiator rules!
review:
Yeah, so it's not the most historically accurate document on Roman times. Gladiator rules anyway! Ridley finally hits one out of the park, succeding in delivering not only a very good movie, but one that crosses over to mainstream success... all without compromising his artistic vision, and giving us fans of his work everything we've come to expect from each of his works.

Crowe is awesome, Phoenix enjoyably campy... and Oliver Reed, well, this final performance is just a sad reminder of what an amazing performer we have lost.

Ten out of ten!

title: I was impressed....
review: This movie is good because of the way Russell Crowe plays Maximus. Always serious and determined. The story is very good, you never get bored. I also liked the camera shots, always moving as if the camera man was there. Very original...I loved every seconds of that movie....

title: Perfect
review: Gladiator is the BEST Roman era film made yet, beautiful settings, great direction, superb cast and a simple yet excellent story line that never gets boring if you haven't seen it then the only person missing out is you GO SEE IT NOW!!...

title: Brilliant
review: Gladiator is so far, the best film of 2000. The story is brilliant, the performances are excellent, and the direction is marvelous. Russell Crowe is amazing as Maximus and Joaquin Phoenix is excellent as the evil Commudus. A must see for anyone who loves epics, action, and blockbusters. Finally, 2000 has come out with a movie that destroys all expectations. See this film.

title: Intense acting by Russell Crowe
review: Intense, brilliant acting by Russell Crowe. This is an excellent vehicle for Crowe to achieve major star status. This is one special effects movie where both acting and technology worked together quite splendidly. Joaquin Phoenix was brilliant too as the hateful Commodus.

title: Russell Crowe is Hollywood's new favourite actor!
review: Gladiator is one of the most phenomenal movies you will see this year. With an excellent story and outstanding acting, Gladiator is definitely the most popular movie to come out in 2000. The true Roman culture and life of a gladiator is displayed through the eyes of Ripley Scott (the director). You will definitely feel as though you are Roman when this film is finished. With a powerful enemy and a damsel in distress, this clearly is one of those true action movies that almost runs along a Walt Disney storyline. During a survey for the best movie movie to be out yet this year, 89% of the votes were for Gladiator. It clearly shows that Gladiator is everything you've heard about in the reviews and comments from the IMDb users. This is a movie that if you don't like, I will be extremely shocked!

title: Very Good movie
review: Great battle scenes. Great photography. Visually stunning. Ridley knows how to make a movie that looks outstanding. CGI at it's best. Thought all the cast were perfect except....the bad guy. Sure he was mean - said and did bad things, but I couldn't see him in quite the same light as the bad guy in the Patriot. He WAS bad.

title: Great
review: When I went to the theatre yesterday to see Gladiator, I didn't get any idea of what kind of movie it was going to be.  Will it be like Braveheart(my favorite movie) or more like 13th Warrior( that I didn't like).  Now, I can say that it's between the both, but very different.  The playing of the actor, the story and surely the pictures very impressionate me.  Gladiator is a movie that I will counsel to all my friends.

title: Something missing...
review:
8/10. I want to be more generous, as I enjoyed this film, but it has too many little weaknesses.

I remember thinking as I watched it, 'if they cut the fight scenes, would I watch this film again?'. The answer is no.

The fight scenes are excellent, if a little stronger than in Ben-Hur (et al.) in order to satisfy the modern audiences' bloodlust. I understand the comments likening this film to Braveheart. In both films you feel you are being given a glimpse of what it really must have been like to be involved. They are gripping scenes and, unlike Saving Private Ryan, the fighting comes along at nice regular intervals, a fresh hit to prolong the high...

While the rest of the film is not too bad, I felt it was just a little simplistic. Only Commodus was what could be described as a complex character. His sister should have been, and maybe she was before the cutting room, but she ended up behaving like a Bond girl. The actors were up to it but I felt the quality of the script let them down. It wasn't ambitious enough. It was as though Ridley Scott lost his nerve and tinkered with it to ensure mass market appeal (i.e. shortened it and dumbed it down).

I cannot leave without mentioning Olly Read. I am really happy his last film wasn't a turkey. He was a bit a scene stealer too, it is his eyes I think - twice the size of anyone elses!

title: Maybe I'd expected too much but entertained
review:
Since I'd heard the new Roman gladiator movie has been made, I'd gotten excited and had high expectation. I'm not trying to say I didn't like this movie. I loved this movie and want to see it again. I think that I'd expect a movie, a masterpiece like ben-hur. This movie should have been a masterpiece with these marvelous actors, big budget, talented director.

When I first saw "Gladiator", the one thing I didn't like was ending. in ending scene the whole theater starts laughs. too cheesy to touch. How could Lucilla and the people let Roman Emperor's dead body abandoned like that? I think there's lack details of how brutal, devilish the emperor was. and how much the people in Rome hated their emperor.

Joaquin Phoenix was the most outstanding part to me. Russell crowe was a gorgeous and excellent figure as always. I hope there would be lots of Oscar chance to come!!

title: Makes a refreshing change
review: I'm writing here as someone who enjoyed the film a great deal, excusing its liberties with history and minor plotting niggles. However, one of the most refreshing aspects of the film was that, as an Englishman,it eased my movie paranoia. A major epic, internationally successful- and the villain's played by AN AMERICAN! And the hero isn't! And most of the "Good guys" are played by Brits! If recent hollywood epics (E.G "Braveheart","The Patriot", the one where the bloody boat sinks) are anything to go by, we English are all sadistic, devious, perverted Nazis! (Actually, the whole "need a villain, get in a Brit" thing goes a long way back- George Sanders as Shere Khan, Basil Rathbone  and Alan Rickman as Sherrifs of Nottingham ) And if "Private Ryan" and "U571" are anything to go by, we just curled over and downright surrendered to Hitler without a squeak! (Mind you- does anyone remeber Errol Flynn in "Mission Burma"?- plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose, as the French sometimes say, when they're not too busy collaborating with Germans (That's a joke, by the way). Oh well, it's nice to see a thoughtful film with a memorable cast and visual appeal go down well with the public. Am I the only one who thinks that cinema goers are getting a bit brighter and perceptive? I hope I'm right.

title: The best big budget movie of 2000 so far.
review: I had high hopes when I walked into the theater to see this movie with my girlfriend.  Two and a half hours later, I knew my hopes had been realized. This movie struck me the way few movies have ever done.  It involved me deeply with the plot and the characters;  the special effects where done very well to mask that they were there, thus making them even better;  and the battle scenes were enthralling.  Russel Crowe showed again why he is rapidly ascending the ladder of success in Hollywood with his superb acting job, and Ridley Scott showed off his directing prowess in a way I haven't seen since Alien.  This movie is a must see. Phalanx

title: Astonishing, wonderful, great...what else to say?
review:
"Gladiator" is one of the best movies I've seen for the last few months! This is great entertainment...I loved it! words are difficult to find in English to express what I feel, so let's speak French for a while... Bravo à Ridley Scott qui signe un film superbe (oui!) servi par des acteurs non moins superbes!!!

A French fan (I'll probably go and see it a second time...pure pleasure!)

title: An entertaining and captivating film
review: Gladiator was a very exciting and captivating film, the battle scenes and characters kept my interest at all times. Russel Crowe gave an intense and convincing performance. My only complaint is that the movie seemed at times like an unofficial sequel to 'Braveheart' as it concentrated on the same idea of a would be farmer whose revenge inspires him to fight for the good of his people. In short, it is a good old fashioned epic well worth watching but nothing we have not seen before.

title: A Roman Re-hash of Braveheart
review: Basically, this is Braveheart re-written and shot for fans of Ancient Rome. As this is a new film, the obligatory special effects are excellent and do not look out of place.  The fighting in the gladiatorial scenes is some of the best I have seen and that is including Bruce Lee.  However, there are a few flaws to this film, such as an extremely banal plotline and the odd cliche.

title: What a cracker.
review:
I enjoyed this movie from beginning to end. I wonder however if anyone else spotted that the sound-track purporting to be 2nd century AD German warriors psyching themselves up for battle was actually poached from Zulu starring Michael Caine. That was I think a little joke from Ridley Scott.

Don't however let that put you off, this film will be regarded as a classic in years to come. Russel Crowe shows great maturity as a actor and certainly has the presence to handle the lead role in an epic movie. Kirk Douglas and Charlton Heston can now see that they have a worthy successor.

Let this film stand alone and please lets not have "Gladiator 2, the sandals' return".

title: The return of an Epic-class movie, ....long overdue.
review:
Cinematography and some kind of digital film enhancement of action scenes also add to this impressive story. Not since 'Ben Hur' and 'Sparticus' has the movie screen seen a really successful film of early Roman Empire history.

If this starts a trend, I hope that producers look into such historical figures like that of Constantine I (273?-337C.E.) who have enough of both impressive facts and mystery surrounding their life that would make for entertaining story telling on the big screen.

I agree with others about how entertaining this movie was. I would not even go to the restroom while this film was going on. Every scene was impressively done with fine supporting cast. The energy and flavor of what it must have been like in the time of the Roman Empire was very well captivated: particularly with its demand of political obedience to power, how people of an era were entertained by real violence, barbarian invasions at the Empire's borders, different personalities and thought among a Roman Senate, an excellent portrayal of Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius, all fine supporting acting, and of course Russell Crowe. I will be interested in seeing if the Academy of Motion Pictures chose 'Gladiator' for any of its Oscar categories.

title: A Sweeping Epic
review: I did not have any expectations when I saw this movie because I did not know anything about it. The trailer was enough to compel me to see this movie... and was I ever surprised. I was expecting a good movie; what I saw instead was beyond that. This movie is a sweeping epic that blew away my every concept of what a "grand movie" is. It is, without question, the best movie I have ever seen. And the original motion picture soundtrack (by Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard) is a haunting and stellar composition.

title: Things I like about GLADIATOR (warning: spoilers)
review:
1. The battle scenes. Even on second viewing, they had me on the edge of my seat, teeth locked, fists clenched. "Are you not entertained?" Maximus demands. Yup, I sure was. I was scared, horrified, nerve-wracked and at times revolted. But bored? Hell, no!

2. Marcus Aurelius. In every other movie that shows Caesar Marcus Aurelius, the director slobbers all over him and makes him out as an all-wise philosopher. Ridley Scott portrays him more like what I feel he was: a well-intentioned fool.

3. There are NO CHRISTIANS in this movie! Scott broke Rule One in Roman-Epic-Making, which saith the plot must be at least tangentially about conflict between persecuted Christians and evil heathens. Of course, Christianity in Imperial Rome started out as just an insignificant player among many, many cults. For once we not only get a hero who isn't a Christian, but a hero who is devoutly and warmly pious in the old pagan traditions.

4. The acting. Everybody does a wonderful job. Crowe is so subtle that Phoenix upstages him, but they're both excellent. Crowe, as always, is a master at hinting at deep thoughts that just barely ripple the surface of his face. Phoenix gives us a wonderful villain, provoking both pity and disgust, whose footsteps on the path from good to evil are clearly visible behind him. Nielsen, Jacobi, and Hounsou all enrich the movie, and even Harris (perfectly cast) gives a good performance. And Oliver Reed is delightful; if he is playing himself, as the stories about him suggest, then he must have been an interesting man to know. It took a lot of good acting to rescue some of the lamer dialogue, but by God they did it.

5. The coliseum. Some of the rest of Rome looked too colorless and washed out to be believable, but the coliseum was spectacular. And those tigers! How magnificent! This truly was the "grandeur that was Rome."

6. Tragedy. Not only does Maximus die, but his death achieves almost nothing. We know the Republic will never be restored, the "light" that is Rome will be snuffed in the Dark Ages, the dream will die. But Maximus has kept his integrity; he has fulfilled his word to his emperor by seeing that Commodus will not rule Rome; he has done his part to try to restore the Republic, even if it is in vain, and that may not be such a small achievement.

7. Hans Zimmer's score. Somebody said he lifted it; I don't know if that's true, but if he did then he lifted it from the right place. It's simple and powerful, perfectly chosen for the scenes. The Celtic wailing was a bit much at times, but I don't think Zimmer did that part.

8. A small touch, but a good one. Lucilla, bending over the dying Maximus, does not say "I love you," which she surely must have been thinking. Instead, she says "Go to them." Which, when you think about it, is really a much better demonstration of how much she cared about Maximus than the more obvious line would have been.

And some things I didn't like...

1. The ending. Ten points for having the guts to kill the hero off. But Lucilla's and Gracchus' "truly this was the noblest Roman of them all"-type posturing was pompous and unnecessary. If we had to have an epitaph, it would have been better just to have Lucius say one sentence: "There will be no more games as long as I reign." Of course that would probably be historically inaccurate, but since when did that ever stop a good storyteller?

2. Tigers Lite? An adult male tiger weighs 500 pounds. I don't care if you're Arnold Schwarzenegger, if one of those things jumps on your back, you're going DOWN and staying there.

3. Maximus' home. Farmers that stand immobile, a mother and child we never get to know before they die. It all sounded so much better when Maximus described it then when we saw it.

But I'm just carping to show that I paid attention. GLADIATOR's a magnificent movie. For heaven's sake, fork over the money to see it on the big screen.

title: A cinematic masterpiece!
review: This is truly cinema at its best!  A breathtaking performance by Russell Crowe, and one of the best supporting casts I've ever seen make this a perfect film.  Joaquin Phoenix is perfect as Commodus, as he makes you hate him.  The story itself is simple, but simplicity can be a good thing.  We don't need complex storylines for movies to be good.  In all of my favorite films, I can pick out at least a few small problems, whether it be in dialogue, acting, or plot inconsistencies, but with Gladiator, everything is completely perfect.  Why they don't make all movies this great is beyond me.

title: first rate film with a schoolboy error
review: overall a really enjoyable film which kept me on the edge of my seat for the full showing. excellent acting by all involved, which makes me quite sad that i had failed to appreciate oliver reeds qualities until his point. however, one moment early on rather made me feel uncomfortable. why, having spent all this cash on wonderful sets, costumes and special effects did the film makers have to ruin my concentration with using the zulu chorus from the stanley baker / michael caine film of the same name and try to convince me the germanic tribes were singing it. i am by no means a purist or difficult to entertain but i do know my film music and i am afraid that this stupid use of old soundtrack rather devalued the early stages of an excellent film.

title: almost the top of its genre
review: The battle scene in Gladiator presents the dichotomy of the human butchery below and the serenity of the sky above.  That image becomes the theme of the film itself.  Like all worthy films, Gladiator is a love story.  Love being a complex emotion with two faces, it is the character of the cruel and cowardly emperor Commodus that truly stitches this movie together.  As Commodus, I found that Joaquin Phoenix gave a performance comparable (if not exceeding) that of no greater a portrayer of cinematic villainy than Christopher Plummer.  Plummer, the most noted Iago, Shakespeare's ultimate bad guy, of the 20th Century, also assayed the part of Commodus in The Fall of the Roman Empire (1964).  In that, lesser, film Plummer's Commodus provides the common foe that enables the love connection between Sophia Loren and Steven Boyd to shine.  In Gladiator, Phoenix's brooding depiction of a man balanced on the edge of insanity lends his victim the pedestal of greatness, and in turn propels Gladiator above other Ancient Roman era epics, with the exception of Ben-Hur.  It is love that sends Commodus over the edge, not love of a woman, but love of himself, when he finds that he can't truly kill his father, the emperor Marcus Aurelius, whose spirit carries on in the person of the betrayed general and eventual gladiator Maximus (Russell Crowe).  The battle scene and the scenes of gladiatorial combat are not cheap gore.  They underscore the inherent brutality of that place and that time in history.  There is blood, but just enough to make the point intended.  Another theme in Ancient Roman costume epics has been the birth and fruition of Christianity, most notably in Ben-Hur and The Robe. This is touched into the canvas of Gladiator with a fine brush, as if Seurat had painted the scene, but it never comes forefront, almost thankfully. Like the sky above the battle scene, it is simply there, in the love of Maximus for his absent wife and son.  There are some noted actors who contribute to Gladiator:  Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius; the late Oliver Reed; and Derek Jacobi (who has had plenty of experience in a toga as the star of the I, Claudius series).  Gladiator is a worthwhile and uplifting film, well-acted and well-directed.  It does not succeed to the top of its genre, but very nearly so.

title: Great movie...but no Braveheart (or Titan AE)
review:
This is the first time I'm aware of that the "sword and sandals" epic has really made a comeback. I've never seen Ben-Hur or Spartacus...but I'm sure they're quite different from this. The whole time I was watching this I was getting vibes that while this was a great movie it was not trying to show us what Roman Times were really like, but rather trying to please the crowd and get more money.

Still, I liked this movie and it is a lot more intellegent than most of the other films that will be coming out this summer. Surprisingly, this film is 70% talk. If you go expecting Bloodsport you'll be disappointed. The plot is interesting, well thought out...but it was too long. I think the movie was trying to become an epic that will be remembered..and all great epics are 3 hours long. There are too many scenes that seem unnecessary.

The best part of this movie is Crowe. He isn't another hollywood pretty boy like Tom Cruise...so you can actually believe that his character is there in the action and not just dancing around pretending to hit each other on screen. He's a good actor I guess, though I can never really tell. He was nominated for best actor, though, and thats good enough for me. I also liked that one guy, something-Phoenix. He was good for his role as the films villain (probably the summers only villain that will have some redeeming qualities, therefore being a real character) SPOILER ALERT The climax of this movie, however, is weak...totally anti-climactic and out of character. It's too simple as well...hero challenges villain, hero wins...hero dies...movies over. I liked how when the villain died that didn't make a big thing out of it, with slow motion and all that, it makes it more life like that way. But the ending made me stop caring. When the hero died, I wasn't as sad as I could of been.

This movie reminded me of Braveheart...both telling the story of one man making a differince in his fight for freedom. But I enjoyed Braveheart more...I liked the music better, the characters were more interesting, and the setting was so much more beautifal and intriguing.

But it was fun, and it had a brain...something many movies you see this summer will not (60 Second, Big Mommas House, MI-2). It's no Titan AE...but since it isn't trying to be thats ok.

This movie earns the following awards: 2nd BEST Protagonist of 2000 (1st going to Cale) WORST Climax of 2000, and STUPIDEST Historical Facts guy...the romans use thumbs up to signal a win, instead of a closed fist. I actually think the filmmakers were aware of this, they were just making it clearer for the average action movie viewer this film will attract to most. Overall this film earns the better than average rating of "a movie that successfully combines good action with an interesting plot, setting and characters...just ignore the ending."

title: The movie rocked the collisseum
review:
Drawing the line between martyrdom and heroism is what makes Ridley Scott's Roman epic, Gladiator, such a powerful and moving movie. Using some computer generated shots as well as a cast of extremely talented actors, Scott beautifully creates a fictional story that shows the start of Rome's eventual downfall. I don't know too much about the history of Rome, but I didn't need to in order to enjoy this five star movie. Despite all the action and bloodshed, the humanistic issues are what bring this movie above any Hollywood anti-hype it would otherwise get.

There wasn't much to this movie that I didn't like. Graphically, there were some great matte scenes of the city and the bird's-eye view of the opening battles added to the war-like feel of the movie (however this scene reminded me a little too much of the Gungans- Droids scene in Phantom Menace). All the gladiator battle sequences were great- brilliantly choreographed and superb in cinematography. The shots were rapid fire, not allowing the viewer to focus on any one image for an extensive amount of time, but slowing down before the victory. Thus, the movie felt like it was more action packed, albeit bloody. The themes of the movie, "Strength and Honor," were always in my mind and reinforced the concept of the tragic heroism of Maximus. Maximus wouldn't be a martyr, nor would Commodus have him that way, so the element of tragic heroism overshadows the movie. Because of this feeling and the intense acting that Russell Crowe puts into his character, the closing scene was extremely moving, almost bringing tears to my eyes. Adding to the emotion is excellent scoring by Klaus Badelt, Lisa Gerrard, and Hans Zimmer. The classical music gives movement to the slow scenes as well as the fast paced battles, yet doesn't detract from the story itself. Maximus deals with human issues such as death, honesty and trust, and loyalty to a cause he believed in. Gladiator was probably one of the best movies I've seen in a while and although it is rather gory with several heads getting sliced off and a lot of bloodshed, the movie as a whole comes through as something that is definitely worthwhile seeing. It probably wouldn't surprise me if some Oscar nominations are given to this movie, either to Crowe or Phoenix, but that won't be for another year. Definitely a must-see movie.

title: Sword Wielding Fest
review: Okay, I enjoyed it in spite of the blood, body count and gore (or maybe because of it). It was well-paced and well-acted. The fight scenes were satisfactory and Russell Crowe looked liked he did know how to hold a sword. This viewer still doesn't know what to think of the ending... seems rather bizarre to me. I guess it was necessary for the two foes to come to a head but I'm not sure that it was entirely convincing to do it in the way it was done. Still I enjoyed the performances of several decent British actors and of course, Russell Crowe is always stunning.

title: Brilliant but...
review:
For me the best part of the movie was the beginning. The battle seen is the best, I have seen, of any movie. Past movies have depicted ancient battle scenes with clean soldiers, on unsullied battlefields and with uniforms that are just fresh from the dry-cleaner. This battle scene encapsulated to a degree never seen before what any battle must be like. But, in particular, it accurately depicts a Roman campaign with a battle weary/hardened Roman legion, dug in (like some unit, in the filthy trenches from the First World War) with their superior technology and training facing a barbarian horde. The battle itself was magnificent!

The rest of the movie was less plausible. I welcome any twist on historical fact (c.f. Shakespeare in Love) however this one lacked something. Maximus seemed to give in and accept his lot when "picked-up" by the gladiator owner. If my family had just been murdered I would made an attempt to escape and headed straight for my legion and then marched on Rome.

The scenes at the Coliseum and there on were lacking too. Comodus not just murdering Maximus on immediately hearing of his survival just doesn't seem right to me. The last ten minutes were the usual sentimentalist rubbish. The writers obviously couldn't agree on an ending.

However, all-in-all a good spectacle. I give it 8.

title: WOW!!!!
review:
The story is the best, the cast is great, it's the best movie ever.

It keeps you stuck to your seat during the 2:30 hours the film lasts, everytime you watch it. It's a movie to watch again, and again, that you'll never get tired or bored.

title: Very honorable man...
review:
"Gladiator" is excellent film. It has very strong message of honesty, honor, dignity and love. Do you still remember this words...? Russel Crowe is in a role of Maximus, Roman general, who is favorite of Marcus Aurelius, Roman Cezar, who wishes Maximus to be a Roman Protector, a guardian of Roman republic. Aurelis son, Commodus, has some other plans... Maximus was very popular amongst Roman army, but, over the night everything changes... In this movie, Ridley Scott guides us through ancient Rome, through it's plots, factions and nasty tricks. Great camera, picture, music and effects is visual luxury; movie has action, story, great players and moral. Oliver Reed is great as Proximus, the spirit of old Rome, honest and bloody, when human life has very little meaning. Violence in this movie makes the point - in movie where human life on battlefields has no importance at all, it show us how meaningless and horrible and monstrous is taking human life in Arena, or killing helpless women and children for political causes...

Russel Crowe is really good. His tired face is representing human struggle between honor or surrender...

title: Awesome!
review: I recently saw the teaser trailer for this and I immediately thought that it's just another action flick which people are going to forget but fortunately I was dragged into seeing it by my friends and all I can say is WOW! Yes, the action is excellent but there's more to it than that! I don't want to give anything away so please, just go watch it! It's an essential part of life!

title: I am writing this, because I cannot leave the line blank. Read the comment.
review:
In the Academy Awards show, the host, Billy Crystal, claimed to be able to read people's mind and thoughts, and when Russell Crowe's face was shown in the big TV screen, Billy said something like "..I could use a cigarette.", and those who got to see Crowe's face might have noticed that he had the same facial expression as in all his films, a serious face. I personally believe that is something to admire, being so serious all the time. We don't see Russell smiling or laughing a lot, but that doesn't affect his acting skills at all.

Crowe did an excellent job as Maximus in this movie, Gladiator. The rest of the cast was very good, including Joaquin Phoenix, who surprised me with his great performance.

The plot is pretty good, I wouldn't say it's VERY entertaining, it has some very few dialogues that could be considered boring, but overall, it's a great script.

The recreation of the ancient Rome is just excellent. The architecture of the buildings and The Coliseum is just fantastic. People in charge of that deserve a lot of credit and recognition.

The movie could be considered long (over 150 minutes), and some people might find a few scenes boring, but generally the movie keeps the viewers paying attention all the time. The fight scenes were very good, people who aren't big action fans might enjoy watching this film (though it's not completely action, a little drama too).

Crowe's character in here is very interesting. It's the kind of person that expresses the kind of feelings that make you think he doesn't fear anything, he always knows what to do next and he thinks the right way. While watching the film you get to like the character.

The ending is tragic but at the same time happy. The "bad guy" dies and the "good guy" wins, but something that maybe people weren't expecting, the good guy dies too. Maximus takes revenge, killing the Caesar, and then he dies, but if you think carefully, you'll notice that he actually wanted to die, to be together with his wife and son again, in the life after death.

This was a good movie. It's not the kind of movie that really "gets into you" and causes strange feelings and such (not many movies do that), but it's a good film and certainly worth watching. I'll rate it with a 9 out of 10.

title: Not a Spartacus for the new millennium
review:
I was really looking forward to see this one, everybody said it was great, critically acclaimed and a place in the Top 250 must be something special. But this was not what I expected. This is nothing else than your average Death Wish - one man goes for revenge flick, only difference is that it's set in the roman empire. Why do we have to see the same story over and over again? Where are new, fresh ideas? Yeah, you don't see a $ 100 million movie for intellectual advance, but this is Ridley Scott!

Remarkable is the physical presence of Russell Crowe. Since his cool-as-hell performance in `The Quick and the Dead' he was the man for the important roles, and here he shows that he's able to carry a whole movie. A truly breathtaking performance, he's the man right now!

Good action scenes and SFX, amazing sets and great acting are not enough to distract from the weak plot, but makes at least a typical popcorn movie, and isn't that what most movies are all about? 6/10

title: Rousing entertainment with subtexts you can engage with, or not. .as you please
review:
Gladiator is one of those rare films that does not depend on one single knock-em-dead effect or device. It's like a great meal you really enjoy without noticing one individual ingredient. Hence it's rather difficult to take it apart.

Firstly it's great entertainment. This is a film designed to entertain, something many studios and directors have forgotten how to do in search of the Great Message that will change the World. You could almost call it a 'people's film' just as Maximus becomes the people's hero.

The analogies in the film to modern life can be taken as far as you like without spoiling your enjoyment of the story and the spectacle you engage in. Entrepreneurs, the Olympics, sport-as-war, war-as-entertainment, public image creation, it's all there if you want to philosophise about modern spectacle.

But Gladiator is still a good story about a deprived hero setting out to Get Even with the usurper who knocked him down. It sounds hackneyed but Ridley Scott knows how to get your emotions really inside the story so you care about the characters.

It's really Russell Crowe's movie. He's so dominant and so bloody good. However he doesn't steal the film from other characters, which is another measure of a great actor. Joaquin Phoenix gives a very insightful interpretation of a man who just doesn't get it, who can't work out the secret of how to win love and how to be powerful where it matters most. He's not a stereotypical villain, but this does not detract from the film's impact, rather it enhances it.

The supporting cast are just as good and it's an eclectic blend of accents and styles but it works. Actually I found it refreshing to hear Australian, English, American and European all together - it made the film more universal.

The pacing of Gladiator is excellent. Despite the early fight scene I found my involvement built up slowly until I was hooked about half an hour in. The Germania battle I found distracting, only because I hate dropped frames and I don't think Scott does this as well as Spielberg did in Private Ryan. It's well-intentioned but I found it irritating.

Violence was controlled and in context and worked very well. This is after all a battle epic. The choice of film stock sometimes came to the fore a bit more than I liked - I felt it was overdone.

But on an emotional level this film worked beautifully for me. Like the Colosseum audience, I cheered for Maximus and booed for Commodus. It was fun. The ending was appropriate given all that Maximus had lost. I didn't feel cheated or deprived. I felt I saw what I came to see and got a bonus.

The subtexts you can take or leave as you wish. Gladiator doesn't force them down your neck. But if you want to engage at a philosophical as well as a visceral level, then you can. A rare achievement. Ole Scott, Ole Crowe. Ole Gladiator.

title: "We are all ultimately dead men. We cannot choose when we die, but we can choose how... so that we are remembered"
review:
This is probably the most sadly ironic line of Oliver Reed, here in his final film role. A cut 'n' paste last scene aside, the veteran actor gives a graceful performance in a film which would see his death before completion.

Sadly, British audiences now associate the star more with a performance on Channel 4 programme "After Dark"; where, amongst a group of chin-scratching pseuds on a discussion show a drunken Reed argued and forcibly snogged a large lady who was far from amused. "Do you want me to go?" questioned Ollie, who promptly did, gin in hand, when the rest of the guests begged him to leave the studio. Or maybe his most famous moment would be a slot on a primetime chat show, a jug of orange juice and vodka in hand, bellowing the lyrics to "Wild One".

If only for giving Ollie back his grace does Gladiator deserve praise. Direction, while derivative and gimmicky, is also well done (though it's easily Ridley Scott's weakest work). Derek Jacobi has a nice role, most famous, of course, for the mini series I, Clavdivs. Russell Crowe is Russell Crowe, all mean, macho and moody with a tiny glimmer of sensitivity underneath. A bit dull for a film that lasts ten days or however long this one went on for.

The visions of the afterlife are a little bit silly, and there's never a moment when you don't know how it's all going to end. But objectively, this is a film you can admire. Subjectively, I was bored rigid and kept losing concentration all the way through. Don't mistake me, I enjoy a good epic, but there's no emotional involvement to root you to this film, and ultimately I didn't care about Crowe's character.

Sometimes the CGI is a little too obvious, already dated whereas the 50-odd year old Ben Hur still stands up. I laughed at the tiger that looked like it'd come straight out of a ZX Spectrum, and as for the dead one. I was reminded of comedian Brian Connelly. His catchphrase? "It's a puppeeeeeeeeeeet!"

The villain is a nice portrayal of the guy that just wants to be loved. But what makes him such a bad guy? Maybe it's the fact that he kills his father, wants to sleep with his sister and has a harelip. No grey areas for Ridley. Crowe is the manly, bronzed, masculine guy that all the women love.

Gladiator is not a bad film, and I did give it a "6". I would have awarded a higher mark, if only it didn't singularly succeed in boring the pants off me.

title: ONE OF THE BEST MOVIES OF THE YEAR!
review: This movie is very good, in no way is it dissapionting, unless you has unrealistic expectations.  I personally think that this is Ridley Scotts best movie since Alien.  Russell Crowe is in top form and the action scenes are nothing short of intense. I found this film very emotianal and very entertaining. I look forward to seeing it again.  ****

title: Superb
review:
This film seems to divide people - those who think it is brilliant example of populist film-making, and those who are looking for Citizen Kane with swords, and end up disappointed. I am firmly in the former camp, and think that those in the latter are forgetting that this film stems from a line of films praised for their scale, imagery, and audacity (Fall of the Roman Empire, Spartacus, Cleopatra...), not for their genre-breaking content.

This film has all the components - a stunning lead performance by Russell Crowe, fantastic support (particularly Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, and Richard Harris), visuals to die for, fantastic action scenes, and a romantic storyline that is perfectly handled. If you accept it on those terms, you can't fail but to enjoy every minute.

title: Where's the gore?
review: It's a film about Gladiators so where's the gore? Predictable in in the most part, especially for those who are familiar with "The Life Of Brian" or even several Billy Connolly sketches, but moves along at a reasonable pace. I fully expected to see John Cleese selling Otters noses in the arena, and is that really Big Gay Al running the theatre? Manages to keep your interest (it had better - it's a long film) but is a bit lacking in gore. It's a film about Gladiators for goodness sake so a little less mawkishness and a bit more of the old blood and guts wouldn't have gone amiss. It doesn't have to be Texas Chainsaw Massacre but it doesn't have to be Asterix either. And Oliver Reed is fantastic so yah boo sucks to any director who worried about working with him.

title: A full, satisfying film
review:
Gladiator had the best of thickened plots, complex relationship issues, outrageous effects and realistic settings for this attempt to depict the struggles of a "warrior with a heart" in a nearly heartless world.

I found the opening scene powerful in its ability to draw me in to the hard, brutal world of the noble warrior and the Roman emperor, as well as giving a glimpse of the vision of the "next world" held by its protagonist.

Especially enjoyable to me were the dynamics of the son who could not force his father's love and the warrior who earned that same love by being a man of integrity, vision and value. The sins of the father's distance are visited on the son, who then visits his own sinful responses on an entire empire.

A fascinating study of the best and worst of human nature without going into caricatures, Gladiator was an epic romp, with enough meat to make chewing the bones deeply satisfying.

title: High expectations, big disappointment.
review:
Everybody said this movie was worth seeing, so I went and saw it. The beginning was promising; mighty battle scene. After that, I just kept wondering if I'm missing the greatness, because I couldn't see any.

Action scenes were very nice, otherwise very big disappointment.

title: Wonderful Stuff
review:
What we do now .. echoes through history...

A true masterpiece from director Ridley Scott, Gladiator has everything a epic movie could wish for. From the battlefields of Germania to the Gladiatorial contests of the coliseum.

It stars Russell Crowe as Maximus, a brave Roman General who is betrayed by the evil Emperor Commodus. Left for dead he is rescued by a Gladiator trainer( played by the late Oliver Reed) who trains our hero as a Gladiator. He eventually fights his way to the Coliseum in Rome when he confronts his enemies and his destiny

Everything about this movie echoes pure class. The battles, the sets, the direction. The cast is superb especially Russell Crowe, Oliver Reed and our own Richard Harris as the dying emperor Marcus Aurelius.

What the author really loved about this film was it's authenticity. Ridley Scott shows the filmgoer what Rome must have looked like at her height, decadent but wonderful. This film is a must for anyone who enjoys real entertainment, after all isn't that why cinema was invented.

title: Neither great nor bad -- good entertainment
review:
This is a much quirkier film than you would expect from a gladiator epic, and it's going to disappoint some people.

First off, it is NOT history, although a few historical characters are used. In the film's defense, it really doesn't try to BE history, either, merely using historical backdrops for a morality play. Although, having said that, the opening battle use of the longbow is an anachronism, I believe; the longbow didn't come into use until the thirteenth or fourteenth century, and its origin was Welsh and English. Minor point, but since I have castigated other movies on similar points ...

The performances were outstanding, subtle, and complex, even the sometimes over-the-top performance of Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus. Connie Nielsen is especially effective, and for the first half of the film you're not quite sure where her character stands. I thought Oliver Reed was breathtaking in this film. It's the only film I've seen where I liked Reed, and what a shame he passed away during the filming.

The script gets pretty conventional in the second half of the film, and therefore predictable. However, the visual presentation is stunning, with washout coloring and inventive camera techniques. I can understand why these might be irritating to other filmgoers, especially if they're expecting a traditional epic. Obviously, I liked it.

Overall, it's a good film, not a great one, and not one everyone will appreciate. I think it's overall ranking is excessive, and I rated it a 7.

title: The movie is way over-rated!
review: Several excellent action sequences and a strong performance by Russell Crowe can not make up for a movie that's too long.  The excitement of the film is front loaded, and all the interesting points of the film are exhausted by the middle of the film.  A lot of time is wasted with countless redundant scenes establishing and re-establishing that (1) the new emperor is a spoiled insecure rodent, and (2) "gee, things would sure be swell if Rome was a Republic again!"  The emperor's conspiring sister is played poorly by Connie Nielson, who couldn't act her way out of a high school play.  Joaquin Phoenix spends most of his time trying to pull off being demented but comes across just looking bitter. This movie is worth the money if you're looking for exciting fight scenes, but plan on making lots of trips to the concession stand during the dialogue scenes.  You can afford to miss them and still be able to figure out every single thing that's going on. *SPOILER WARNING* This film is total fiction, of course.  However, even in fiction there's a limit to believability.  For example, I hope the producers don't actually expect us to believe that after 25 years the emperor of Rome changes his mind about the morality of having an empire the day before he dies, or that the Roman Republic could have been restored in the second century by a single man!

title: A little on the LONG side, but definitely worth the wait.
review:
This was an awesome movie! I have no idea about the historical significance of this time period, but the story line was great. At first it seemed like it was going to be an action film about the glory of Rome, but surprised us all when we started getting deeper and deeper into the lives of those involved.

The actors do a great job of staying in character.

The Special effects were cool too. From the trailers, it looked like they were very poorly done, but it didn't show in the actual film.

All in all this was a great film. Definitely worth the two and a half hours it took to get to the end.

title: This film rocks!
review: This is an epic with no questions asked. Ridley Scott has done his job here. Russell Crowe is a force. His character comes off as a mix between the Terminator and Rambo. He commands every scene and has that "God-like" presence. He plays Maximus, the commander of the Roman Army who is sent to die by Ceasar's son Commodus(Joaquin Phoenix). But when he escapes, he has to join up with these prisoners and fight battles. This film is going to live for a very long time. It has the Braveheart quality but much cooler battle scenes. It may be long but it flows by quickly. I have to give it a 10. Russell Crow is the new action hero and I think he should go the way of Nick Cage(Oscar nod followed by a string of action films). Let's get him two guns, John Woo, and call it a day. He is such a force on screen, you can't help but call him "The Man". Gladiator is a must see and a can't miss. It should be number 1 or 2 on all must see film lists.

title: a-must-see-movie
review: Gladiator is awesome! In fact I watched it 3 times already. The movie had impressive plot. It gave a wide range of emotion from heightened action scenes to moving sorrows of dead loved ones. I could only empathize Maximus! The visuals of the film were just stunning. With the recreation of Rome, I felt I was there. The fighting scenes were just stylish removing the gore in a rather violent and brutal scenes as demanded for by the gladiators. And of course the costumes were elaborate. Commodus's costume enforced his majestic appeal concealing his weak character as an emperor. Lucilla was as fashionable as ever with Eastern influences depicted in the film showing a vast Roman Empire. For sure Russell Crowe will be remembered forever in this film particularly in the Philippines and who knows a nomination for the Oscar (again?)!, and to Ridley Scott, make more films something like this. Kudos to you!

title: Excellent story, sword fights were choreographed very well
review:
The story is based on the end reign of Emperor Marcus Aurelius, 180 AD. The story does not follow the historical perspective, but rather centers on the Roman General, Caelius Maximus, and his heroic battle for the glory of Rome.

The sword scenes are graphic but very well done.

title: I wanted to love it, but ...
review:
Gladiator sounded like the movie of the decade and I just couldn't wait to see it. I'm an Aussie so I'm really, really proud of Russell Crowe who is deservedly having a great career. And I love action movies and adored Braveheart, so it just seemed like it would be heaven on a plate.

But it wasn't. I agree with other reviewers that the fight scenes are really well done, but there are just soooo many of them! And there is really not enough plot to carry the film. After the first half hour, due to a mixture of seeing lots of previews, and my incredible sixth sense, I leaned over and whispered the rest of the plot to my companion. And I was right.

If the characterisations had been a bit better done the film might have just got away with a thin plot. But they are given so little to work with that we don't understand anyone's motivations, not in the visceral way we need to in order to really cheer for them, to really care what happens to them. And the lines of good and bad are so clearly drawn that we don't have to bother coming up with an opinion of our own.

Which means that although Gladiator is visually engaging, it does not hold the attention in the way that truly great movies do. It is, however, a really good movie and well worth seeing.

About the soundtrack ... I felt it was intrusive and overbearing at several points in the film, particularly in the early scenes and the final ones. It tried a bit too hard. But I have gone out and bought it as it is a brilliant piece of music, moving, exciting and majestic. Bit too good for the film!

title: Very atmospheric movie. Recommended!
review:
This film has sort of an epic feel to it; the crowds, the sets, and the ambiance in general all work to effectively re-create life as it might have been in the Roman Empire.

We begin with Maximus, a very successful Roman general, and Commodus, the incompetent heir apparent to the reigning Caesar, Marcus Arelius. Maximus, after winning a key battle against Germanic hordes, is offered what is essentially a wish by Arelius. Maximus is battle-weary and just wants to go home. While the aging Arelius initially agrees, he is in failing health and recognizes that Commodus isn't fit to rule, and therefore offers Maximus a "protectorate of Rome" position instead, which the reluctant Maximus takes under consideration. If he accepts, he effectively would be Caesar, something that wouldn't sit well with heir apparent Commodus...

I thought this film was quite effective on many levels. Maximus was portrayed as a general following the orders of his Caesar, sometimes reluctantly but always to the best of his abilities. Commodus was portrayed as a cruel letch which, if memory serves, he was. And the Roman Senate, a hotbed of intrigue and corruption, served as a curious counterpoint to the concept of a Caesar, showing that not even the Caesars were perfectly free to do as they wished. All in all, a very watchable, atmospheric movie well worth the price of admission.

title: Excellent story, vivid characters, awesome fight scenes
review: "Gladiator" is one of those truly memorable films.  The story is harrowing, the bad guys are truly evil, and the heroes are heroic.  Russell Crowe plays Maximus, a former general in the Roman Army, and a favorite of the late emperor, Marcus Aurelius(Richard Harris).  When Aurelius tells his son, Commodus(Joaquin Phoenix), and heir to the throne, that he will not be choosing him as his successor, but Maximus, Commodus kills Aurelius and has Maximus sentenced to die.  Commodus rises to power and has Maximus's family condemned to die as well.  Maximus escapes his executioners and heads to his home in Spain to save his family.  The Romans get there first, though, and Maximus's family is crucified.  Maximus collapses at their graves and is taken prisoner by a slave trader.  The slave trader sells him to an entertainer, who has Maximus trained as a gladiator.  Maximus is incredible in the ring, and is taken to Rome to fight in the just re-opened Coliseum. I can't tell you any more without spoiling the story, though.  The acting is excellent, and the viewer really begins to hate Commodus by the end of the film, and love and admire Maximus.  The cinematography is good as well, with vivid colors and breathtaking shots.  This is truly a great fight movie.

title: Maximus Disappointus
review: After a very promising opening,I have to say I found this film pretty underwhelming. Dull, predictable dialogue, one-dimensional characters, over-rated special effects (Rome looked like something out of a Disney film) and historical inaccuracies  (in the Coliseum, women were never allowed sit together with men). To his credit, I thought Joaquin Phoenix played a good part as the demented Commodus, but Russell Crowe, excellent in The Outsider, was restricted by the poor script and complete absence of character development.

title: It makes you wanna know more about Roman History
review: The movie was superb in every respect. The special effects were wonderful. The plotline is very carefully studied and it parallels the real historical events that took place during the rule of Emperor Commodus. Only for the sake of historical truth I tell you several characters and events are fictitious but that doesn't make the movie any less breathtaking. I strongly recommend it.

title: Dreamworks strikes again
review:
Go see this movie, Dreamworks has another great piece of entertainment for us all. Russell Crowe and Joaquim Phoenix are great. This movie has enough fact, to make it believable, and enough pathos and drama to entertain.

Go see this one!

title: Very good.
review: This movie was great. The costumes were awesome (especially Maximus's fur general uniform, and his helmet when he was a gladiator). The story was really action-packed, suspenseful, surprising, and a little emotional. The special effects with the gore was awesome. I didn't even notice that the movie was a little longer than others, it's so good you wish it would never end. It has a great plot, and you really feel there along with the characters. I totally recommend it, 2 thumbs up!

title: Epic film...excessive slow dialogue
review:
I first want to say that I loved this film and really surprised myself as historical dramas are not my sort of thing. The action was the best since the Matrix and the battle scenes managed to surpass Braveheart. The acting is also top-notch with great performances from Crowe and Phoenix...I really did feel hate for the Phoenix's character, strange when watching a large screen.

I found myself really drawn into the plot of the first half as Maximus showed his strengths and triumphed against adversity. My main criticism came when the dialogue mainly between Ceaser and his sister was so drawn out and lengthy. It created a slight atmosphere but I found the speed of speech unnecessarily slow to the extent of losing what was being said. I like a film to keep moving and the majority of the film did just this, however, there are some very slow parts.

Overall, this is a film to get on DVD but whether I will watch it over and over without fast forwarding to the amazing action is another thing. The first viewing is epic...but like Titanic I think multiple viewings are just not meant to occur within the same month.

SEE IT FOR: great sword work, fights, incredible sets and scenery, acting and the seemless blending of computer graphics with reality.

title: Remake of "The Fall of the Roman Empire"?
review: If one compares the plot of "Gladiator" to "The Fall of Roman Empire" by Anthony Mann, 1964 the similarities are self-evident. Nothing wrong about that. I like it anyway, but if you want to see a movie which is almost like Gladiator, find "The Fall of Roman Empire" from your local video store.

title: nice......
review: Simply put, this is a gladiator flick; a movie about half-naked men beating the crap out of each other, and it looks like it cost about a billion dollars. Everything looks so expensive you know they could have fed millions of those bloated African kids with the money they spent. They've rebuilt massive amounts of old Rome and did a pretty good job too, except their Coliseum looks like it holds about 5,000, not 100,000. The script is unbelievably well paced, and the special effects don't stick out like they did in The Phantom Menace. It's amazing what 100 million dollars can do for a Hollywood flick when it's not wasted on people going to Mars in phony space shuttles.

title: i think i liked it even more than braveheart, which is hard to say
review: ok, in order to talk about this movie of course one gets embroiled in talking about braveheart. i really liked braveheart. it was the 1st good epic in a while. i own it. really, i liked it. however, here are some reasons i have, after much deliberation, decided gladiator is a better movie. there will be some SPOILERS probably. 1. mel gibson is a good actor. i liked him in braveheart and even more in lethal weapon. he has a unique ironical twist to his acting. but i think russell crowe is overall a superior performer. he is quickly becoming a favorite of mine, from what i've seen him in: l.a. confidential (awesome!!), the insider (didn't really like it but he was great), and now this(also some movie the name of which i don't know but i think bridget fonda was in it and it was about magicians). 2. better story. braveheart was very simplistic, which worked, but i thought there was a more substantial plot here. roman politics i personally find very interesting. 3. i could care less that it's historically inaccurate. anyone who thinks braveheart was accurate needs to brush up on some history. geez, robert the bruce was way more historically significant than wallace. 4. i thought the action was better. braveheart had great battle scenes but i thought gladiator's action scenes were more inventive and original. 5. phoenix was real good. some people will say he was too whiny but i thought that was what made it good. i don't know a lot of pathological villains but my gut tells me real bad guys probably have at their core real insecurity issues. a word about the 1st scene - SPOILER!! - i thought the shift to blurriness at the end was great, it was melodic and if they had just had just continued the fight as was there definitely would be even more braveheart comparisons. now, just to be objective, a few problems: 1. the ending. the whole thing with people crowding around him and someone saying "who will help me carry him?" was cheesy and out of place. 2. that part at the beginning where he's riding home threw me for a loop. i don't mind time elapsing quickly but it seemed disjointed. i mean, he rode really far, like across the whole freaking roman empire!! anyways, overall it was awesome. i genuinely think that if both braveheart and gladiator came out at the same time more people would like this, but it's hard to say a new movie is better than one you already love.

title: Superb movie, one of the greatest ever.
review: Gladiator is an amazing movie, featuring sensational cinematography, great special effects and computer graphics, and some of the greatest fights and battles ever seen in a movie.  The shot when the camera pans across the battle field in the opening sequence is amazing, as the viewer sees the arrows streaking across the sky, the catapults launching in order, and the armies marching.  And it was done on computers too, but it looks completely believable.  Great sequence, great movie.  If you haven't seen it, go see it.

title: Don't listen to those self centered critics, this movie is wonderful!
review:
Gladiator will definitely win various Oscars next year because of the following.

Breathtaking score by Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard.

Artistic direction by Ridley Scott.

Wonderful Cinematography.

Terrific acting by all cast members.

And the film's impact on the viewers which stays in memory long after they leave the theater. Movies like this don't come often which is saddening.

I can only look at the people who complain and slam this film and wonder what the hell is wrong with them. They are poison people don't listen to them.

Now comes the extremely difficult task which is to wait for the DVD release which might not happen until 4 or 5 months from now, as well as the Hannibal motion picture the Scott will give us next year. (sigh)

title: The Glory of all Movies
review: You already probably know the plot so that i will not tell you of. But this is the best movie of all time. From the campaign in Germania fighting the Ostrogoths and Jutes to....well, you have to find that out! The movie has an all star cast; Russel Crowe from The Insider, Joaqin Phoenix from 8mm, Connie Nielsen from the Devils Advocate, Oliver Reed from A LOT of movies, Djimon Honsou from Deep Rising and Amistad, Chick Allen as a German Chieftain with a severed head and a huge ax. The fighting in this movie is so excessive and well-done, I've never seen anything like it before. The story is not a slacker, it really has plot (a good one i might add). The recreation of Rome was very accurate and the costumes were awesome. I know maybe they usually didn't wear as much but I happen to know that Gladiatorial fights differed from time to time. The only mistake i found was the repeating crossbow, which wasn't invented until 7th Century by the Chinese. But oh well... it still looks awesome.  The soundtrack is compelling done by Hanz Zimmer from the Rock and Lisa Gerrard from...? It's a wonderful soundtrack. The Gladia they used in the movie were well-made and the chariots were magnificent with an added blade coming out from the wheel. Buy the soundtrack. This movie doesn't have as much gore as it could have which is a plus since gore has been taking over Hollywood. I've seen this 3 times and I love it more EVERY SINGLE time i watch it. This is my favorite movie of all time, it beats braveheart by 0.5 of a point. I love this movie. It's magnificent. I recommend this to all people, even those who don't like too much gore. This movie doesn't have it. It's a magnificent movie (I'm 13 years old... and I'm a history lover so...)

title: Definate oscar contender for art direction, effects
review:
This movie had some of the best visuals I have ever seen. I can only compare it to last years Star Wars or Matrix. It also has cinematography reminicent of Thin Red Line, which adds to a fantastic picture.

One of the two problems I had with this movie, is that it seemed to attract a large audience of professional wrestling fans. I happen to think that anyone who comprehensively watches wrestling has the attention span of a 6 year old. So it felt like there were a bunch of 6 year olds staying up later than they should be to watch this movie, when I was there. Screaming "Can you smell what the rock is cooking" when the fight scenes are happening and "BORING" when they stop and talk.

The other problem, is that it for some reason doesn't feel like a masterpiece. At the end, Phoenix didn't seem to be sooooo evil as he was hyped to be throughout the movie. He was just a misunderstood problem child who got mad at daddie for embracing someone better then him. He could have been more powerful, and evil, there are ways.

title: Close to Perfection
review: Close to perfection, Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe at their best. Mr Phoenix also great as the greedy Caesar. Should win everything at the next Oscar ceremony.

title: Couldn't take my eyes off the screen
review: Spectacular. Must be seen on a wide screen. Ancient Rome as it surely was. How did they create those crowd scenes. Has any film ever employed so many extras? The story line although weak did not real matter. As a spectacle it is the finest film that I have ever witnessed.

title: Superb
review: Visually the film is truly amazing, with convincing CGI sequences and amazing attention to detail. The acting is also strong, particularly from Crowe and Reed, with only Phoenix letting the side down. The script was above average for a film of it's magnitude. One of the few great films from Universal in years

title: Not Something you'd expect!!
review:
Wow,

I didn't expect this movie to have a plot, but I was pleasantly surprised that it did. The movie's success wasn't based on WHO was starring in it. But the movie itself was able to stand on it's on merit. Simply amazing!!! You leave the theater coming off your adrenaline rush. It's not fair to classify this as an action movie because the action HAS A purpose unlike movies like diehard, and the Damme movies that can only breathe action. Anything else, they suffocate. But not Gladiator

title: Such a Mixed Bag
review:
I absolutely love Ridley Scott. "Alien" and "Blade Runner" both rank among my favorite films. "Gladiator," though, just didn't work for me.

Russell Crowe is a fantastic actor, and really ought to be a big, big, big star. Unfortunately, he's not given much to do here. He fights, he broods, he whines...but he's never really forced to stretch his talents.

My main quibble, I suppose, is that the movie was clearly going for "Braveheart" effect, and it fails. It was easy to get some sympathy going for Mel Gibson's character in "Braveheart." He was fighting for freedom and justice. Sadly for "Gladiator," it's pretty hard to develop much sympathy for any particular faction within the Roman empire. Where "Braveheart" was able to give us a few effective hallucinations and dream sequences, "Gladiator" shoves it down our throat with oddly-colored, tripping-on-acid dream sequences every five minutes. Yes, we get the point. He misses his family, and he'll see them in the afterlife. Move on already!

Apart from the dream sequences, the movie does look pretty spectacular. The Colliseum is an impressive sight. The costumes, for once in a sword-and-sandal epic, don't look like the costume department simply raided the bedding department at K-Mart. And the fight scenes are, indeed, entertaining and visceral.

In the end, though, the movie is less than the sum of its parts.

title: A spectacular remake of the Decline & Fall of the Roman Empire
review:
While some of the visuals are truly awesome, and Crowe & Phoenix's performances are gripping, I felt the story was unimaginative, and the overall pace disrupted by some scenes that were cliched and boring.

A film to be seen on the big screen with surround sound, but will probably be a bit tedious on video

title: Awesome!
review: Oh my! I was really speechless when I saw this movie... great pictures, I've hardly ever seen anything like that. The music is perfectly matched too and the plot is fascinating... if you haven't seen this one, go see it!!

title: A movie worth watching
review:
This movie had what a lot of recent movies lack--good acting, plot, and special effects that assisted (and didn't try to steal) the spotlight.

Thankfully very light language (let's have more of this!) and there was some gore, but again, filmed in such a way as to NOT highlight it like many films do (such as Black Mask and Three Kings).

title: Gladiator is the last of the great Roman epics, superbly brought to life by an amazing cast, outstanding scenery and special effects, shrewd directing and Hans Zimmer's emotional score.
review: Gladiator is the last of the great Roman epics, superbly brought to life by an absolutely amazing cast and some outstanding special effects and scenery perfectly complimented by Ridley Scott's shrewd directing. It tells the story of Maximus, a General in the Roman army sent to Germania under the watchful eye of Emperor Marcus Arelius to conquer the last barbarian tribes holding out. Marcus is dying and after the battle, tells Maximus that he is to become Rome's new ruler. Having broken the bad news to Commodus, his evil son who responds by punishing dad, Maximus is accused of treason and sentenced to death. The rest of the film focuses on Maximus' rise as a gladiator having been discovered by Proximo, an ex-gladiator who has been granted his freedom. Maximus' career culmilates in a brathtaking finale in Rome and the Colosseum. We all know what that means, a final showdown with the newly self-elected Emperor Commodus, providing of course Maximus and his Gladiator friends survive the trials that the new Caesar throws at them. The film itself stands out from previous epics with its technically perfect fight scenes in the Colosseum and at the beginning with the German barbarians.Russel Crowe must be an Oscar winner for his superbly emotional performance as Maximus. The film is very emotional in places and this is perfectly multiplied by Hans Zimmer's score which must also be an Oscar nominee.Joaquin Phoenix portrays evil Emperor Commodus as the weasely snide Roman we all know he is. Oliver Reed's final performance as Gladiator trainer Proximo must also not be ignored. All in all, Gladiator is one of the greatest films i have ever seen and i would strongly urge everybody to go and see it regardless of what you have planned for that day. Purchase the soundtrack too and play it as loud as your player will allow.This film kicks and is easily one that will make you cry your eyes out come the end. 100% easily-and don't forget the Oscars.

title: A big-screen must-see.
review: In a nutshell:  I loved it!  Russell Crowe turns in a phenomenal performance as Maximus, and Joaquin Phoenix does likewise as the tormented Commodus. While the cinematography itself is quite dark and brooding, it mitigates the feel of the movie.  The battles are well choreographed, and the story moves quickly.  I've always been a big fan of Ridley Scott, and he hits one out of the park with Gladiator.  Also, the musical score, written by Hans Zimmer, deserves a mountain of praise.  You've got to see this one, folks!

title: A TRUE RIDLEY SCOTT MOVIE
review:
Ridley Scott who is in my opinion one of the greatest movie directors in Hollywood history is back in form mixing style and substance very cleverly to deliver a movie that will catch your heart and your imagination.It is quite similar to Braveheart actually since the story does involve a fallen soldier seeking justice.

Scott who did not have a very goodtime in the nineties except for Thelma and Loiuse is in top form here and showing everybody what is talents are whether it is action drama or beautiful sets.Jaquain De Phoinex gives a very convincing and admirable Performance as the spoilt Prince.Costumes are beautiful and I will be very suprised if it does not get an Oscar nomination.

title: Wonderful Crowe combined with amazing action
review:
Russell Crowe has a definite presence on the big screen and he makes Gladiator his own as Maximus, a general in ancient Rome. Beginning with an impressively staged battle in Germany, Crowe embodies this warrior with his whole being. The favorite of Richard Harris' Caesar to take over Rome, Crowe refuses, and ends up as a slave whose only existence is to fight in the arenas, where most of the warriors die very young deaths. Maximus sees this as his chance to redeem himself.

Besides Crowe's terrific performance, Harris and the late Oliver Reed, as Profumo, Maximus' master, deliver wonderful performances.
