The special effects are amazing as well, from the battle and action sequences, to the renderings of the Colosseum and ancient Rome. Gladiator is a top-notch action film, and one that signals Russell Crowe as a major star on the rise.

title: best movie of the last ten years!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
review: forget MI2 or gone in 60 seconds, this movie is the best movie i've seen in a long time! russell crowe was made for this part and the story was very well written, finally a summer movie that is actually worth seeing, public enemy said "don't believe the hype" well believe it, cause this movie is a solid 10!!!!!!!

title: Rome will Rule!
review: Gladiator was a great film.  Although the beginning was a bit boring the middle and end were great.  An excellent story of the Roman Empire and the way things were back in that time.  Russell Crowe played an excellent role in the must see film of the month.  A HERO WILL RISE!!

title: An epic.
review:
First thing a friend of mine said when he left the movie theatre was "Too many small things were wrong. They didn't pay attention to detail. And the old guy was breathing!" (see: scene in Marcus Aurelius' tent)

Another friend of mine and I were speechless and on the verge of shouting "Maximus! Maximus" at a volume that most likely would have gotten us a free night in a local police station. Perhaps even with padded walls.

"Gladiator" is by no means a small movie. It is a HUGE movie.

I'm not familiar with the exact moviemaking dictionary definition of an epic.. but I'd say this movie was definitely one. The acting was grand, the scenery was grand, the fights were grand, and also quite surprisingly, the emotions were too.

I hate to be harsh on movies, but the day afterwards I went to see "Story of Us".. a cute little middle aged marriage problem drama. Not my kind of thing, especially not after "Gladiator". To those of you who have seen both movies you can imagine what a surreal experience that must have been.

My friend was right, as some critics will point out.. the little details weren't quite there... but WHO CARES??? Sit through "Gladiator" in a sizable THX movie theatre and I can almost promise you that you will feel the same way.

title: This movie was awesome!
review:
I absolutely loved this film. I have seen it three times and would see it again in a minute. It was much better than Titanic (I would love to see Russell Crowe battle Leonardo DiCaprio...boy, would that be funny!) A lot of people complained that the storyline was familiar and simple. Well, most epics are similar..and why does one need complicated storylines all the time?? I thought it was refreshing to see a character that was truly good, without hidden agenda's or alterior motives. All of the acting was wonderful, but I have to especially mention Russell Crowe. I first saw him in L.A. Confidental (which he deserved an oscar for) and have seen most of his movies. Whether or not they were good (like Virtuosity or Rough Magic) he did a wonderful job. I think the thing that amazed me the most about his performance was the way he could show so much emotion without talking--through his eyes. It made me want to cry, seeing the emotions that man expressed. I have to also mention the acting of Joaquin Phoenix...I couldn't decide whether I despised or pitied him more. Making the audience hate him really demonstrates his acting abilities, imo. The special effects, music, and acting combine to be one of the greatest epics of the past three decades....a must see.

10/10

title: A must see film for 2000
review: This film completely took my breath away.  It starts with amazing visuals and unlike most films of recent years, never disappoints with content.  The action in this film is absolutely tremendous and the casting and direction are faultless.  An absolute classic.

title: Solid, but nothing special
review:
Walking into this movie, I was extremely hyped. Walking out of this movie, I was reading the list of ingredients on the back of the Malteser packet. Enough said.

Gladiator is certainly worth seeing - the visuals are impressive, the action is fast-paced, and Russell Crowe is gruff and heroic. But that's about all. The script is so-so; the plot is basic and predictable; and, most disappointing of all, you really don't get sucked in emotionally. I mean, all a film like this aims to do is:

(a) present a two-dimensional hero;

(b) do some nasty things to his relatives; and

(c) get you squirming in your seat waiting for the bad guys to get what's coming to them.

It was like this in Mad Max ('Road Warrior' for you Americans out there), in was like this in Braveheart, it was like this in Rob Roy, and it was like this in virtually action/drama ever made. For the film to succeed, an audience should be 'angry' when the relatives get fried, and 'pumped' when the good guy gets revenge. I was pretty non-plussed on both counts.

As for specifics:

Russell Crowe is good but not fantastic (and nowhere near as good as his performance in LA Confidential)

Oliver Reed's character is overdone and annoying (the only thing he adds to the film is the 'pick which scenes Olly is dead in' game - as he died before filming finished and is computer generated in some parts).

The CGI effects are, as always, dreadful. Although the stadium itself looks ok from the inside, the wider shots of Rome look fake. Why they PERSIST with these crappy effects I don't know.

title: For your eyes only
review:
I expected something stunning from from this film, and it delivered. Ridley Scott has gone off the deep end at last. He isn't even movie director anymore, in the way people normally think of movie directors. He's an artist who makes things that look good when you project them on a screen -- especially a BIG screen.

"Gladiator" has a plot of sorts, some good acting, a decent script. But Scott just had to throw those in to get the money. What he did with it was create an icy blue forest, decadent Roman tents lit by fire, an idyllic Spanish farm, and a rendering of Rome in gold and charcoal gray. There is not one "straight" shot in the film. There are filters from beginning to end. He clearly spent more time dreaming up colors than plot twists -- and it paid off. Lots of great shots add to the beauty, plus jolting edits, fast motion, and slow motion. But Ridley Scott didn't just make his own Rome on a computer because he couldn't film the real one, anymore than Whistler painted his mother because he didn't have a camera handy.

Don't wait for video, take it all in on the big screen!

title: uneven
review: A general in ancient Rome is betrayed by a corrupt emperor and sent to die in an arena as a gladiator. Potentially good Indomitable Human Spirit film is marred by inconsistent direction, somewhat primitive special effects and holes in the plot. Brisk pacing and decent character development work in its favor.  (Rating B+)

title: Impressive action scenes make for great cinema.
review: I liked just about everything in this movie.  The intrigue is enough to keep you glued to your chair.  Some of the battle scenes are reminiscent of Saving Private Ryan (in the movement of the camera).  Both battle and gladiator scenes are among the best I've seen.

title: Superb cinematography, breathtaking stunts & excellent performances particularly Russell Crowe.
review:
Gladiator is one of those rareties in Hollywood these days that transcends the boundaries of commercial and independent films. It is a film that is undoubtedly a blockbuster but is so well acted and directed that it simply cannot be categorised as one.

The most obviously appealing feature of the film are the breathtaking action sequences especially those in the collosieum. it can be argued that they are simply too fast but the speed of the stunts actually adds to the ferocity of the gladitorial fight scenes.

What separates the film however from most of its inferior contemporaries, such as Rob Roy & Braveheart is great acting and direction. Russell Crowe stands tall not merely as a Gladiator but also as an actor with great screen presence and charisma. It is simply the culmination of a series of fine performances following on from L.A. confidential & The Insider. On this occasion it is sincerely hoped that that his achievements will finally be rewarded with an Oscar at the next Academy Awards. The surprise bonus of the film is Joaquin Phoenix however who makes a rather good villain in a departure from his standard bit part roles in films like 8mm.

The final postscript should be reserved for Ridley Scott, a particular favourite of mine. His direction is careful yet never slow and simply the latest in a long line of great films -remember The Bladerunner & Alien.

title: Absolutely great movie, definately a classic like Spartacus!
review: This is one of the best movies I have ever seen and the best movie of this year, definately worth an Oscar next year. Russel Crowe as Maximus was verry good as well and the same goes for the other actors in the Gladiator. Thumbs up for the people who made this movie, a definate classic like Spartacus and Ben Hurr.

title: Mysteriously mindblowing
review:
After the first time I saw I was flabbergasted. I didn't know what hit me. Well, that's not completely true: the movie is a perfect example of action director Ridley Scott (Crison Tide, Alien).

So I went back for the second time to find out what it was.

Firstly the visuals are great, but the created atmosphere (especially the battle sequence in the beginning) throughout the whole film is exquisitely darkish.

Secondly Russell Crowe plays Maximus as Steve McQueen did in his Heydays. It was a pleasure to see someone play the anti-hero in McQueen/Eastwood style. Supporting roles by great veterans like Richard Harris and Oliver Reed (the film is dedicated to him, having passed away last year after a drinking contest on Malta) make the cast and acting performances complete for me. Joaquin Phoenix, While a great actor-to-be, wants to star a little bit to much for my likeing, however he presents a villain devlish seldom seen on the white screen.

Thirdly, having a major part in accomplishing that, the music contributes in a great way to the whole ambiance. Hans Zimmer outdid himself and Lisa Gerard Is mysteriously enchanting.

I found he story itself is good, with a few unexpected plot twists. But it isn't great either.

That's my two cents.

title: Eye Candy for the Bored
review: A visual delight indeed. This film appears to be a facetious attempt toward Hollywood and the 21st century moviegoer.  It is a true mess of celluloid. While the film possesses a visual charm, it tends to stray in to an array of images that leave the senses feeling sick.  It is a difficult film to watch because so much resides on imagery than on historical importance.  Yes, it has action, suspense,and beautiful people to look upon (and some ugly) yet, it is forgettable.  Scott seems like he lost control of the picture and I don't blame him for the script is so one dimensional and portrayed by the actors on such a corny level-what is one to do?  Well, a smart director would give Hollywood and the comfortably numb what they want, A mindless romp through the Roman Empire using high tech imagery and pop celtic/fantasy music to leave us agasped.  This is what we get for the money spent? The pop culture eats it up while the higher culture sulks in it's humility for buying a ticket.

title: Totally Bizarre and totally awesome!
review: Although there was alot of violence, it must have really been like that in those days or was this just fiction.? I am very into history and enjoyed the movie along with my husband. We just sat and did not say a word thru the whole movie.Very Very Good, it kept you in your or should I say on the edge of your seats!!!

title: Braveheart Meets Spartacus--next Springs Academy Award for best picture a shoe in.
review: If I were a betting man I would say that I have just seen the film that will win Best Picture at next Spring's Academy Awards.  This is the most riveting film I have seen since Titanic, even if it is rather "Braveheart meets Spartacus." It was still inventive, masterfully crafted and just plain awesome. Three thumbs up for this one.  LIVE, LIVE, LIVE, LIVE.

title: This is why we go to the movies...
review:
I finally went and saw the movie with my girlfriend on a whim, although I have been wanting to watch it for awhile. While waiting for the film to start, I noticed the usual groups of movie hooligans coming in, and I was expecting usual hooting, laughing, and loud talking that make modern movie-going a torture. From the opening scenes to the final ending, I never have experienced such a silenced crowd as I did last Friday night.

The movie was brutal, relentless, tragic, and funny. The audience were deer caught in the glare of an oncoming freight-train. Two and a half hours later, upon noticing my girlfriend silently wiping tears from her eyes, I realized this is why we go to the movies. Not to compare and nitpick the movie the way these silly, silly people with no lives tend do, but to immerse one-self into the story and stunning visuals that very few movies in our generation have been able to do. Thank you, Ridley Scott, for giving us a reason to go to the movies again!

title: A very good film to start the summer...
review:
The first of the summer blockbusters finally arrives, and if it is any indication of what the summer will be like, this will be a great year for movies.

Gladiator tracks the career of a Roman general named Maximus (Russell Crowe), who falls from grace after Emperor Marcus Aurelius dies and is succeeded by his son, Commodus. Maximus finds himself in the arena fighting as a gladiator, trying to gain revenge for the murder of his family.

Ridley Scott's direction is simply inspired, and he is able to bring stellar performances out of his actors. Further, the art direction and computer imaging brings the ancient Roman world to life more vividly than any film before it.

Perhaps one truly great trick that Ridley Scott pulls out of his book is to turn the theatre audience into Romans. I personally found myself excited as the blood spilled onto the floor in the arena, much to my horror (I have always considered myself peaceful and civilized). One comes out of the theatre with a sense that perhaps one isn't quite as far from the brutality of the past as we all would hope.

If I have any complaint, it is that some of the combat scenes move too fast and have too much going on. The end result is that the viewer doesn't quite know what is happening. Perhaps the clarity of the battles in Braveheart would have been more helpful here.

So, the final score: 4.5/5. Definitely worth going to see.

title: A hero has risen.
review: I loved this movie.  I decide how good a movie is by how entertained I was. I was entertained by "Gladiator."  Russell Crowe was great, Oliver Reed was outstanding.  He will be missed.  I am glad I was able to see him perform so well in his last role.

title: This is no Braveheart/Titanic!!!
review: Why oh why, have soooo many people compared this wonderful movie with 'Braveheart' or 'Titanic', I do not know. Stop comparing it to two films which are so completely different, and just enjoy the film!!!! Sorry, but I just had to get that off my chest. I'm going to see 'Gladiator' again next week cos I love it so much. -Yeah, yeah, I know, it's  more of 'a guy' movie, but I think it's GREAT!

title: Great epic not dwarfed by the effects
review: I went into this movie expecting it to be nothing but guts and gore and lots of screaming.  Boy, was I wrong!  Yes, there was some of all those things, but what also came off the screen was an absorbing story of a man's determination to bring his life full circle -- make it complete by avenging those who had wronged him.  The computer generated effects were far above those of TITANIC and the work done in the battle scenes was simply awe-inspiring.  I had a few quibbles: the relationship between Drucilla and Maximus prior to the opening of the movie was not explained and the speed of the opening battle varied from slow to fast and it was hard to keep an eye on any one person.  Very minor things!  I spent $4.75 to see the movie and it was WELL WORTH IT!  I think I've recovered from the belly flop that was TITANIC.  I can now go to a theatre and spend my money with confidence.  There ARE good movies out there!

title: An Instant Classic
review: Wow is all I can say to this....I went to see Gladiator expecting to see a great film and it delivered big time. The storyline and atmosphere of the movie is reminiscent of the classic Braveheart but this movie is just as good as Braveheart in its own right. From the amazing special effects (computer images are used extensively I hear, for example to recreate the Colosseum and also to replace Oliver Reed after he died in real life during the shoot!) to the breathtaking scenery; from the masterful treatment of the gladiatorial violence (split second shots of the gore, a la Braveheart again) to the outstanding performances of the cast, this film just oozes class from every pore. Scott is a genius and I don't believe that anyone would have done the gripping storyline of the movie any more justice than he has managed here. A real "tour de force" and surely the best film of the year. Endlessly recommended.

title: Hardly original, but terrific entertainment
review:
"Gladiator" is not an original film. There's tons of comparisons to "Braveheart" floating around, but there's dozens of movies that came before, and dozens more will come that have this same basic story. Sympathetic powerful man is wronged by those around him, loses everything, comes back to attempt vengeance against the forces that destroyed him. Frankly, there's much better comparisons than "Braveheart". "High Plains Drifter", "Rob Roy", even films like "Payback" just to name a few of many.

But this is unimportant. A film like "Gladiator" is not about originality. It's about sweeping vision, high production value, and engrossing entertainment. And "Gladiator" achieves all this extremely well. You'll hardly believe 2 1/2 hours have gone by when you reach the end of this film. The portrayal of ancient Rome is exciting and believable, the story is predictable yet gratifying, and the directing is interesting without being distracting. I particularly enjoyed the rapid cutting of fight scenes, which Ridley Scott has managed to make both exciting and excruciating without showing excessive gore, and without highlighting fake swordplay.

While I think the cries of "Oscar!" only serve to illustrate how haphazardly Oscars are handed out, the performances are very good. Joaquin Phoenix is particularly effective as the despicable, creepy, yet pitiful Commodus. Russell Crowe is an excellent fit for our grimy hero, and Connie Nielsen lights up the screen with her refined beauty and presence.

Ridley Scott has demonstrated his slick professionalism as a director in a way that has not been seen since "Blade Runner". "Gladiator" is a big movie, and it deserves to be seen on a big screen. Go to the theater before it's too late, there hasn't been a movie as deserving of a big screen and big sound since "Titanic".

I rated this movie 9/10.

title: What a movie!!!!
review: what can I say about it, It`s just amazing!!!!, the characters, the story....everything is so cool!. From the beginning til the end this film takes you to another dimension. I advise you to see it, because if you don`t, you`ll lose the half of your life!!!(hehehehehe).

title: Great visuals, plot contrived
review: When I saw gladiator, I couldn't help juxtaposing it with Braveheart: Very similar story lines and both movies try to be epic in scope (not to mention that people compare the two australian stars, russell crowe and mel gibson).  I enjoyed Gladiator's breath-taking visuals and its WWII style battle scenes and even its occasional gore, but i walked away from the movie thinking that it was lacking something.  Gladiator lacked qualities that made braveheart a true epic.  Perhaps i speak too harshly of gladiator because i compare it to Braveheart, but i thought that braveheart was immensely more powerful.  Gladiator's Maximus, though suave, spent too much of early screen time not wanting to be involved (then later being forced into action) whereas Wallace from braveheart is shown as a child to build history and align the audience's sight and sympathy with the soon-to-be older wallace.  Beyond little petty things such as that, Braveheart is more more grand in scope than gladiator.  Braveheart dealt with the issue a nation of people who were struggling againt tyranny and the passion of one man, further powered by the fury of his slain bride, to free his country. Gladiator shows corruption within one system of government and one man who is quite indifferent about it.  Only later... way later does Gladiator push its protagonist into limelight to shake up the scene; but with what motivation?  Only that to avenge his lost family (something that braveheart used as its auxillary motivation) and to kill the corrupter of Rome. Sorry Maximus, but Rome became corrupt anyway. Talk about phyrric victories.

title: Breathtaking - part II
review: I know I have "stolen" summary to angelo-29, but I agree with him! Well, that's cinema: two people living at the opposite corners of the world have same ideas! One more thing that I would like to point out (that angelo-29 didn't) is the use of different colors related to different characters: cool colors for "the bads" and warm ones for "the goods" (Russell Crowe). Yeah! Russell Crowe... who is he? Where does he come from? I cannot answer these questions, but I'm quite sure where he is going to: fame! He has been a very pleasant surprise to me (and to female surfers I can tell he is very handsome...!). Rossana

title: A True Classic!
review: I was at first a bit skeptical about the renewal of the great Roman epic. But I must say that I was Blown away! Russell Crowe's and Joaquin Phoenix's perfomance's were Top-Notch (Both deserve Oscar Nod's). The Special Effect's were flawless and the  battle scene's awsome. All the actor's were great and kept me either in suspense, humoured, or almost in tear's. I Just had to voice my opinion on this great movie. (which I have already seen 3 time's ,bought the soundtrack and the Novellete.) I keep recommending it to all my friend's and those who said it was Just "OK" I told them they were nut's.

title: A Colossal Disappointment!
review: The "coming attractions" were more exciting and fun than watching "Gladiator" after them.  I was all prepared for a movie of action, and romance and adventure.  The kind of film that gets you caught up in the story, and has you rooting, cheering and clapping at the climax of the movie.  This wasn't it.  The story never drew me in, or gave me a reason to care what happened.  I think Russell Crowe is a talented actor, but not in this...  His acting consisted of variations on looking stern or solemn, with maybe three smiles thrown in to show his range.  As for this moviegoer, I'd rather watch an old Steve Reeves movie.

title: Oh My God... BRILLIANT!!!
review:
This is quite possibly one of the best movies ever. What can I say about this unique masterpiece that hasn't been said already? . The cast is amazing: Russell Crowe should win an Oscar for his performance; I don't think I could imagine anyone else in the role; Connie Nielsen is beautiful and Joaquin Phoenix is menacing. The scenery is breathtaking; the action scenes are well done and the ending almost had me crying. (I would have been able to cry, but since the theatre was packed, I restrained myself.)

All in all, a masterpiece. This movie is right up there with my all time greats, and I can't wait for the DVD. Also, buy the soundtrack! It's the music that makes the movie! I really hope this movie wins big at next years Oscars, it really deserves to.

This is definately one of my favorite movies ever (if not my favorite.) Everyone should see this!!! This is one of those films that has you thinking for days after you've seen it, and then you want to go see it again!!

My Rating: 10/10

title: Not a classic, but still a winner
review:
This movie was not without faults (the one that first comes to mind is the thumb-out, thumb-in error), but none of them are worth recommending for anyone to see who can stomach a lot of violence. The plot is far from original, a betrayed warrior's wife and children are murdered by the new Roman emperor and he goes through hell and highwater to meet him in the obligatory fight scene climax.

The characters in this movie are good enough, but they are always so sad. I think Russell Crowe only smiles once, but then again, his life is in shambles. Joaquin Phoenix (who should be praised just for taking a role whose character's name is Commodus) suffers from some sort of twisted form of the Oedipus Complex. All of the supporting cast do a good job of filling their roles even though they're basically invisible. Just throw-in characters to feed the plot between Commodus and Maximus. And I'm not sure everyone's accents are consistent with how they actually spoke back then, considering the era.

What the picture lacks most, though, is special effects. A movie like this should strive to serve up eye-candy, but instead it looks like second-rate computer graphics. I was expecting a glorious view of ancient Rome, but instead the colisseum looks drab, almost like someone snapped a photo of a video game using high speed film. Even the scenes that show flashbacks and past emotions look... easy, for lack of a better word.

But I must praise this film for its engrossing qualities. Any movie over 2.5 hours in length is subject to get boring, or at least experience a lull somewhere during the middle. But not Gladiator. The character development is sufficient and it makes us care about the characters and what happens to them. The battle scenes are passable, and the director wisely uses choppy editing techniques to disguise the sword fighting abilities of Russell Crowe and others. Usually that's not a good sign, but the point here is to see and feel the intensity and vengeance that Maximus fights with, and it works.

So based on what I wrote in the last paragraph I'm recommending this film. It is by no means transcends its genre and probably will not be considered a classic, but it does well as a stand-alone movie, and it is entertaining.

*** (out of 4)

title: A Spectacle worthy of classic Hollywood
review: Yes, my boyfriend complained that it was too much like Braveheart, but that's only on a superficial comparison.  Wow, I can't begin to explain what a great film this was.  It managed to captivate and excite the entire time. There was humor and great pathos and insane emperors and the noble warrior with a heart of gold.  All the things that MIGHT have added up to a cheezy overblown Hollywood machine if the actors weren't so fabulous.  Oliver Reed can be proud of his final performance, one of the best of his career. Finally Russell Crowe captures a starring role where he can let his fine acting talent shine while showcasing those gorgeous looks of his.  And Joaquin Phoenix makes you both hate and feel a modicum of pity for the tortured and malicious young emperor.  It's a flick that can appeal to guys and girls (if the girls can stomach the quick cuts of violence and gore) and DEFINITELY DEFINITELY go see it!  the visuals alone of the Roman colosseum, the tigers, and the gladiating sequences are worth the admission.

title: Good film but the action scenes were too disjointed.
review:
This film will probably go down as an all time good film. The story line was good and the acting excellent. For the best part of the film I was interested although there were times????

One problem that I had with the film, was that all the action shots were flashed by jumping from one scene to another without allowing your brain to take in what it was seeing. It reminded me very much of the subliminal advertising where words are flashed up on a screen so quickly, your eyes may see them but your mind doesn't consciously register them.

I came out wondering what the hell I had just watched. Never the less, I still feel that this was a great film that would entertain a large spectrum of the movie going public ranging from pure action seekers to those who prefer their action more in the form of a good honest wife loving husband and father.

title: A Visual Stunner and Nice Escape on a Hot Summer day.
review: First the good, I finally got to see what the big deal about the Roman Empire was.  When you read it in books and see it in pictures it doesn't have the same punch as when it becomes a living breathing thing as it does in Gladiator.  Russel Crowe is great as Maximus and Phoenix makes Commodus the biggest wussy in recent cinema.  Overall, I give a big yippie-yahoo to Gladiator for a nice escape from whatever you are escaping from.  My only complaint?  It was just a wee bit long and the drama-love story aspect of it just was a bit of a letdown.  How long did it take Maximus to get from Germania to his house anyway?  Did anyone else notice that his hair had grown out?  Who cares, right?  Enjoy the show...but, I suggest you buy a snack and hit the head before settling in.

title: proper epics are back!
review: What can be said about this?  It was pushed as a bloke movie, but it isn't. Its been suggested it is a mindless action flick, using computer effects to take attention away from a flimsy plot - not so.  The script is fine and a hundred times better than the last epic I was unfortunate enough to see in the cinema - Titanic.  Gladiator has a lot of heart and yes, the story may be a little hackneyed, there may be reminders of everything from Ben Hur to Caligula, but the acting is superb, the effects (which don't detract from the story) are great and the whole piece is very enjoyable.  Proof that the epic isn't dead and that Hollywood can still make decent thoughtful films when it wants to.  Excellent.

title: Outstanding! Best film of the Millennium!
review: Great movie....Excellent story line and outstanding cast make for a top notch film.  I went to view this film thinking it was a "guy movie" and left with a whole new perspective.  I recommend this movie for young and old alike and, for that matter, men AND women alike!  A+++!!

title: Excellent movie
review: This had to be one of the most visually spectacular movies of all time!! It was tremendously fun!! I think Ralph Moeller was great as Hagen. Ralph has all the potential in the world to be the next Arnold Schwarzenegger and he definately showed it to us all in Gladiator!!

title: Great!
review: I really loved this film. It reminded me of when they used to make films like this e.g. Quo Vadis and The Robe. My wife hated it as the violence was all too real and she spent most of the time with her hands over her eyes! All the more credit to the film for this.

title: Braveheart meets the 13th warrior!
review: If you've seen Braveheart, then chances are you'll think this film is eerily similar.  I wouldn't rate Gladiator up there with Braveheart, that's why I say it's a mix.  The 13th warrior had plenty of action, but it lacked a central theme and a strong character.  Gladiator has these faults to a lesser degree, and it has the same muddy look to it.  It is a good film...just not a great one.  So, if you liked the 13th warrior then you'll like this film, but if you think 13th warrior was a little shallow and convoluted, then chances are you'll come out of this movie with similar thoughts.

title: Listen Up
review: "Are you not entertained?  Are you not entertained?  Is this not why you came here?"  These were the words of Russel Crowe to the audience in the arena.  But he's talking not only to the fans on the bleachers, he's also talking to those watching the film "Gladiator."  The film is not a story about a hero - it's a story about the herd - ie: the Roman mob.  Would there have been such a tragedy if vox populi (popular opinion) did not ask for it? They were the ones who wanted it.  Likewise, we are the ones who are asking for it now.  Are we so different from the Roman mob?

title: Pretty good
review: It was a pretty damn good movie, but they could have made it great.  Some of the action sequences were sped up, which took away from the coolness of it. Also, some of the dialogue was quite bad, which decreased the value some as well.  Plus, the villain, Commodus, did not strike any sort of fear in me at all, or at the very least, respect.  Last time I checked, the villains (esp. of movies such as this) were supposed to strike terror in people's hearts, but all this guy does is whine incessantly like a little girl, and I don't know about you, but little girls don't scare me.  However, even with all these faults, the movie is still quite good and I'd recommend seeing it. However, if you want a superior epic movie, see Braveheart.

title: Cinematically lush, but overly dramatic and predictable.
review: It's a good movie to see if you want entertainment and you like gory violence. The battle scenes were fantastic. The plot seemed like an afterthought...overly dramatic and almost silly. The acting was decent, best to see it in the theatres.

title: One of the Greatest movies i have seen
review: I'm not a historian but i did some research and read others comments and Gladiator isn't very historicly accurate ... but Titanic wasn't much too and i haven't seen many people complain about it ... So why Gladiator should perfectly history accurate ???... the plot is romanced in the way to make a great emotional feel and i don't see anything wrong with it ...  At the very first moment of the movie i knew that i would enjoy it the score by Hans Zimmer & Lisa Gerrard during the battle with the barbarian is really great, we have the feeling of all the "grandeur" of the Roman army, its like nothing can't stand in the way of this highly technical advanced army for this time ... The brutality of the combat (a la Braveheart) is true to what it most have been during this time ... The rest of the movie is just great fight scene, special effect a very well done and not overuse and good dialogue ... Finally i just love the theme of this movie of honor, loyalty and courage values that we should preserve in our modern society ... 9/10

title: great comeback of a classic genre
review: This movie has it all and Ridley Scott almost perfectly understood to put a genre back to life nobody dared to put on the big screen again. "Gladiator" is made for big screen and does perfectly fit into the world of classic heroes everybody is looking for when he is going to such a movie. "Gladiator" is also entertainment at it's best and thanks to Russell Crowe a movie that touches you a long time after seeing it. Good cast next to Crowe who really surprises everybody concerning his art of changing his roles so dramatically (e.g. "Insider"). Very nice Score by Hans Zimmer who did not choose for too much bombastic music but put some very harmonic songs in co-operation with Lisa Garland to it which makes it worth listening.

title: Fight to the Max
review:
Don't expect a history lesson here, but who does that anyhow? It's an ancient action movie in amazing modern visual design!! The computer-generated colosseum & the old city of Rome, the gladiator fights, the set and costume design and, of course, the excellent actors make this movie worth seeing. Russell Crowe is brilliant as the general who...(you surely know the movie trailer), Joaquin Phoenix is convincing as Commodus even though sometimes slightly annoyingly overacting his part, but I especially liked Connie Nielsen as his sister who tries to save Rome from her brother's folly while at the same time being in fear of him.

Still the film has its flaws as e.g. the sometimes rather incoherent story line, or its at times overtly annoying score (which in general, in my opinion, was not suitable for this kind of movie--it sounds most often more like the soundtrack for a medieval English history drama). But these are rather minor cracks in an overall very entertaining and enjoyable film!

title: Commodus the punk
review: It was a great movie but, like a lot of Ridley Scott's movies, a great deal was cut out.  I hated the fact that Commodus came across as such a whiny spoiled I-hate-my-father-because-he-loved-Maximus-more-than-m e bad guy.  What was so bad about him???  I'm sorry but if you're going to have a badass like Maximus in the movie, you'd better have a hell of a tyrant to go up against him.

title: Hands-down My Favorite Movie
review: I loved this movie!  Terrific in almost every aspect.  I thought the plot could have been a little better, but the acting, fights, settings, and everything else makes up for that!!!  Russell Crowe delivers an excellent performance as the main character.  Joaquin Pheonix is a superb villain, much to my surprise.  Again, an outstanding film.  I'm sorry, but if you didn't like this film, get your thumbs out of your ass and go watch it again!! Final Thought:  10 out of 10, fantastic

title: Spellbound!!
review: If Russell Crowe does not win Best Actor at next years Oscar's there is something wrong with the establishment!! I was surprised that this film was an 15 because it can be a bit bloody at times, but like all good stories the good man was good and the bad man was really bad! This film is an epic but the computer effects let it down just a little bit. Why is it that in all good stories the women are flaky and the kids always give away the plot? Watching this film reminded me that Oliver Reed was going to be sadly missed as he was an actor of the old school. My last words about this film is see it or be extremely sorry! GO!!

title: It gets the adrenaline going...
review: Russell Crowe, now that name sounded vaguely familiar to me.  Yeah, he played in a little movie called "Virtuosity" with co-star Denzel Washington back in 1995.  Now this movie didn't earn very much recognition, but I'm sure Gladiator will.  The movie had me hooked from the beginning with the battle between the Romans and Barbarians.  The panoramic shot of the battle was breathtaking.  Russell Crowe delivers one heck of a performance, as one would say "whoa".  I heard myself muttering that word over and over again. The battles are very well done and flow with smooth perfection.  I was a little disappointed with the ending, but it was definitely fitting, nonetheless.  This movie is a must-see, for movie fans of all genres. Gladiator delivers a bit of everything.  Perfect 10.

title: Movie of the year!
review: This movie is a masterpiece. Gladiator has the same qualities as great movies like "Saving Private Ryan", "Braveheart" and "Titanic". Historical elements, stunning scenery and brilliant casting are the reason why this movie deserves to be compared with these other great movies, even though the story of the movie is not as authentic as the others. Russell Crowe is fantastic - he has the same presence on the screen as Mel Gibson. Connie Nielsen and Joaquin Phoenix also deserves credit for their performances. If you want to be entertained in a big way - see Gladiator, it will leave you breathless.

title: A fantastic movie!
review:
I have read over some of the past comments and have seen many contradictory statements. Of course this is to be expected from the diverse viewers we have, so I think it may be hard to actually get an average review.

I must say that I loved this movie. I have always been fascinated by historically based fantasies, especially medieval and roman. So of course I felt an obligation to see Hollywood's latest attempt. Of course this dedication I have is not a resented one, because many of the past works I have witnessed are very good indeed.

So I embarked on my trip to the cinema with little more than a rough idea of what it was all about. I emerged with the feeling that I had in fact stepped back in time.

I thought that the whole concept of the movie was excellent. I can never get enough of producer's manipulation of history. The costumes were enchanting, the computer animation for the Colosseum was perfected.

The acting, though, was what really captivated me. My favourite being Joaquin Phoenix. Him being the brother of the mesmerizing late River Phoenix, I knew that I was to see some good acting. But of course I had my doubts. In th past many let's say, aspiring, actors have tried to stumble in their siblings success. They then deliver a so-so performance, wrecking whatever status they were on to begin with. This in mind, I believed that Joaquin would be good, but not that good. I was wrong. The way he brought his character's personality to life, was captivating. Every little detail was manipulated so as to bring Commodus' insanity to it's full extent. Though, he was evil, the vulnerability was always there, always seeping through.

So to conclude I must give it a score of 9/10. I would give a full 10 but the gore did at some times exceed even my limits.

If you enjoy being captivated I strongly recommend you see this movie.

title: OhMyGod...
review:
ok, u know what? RUSSELL CROWE IS HOT!!! but besides that, he is one amazing actor. i couldn't believe this movie- it was breathtaking. i even saw it twice, to understand what i didn't get the first time around. but it was WELL worth the time and money. i can't wait for it go on video. now, EVERYONE go see this movie!!!! if Crowe doesn't get 'best actor' for his role... i think i'll scream. this guy is a find.. truly top quality acting. so, like i said, GO see this movie! what are u waiting for??? i'm not gonna give u a thesis... that would ruin the ending. don't u wanna be surprised? thought so. ok, just go see it. go now. go again. an again:):):)trust me.

LO

title: Prepare to be shut up :+)
review: Thinking to see another silly hollywood action movie with some american rambo-cowboy pretending to be a roman soldier i went to see gladiator. But when the lights went out and the movie started, like everybody else in the theatre, all i could do is hang on to my seat and stare at the screen and be totally impressed. This movie is just amazing, its been years since any motion picture got a hold of me in any way whatsoever (last one was URGA, another must see if you love good movies) I had  completely forgot what it was like to be gripped, thrilled and be pulled into a story by a master director. Perhaps the good thing about it was i had no idea what to expect, didn't even know who directed it. After the movie ended the surprising thing was it was the silence in the theatre, everybody was so impressed nobody felt the need to talk. My advice is, if you want to see what a real motion picture is like, go and see gladiator in the cinema. For me this is the ultimate in its genre, completely thrilling action, great dramatic story and totally believable caracters. Of course the fact it shut up 500 noisy macho's in the theatre is something worth mentioning too :)

title: not a technical review
review: while I do not possess the technical expertise of some of the commentors, I am an avid movie fan familiar with R. Scott. He and RC are the reasons I went to see this film. There are indeed many technical and logistical weaknesses but I believe RC's performance will carry it to a place in movie phenomenon history. The success seems to be a combination of excellent casting and artistic ability. I applaud the other characters as well. Because they are a human endeavor, I can think of no 'perfect' film. This one does what films are supposed to do, it captures the majority of the audience who sees it, touches a sensitive place in their psyche and leaves them with a fond remembrance.

title: Even Roger Ebert is wrong once in a while...
review:
I can't understand for the life of me why he was so harsh on this picture. This is easily one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. It kicks the crap out of Titanic, by a long shot. Basically, take an event film like Titanic, but add real actors and a better plot...

I totally fail to understand how someone could fault this film for bad graphics while praising Titanic. Certain scenes from that movie look so bad as to be laughable. (I'm thinking of long external shots of the boat at night...)

Russell Crowe kicks ass in this role. He's every bit as good here as he was in "The Insider."

title: Battle scenes were awesome! Rest of movie was average.
review:
Just as I've said above, when there was fighting on screen the movie was good. When there was no fighting the movie was average.

I really wanted this movie to be better than it was. I had high hopes for it.

I can only give this movie a 6 rating. It came close to a 7, but overall I can only give it a 6. Based on the IMD rating scale this movie did not achieve the mandatory 7 which makes a movie worthwhile for me to see. Came close though.

title: greatest film of the millenium
review:
My compliments to Mr.Ridley Scott for making this excellent film.He made the revival of the antique Rome possible.I have seen yet the film five times and at no point it seemed to be tedious Surprising special effects but also a great praise to the actors:Mr .Russell Crowe, Mr.Joaquin Phoenix and Mrs Connie Nielsen Mr. Crowe plays his role in a fascinating manner.We believe him his part of a hero who shows sense of duty ,wisdom ,fear and heart. His opponent Mr Phoenix has quiet a difficult role, the hero is loved by everyone,but he plays a man most people don t like,although he is victim and perpetrator in one person,a complexe character.His growing madness is really impressing. And then Mrs Nielsen between the two different men,her convincing fear against her brother ,such a great performance. Not to forget the other actors which make possible that the audience is dipping in a former epoch and living through it.Also my congratulations to the whole crew in the background.

Nothing has really changed since now,we only observe the games in the television and we have not to go to the arena,we want to be entertained and we have reached another form of brutality. This film is like a mirror. Mr Scott uses entertainment that we are forced to see in this mirror.For these efforts an Oscar nomination is waiting, For strength and honor.

title: Best film of 2000!
review: MI:2 may beat Gladiator at the box office for total receipts, but I'm casting my vote for Gladiator to stomp the competition at the Oscars.  I realize, of course, that it probably won't, given the Academy's preference for art over entertainment.  But still, if Braveheart (another excellent film) can win, then maybe there is hope for the sword and sandal epic yet!

title: Russell has something to Crowe about....OWWWW!! Sorry...
review:
This is really pretty good, a nice updated combo of 'Braveheart'(see the great opening battle scene), Ben-Hur, Spartacus, Samson and Delilah, Quo Vadis, etc(Coliseum/gladiator stuff) and Rob Roy. Maximus/Crowe is the same basic guy, big strong hero/general/fighter who winds up taking on the sadistic/twisted Fop at the end, sword on sword.

Spoiler alert!!!!!!!!

Somehow or other I was let down the the failure of the coup-I think that that would have brought the film to a somewhat more fitting end myself, and more satisfying. But Sod it-what they did do was pretty good in and of itself. No big problems here.

I felt the scenes showing Commodius and his sister were long and draggy in places, and to be honest, by about the 4th time they showed Commodius there making Googoo eyes at Dear Sister and prattling about how big a failure he'd felt in his fathers' eyes...I think we got the idea by then, thank you. Phoenix was pretty good as the fop and Neilson ditto as his sister, its just that their scenes fell flat at times.

I liked Derek Jacobi, didn't recognize Richard Harris(!!) as Marcus Aurelius-but enjoyed his scenes-and thought that this was a fitting fineale to Oliver Reed's career too. Go back the Wolfman, Three Musketeers, etc, and he's played similar parts...it is good Hollywood saw fit to haul him and Harris and Derek Jacobi into this for one more go around.

Crowe carries the film, I could have pictured a younger Mitchum or Bronson doing it but nec. any better. If you like action, spectacle, Ridley Scott in general or stuff like Braveheart-then this one is for you.

*** outta ****, involving, shows Rome as not film has before, well done.

title: It was the sword the women liked!
review:
Gladiator is not just a display of how perfect special effects can be a giving part of a movie - the effects of Gladiator give you a chance to follow a splendid story of a man who puts honour and friendship above ambition. What I especially find so amazing is the details - for instance how both the ageing emperor, Marcus Aurelius, and his son, Commodus, have a harelip or how the colour of the light chances: warm and red in Marcus Aurelius' tent as he speaks with Maximus - cold and blue as Maximus steps out of the tent. And historical facts make the movie so much more interesting; how the emperors kept the people happy and in the hollow of the hand with food and entertainment or how the gladiators kept wealthy women "happy" (it was the sword the women liked).

Altogether this is not a movie anyone should let go unnoticed.

title: MIND CANDY
review: MIND CANDY! thats the best way to describe this film. i went to see this with my mates and we all agreed that it was amazing.The battle scenes where excellent as was all the acting.Ridley Scott has done a great job of creating a convincing Rome .It's without a doubt his best work to date. *****

title: The best movie I have seen since Braveheart
review:
I see many movies most of them I either don't like or forget what the story was about a week after I see it. This was something special. In an era where studios spend 100 million on special effects and actor's salaries and 5 bucks writing the script this film has great balance of story, action, romance, all the elements that make a story great.

The 2 1/2 hours this movie goes for just flies by. If you are one of those people who look for historical accuracy, you will not get it from this picture. The opening seen looked like the beginning of Desert Storm on CNN. But anyhow great picture! If the Academy does not look at this picture come awards time there is something wrong.

title: General to Slave to Liberator
review: As usual Ridley Scott produces what is visually stunning, almost historically accurate and a picture that holds your imagination for the two plus hours it runs.  Russell Crowe is perfect as Maximus the rugged Spaniard who is betrayed by Commodus and wins his freedom in the arena as a Gladiator.  Creative sets and use of cg enhance the story but do not intrude on your senses.  So don't wait for the video this is a film that deserves to be seen on the big screen.

title: This film MUST be seen on a big screen.
review: Don't kid yourself that you can wait until the video comes out to see this movie. Gladiator cries out to be seen on a big screen. Scott's talent for stunning visuals is used to the full here.

title: Braveheart with Skirts
review: Although the summary may seem a little cynical, the most important aspect to remember is that this is a very impressive film. Russell Crowe continues his fine run from 'L.A Confidential' and 'The Insider' and is ably supported by a strong cast. And yes, the battle scenes are excellent, but the overall impression I received from the film was very similar to that of Braveheart. You will see what I mean once you have seen it; the strong lead, the love interest etc. I left feeling thoroughly content with my money spent on the ticket, but felt that the film lacked perhaps the strand of originality which, to my mind is an essential ingredient of classic films, and as such must avoid awarding a full 10/10. The hype is worthy of the film, but I believe it only acquires epic status due to its length and its historic subject matter. Nevertheless, go see it and enjoy - easily worth a 9/10.

title: Fantastic movie!
review: I have seen this movie twice already and I have enjoyed it each time. Wonderful movie with great acting and Russell Crowe simply took my breath away.  Ridley Scott did a fantastic job in bringing Rome back to life. This movie truly pulls you into the story.  Highly recommend it anyone and everyone.

title: Acting blew me away.
review:
Having just seen "The Insider" a couple of weeks ago, I was already impressed with Russell Crowe. This film shows his versatility. And maybe it was just the role, but he reminded me of a young Richard Burton.

Connie Nielson was excellent also; I had never heard of her before.

The one who really awed me though was Joaquin Phoenix. From the movie reviews I was expecting the standard, pure evil bad guy, but this nuanced, complex performance made me feel the inner torture of this character and helped explain how he came to be who he is. I didn't like him, but I couldn't hate him.

Even if you don't care for bloody fighting scenes this movie is worth seeing if you love top-notch acting. I will be surprised if we don't hear about "Gladiator" again at Oscar time.

title: Brilliant acting
review: I expected much before I saw this film and as every film fan knows; you should never expect things before you see a film. So, I didn't like "Gladiator" as much as I thought I would, but I still think it's a good film. It's interesting, the action scenes are great (the opening battle scene is reminiscent of both "Braveheart" and "Saving Private Ryan"), the drama quite interesting, and the acting brilliant. Of course, Russell Crowe has never been better (I haven't seen "The Insider yet, though), and we all know how good he was in e.g. "L.A. Confidential." Joaquin Phoenix doesn't play a very likable character, Commodus is a pathetic loser, but he does a good job with it anyway. Recommended. (7/10)

title: "FOR THOSE OF US WHO ARE ABOUT TO DIE, SALUTE YOU"
review: yes! This movie lives up to it`s name!! You almost feel like your a Roman spectator at the coliseum watching the games!! The costumes and scenery seem very realistic to that time in history. And the battle scene at the beginning of the movie is one of the best battle scenes i`ve ever seen, in fact it might be better than the battle scenes in braveheart, it`s very very close!! the acting is good, and this movie should win atleast one award. The only thing that might keep this movie from winning best picture is all the gore. So if you have a weak stomach don`t watch this movie, but if your into this type of action i highly recommend it. rating (best of 5 stars).....4.....

title: Superb!
review: I have seen Gladiator 3 times, one on opening night, and I have to say it is superb. Far from perfect, but that does not mean much, since its strengths are so many. I won't go on too long, but two things I want to make note of. One: The tigers aren't CGI, so stop saying that. The reason they looked like they did was because of the frame drop. One review said they were CGI and looked terrible, your wrong. Also, TWO: If you don't want a plot or dialogue to listen to, go see M:I-2. That's not a bad thing, but this is more than a bunch of fights. Strongly reccomended, 9 out of 10.

title: MUTTON DRESSED AS LAMB
review: Anyone who goes to the movies to be entertained, and expects to come out of the cinema feeling happy, is going to be disappointed by GLADIATOR. This is an unhappy movie with an unhappy hero,unhappy people who lived in unhappy times and an unhappy ending. True, there are tremendous action scenes enhanced by digital sound but to those of us who are now aware of techniques involving blue screens, green screens and CGI, these scenes are just reminders as to what can be achieved by way of computer magic. It is a fact that if GLADIATOR is compared with movies like BEN HUR and THE TEN COMMANDMENTS it would pale into insignificance considering that the makers of the first two movies had only stunt persons and basic 'camera tricks' with which to work although they had the advantage of  stars like Peter Ustinov, Robert Taylor. Charlton Heston, Yul Brynner etc etc to bring their stories to dazzling life. Too much computer imagery and too little reality would be my description of GLADIATOR. I stress that this is MY opinion. It may not necessarily be the opinion of others who look for different attributes in the movies they choose for entertainment.

title: Awesome movie, must see
review: Great story, kept me on the edge of my seat the whole way.  Was afraid that my wife would not like the violence but she loved it as much as I did. I cannot recommend this movie more highly. It is one of the all time best.

title: Great flick.
review: Loved this movie tremendously for a couple of reasons -- Russell Crowe is fantastic and, surprisingly, Joaquin Phoenix is excellent (yes, you despise him, but that's the point). I also enjoyed Oliver Reed in his role. The plot was strong and the gore wasn't too much in your face (a la Braveheart). Crowe is becoming one of my favorite actors with his performances in this, The Insider and L.A. Confidential. He carries this film well, and Ridley Scott does an excellent job with not allowing the violence to take over the movie.

title: my comments are to the point and i feel there direct
review: i thought this film was excellent.  russell crow gave an outstanding performance.  the action and story line were never slow, it kept at a good pace.  i was asked did i like this film better than titanic, i answered it blew titanic away.

title: SWIIIIIIIINGGGGG!
review: I am sure glad I decided to go see the new epic film "Gladiator." This movie is sure to be a hit with all audiences! Set in the glory days of Rome, the film is about a former commander who is enslaved and must be a gladiator to seek revenge and survive. Could somebody say "summer blockbuster"? It is not inside confidential information anymore, Russell Crowe is not just a fine actor but now he is a big star. His performance as the gladiator was subtle, but yet, powerful. Co-star Joaquin Phoenix also delivered a swashbuckling performance. However, he still has many rivers to cross before he gets to Crowe's acting status. Follow my advice- Do not save it for later, go see "Gladiator." **** Good

title: Great action movie, yet very disconcerting.
review:
This movie is good and bad at the same time. I came out of the movie with very mixed feelings. To start off with the good points and not repeat what others have said, the battle/arena sequences were very exciting. The script is not original, but there were enough twists and turns to make an otherwise formulaic movie interesting. The acting was also very good. Connie Nielson was just excellent. Joaquine Phoenix was perfect for the part. And Russel Crowe shined through out the film. In short, this is a great action movie. Some might not like the ending, but to me, it was very unexpected and very out of the conventional Hollywood way.

However, if you look at the film in terms of its appeal and content, the movie is very disconcerting. I would imagine that most people are attracted to this film by its Roman glory. But imagine 2000 years after the Romans, we still want to be entertained by the spill of blood and excessive violence. We thought of Romans as barbaric and ourselves as enlightened, yet many will flood to this movie to watch people's heads get chopped off. This movie is simply a new trend of Hollywood movies (such as Legend of the Fall, Saving Private Ryan, the Thin Red Line, Braveheart, and the upcoming the Patriot)that is designed to feed off the audience's hunger for violence. This film will do great at the box office, but what does that reflect about our society?

title: Not bad
review: This could have been a real master piece and the best movie of the year if a couple of details. The gore is totally exarragated in many parts in which they were not necessary. You expect violence in a movie like this but it was just way too much. Also  all the other Gladiators would not have been that nice to Maximus in real life. They would normally just save themselfs. So the movie is not bad but not as good as it could be.

title: This movie kicked my butt!
review:
"Gladiator" is a very simple story. Most of the time, it is a typical war hero adventure. Sometimes it even appears stupid. The plot is not very complex and gets repetitive. The hero kills because he must and that is enough reason for him. He wants to avenge the death of his wife and his kid so he will plow through his enemies until he gets to the man responsible. When he does, he will save the day and all will be well. There are a bunch of other war adventure cliches in between the major plot events. Normally, no matter how compelling the story is, a simple war film will not win me over 100 percent. Although "Gladiator" is very one-dimensional and predictable at times, it surpasses other similar movies. Many elements contributed to grasp my attention and have me surrender to this adventure.

As I said the story is simple. General Maximus (Russell Crowe) has just led Rome to yet another victory and the empire has expanded once again. The Caesar, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), is a dying man doubting what he has achieved for his people. Since he has such a close bond with his general he decides to change his mind and ask Maximus to become the next Caesar instead of Marcus Aurelius' incompetent son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix). Maximus is a simple warrior that only wants one thing: to go home. He knows the exact number of days he has not seen his family. Although he loves Marcus Aurelius, he cannot imagine himself as the next leader of Rome. For that reason, Marcus Aurelius wants him to take over and bring happiness back to the people. As Maximus ponders whether to accept the offer, Commodus finds out about his father's decision. He is heart-broken and jealous and in his rage he murders his father. Quickly he announces himself as the next Caesar. Because Maximus is suspicious and not willing to serve his new leader, Commodus has him arrested and orders an execution. Similarly, he orders Maximus' family to be killed as well. While Maximus escapes, his loved ones are murdered and his house is burned down. The exiled general is eventually captured and bought by Proximo (Oliver Reed) who trains him and many others to be gladiators in a smaller province outside of Rome. Maximus quickly steals the hearts of many spectators and becomes their favorite. Back in Rome, the power hungry Commodus decides to bring gladiator games back to the people of Rome and so a confrontation between the young Caesar and Maximus is evident.

Ridley Scott's direction sells this story. He uses dark lighting and vast settings to create a similar tone to the one in "Blade Runner." The darker mood is great in "Gladiator." Not all hero adventures such as this one have to maintain a mostly positive atmosphere. The storytelling is overwhelmingly powerful and very compelling. Dynamic cinematography is effectively used during all major battles and gladiator fights. The music is excellent. It just screams out at you. This simple tale is transformed into the most interesting and engaging picture of this year. Russell Crowe is great as Maximus. He portrays courage, honor, and anger with a warrior's mentality. His repetitive drive for vengeance is forgotten in the way this film is presented. Joaquin Phoenix is even better as Commodus. This is a confused man that wants power, but doesn't know how to get it or what to do with it. He expresses jealousy in sight of anyone who is more loved than he is. That is why he hates Maximus. He believes his father loved Maximus more than he loved him. He wants to feel love from the people of Rome; therefore he will do anything to please them. He wants to be loved by his sister, more than a sister should love her brother. He forces these things and they confuse him. Commodus is in pain and is blind to what he is doing. Ridley Scott makes sure Commodus' eyes are never quite visible in the film. They are always encircled by darkness or make-up. This is exactly the type of character that would be present in the future world of "Blade Runner." Phoenix's performance is Oscar worthy.

Because of the performances, the beautiful music, the dark lighting, and the energetic cinematography the simple story of "Gladiator" evolves into an overpowering film. It's good to see a film set in a darker moodier ancient Rome instead of another World War II epic. It's also great to see a movie with so much energy and power that it makes you forget about its simple storyline. Many beautiful sequences in "Gladiator" make this film an unbelievable experience. It is tremendous and seems larger than life. "Gladiator" is better than, say, "Braveheart" simply because of its raw power. "Braveheart" was a great adventure that just wasn't enough in comparison. "Gladiator" is exceptional and surpasses other smarter films in the genre simply because of its overwhelming presence! It will absorb you with all its might. This film might be overlooked during the Oscars because it is another war epic, but hopefully it will get some recognition. "Gladiator" achieves greatness in its dark powerful storytelling and great direction by Ridley Scott. It will be one of the best films of the year. Thank you for making a predictable story burst out as if it was so much more. This movie kicks ass! Overall, a 10 out of 10!

title: Great Scott!
review: After weeks of waiting and waiting to see this movie, I finally got round to seeing 'Gladiator' this afternoon. I'd read a lot of reviews praising it, and I've always liked Ridley Scotts' work. Here he proves again what a brilliant director he is. 'Gladiator' has got to be the best Roman epic since....well, 'Ben Hur'. Russell Crowe is not a name I'd heard of till seeing this film, but I expect we'll be hearing a lot more of him after this. He is simply superb. He has a good mixture of toughness and emotion in it to make you sympathise with him, and will him on. Joaquin Phoenix's bad guy emperor is a brilliantly nasty, and probably a bit mad character, who you want to see get punished. Well, everyone is brilliant, lets face it, cos it *is* a Ridley Scott movie, and he always casts well. All in all, brilliant. 9/10

title: One word: SPECTACULAR!
review:
I saw Gladiator last Saturday and I was completely blown away by it. Russell Crowe is fantastic as General Maximus, who is betrayed, becomes a slave and later a gladiator. When he is a gladiator, he seeks to revenge his wife and son, who were brutally murdered by the the new emperor. There are spectacular battle- and fightscenes in gladiator, great characters(both hero and villian), a blockbuster-soundtrack and also a great story. I can`t recommend you enough to see this movie. This has to be one of the best films in 2000.

10/10

title: Rome revisited!
review: Ridley Scott, te saluto! This film was so much better than I expected when I'd seen the trailer, the old city of Roma Aeterna so much better done and the Germans so much more true to the possible truth than in most films! (I still wonder what the German in the beginning says...anyone who knows?) Sure, this is an action movie, but with enough heart and soul to keep you tight in your chair for almost 3 hours, which is more than you can say of most films... Of course, the film is not following the true story (Commodus was, as they say, strangled by a certain Narcissus), but that isn't so important when the film grabs you like this does. So: one complaint: why put in the birds? They're animated and you see it! Why???

title: Not his best- but he doesn't wear pants so it makes up for it
review: Yup,yup, no pants :) Not Crowe's best, I think L.A.C. takes that cake but still, very very good. Also enjoyable, the costumes, they were soo beautiful, if the designer doesn't win for them I shall be very angry.

title: Beautiful, thrilling, action packed...
review:
Even with the typical annoying theater patrons talking and ruffling there packages of Reeses Pieces, this was the fastest two and a half hours of my life. The film was beautifully done and the story line was intriguing. Russel Crowe is destined to be a huge star. I haven't seen him in a film that he hasn't carried.

One can't help but see the similarities between Gladiator and Braveheart. A lot has been said about this, and I would have to agree that they are there. However, I can say that Gladiator gives you a much more exciting and uplifting film experience. While Braveheart gave us a dark and dreary Scotland, Gladiator gives us a bold and beautiful protrait of Rome. Gladiator has the dark undertones of its story line, however is filmed in a way that takes them in a lighthearted manor, giving the audience a more exciting ride.

I gave Gladiator a 9 out of 10, on sheer excitement. As I sit here and write this review, a get the feeling that it should be higher than that. It was an exiting film and had the great battle scenes that mark a roman epic, however it was a whole lot more than that. The acting was superb and the story was well written. The directing, while not typical of Ridley Scott, was wonderful. His use of CGI was the best I have seen as of yet. He did rely on it, rather used it to make picture more beautiful. The balance between the action and the storyline was perfect. All and all Gladiator was a ride worth taking.

title: Extremely violent, but impressive go see!
review: "Gladiator" is well worth your money. Go see it in a cinema. Don't wait for the film to be released on video or DVD. This is a cinematographic experience that will only happen once or twice a year! This is why people should go to movies, to see impressive feasts like this. Visually "Gladiator" is of extreme good quality. The story itself is a bit simple, if you compare it with those heroic epics from the 50's and 60's, the Ben Hurs and Spartacusses. In itself, the movie's graphic violence is sometimes a bit too much! While the story line could have been a bit more developed. Set dressing and computer effects, such as the Roman Collosseum, were done so well. Therefore, go see "Gladiator", you won't regret the experience. Sit it through, what you're gonna see is of extremely high value for money...

title: Blows away Sparticus and Ben Hur
review: Loved this movie. Russell Crowe fantastic as Maximus! The story line was brilliant, and the action was non-stop. Pay attention to the sound-track - it was great, also. The attention to detail in the Roman soldiers uniforms and their battle tactics was very satisfying. It was nice to see that somebody read a history book before making the film. This is a Big Screen movie. It will not have the same impact on the television. See it!

title: A MOVIE'S MOVIE
review:
And that's not a comment I throw around lightly. This ain't no stinkin' summer action flick folks. On the surface, it may seem all action action action, but really, thanks to the furious pace of the cinematography, the action (and gore) isn't centered upon at all. That's not the point. If you find yourself wanting to see it all more, you're no better than the mob in the Colliseum. THAT'S THE POINT OF GLADIATOR.

Having followed Russell Crowe's career for some time, having seen him in interviews, and now, having seen him in Gladiator, I realize no one else could play Maximus because Russell Crowe IS Maximus. It's that simple. Gladiator in its early stages very much resembles his career up until this point, and in his dialogues (some of which Russell is said to have written himself) Russell is letting himself exist up on the screen under the pseudonym of "Maximus".

Ridley Scott is known for taking massive images and then telling intimate portraits. While Russell's is a piece of the intimate portrait, the massive image of Gladiator is the Roman world paralleled as our own entertainment (not just sport)-centered way of life. The world Scott shows is dark, Rome a shadow of what it once was. His use of light is reserved for places where the ideal and metaphorical are able to peek through the canopy of the real: home, Elysium, forelighting, etc.. And indeed, light is rare, just as in the world Scott creates. But mind you, watch the characters for this as well: Lucilla and Lucius, what's the Latin root of these names? ;)

In all, this is my ideal movie, going beyond what I could have ever expected coming in, knowing Russell Crowe, Ridley Scott, Hans Zimmer, and DreamWorks were all attached. The subtle commentary Gladiator offers on the experience of viewing the movie itself is on the same level as that of L.A. Confidential. That is the qualification that makes a well-executed movie go from a 10 to an 11 in my books.

Light and Dark. Life and Death. Strength and Honor.

title: Don't believe the hype!
review:
Now don't get me wrong, Gladiator is not a bad film, it simply isn't as good as everyone seems to be saying it is. For some reason it has captured the imagination of what I call the James Bond audience, the people who only go to the movies once or twice a year and this has artificially inflated it's rating. There are plenty of other people writing about how good the film is, so I'm going to concentrate on it's flaws.

Firstly, it is far too long. Clearly the producers wanted to make an epic like in the old days, but they seemed to have assumed that epic means length. Wrong! I'm sure a half-decent producer could have taken at least half and hour out of the film. It takes far too long to get going. After the inital battle, which for me was the high-point of the film, there is no action for about 45 mins. This is the point where the plot takes place. The problem is, the characters are all so cardboard that the audience can easily work out what the plot is about, and five minutes here would have been more than ample.

The fight scenes were some of the worst I have ever seen. You would think Ridley Scott (or his second unit director) would have seen The Matrix, a Jackie Chan film, or at least one Martial Arts film. That is how to direct an interesting fight; long, stationary shots showing off the skills of the stuntmen, not close-ups and constant irritating cutting on movement. It was impossible to work out what was going on in most of the fight scenes.

Thirdly, there is far too much CGI. Yes it was impressive to recreate the Coliseum, but then they ruin the effect with overkill. And the CGI tigers were absolutely awful. Surely real tigers would have been cheaper and far more impressive.

Fourthly, historical accuracy... oh we don't need to bother with this, after all, it's only a movie...

And don't forget the wonderful array of accents!

I can't help comparing the film to Ben Hur or Spartacus and I'm afraid that Gladiator comes a poor second in terms of story and spectacle.

title: The most epic movie for years
review:
Gladiator by Ridley Scott is easily the biggest and most dramatic movie since...oh, heck, it´s just GREAT. The story is straightforward and simple, but (as some folks wrongly thought) that´s nothing to complain about. The best stories are the most simple ones, and this one is about classic elements like friendship, betrayal and revenge. Granted, it´s a men´s movie. So if you don´t like it go see the new Julia Roberts comedy.

The Acting is just terrific. Crowe, who already was great in "L.A. Confidential" and "Virtuosity" is going to get an Oscar or i´ll never again enter a movie theatre. Phoenix is also terrific as his Nemesis who has some very human weaknesses. The supporting cast is also very good. It´s also nice to see Ridley Scott back in town.

The CGI Graphics are not always convincing; they look too artificial. Most impressive, however, are the battle scenes (did I hear someone say "Braveheart"? As another guy here pointed out, the battle scenes in "Braveheart" looked like a picnic, compared to "Gladiator". Nothing to add here.). The fight against the guy with the face mask, surrounded by tigers, is just breathtaking.

"Gladiator" is simply the best movie for some years (if you don´t count "Star Wars", which is beyond and above competition).

Go see it!

title: One of the Best
review:
I think the critics have entirely missed the reason that people want to see this movie more than once and why some call it the best picture they have ever seen. It isn't because of the action scenes or the digitized recreations, both of which are tremendously well done. Nor is it because of the wonderful acting by several members of the cast or Ridley Scott's incomparable cinematography. The fact is, none of these elements is independent; all are choreographed to work toward one theme in the movie. Scott has an exceptional talent for doing this, as shown by his other films such as Alien, where sound and action and acting were so seamlessly integrated to produce a sense of impending doom and terror.

But in Gladiator the theme is entirely different and it is all embedded in the character of Maximus. As in all the epic historical movies this is a study of virtue combined with strength. Maximus is at ease with himself, as are we, and the lack of internal conflict would normally cause us to loose interest, but he is such an admirable person that we become only more involved as the movie progresses. The artifice and cruelty of Roman society, and of course the character of Commodus, are provided to enhance the sense of Maximus nobility. But there is something in Maximus' which represents a fundamental link between nature and man, life and death, which is presented with such direct simplicity and appealing honesty that we must be attracted by it.

Maximus is a man of the earth, a fact repeatedly illustrated in the movie, from his stated love of the land to the close-ups where he dusts his hands in the soil before battle. More than this, he shows us a man whose strength comes from this devotion to the earth. If Ben-Hur gave us a man to admire for his devotion to faith, and Spartacus a man with noble conviction about human value and dignity, then Gladiator does equally well in showing a man whose attunement with nature is both shield and sword, for whom death and life are part of one experience, and who has taken unshakable faith from those beliefs.

A character in TV's presentation of Arabian Nights said that fairy tales show us how to win. I think that drama and acting, at its best, shows us how to be, and the portrayal of Maximus has reached that height. We are all carried along by this earth. The inevitable forces it imposes on us finally transcend the society we create to shut it out. Seeing this illustrated in a film can be a moving experience.

If you don't see this, then all you see is a thin plot pumped up by fight scenes and computer graphics, which, however well done, will never be in a class with the great films of the past.

title: WOW WOW WOW! One of the ten best of all time in my book.
review: Wow!  That is one of the few words that I have left in my Vocabulary after seeing this flick.  It hits on all cylinders and never lets up.  I mean everything is pulled off perfectly!  Everything!  Not many films can say that.  The acting is perfect.  The action is above first rate, and the direction, oh the direction, never seen it done better for a gladiator flick.  Even better than Spartacus.  Forget about Gibson and Scharzeneggar. Russell Crowe plays this part perfectly.  He will not get an Acedemy Award, but he should.
