If he were really so weak as to be unconscious or delirious for the duration of the journey, as the audience is apparently expected to believe, than why would anyone as pragmatic as a slaver have bothered to bring him along in the first place?

`Gladiator' depicts the period of Roman History during the reign of Commodus, reputed by Roman historians to have been one of the four worst rulers the Roman Empire ever had (the others being Nero, Caligula and Septimus Severus). Commodus was all the worse for having succeeded one of the most able of the Roman Emperors, his stoical father Marcus Aurelius, whose volume of `Meditations' is still in print today. In `Gladiator', Commodus is depicted as a patricide, which was, curiously enough, one of the few crimes of which he was not guilty. In reality, Marcus Aurelius died of plague in what is now Hungary while preparing an expedition to extend the Empire to the Vistula River. Commodus, who had delusions of being the reincarnation of Hercules, actually did participate in gladiatorial games, a circumstance which scandalized his subjects. It was somewhat analogous to the President of the United States associating with punk rockers or outlaw bikers. He was eventually murdered by members of his own household, on the theory that it is better to do onto others before they do onto you.

Perhaps the most glaring anachronism in `Gladiator' is the implication that, upon the death of Commodus, the Roman Empire reverted back into a republic. Actually, there followed one of the most bizarre and grotesque episodes in the history of human government, in which the Praetorian Guard actually auctioned off the Roman Empire to the highest bidder. Obviously the producer's audience research determined that a satisfying happy ending would sell more tickets than the far more dramatic, and infinitely more cynical, real ending.

title: Best movie of 2000
review: ya it may not have the biggest names in acting, but those actors were all perfect for the roll they played. This movie had a lot of emotion, drama, action, and a little bit of romance, BUT NOTHING MAJOR! I think Gladiator was a must see movie because of the incredible amount of emotion and action. go see gladiator, its worth the money

title: Great directing by Ridley Scott
review: Ridley Scott has done it again (creating a superb motion picture, like Blade Runner and Thelma & Louise). This time, he has made the first good picture on Imperial Rome since "Spartacus", a picture appealing even to those who do not appreciate the genre. From the opening scene to the film´s closing, the audience is drawn into the story and into history, led by brilliant camera work, solid acting, a captivating musical soundtrack setting the mood for every scene without interfering with the picture, and brilliant cinematography. Characters are well developed and realistic, true to historic records (in fact, history tells us that Commodus, the Emperor, was even more of a megalomaniac than he is portrayed in the picture. If the script writer had portrayed him as he really was, audiences would probably have considered it as too much of a Hollywood cliché...). The computer-designed scenarios are breathtaking, notably of the Colisseum.

title: Why do we go to movies?
review:
For me, I go to movies primarily to be entertained. Gladiator is top notch entertainment. It fits the definition of an epic to a tee. Some have board posts have reflected complaints about historical inconsistencies, length (more minutes per $), and a so-called lack of character development: Maximus and Commodus, the early years....were these watcher's eyes and ears closed?

The movie was presented in such a manner that the viewer didn't HAVE to bear witness to the early years. The character's were written and directed well enough that it was quite obvious how the relationships were intertwined. This allowed for the action to get underway in conjunction with a very engaging, yet simple plot that contained a few nice surprises.

Forget the naysayers and what they say. They probably come from the art film world where no foreign language film is bad and other movies such as Shakespeare in Love, Dangerous Liasons, The Thin Red Line, etc. are king...to me can you spell BORING.

Gladiator ranks with Braveheart: Best Picture 2000 (to date for sure)

title: I knew Spartacus...you're no Spartacus
review: This is a good-looking movie. Let's get that out of the way.  The character actors are very good (including Derek Jacobi, thrown in perhaps for associations with "I, Claudius"?).  Crowe is good enough, although he isn't given a lot to work with, meaning he doesn't have very interesting lines. The Hans Zimmer score is predictably derivative: Holst, Orff and now Dead Can Dance -- things that go thump-thump-ahh-ahh.  But the "atmospheric" style seems to be in vogue at the moment.  It really interfered with my enjoyment, though.  The historical accuracy was wildly varied: pedantic details of the manmade environment peeked out from wholly unrealistic scenes.  You can hire consultants to reproduce period textiles, but not period sensibilities.  The writer and director have to find those in reading some of the plentiful sources that have come down to us from Rome.  I wonder how much time they devoted to hearing the voices of ancient Romans before staging their big computer crowd scenes.  Spartacus took up some serious issues, even though it was quite corny.  This is just a revenge tale with exquisite production values. 6/10

title: a great tale and vision but not flawless
review: Ridley Scott has always encountered us with other worlds, he likes to create his arena from scratch, in this case the arena is the ancient roman empire, but sadly it is inhabited by more virtual people then toy story. It is a great loss that this great tale and well acted story suffers from this modern desease called cgi, the time of great masses of extra's (real people seems to be gone. now we have to asume that those awkward moving people are real, the movie suffers from it! And why does these days everybody has to have a deathwish be reunited with their family in the afterlife (startrek generations had it, end of days had it and so does gladiator) it makes it look a little bit rediculous. but the rest of this movie is so impressive that i'm still giving it an 8.

title: 'Bloody and the Beast' entertaining action for those in need of a killing frenzy.
review:
Lots of very exciting action. Generally good story line until the total collapse at the end.

And I thought only the French did not know how to finish a movie! Forget about the end and you're on.

General is victorious ... betrayed by jealous heir to Caesar ... escapes death ... somehow winds up a gladiator (super gladiator) ... goes to Rome... drives his betrayer (new Caesar) crazy ... wins big at killing and becomes a superstar ... new Caesar's sister betrays Caesar for gladiator (sounds real to me!) ... from here the story line goes south.

Basically this is a revenge story with terrific action and some stars that make the movie fun. Russell Crowe, as Maximus the gladiator, is a terrific presence on screen. His only weak lines were with Caesar Senior (Richard Harris who looks like he has just about recovered from the beating in "The Unforgiven") when he is describing his home. Crowe just could not do those lines. No one could do those lines! Elsewhere, Crowe is the gladiator! What a killer! Crowe looks perfect in this rugged, physical role and he has a very good voice. Joaquin Phoenix as Caesar Junior is fantastic as a disgusting figure. He was nervously sexual around his sister, played by Connie Nielsen. He definitely convinced me that he was unstable. Nielsen is a real beauty and gave a strong performance - where has she been? Oliver Reed was pretty good as the master of the gladiators. This part lacked consistent definition. I think that Reed needed to be cruel and money driven from start to finish. What other kind of person could run a gladiator slave operation?

The scenery, clothing, and hardware are outstanding.

Flaws and all, I liked the movie because the good parts and good scenes carry the imagination along quite well. Most of the acting worked and Russell Crowe is truly powerful on the screen. He moves so well and just looks believable. See it!

title: Let's go back in 180 AD...
review: Though the plot of Gladiator is completely fictional, using historical characters requires keeping a certain accuracy. In this respect it is intersting to learn who Emperor Commodus really was... Marcus Aurelius became emperor in 161, and until 169 he reigned in cooperation with Lucius Verus, husband of his eldest daughter Lucilla. Then the latter died. In 177, Marcus Aurelius associated his son Commodus to official functions in order to prepare him for the succession. In that sense, Marcus Aurelius reestablished the blood succession. Marcus Aurelius died shortly after the victory against thr Danubian barbarians near the actual Vienna in 180, but, he wasn't strangled by his own son as in the film, but died or of the plague or of exhaustion.Commodus becomes emperor, but shows little ability to succeed in his new functions. He concluded a quick peace with the barbarians, came back to Rome and actually did not care about politics. He lived in his world of laziness and lust. Lucilla was very angry at him and did not like his lover Bruttia Crispina. She set a plot and an attempt was made to kill Commodus, but it failed. This marked the beginning of a series of executions within the royal circle and the senate. Dio Cassius, Roman senator said: "The fear was shared by us senators.He killed an ostrich, cut off its head, and came towards us with the head in his left hand, brandishing his bloody sword in the right. He wagged his head to show he would do the same to us." When he entered the senate, the senator had to salute him in this way: "You are Lord, you are first, you are most fortunate. You are Victor, you will be victor; from everlasting, Amazonian, you are victor". More than that, Commodus was clearly a mad man, influenced by oriental religious practices. He wanted Rome to be called Commodiana, and the Legion Commodian.. He called himself the Roman Hercules, and styled Rome the "Immortal Fortunate Colony of the Universe"! All the months were given his names: Amazonius, Invictus, Felix, Pius, Lucius, Aeliuys, Aurelius, Commodus, Augustus, Herculeus, Romanus, Exsuperatorius. He applied Exsuperatorius (his own image of Jupiter) to himself regularly to show that he surpassed mankind in many ways... Many statues represented him as Hercules. Commodus loved the games. He often went to the amphitheatre and entered the arena dressed as Mercury, beginning his exhibition barefoot and in his tunic after having got rid of his garments!. According to the historian Aurelius Victor, he was "so depraved that he often fought in the arena as a gladiator"!! He had a real fascination for gladiators and wild beast, and when he wanted in January 193 to kill two senators in sacrifice and to make a procession in Rome at the head of his gladiators, it became necessary to get rid of this dangerous psychopath! His surroundings plotted, and Marcia, his favorite lover handed him a cup of poison, and he was then strangled in his bath by his coach, Narcisse, on December 31, 192. The reign of Commodus marked 12 years of terror, lust, cruelty and greed. He was obviously a megalomaniac. If a date can be fixed for the beginning of the decline of the Roman Empire, it would be his reign. In the film, his folly is well represented, but in a different way though. We can see that he is a megalomaniac the way Ridley Scott made him enter Rome, and through the fact that he wants to rule alone. We als see that he loves the games, since he introduces 150 days of gladiators' fights. But his obsession with religion has been replaced by an incestuous love for his sister, whom he nearly consider as a goddess. But he didn't die in the arena (though he often fought as a gladiator), but was murdered. Nevertheless,with an astonishing photography and editing,  Ridley Scott's Gladiator is one of the best epics of the last 20 years, and will remain as such in many people's eyes...hopefully!

title: Excellent!
review: This is a movie well-worth the rising movie ticket price.  It is about heroism, politics and all kinds of love.  Not only are the actors extremely talented, but the script writers knew how to work the plot and the dialogue. Even the music adds to the grandeur of this film.  From the set to the costuming, to the directing and the acting, this movie pulls the viewer in and makes the story very personal as if you're the only one in the theater.

title: G.C.S.E Latin at it's finest!
review:
I didn't think of it as an Epic, I thought of it as a G.C.S.E Latin fictional 'Roman Life' book on-screen, but with additional storylines, vivid adventures and heart-warming dialogue. (ok, not ALL of it was 'heart-warming', but it certainly did touch me).

It was truly action-packed with various twist and turns to maintain interest of the viewer. I also highly appreciated the fact that the film jumped straight into it and prevented me from napping before the story had begun!

A big slap on the back for Russell Crowe. I think that this was his first 'major' film, and it was brilliant. Also the same for the actor that played Lucius. I'm sure we'll see more of him in the future.

My mother said that this was the best film that she'd ever seen and I respect her judgement.

title: People complaining about the gladiator
review: I am shocked, stunned, and amazed by people who dislike this movie.  Citing its historical inaccuracy and casting mistakes.  First of all, if we wanted to see a documentary on the trials of Ancient Rome, all we would have to do is flip to PBS.  I'm sure that they have made an "as close to accurate" ditty on Marcus Aurelius life, and the death of Commodus, and ultimately the fall of the roman empire.  Now I don't know about you, but when I go to the movies, I would like to be entertained.  And secondly, Russell Crowe was perfect for the part of Maximus.

title: An Unique Opportunity for a Great Actor
review:
This is one of the best movies in recent memory. Not because it is "perfect" film by any means; it definitely has it's flaws. But it is worth the price of admission if only to see superb actors such as Russell Crowe, Jouquin Phoenix, Richard Harris, Oliver Reed, Derick Jacobi, etc. strut their stuff.

While many people who have been Russell Crowe fans for years will resent the fact that many are touting "Gladiator" as Russell Crowe's "breakthrough" role, fans long ago noticed there was something unique about this guy in such film as "Proof", "The Sum of Us", "Quick and the Dead", "L.A. Confidential" and "The Insider".

But in spite of the films flaws, Crowe fans will not be disappointed in "Gladiator" because they get a chance to see him carry the entire weight of a big budget film (he's in practically every scene) on his ample shoulders. As with Vivien Leigh in "Gone With the Wind", it is hard to imagine this film working without the presence of Russell Crowe.

He makes the most believable gladiator I have ever seen on film. I'm sorry, but as much as I loved "Sparticus", I never believed Kirk Douglas could be a real gladiator. He looked more like a gymnist; I never believed he could survive in the Coliseum.

But as good as the other actors in "Gladiator" are, and as good as the effects and fight sequences are, the plot and script could not have been as compelling with any other actor but Russell Crowe playing Maximus.

There is some unique quality about this guy (perhaps the strange mixture of violence and compassion in his face) that brings an absolutely unique contribution to this film. His acting covers the gaps in the script....mostly done with his facial and body expressions since he is rarely given quality lines to say. (Most of the lines in the film are a bit corny or cliched. It's a good thing they had this brilliant cast!)

For example, we are expected to believe that this man, Maximus, who is capable of the most excruciating violence, is at heart a tender hearted family man who simply wants to go home to his farm. It is left up to Mr. Crowe to make us believe this, and he rises to the occasion in spades.

Someone pointed out to me that Crowe does not speak one word of dialogue from the time that Maximus is sent out to be executed by Commodus to the time he is in the gladiator ring shouting, "Are you not entertained?" The fact that, throughout this long sequence (20-30 minutes) I never even noticed Maximus never spoke, is just proof of the unique abilities of Russell Crowe as an actor. This is one guy who could have easily been a silent movie star; something that can't be said for 95% of the actors around today.

As "Gone With the Wind" would have been just a so-so well made movie with nice production values without the presence of Vivien Leigh, so too would "Gladiator" have only been a so-so movie without the presence of Russell Crowe. But because of him, it becomes a symbol of brave people everywhere fighting everywhere against unbelievable odds. Let us hope, as with Vivien Leigh, that the Academy recognizes this unique talent and gives Mr. Crowe his best actor Oscar!

title: An Early Favorite for Oscar
review:
After seeing the ad for Gladiator, and realizing that Russell Crowe was the main character, I was determined to see it. His portrayal of Bud White was what made LA Confidential transcend to another level. Finding out that Ridley Scott was the director made it 100% certain that this was a film not to be missed.

From the opening of the film, with the wheat blowing softly, leading up to a battle that combined the frenetic camera work similar to Private Ryan mixed with the brutality of Braveheart all set to Hans Zimmer's great score, I was hooked.

Here is a film that includes all the pre-requisites of being a hit. Superb acting from all the leads (Joaquin Phoenix - I didn't realize he could act that well!?) Richard Harris as the elderly Caesar, the late Oliver Reed, and Djimon Hounsou all did superb jobs. What MADE this film what it was though, was Crowe's performance as the betrayed General Maximus.

The sheer emotion and depth that Crowe brought to what could have been a cardboard replica of a historical figure proves with no doubt that he is now one of the top actors in Hollywood.The vulnerability mixed with the intensity, with the ever underlying thirst for revenge drives the character and subsequently the film. It is doubtful one will see a better performance than the scene where Maximus discovers his family killed.

With a lavish set design, aided by stunning CGI work, the viewer feels literally immersed in the world of old Rome. The battles (the best one being the Barbarian Horde) are staged elaborately, and truly evoke the quality of what they must have been like.

This movie is similar in some ways to 1995's Braveheart, yet differentiates itself enough to be truly original. It is a strong possibility that come March, Ridley Scott could be standing at the podium holding Oscar. Of all the films that have come out in the past year, this is one that NOBODY should miss!

title: At last, violence with a purpose.
review: An impressive movie with great acting and superb photography.  Underlying is a good comparison of what's going on in our own society.  Bread and games, that's what people are asking for.  Just look at those extreme combats shown on tv and that so many people enjoy.  Let's hope that we get more of that kind of movie and let's also hope that some will get the message.

title: Ridley Scott does it again.
review: Ridley Scott has become my favorite movie maker. Once again he has taken me to another time and another place. Although this movie does not have the soul of Blade Runner or the suspense of Alien, it is a visual masterpiece. For over two hours I was transported into the ancient world. What makes this movie great is the acting and the world according to Scott. The acting of the film veterans is just great and it holds this whole movie together. Then you have Russell Crowe who is again a presence that grabs you every time you see him. I would have followed him into battle and died for him. Bottom line is, really really great entertainment.

title: A soaring movie of epic proportions.
review:
This is an excellent film for those who are interested in the field of Roman History. The first battle was very realistic as to what would have happened. The sheer destructive power of pre-gunpowdered weapons was almost beyond belief. And all this in the first ten minutes of the movie.

There are those who would not like this movie because of the violence in it. My reply would be, "How can you do a movie about a gladiator without violence". The violence was not the main feature of this film. It was about the will to survive, and about revenge.

Overall, if you want to see a movie that grips you from the start and gives you an insight as to the political maneuverings in the Roman empire in the second century, this is definitely the movie to see.

title: for those who believe in heroes
review:
As my summary suggests, this is classic example of a legendary "hero" way back when, with battles and death galore, tinted with unsurmountable odds and a love interest to boot. Clooney (Maximus) plays his role surprisingly well as talented general who, after his initial escape from death, battles for vengeance on his own. And we all know nothing is more dangerous than a man who has nothing to lose. Despite what you might think beforehand, the fight scenes are NOT repetitive; each has its own flare and creativity that will interest the most of you, if not sicken you with special effects (plenty of blood; not for the weak stomach). My only complaint is the way the final scenes were handled; they seemed set up (unbelievably I might add) and they made you expect a huge battle to conclude the story, but it never happened. That foible aside, I had high hopes and was not disappointed.

If you've seen Gladiator, you may think I'm over-generalizing it, and well, I am. If you haven't, for the most part, it's well worth your money, because everyone needs a little fantasy story with honor, loyalty, and heroism ironed into their head. When we see someone achieve something like that, even in a movie, although me might not know it, we feel refreshed at what a single human can accomplish.

title: A worthy film, though not without flaw
review: Gladiator is an epic film.  A moving story with good characters. I must compliment all the actors, Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix especially.  I felt I understood all the characters, each had motivation, goals, and a personality.  To those who have belittled Phoenix's performance, I suggest you check whether he was merely playing an unlikable and deranged character very well, or if his actual acting was lacking.  I think the former is the case. I did notice a few flaws.   The first was the excessive and obvious use of CGI, which I feel gave the movie an unreal and unbelievable look at times. The second flaw involves the historical accuracy of the film.  While this only slightly detracted from the film, I did find it distracting.  For example, I seem to have noticed stirrups in use (certainly the actor's foot position suggested stirrups), which weren't invented until the millenium after the time depicted.  Pens and paper, and other minor inaccuracies were to be noticed if you were in the know.  As I said though, these minor inaccuracies did not take away from the depiction of the film.  Of course, the largest inaccuracy is the eventual outcome of the film, with regards to the fate of the Roman empire, which I will not reveal.  In the end however, this is a story, for entertainment, not a historical documentary, and I am more than happy to forgive and overlook such transgressions in the name of a good film, which this definitely is. The only other complaint I have about the film was the use of cuts to the 'dream world'.  These cuts are confusing for most of the picture.  Who is having them?  Why?  What do they mean?  They gave the film a disjointed feel to me.  Though eventually the reasons for these 'dreams' becomes clear, their execution left something to be desired for me. The conclusion?  "Gladiator" is a fine film, worth seeing.  The closest to an epic film I have seen in some time, "Gladiator" regales with war and love, vengeance and madness.  What more can you ask?

title: A wonderful adaption to a traditional storyline from the inspiring Scott and Crowe
review: The story revolves around Maximus, a noble leader who is chosen by Marcus Aurelius himself to take his place as commander in favour of his dysfunctional son Commodus.  Commodus then murders his father and sends Maximus to be executed.  Maximus survives the forthcoming execution and flees in search for his family - who he finds hung in his home town.  He then rides forth to become a gladiator to avenge the sinister Commodus. There are some fantastic battle scenes but what makes this better from all the CGI'd sci-fi films is content and depth.  Commodus loves his sister for more than just being a sister (reminiscent of Star Wars) and some of the minor characters are executed with precision.  Russell Crowe was believable, realistic, well hard and quite frankly a master in his role of Maximus, Joaquin Phoenix lacked edge but delivered as the sinister Commodus and the late Oliver Reed played a final memorable performance as Maximus' trainer. Ridley Scott's direction is awesome.  This movie shows what CGI effects should be used for.  Although gory, this is not disturbing - this is deep and portrays a powerful and awe-inspiring message.  Best movie of year 2000 so far.

title: A hero will rise... and a movie will rock.
review:
I can't remember the last time I walked out of a theater so satisfied with a film I'd wanted to see so badly. My expectations were raised repeatedly, as the first and second trailers plus the glowing recommendations of friends who'd seen it equaled the possibility of a huge disappointment.

Thankfully, the work of Ridley Scott, Russell Crowe and others did not let this moviegoer down. While the plot was good and well done, Gladiator's strength lies in its great battle sequences. You want blood? You got it. You want guts? You got it. These battles are some of the best I've ever seen on film.

A certain MTV Movie Awards winner for Best Fight Sequence... the hard part will be deciding which battle to pick.

While the battle sequences will be the number one topic of discussion as you're walking out of the theater, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the great performances from the main actors. I doubt Crowe has ever been better, there's a good chance you'll be chanting his name along with the crowd during the Coliseum scenes. Probably not Oscar-worthy, but you never know... Joaquin Phoenix deserves some recognition as well, he makes a good villain. From the moment he arrives on screen, the audience immediately hates his guts. By the time that these two finally meet, you'll want to see Phoenix get what's coming to him quite badly.

A great movie, the best I've seen this year (so far), and a certain DVD purchase in the winter. But don't wait... see this one on the big screen. It's well worth the price.

title: Russell Crowe is a true and classic hero right from the start
review:
The opening scene of the film is excellent and ties you to your seat and draws you directly into the movie. Russell Crowe does impress immediately with his performance as Maximus. He is truly heroic from the start.

The battle against the German barbarians is one of structure against chaos. You can see clearly why the Romans did win so many wars with their formations and attack patterns.

After the opening scene the story develops quite well. I know that there have been a lot of negative comments about the story but I disagree. Maximus is a simple man of 'strength and honor' from the start to the end and he fights for his vengeance. There is simply nothing more to it and the script contributes to that theme quite well.

Connie Nielsen as Lucilla (Christabella from the Devil's Advocate) plays her role very well. She plays a tough aristocratic lady not to fool around with; her relatives (Marcus Aurelius and Commodus) don't want her as an enemy! When the story develops the true nature of Lucilla reveals as mother and fighter for the right cause but trapped in the web of her brother. Nielsen (well educated, speaks 7 languages fluently) must have prepared herself quite good for the role. Oliver Reed is quite impressive as Proximo, the big boss of the gladiators. While filming Reed died in Malta from a heart attack. Joaquin Phoenix is fair enough as Commodus but not as impressive as the other main actors (including Richard Harris as the old and tired Marcus Aurelius, the old Ceasar).

The photography is astonishing and sometimes breathtaking. The creation of the old Rome is quite an achievement. It is amazing what they can do with computers these days. (I read that the scenes of Proximo in the second part where computer generated because of Oliver Reeds death) The few times repeated weat scene works well and gives a peacefull quiteness to the violence and blood shed.

It is an excellent movie and I'm sure that we will see more historic dramas in the near future.

title: Stirring film with an impressive performance by Crowe
review: This was an impressive film, highly recommended.  Russell Crowe has gone beyond his performance in L.A. Confidential and shown himself to be a truly first-rank actor.  Maximus is portrayed realistically and vividly, and you leave the film feeling that he really existed and that you met him.  Only a stone will view the film and not feel his pain.   Russell Crowe makes this film, outshining even Derek Jacobi  as senator Gracchus (whose part is on the small side) and Richard Harris as the aged Marcus Aurelius (who seems now always to play himself).  Crowe gets my vote thus far for best actor this year.  On the whole the film strikes and excellent balance between the action sequences, the power struggles of the empire under a bad emperor, and the passion of Maximus for his family.  From an historical point of view, this film does many more things right than wrong, which is remarkable for any film these days.   On the minus side, the viewer may come away with the impression that Commodus' reign was relatively brief, but he ruled from 180-192 C.E.   What the film does best in those terms is to portray aspects of Roman religion, in Maximus' devotion to his household gods.  Some may be disappointed that there are too few actual scenes of gladiatorial combat (the film's title is somewhat deceptive) but I think most viewers will find this a relief.  The film is violent but it does not dwell on the violence needlessly, and many opportunities for gratuitous depictions of violence were wisely skipped.  Add to this an impressive and haunting musical score and you have a wonderful movie.

title: Entertaining but silly...
review:
Okay, it was entertaining... okay, Russell Crowe does know how to act and does have "le physique du role" to be the perfect gladiator... okay, both Richard Harris and Oliver Reed do shine in their roles... but how can so many people do not notice the flaws in this movie?

The screenplay? Almost non existent... The CGI effects? Good, but you can spot the fake in some of them even if you're almost blind... And what about all the historical mistakes? Commodus signing (with a pen!!!!) some documents (contracts?) apparently written on paper (but this is an old cliché)... again, a paper sheet advertising the gladiator fight (has Ridley Scott or his historical consultant any idea about how much did papyrus cost???) Let's not talk about the art direction and set decoration... is it really enough to fill any room with pillars and marble busts and statues to give a "Roman look" to a period picture? And was the Russell Crowe character so strong to walk around dressed as for a battle even in scenes where it was not required?... I could go on even longer, but let's stop here... I really expected an improvement over the movies of Hollywood's golden age, and it's sad to see that while computer graphics can do wonders, screenwriters and directors tend not to do it anymore...

Where's the spirit of the man who gave us "The Duelists", "Alien" or "Thelma & Louise"? Will it resurface in "Hannibal"?... Let's hope so...

title: The epic adventure we've been waiting for!
review:
Gladiator takes you back to the days of the Roman empire and gives a perspective of what life in 180 a.d. might be like. Not since the days of Ben Hur or Spartacus have we had a movie like this. It tells the story of Maximus, the saluted Roman general who becomes a slave and a gladiator after Commodus, the sinister son of the old emperor Marcus Aurelius, through patricide takes over the position of emperor and slays the general's wife and son, destroying his life. Maximus swears revenge and fights his way to the mighty stage of the Colloseum in Rome, where he squares off with his foe.

I saw this movie at the premiere in a theater with over 600 seats, a screen reaching 65 feet from side to side, and the most brutal THX sound system this side of the known universe. The place was packed to the brim with people, dying to see this movie. From the beginning to the end, two and a half hours later, this movie delivers on all levels! Everyone in the audience started to applaud when the movie was over, something I haven't experienced since the premiere of Episode I, as they, just like me, were in utter awe of what they had just seen.

From the acting to the photography, from the music to the realistic brutal violence, this movie never failed. It's a master piece deserving both a second and a third viewing at the cinema, and a definite pre-order when it hits DVD. Ridley Scott hasn't made anything this good since Blade Runner and Alien.

I can't recommend this movie enough. You simply have to go see this picture now!

title: perfection at it's best
review: This movie took my breath away.  i was so amazed at Crowe's performance (as well as the other actor's in the movie) that i even went to see it a SECOND time! It was phenomenial. Gladiator definitly ranks high among such films as: Braveheart, Saving Private Ryan and The Green Mile. I recommend this movie to anyone-- you  won't regret it!!! Starla

title: Discontented
review: I'd been looking forward to seeing Gladiator, since reviewers have hailed it as a revival of the Roman epic. Frankly, I don't see what the fuss is about. The story failed to engage me and was altogether silly with its blend of historical figures and obviously fictional events. What's more, the screenwriters seemed intent on having the characters attempt to solve their problems and dilemmas through the most convoluted means imaginable. Russell Crowe's character was distant and broody for much of the film, but suddenly and inexplicably developed a sense of humor midway. Nevertheless, the movie could have been enjoyable as pure spectacle, but I found it disappointing even in this regard. Unlike other viewers, I felt that much of the scenery had an obvious computer-generated quality (crowds out of focus, blurry backgrounds). When I imagine gladiators in combat, I picture them in the coliseum under a blistering sun. Most of the photography however, had a dull, murky quality to it. My biggest complaint concerns the hyper-editing & camera style used for most of the fight sequences. Indeed, it was so hyper that half the time I couldn't tell who was killing who (perhaps it didn't matter?). The Gladiator isn't awful, but it's not particularly memorable either. You may want to see it to satisfy your curiosity, but not if you're concerned with getting value for your money.

title: Behold! Braveheart with that cop from L.A. Confidential!
review: If there's one thing that gets to me while I browse through movie reviews, it's pedantic, bitchy rants about "historical inaccuracies."  I'll be honest--SCREW HISTORY!  You don't go to the movies for a history lesson; you go because you want to scarf down popcorn while seeing two people kick the flying crap out of each other!  Intelligent movies are the ones you watch at home... with the exception of Gladiator.  Sure, some people can say that it's all action and not much else, but compared to the rest of the action epic crop, Gladiator pumps the most brain power out of all of them.  Name another action movie this year that makes you wanna go "ick" at Commodus' incestuous advances towards his sister.  Name another action movie this year that almost brings your critical ass to tears when General Maximus comes across the ashen remains of his old life.  To end it all, name a Roman epic that tops Ben-Hur and Spartacus in spectacle, and you have Gladiator. Sure, Kirk Douglas would beat Russell Crowe into a body cast, but I'll go with Ridley Scott's prettier, CGI-powered Rome.  And it's by DreamWorks, which is always a good thing in my book.

title: Fast, Furious, Fabulous!
review: An amazing mix of action, drama and splendid special fx. Russell Crowe superbly portrays his character and the epic feel of the whole film definately puts it up there with Ben Hur and Cleopatra. This film is sure to delight everyone from the big film buff to the subtle fan.

title: a real experience - especially the music
review: I must say, that at first when I left the cinema I was not that excited about this movie. More interesting was, that it was the music that I still had in mind. But after a night to reflect over this movie, I have to say, that it was one of the best movies I have ever seen. A great plot, and although it is running about 2 and a half hours, it is never boring. Go and see it for yourself - I will do so again, too!

title: Simply put, one amazing movie!
review:
Gladiator has everything. Amazing visuals, superb fight-scenes, and a strong plot with a fierce revenge angle.

The first part of the movie is quite slow, but concentrates on building backgrounds for the various characters. The movie really takes off when Maximus begins his Gladiator career, the action scenes are similar to Saving Private Ryan (like Gladiator, a film that also moved me) as the pace is frenetic and very 'in your face'.

Check out the scene where the Gladiators first enter the Coliseum arena in Rome, wow, you actually felt like you were there. During the fights you will be on the edge of your seat, willing the 'good guys on'. Apart from the action, there is a healthy dose of drama, which didn't do much for me. However, this does balance the movie quite well, but after seeing the fight scenes you just want to see more action!

The ending is predictable, but quite powerful, it really does go for the heart strings, I was moved, and that's no easy thing. The best movie I have seen in ages, Star Wars TPM had the visuals but not the story, check Gladiator out, you won't regret it!

title: kind of like an imax film
review:
Good graphics, good gore special effects, awesome decapitations. About an hour and a half of useless boring talking head crap that should've been cut or infused with decent writing. Semi-interesting but ultimately flat story. Reminded me of "Payback" (Mel Gibson takes on the mob) minus the humour. This guy was UNSTOPPABLE.. I mean, why didn't he just take on the whole Roman army himself? Totally unbelievable.

The special effects are awesome, the fight scenes are stylistic masterpieces. I have been to Rome however, I have seen the Coliseum, and I don't think it would ever look quite so "gold". Actually, everything looks "gold" in this film, giving the film a somewhat tacky commercial sheen. I wish he'd done something a little more rough around the edges like Spielberg did in Saving Private Ryan. The one dimensional story never approaches the emotional impact of Kubrick's "I am Spartacus" climax either.

Still, I must admit that this would make for a very nice Imax experience. The set design is impeccable and the background detail is meticulous. If you ever fantasized about visiting ancient Rome, this is as good as it gets.

title: One of the greatest ever
review: After seeing this movie for the 3rd time this afternoon, the ending still brought me to the point of tears. Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe combine to give one of the most powerful performances in an action/adventure/drama film since Saving Private Ryan. Other than Stand by Me, which i saw when i was just a kid, Gladiator, and Private Ryan are the only 3 movies that have ever brought me to tears. I only wish i would get an email address or agent address for Ridley Scott or Russell Crowe, just to write a letter of appreciation for the film. I saw MI2 the other day, and was grossly disappointed. More like Mission Ridiculously Proposterous, Gladiator is a far superior film. After i saw it the first time, i just sat there after the movie was over, unable to describe how much the movie touched me. I have recommended it to everyone from my mom, to Fraternity buddies, and have gone to see it each time with a new group of people who were seeing it for the first time. The soundtrack as well is amazing. The music alone brings me to tears, and as soft as i sound, i rarely cry at movies, where everything is scripted. But i listen to tracks 15,16, and 17, and i get teary eyed. The music is just very powerful and the vocals are incredibly haunting. Hans Zimmer did an amazing job, and while Hans did the ST for MI2, it doesn't compare. The whole package is an emotional tour de force, that isn't just a hack'em up bloody gorefest, despite the amount of killing that does occur, it has a story and emotion and brilliant acting by Russell Crowe and supporting cast. It's a must see for the summer, and a must own when released on VHS or DVD.

title: If you can stand the gore, it's a good movie
review:
Seems to take liberties with some aspects of history, but is close enough that it's more accurate than most stuff coming out of Hollywood. The fight scenes are excellent and the fact that a man could do what the main character did seems impossible. The production was great with epic proportions and worthy of an Oscar.

The acting was good though at times fair. The power of the story and plot carries this movie. The scenes and confrontations are memorable and powerful. Russell Crowe did an excellent job convincing me he was who he was playing, but the best performance was put out by Oliver Reed. He was magnificent as the slave owner of the gladiators. I thought it was him when I first saw the character, but was not sure till the end credits as he protrayed the tough old gracious retired obviously successful gladiator of times gone by. The performances of the young emperor and his sister/concubine are not as powerful, but adequate. Richard Harris does a better than expected job as the old ceasar.

If one can handle Saving Private Ryan and Braveheart you can handle this movie, though one gladiator fight sequence may out do what was in those movies.

title: Great Film With A Strange Transition
review: I loved this film, almost everything about it, but the transition where Maximus actually begins his life as a Slave/Gladiator by being kidnapped, sleeping, off his property by slave traders In the middle of of the Empire, on his estate, being a Roman citizen was a bit much, but suspension of disbelief worked fine, and I thought it was a great film.

title: Long movie!
review:
I won't lie - this movie is long. Thankfully it's been done well enough that it can hold your interest for the entire length of the movie. I must say the visuals were spectacular. Seeing Rome in all of its greyish-brown glory is quite magnificent. I think Ebert trashed it for the monotonous colour scheme but IMHO, this adds to the feeling of actually being there.

Russell Crowe has been in a couple of really great movies over the last few years: The Insider (also very long :)) and L.A. Confidential. He seems to fit perfectly into the role of Maximus and really delivers a strong performance. If you liked Braveheart, you'll probably like this one as well.

title: Remember the desert in Zucchabar ...
review:
For more than two hours you live back then, you feel the sand, the heat, the fear, you smell the blood and sweat.

I love the story, I like the image, the music and the unforgettable performance of the actors. As there has been a lot said about the fights, I would like to emphasize some other moments of the movie. Remember the desert in Zucchabar, and the cold forest in "Germania"? But how about the smooth wheat fields in Spain where HIS house was? The movie revives the Roman world again at is highest magnitude, on the screens as it was never done before. After all we all have a small piece of Romanity in us today. Think about it.

The great movie ever!!! Go see it!!!

P.S. To those who complained about the correctness of the history events: 95% of the whole literature is just fantasy, the rest of 5% is fantasy inspired from reality. What do you think Spartacus was indeed like? Like Kirk Douglas? How about Cleopatra, Moses, Jesus, Columbus, Shakespeare and all others? Do you think they did exactly what you saw on the screen? I think not, but let's love the movies for what they make us feel or think or for their power to make us a little bit better as Gladiator did.

title: Best Movie of 2000
review: As I was sitting in the theater watching Gladiator for the third time, I was thinking of another movie that it reminded me of. Braveheart. Braveheart is easily one of the best movies of the nineties, and Gladiator is right up there with it. A moving story of a general who becomes a slave, a slave who becomes a gladiator, a gladiator who defied an emperor, Gladiator stuns and amazes. A magnificent spectacle of a movie, Ridley Scott has another motion picture masterpiece notch on his belt. Gorgeous sweeping shots of a flawlessly computer generated Rome make you gasp in awe, and the battle scenes are nothing short of spectacular. Russell Crowe turns in a typically impressive performance as the general-slave-gladiator Maximus, and Joaquin Phoenix is excellent as the young, impetuous, and tyrannical Emperor Commodus. The supporting cast is marvelous, with standout performances from Djimon Hounsou as Juba the slave, and Connie Nielsen as Lucilla. Galdiator is definitely THE movie to see this summer.

title: The greatest movie of all time
review: When I first heard of this movie I thought it would be like Braveheart, only worse. But then I got more curious and decided to see it and I was AMAZED! This have everything that Braveheart has, and doesn't have. Romance, jokes, violence, drama, action, war and blood. And Russell Crowe is excellent in the role of Maximus. He's tough, raw and a great actor. I can't see any other grade for this movie than a big 10, and if you haven't seen this movie I suggest you do it or you're really gonna miss a great experience

title: Excellent film, but it's fiction, not history
review:
Great battle scenes, fine cinematography, excellent musical score, first-rate acting. For these reasons, I enjoyed the film.

However, I really would have preferred it if they had made up the names of the characters and the world in which the action took place, rather than butcher Roman history. Examples: Marcus Aurelius groomed Commodus as his successor almost from the time of his birth (he was given the title Caesar when he was five years old, and became joint ruler with Marcus in 177, three years before Marcus' death); Commodus is reported to be blond and handsome, and saw himself as another Hercules; Lucilla did plot against him, but was found out and killed in 182, early in Commodus' 12-year reign; Commodus was lecherous -- having a harem of 300 concubines and an equal number of young boys for his sexual pleasure; he often appeared as a gladiator in the coliseum spectacles; he was smothered to death as a part of a plot led by Eclectus, his imperial chamberlain, Quintus Aemilius, commander of the praetorian guard, and Marcia, his favorite concubine, not killed by a General Maximus, who does not even appear in the biographies of Commodus that I have read.

I suspect that they could have made a movie just as exciting if they had made it historically accurate, and somehow I would have found that to be preferable. However, it would have been far more difficult to find a hero, which is probably why they decided to create characters and events and pass them off as history. Too bad.

title: Nothing to Crowe about
review: There are many good things about Gladiator. Foremost is the costuming. I've only seen better once before (The Cook, the thief, his wife and her lover.)There is a good chance it will be rewarded for this. Joaquin Phoenix can feel proud of his work. Seen Mad Max? Well so has Crowe and I feel he could have done better, but as it stands my heart was racing 2 or 3 times during this movie so he carried it off. The opening battle is pure cinema and hits the mark but from there the plot drags. I had no problem with the camera work that others have complained about. I felt it successfully represented what it was intended to. Overall it seems to me that Gladiator could not overcome the restrictions it placed upon itself: it wanted to recreate both Rome and and the Roman movie and the idea is solid but old ideas and money are rarely enough. Nice try. 7/10

title: This film has made my top ten
review: I haven`t had a change in my top ten movies since pulp fiction. A very well presented story of a Roman General who is wronged and fights for the right reasons. Family and loyalty. A smooth pace that keeps you interested all the way through. Amazing performances, great action, realistic but still reminded me of some ancient Roman fable. Excellent job by Ridley Scott. I`d recommend this to everybody.

title: In a shell
review: From the start this movie grips you and takes you on a ride with a quality mix of gore and atmosphere. CGI in this film is fantastic and to be honest this is the best film I've seen since the Matrix. A must watch for everyone, everywhere.

title: Pretty damn good movie
review: Gladiator is, in my opinion, a very good movie. It has a certain style not likely to be bested soon. The scenes are beautifully made, with good realism. What? Perfect! If I didn't know all those people died, I would not hesitate to argue so immediately. Very good.

title: Good, but not great!
review:
This was a very well-made film with great acting and an interesting story. Yet I left the theatre disappointed. There was just something missing in this grand epic. Maybe character development?

I would have loved to see the early years of Maximus and Commodus. Why is Maximus so beloved by the emperor - because he is a brave, honourable man? Why does he have such a low opinion of his own son? The fact that Maximus is the emperor's favourite is just a given. The reasons for that are never explored - we are simply told that that's how it is. So we never know why Commodus is who and what he is. In that sense I find the story to be just too simple.

That doesn't mean it isn't worth watching. It just didn't grab me as much as I thought it would. Maybe it's a case of too high expectations!

6/10

title: "...Unleash Hell!"
review: This is what mythic adventures should be.  Bloody, entertaining, larger than life and beautiful to look at.  While not exactly thought provoking or historically accurate, Ridley Scott's "Gladiator" works remarkably as mainstream hollywood entertainment.

title: The work of mediocrity
review:
I was disappointed. I did not have high expectation, but I was taken in by the word of mouth that alleges Gladiator is a great epic akin to Ben-Hur. Sorry, but Gladiator fails to beat Ben-Hur by the distance. In fact, Ben-Hur is marginally better than Gladiator.

There are problems with this film. The cinematography, however beautiful and majestic in some scenes, is murky and at times irritating -- especially the sped-up method used for chaotic effect that left me cold even in the midst of carnage (hasn't this been done already in Saving Private Ryan?). There's a lack of focused direction by Ridley Scott -- the result is too many scenes that droll on and on. I felt no empathy for the cast's stilted performance of the characters throughout the film. The editing is confounding in the heat of the major war battle and gladiator duels. Even a good performance by Russell Crowe can't save this film from being doomed to failure.

I despise the flashbacks. It's the cliche that has been done to death. That's the most irritating part of the film besides that annoying and insipid young actress girl. Right in the beginning of the film after the prologue, with the main character's hand weaving through the wheat field, I knew Chuck Rudolph was right when he murmured: "Malick be damned". (For those who don't get the quote -- it's a sarcastic reference to Terrence Malick's 1978 Mid-Western classic "Days of Heaven")

Although technically impressive, the movie fails to engage me in the story I find meandering and tedious. Though I wasn't bothered by gore, I find the audience's positive response to blood and carnage cynical and despicable, especially after the fact Dreamworks/Universal showed the TV spot comparing Gladiator-esque violence favorably to football and hockey.

It's not a terrible movie, but it's certainly not great as the majority of the moviegoers seem to believe. Gladiator is as mediocre as Braveheart, and that's the only compliment I have for this film.

title: Smells like epic spirit..
review:
(My review might contain spoiler) Gladiator wants so hard to be epic that it is beyond our common wannabees. (ie: The Matrix). The closest experience to watching Gladiator is watching a porno. The sub-plots are so lame and you are so let down by the lame, lame, lame, lame (why did I pay to get depress kind of) ending that you are always waiting for the 'action' to begin.

When you want to do a tragedy make it work, make us care about the main character.. Maximus was just too good, and Commodus was just too bad. You have to blur the good and the bad so we care about our good (slightly bad) hero. And how about that sub-plot of love (or was it?) between Maximus and the Emperor sister, it should have been developed.. and he should have escaped Rome and bring back the army too late to save his new lover.. QUIT IT ALREADY WHERE ROMEO ALWAYS HAS TO DIE. Juliette can die too, it would be less predictable sometime.. or even better they both live to see the next day.. no need for sweet thereafters. The main character had his share of tragedies, no need to make it a Voltaire rip-off.

War, I assume is some sort of hell, but your head is not shaking live a damn arkinson sick patient. Even the glorious fights and armies cannot make me forget that it's all a big hoax, half the military unit seen in the movie did not exist at the depicted time.. I am sorry, but I'd like to believe that when millions are spent on a movie, and with the constant rising of ticket price, the writers are spending some time to make sure of some chronoligical accuracy.

I give this movie 47% (5/10)

P.S. Was the emperor sister pretty or what?

title: A truly magnificent film
review:
I didn't make any comments until I saw this film twice as I wanted to be sure I wasn't just overwhelmed on first viewing. But the second time confirmed my feelings - this is a wonderful film.

To those who don't think Gladiator is an epic - I'd almost agree. It is really a very personal story - that of Maximus and his desire for vengeance against the Emperor Commodus. The grand scope and effects in the film are really there just to underline this fact. They do this very well - the opening battle scene is huge and the scenes in the arena are wonderful (but if you can't stomach blood - don't go!). The scale of the film is epic with an excellent recreation of 'the Glory that was Rome'.

The casting was generally good - concentrating especially on classically trained Brits in supporting roles. But the real focus of the film IS Russell Crowe as Maximus. He is on screen for most of the film and I can't imagine anyone else playing the role - he is the soul of the film and if he hadn't done such a good job the film would have been a disaster. He portrays Maximus' grief and rage superbly - in words, looks and gestures (I don't think I've ever seen anyone act so much with their eyes before...) You will not believe how menacing the line 'I will win the crowd' can be until you hear it.

This should be the role that finally gets Crowe the recognition he deserves. He should have had Best Supporting Actor for LA Confidential, the Best Actor this year was a very tough category. Next year there shouldn't even be a contest - I don't think that anyone will dominate a film as much.

title: GLADIATOR RULES!!!!!!
review: Not since the days of Kirk Douglas and Charlton Heston and Yul Brynner(for that manner) there has been a movie of such tremendous scope and power ever constructed in a motion picture of this magnitude on an epic scale. This was a far cry from the recent glorification of "Titanic",and it was well worth the change. I put it on the same ground level as Stanley Kubrick's "Spartacus",and William Wyler's "Ben-Hur",but it gives more of a volucity and surroundinged then ever since Mel Gibson's picture "Braveheart",especially the scene where Russell Crowe's character takes on the German tribes in one bloody battle opening sequence. But the part of the colisseum in Rome is one eye-popper here,and where he battles two opponents and a man-eating tiger is well worth the admission. If I had a choice of a movie to see on a Friday or Saturday night(whether the local mutilplex or the area drive-in theatre),I would see "Gladiator" again,and again!!!!!! HAIL RUSSELL!!!!

title: Amazing
review: I'll admit, I didn't go in with high expectations.  But several people recommended it, including a stage combat instructor who raved about the fights.  And I admit, I was very impressed.  The first battle scene was well done, and the movie kept my interest.  Excellent fights (though my girlfriend said some of them were "splatty"....  she liked the movie, too, though) and the ending was great.  Once it's out on video, I will be certain to get it and put it next to Braveheart as one of my favorites ever.

title: Swords, Sandals, and Mirrors
review:
After many years of neglect, Rome has found itself again in the spotlight... for the second time in one year! Like Titus, the version of Titus Andronicus released earlier in 2000, Gladiator brings new life to the sword-and-sandal genre and to a supposedly dead chronotope.

Another similarity between the two films springs to mind: to both belongs a much-discussed apparent lust for gore, accompanied by an introspective and self-conscious wariness of violence in the media. Without going into details that might spoil the plot of either movie, it should be noted that both movies:

1. are rife with violence and blood, taken to levels of extremity not customary even in modern theater 2. focus on this violence in its capacity as spectacle 3. examine the role of the film's audience through highlighting an audience in an ampitheater (in Titus, once at the end, in Gladiator constantly)

Through a synthesis of these three points, each film examines the role of violence as a spectacle today, in the modern ampitheater of the mass media. In effect, the viewer is forced to question the enjoyment he's gotten from the movie. In Titus, this question takes the tint of psychology -- is the viewer sick to laugh at Titus' jests amidst his horror? In Gladiator, the examination turns political and asks how much power the culture industry (the emperor in Rome, Hollywood today) has over the populace... its answer is quite an act of narcissism on the part of Dreamworks, but it contains truth.

But the special effects are spiffy keen and there's lots of blood, so what's not to love? :)

title: highly watchable, but not at all a masterpiece
review:
Visually speaking, Gladiator is fantastic, the depiction of Rome being particularly impressive. Furthermore, even at two and a half hours in length, the film is never boring, and I can't complain about the acting, either.

It's too bad therefore, that the ending is so mediocre. The entire production seems to fall apart in the last twenty minutes or so, climaxing conveniently rather than realistically. And, of course, the film isn't historically accurate, but who would have expected it to be?

Now, I don't mean to say that Gladiator isn't worth watching. In the end, it's a good way to kill a few hours; just don't expect it to amaze you. 8/10

title: We Who Are About To Die Salute You
review:
I have been waiting a long time to see Gladiator, having first seen the trailer for the film way back in December when I went to see Galaxy Quest. I must say that the wait was worth it. Comparisons have been made between this film and the earlier Roman Epics such as Spartacus and The Fall of the Roman Empire, but I think, all in all, this film holds it own. From the opening sequence with Russell Crowe remembering what it is like to walk in the wheat fields of his home to the final shots of the Collesium right before the final credits roll, this film was breathtaking. I have always liked movies like Ben Hur, and seeing a modern version of one of these fine films goes to show that sometimes a return to the old days of timeless epics would be good for Hollywood. Special effects pay a big part in the movie, and they have taken the place of elaborate sets that Hollywood once created. In fairness, the cost of making a film like Ben Hur or Cleopatra by today's standards would be astronomical. It would make the reported budgets of Titanic or Waterworld pale by comparison. If you need a computer to do what craftsmen once did, so be it. It is about the film, after all, more so than the sets. As long as they look believable. On a sad note, this was Oliver Reed's last film. I think he did a splendid job and only wish he could have been around to see the finished project. I am sure he would have been proud. I highly recommend this film to one and all, both as a glimpse into what life was like back then and as a return to a grand style of film-making.

Hail, Caesar.

title: breathtaking...
review:
...it was, definitely... yeah, of course one could whine about tiny little bits not as perfect as they could be. BUT: perfect entertainment, great score, brilliant camera... another Scott masterpiece.

ONE THING SHOULD BE EMPHASIZED:

Unlike other production companies, european viewers didn't have to wait half a year to see the glory. Within 30 days, the majority of europeans were able to enjoy what i consider the best film of the new millennium so far... a very special thanks to dreamworks and universal for such reasonable, customer-friendly behaviour.

Would all studios bring their films to europe that fast (I hope that routine will continue with the dvd/vhs of gladiator), they'd have to worry much less about pirated video-cd's. If one can see the big pic in the theatre, one doesn't need a bad copy in even worse resolution. And once one saw the big pic (and the movie was worth seeing), one again will go for the dvd or vhs - if it's available...

title: good but not excellent
review: The opening scene is the best in the film.If the film managed to sustain the excitement and thrills of the first 10 minutes or so it would have been a masterpiece.But it unfortunately fails to do so.After the awesome opening battle scene the film goes downhill.The fight sequences are hardly groundbreaking in a time of huge special effects.It also tries to show a serious face which contrasts with other things in the film.But at the end this film is worth seeing.

title: Good but not great, in fact...
review:
.....the more I think about it, mediocre. After so many duff movies since Blade Runner I was sceptical that Scott had suddenly become the great auteur we once expected of him after the afore-mentioned android epic. And so it proved. The direction is frankly awful in the first half. As an executive once said of 'Heaven's Gate', there is scene after scene of beautiful images, but no film. Too adverty, too many filters and irritating slow-mo. Curiously for an epic, Scott shoots a lot of the film in close up which does not work. How did Crowe escape execution in the wood? Damned if I could work it out. The close up and fast cutting of the fight scenes proves disastrous too. Why do it? Because it's in vogue, so forget personal directorial vision. Ben Hur is years old but the fight scenes here pale in comparison.

Why did he choose to film the whole thing as if you are seeing Rome through light tinted sun glasses? Perhaps to create a disconcerting atmosphere of facism, but the overall effect is one of mental illness. Rome was sunny, that's why they managed to hold games for 120 days in a row. The constant squinting at sepia soon grows tiresome. The ending was moving but it's going to be if you cynically go for the film making by numbers approach. It's routine, push the buttons stuff. Why did he insist on having music playing in the background throughout most of the film? It's a comman complaint against documentaries at the moment and is distracting here as well. Just give us a sense of reality for a moment, please. The use of (I think) Holst's 'The Planets' is el naffo as well.

Classy actors are used as window dressing. Crowe is one note. Despite the hype, Oliver Reed is given little to do. It's not a dead loss, the strange atmosphere is compelling, but there's a sense that contemporary film makers have forgotten how to tell a story and could care less. Check out Spartacus as a reminder. Great performances, especially Olivier, and a cracking script too. For those who want to see a proper historical epic, see Tarkovsky's 'Andrei Rublev.' It's awesome.

title: Scott classic!
review:
I've never been a great Ridley Scott fan. Anyone who can make GI Jane has a lot to answer for, but this absolutely excellent - the acting is brilliant (Crowe particularly), the script is OK and the effects are awesome, especially the coliseum scenes.

The only compliant is that is drags on a little long.

Crowe - a New Zealander who started in acting in Australia, got his break in the USA and plays a Spaniard in Rome - is certainly showing his versatility, despite his accent occasionally being out of place.

Joaquin Phoenix is also good, and undoubtedly the least irritating member of that family! Richard Harris did well, and the Oliver Reed pieces were also good. Despite his notoriety for his drinking, people actually tend to forget that Reed was a talented actor, and it is well displayed here.

title: Awesome Crowd Pleaser, for me though...
review:
This will make a lot of money. I'm telling that right now, it'll make a hell of a lot of money, and Dreamworks keeps hitting the jackpot with last year's success with American Beauty and this year, GLADIATOR.

Even though this will make LOTS of dough, I on the other hand was disappointed. There were all the ingredients to make a Best Picture film, but it didn't quite come close, in my opinion.

The film had Ridley Scott, first of all, one of the most influential film-makers of all time with films such as Blade Runner, Alien, or Thelma and Louise. Hans Zimmer was behind the music, who I consider to be THE GOD of film music. Then there were the actors who I thought all of them including Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix, Dijimon Honsou, Derek Jacobi, and many others, pulled off a wonderful job. Now, the problem was with the pace of the film. There were great action sequences, great dramatic cinematography, great sound, but the pace of transitions and each scenes to be the problem.

The pace of the film seemed to give almost a blockbuster-typish pace of fast-paced, moving camera with the music overtone between scenes which in many respects threw the film off. What's great about epics made by filmmakers such as David Lean or Francis Ford Coppola is that they have moments for the audience to take in what they have just seen and sometimes just enjoy a moment of silence, almost, by just staring into a great landscape or a character who was in despair or deep in thought or etc. The pace that was almost like Michael-Bay-type threw of the film for me, personally. Each sequences were so well done, that I don't think any of the audiences might have gotten bored by five or seven seconds of silence between some of the scenes. This was a very DIFFERENT film than the other Ridley Scotts in terms of the story telling and the work of the cameras in many of the scenes.

One problem I had with some of the visuals, which is usually hard to find in Ridley Scott films but there was anyway, was that many of the angles of the collusseum or the city of Rome or inside the CAESAR's palace, was that they seemed to close down the view. There seemed to be too many BIG master shots and then just CLOSE-UPS that there wasn't really any shots for the audience to look around at the people or the normal structures or objects that might have given the audience more of an open feeling, rather than just watching something that someone else shot for them to see.

Also, there was an awkward problem with the screenplay because of some of the dialogues, but mainly because of the ending. I will not include it in here since you might have not seen the film yet, but you might feel awkward as I did in the end.

Other than those, it was a GREAT crowd pleaser. Also, great images as usual like any other Ridley Scotts but somehow, very different. But anyway, I in someways liked the film, but I was disappointed to see a film that could have been SO MUCH better. ** 1/2 out of **** or a B/B+ rating.

title: ("Blood & Guts in Ancient Rome" - sorry ladies, this film is *not* called "Russell Crowe gets his Kit Off")
review: An epic worthy of the best traditions of this sort of cinema. Top notch acting, an opening battle scene that almost does for that time period what Saving Private Ryan did for WW2 - it recreates the sheer horror inflicted by the Roman Army. Later, the actual gladiator scenes in Rome are also convincingly portrayed. The cerebral elements where we follow the moral strengths and weaknesses of the characters give it more substance than a mere action movie. Its main weakness is probably that which most big Hollywood epics have had - no more than a passing attempt to use the film as an art form - this, as the gladiator organizer says, is entertainment. (Note - from the little history I've been able to glean, the storyline - who kills who - seems to be largely fiction, although the portrayal of the characters of the main players seems reasonable enough and the other details are apparently quite well constructed. So we get quite a reasonable picture of the Empire in this context if we ignore the plot. Perhaps some historians reading this will want to add details about the lives and deaths of Marcus Aurelius, Maximus and Commodus just to keep the record straight.)

title: A superb insight into the intrigues of power in ancient Rome.
review: I went just reluctantly to see Gladiator, with the idea that it would fall wide short of Spartacus, but I was mistaken.   Its 150 minutes passed  quick as lightning; after the first time I saw it I was so amazed that I couldn't quite make up my mind as to the real quality of the piece, so I read some reviews and talked to some pals and got multifarious feelings that ranged from `A royal stunts-and-special-effects surrounding a void' to `A landmark that will get all the Oscars'; so I decided to enjoy it again and make myself clear. This movie has an excellent plot of noticeable roundness, full to the brim with nerve and surprise.  Though it hasn't all the appeal to me of Spartacus, it doesn't lack depth.  A weak point: It spares too much in blood and crudeness, which would be very valuable not for morbid curiosity's sake but as an effective means to represent the most brutal aspects of the Roman Empire and to make us reflect on the value of human rights nowadays and when compared to the most sophisticated of ancient civilizations.  A good movie for lovers of both Schwarzenneger and Stanley Kubrick.

title: Just short of a masterpiece
review: This is a terrific movie which combines fantastic action, a good plot and one of the finest leading characters seen in a long time into a undeniable classic. Russell Crowe's casting as Maximus is perfect and he produces a magnificent performance as the invincible Roman General who's nobility, honour and fearless composure in all things win over everyone. He is a born leader and warrior who has only one dream: to defeat all who oppose his Emperor and to retire back to his Spanish farm with his wife and son. When those things are taken from him by the ruthless Commodus his initial welcoming of death becomes tempered as he sees a way to return vengeance upon those who have destroyed him. Ridley Scott deserves most of the congratulations as it is he who once again delivers us the kind of movie he is capable of making, beautiful, graphic but above all else utterly absorbing. The special effects and the music are amazing and serve to draw you completely into the film as its story unfolds and not once do you find yourself thinking 'Nah, that didn't look real'. If they had to complete some of Oliver Reed's scenes without the great man then the join is invisible and goes to show exactly how well the money was spent. Without a doubt THE summer blockbuster of 2000.

title: A Stunning and Amazing Film That Will Move Your Soul
review:
Before seeing this movie and having only the preview to rely on, I honestly believed that although it looked entertaining and full of action, Gladiator would be mediocre - another over-hyped, blood-and-guts film that would be way too long.

After just watching it however, I am completely humbled. This film is amazing. Everything about it, from the cinematography, to the costumes, the special effects, the score (I am in love with the score!), and even the acting, was outstanding. You know a movie is really good when it is three hours long and you hardly even notice it from all the mind-blowing action and gorgeous scenery on screen. The story itself is also well-done, but I will save all the details for your own visit to the theatre, which I definitely recommend (and find the one with the biggest screen and best sound system possible!). It does contain a lot of violence and "gore", but if you can handle it you will appreciate everything else the movie has to offer.

Not only does Gladiator instill an awe-inspiring sense of wonder and appreciation for history by capturing all the splendour, grandeur, and political complexity of Ancient Rome near the end of its empirical might, but it also has embedded within its story that eternal theme of peace and serenity for which every soul searches.

title: The «Peplum» Is Back...
review: I always love the old movies about the roman empire. The peplum was always one of my favourite movie genre. This movie, gives us again the tremendous fun and the enjoyment of movies like «BEN HUR», «QUO VADIS». Of course the special effects are the main difference, but the suspence, and the action are fantastic. The story, the actors, the spectacular fighting scenes, the special effects...(in two words) all the production are tremendous glorious and they give us again the glory of the peplum genre. Congratulations. This movie is one of the most spectacular movies i ever seen. It is a great movie.

title: One of the year's best; a startling experience. **** out of ****
review:
GLADIATOR / (2000) ****

Ridley Scott is an master at manufacturing highly visual motion pictures with energetic, luminous stories. "Blade Runner" and "Alien" dazzled us with high tech action and suspense. Now the roman epic "Gladiator" vividly captures the time period and atmosphere in which its characters inhabit. This is an excellent looking production, one of the year's best. The movie is a visual tour-de-France; beautiful scenery, awe-inducing sets, convincing cinematography, and believable costume designs bring the ancient Roman Empire to life on screen.

The story, set in 180 A.D., details the bitter life of the highly proclaimed General Maximus (Russell Crowe). We first meet him as he reigns a bloody victory after combating a slew of savage barbarians. Dying roman emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), greatly respects his favored warrior, and even chooses he, over his conniving son Commodus, (Joaquin Phoenix), to rule the dynasty after his passing. The emperor wishes for Maximus to restore the republican government to Rome.

When Commodus perceives his father's intents, he is furious. Before Aurelius is able to explain his final demands to anyone, his own son murders him as well as Maximus' precious family, and orders his father's favorite to death. Maximus is underestimated, however, and escapes his condemnation, only to be captured soon afterward and sold into a slave camp led by the greedy Proximo (Oliver Reed). There, he and several other hopefuls, including Gracchus (Derek Jacobi) and Juba (Djimon Hounsou), are trained as gladiators, brutal and dehumanized warriors who fight one another to the death to amuse a live audience.

"Gladiator" contains a descriptive and clear first act. The set up and introduction defines the situations, characters, and motives respectfully. The character development is unordinary although extraordinarily effective; Maximus and Commodus are explained as the story progresses. The audience discovers more about them as the movie intertwines with perplexity. This method of character expansion devises depth and involvement within Maximus, Proximo, and Commodus and his good-hearted relative, Lucilla (Connie Nielsen). Russell Crowe ("LA Confidential") undoubtedly will be further recognized as a sensational actor after his appearance as the gladiator. This determined actor conquers his role with complexity and optimal intensity. His performance is more solid than his in the Oscar nominated "The Insider." Joaquin Phoenix ("Clay Pigeons," "8MM") is diabolical and mischievously believable. Connie Nielsen ("Soldier") also shimmers in her timid but decisive performance.

The confrontation scenes between Commodus and Maximus are hypnotic. The movie grants profound power when the two arch enemies discover each other's identity for the first time. "Gladiator" portrays its riveting characters with style and penetration; I really cared about the compelling figures in this movie.

I did find a few trifling external problems within this otherwise flawless production. The film's combat sequences are high impact, intensely believable and some of the most involving moments in movies this year. However, the camera work often deprives us from indulging in the shear graphic qualities of warfare. Sometimes the scenes are too sketchy and brief, unlike the fighting in "Braveheart" and "Saving Private Ryan."

In a time of the year when high-brow movies are rare, "Gladiator" offers clever writing, smart dialogue, involving characters, and perfect timing. This film is a feast for the senses, an overwhelming jolt of energy, a touching journey into the past. "Gladiator" is not merely a movie, but it is an experience.

title: A visual Adventure
