Gladiator is a very well done film that also contains some of the most seamless computer graphics I've ever seen (most of Rome and the Collisuem are computer generated.)

Russell Crowe gives a wonderful performance as Maximus. I think we may have a new, and better action hero on our hands here.

title: Well done movie, for action fans.
review: The movie is straight forward without the usual fanfare. Action fans will enjoy the fight scenes. Interesting items relating to the movie were that after 100 movies and 1000 books on the Caesars and Rome depicting the Pretorian Guard with their cloaks and helmet plumes colored red, this movie dresses them in black.It also appears that the choreographer of the battle scene, at the start of the movie, is the same person who did the battle scenes for Braveheart or at least copied the approach. The other note of comparison is that Commodus did not have the strength of power to have Maximus killed for his defiance in the arena whereas Caligula would have certainly ignored the people's demand for life. The movie does depict the power struggle within the Senate and the harsh brutality of the Roman Arena. As an action movie fan, I found the movie very enjoyable.

title: A film about death... *SPOILERS*
review:
*WARNING* SOME SPOILERS FOLLOW*

Some of the reviews I've read here just miss the point altogether.

A short while ago I watched this film for the first time, and came away feeling reasonably entertained. I was not entirely inspired, short of a minor hankering to skim through my old history books, but I didn't think too much about the film following that. Just the other day I was asked to come along and watch it again, with a friend who is very much interested in Roman history. He agreed to pay half my ticket, so I figured what the hey...

It was upon my second viewing that it became clear to me this film was a lot more than just about the story we see on the surface. The story is not about revenge, the story is not about Rome, the story is not about Commodus or Aurelius, or the Roman empire. Rather the story is about death. From the opening swells of the score, we see the idealised final moments of Maximus' life, as he brushes his hands over the wheat field, walking to join his wife and son in death. Then the story begins, showing Maximus at one of his most private moments, dreaming of this ideal moment. Ultimately, the film is to be closed by the same sequence, which then closes the circle, immersing Maximus in his own private heaven. The constant usage of the supernatural imagery in the film ensure the theme is reinforced regularly throughout the remainder of Maximus' life. Upon discovering the death of his family, he loses his will to live, but his responsibilities in life constantly thwart his will to die. Maximus has things to do (in this case to avenge his ruler and family) before he dies.

I'll go out on a limb here, but : I believe many modern western audiences would find Maximus a hero. But few in the audience can quite understand why they do so, after all, he is a walking meat grinder who kills mercilessly, right? I venture they do so because he is the personification of every single member in the audience's wish : an ultimate desire to ensure they can make amends/tie up loose ends before passing into the afterlife, whatever they might (or might not) conceive it to be. Maximus does this, and quite literally drops dead the moment he fulfills his responsibilities to his self and his dead master in life.

Put in this context, Ridley Scott's directorial decisions made perfect sense to me. The use of Lisa Gerrard's haunting, almost spiritual vocals in the soundtrack were spot on. Also worth noting was a device specific to this film : Used as reminder of Maximus' desire to join his loved ones in the afterlife, the shot/sequence of him sliding along the ground with eyes closed was interrupted when his business in life was incomplete, but unimpeded when he was at peace. Then there were the little things - when Maximus was to be put to the death by sword, he pleads for a soldier's death, a "clean" death. The discussions about death with his Numidian slave friend, and finally the last conversation he has with Commodus before they fight to the death, where he quotes Aurelius' about smiling back at death.

Technically? The story we see on the surface employed a tremendous amount of creative license. To the people faulting the film for this creative license, I say go watch the discovery channel if you want a documentary. This film rather was using devices applied on a day to day basis by sci-fi writers, without the cries of historical inaccuracy either. It's quite obvious to even the most naive of viewers (?) that Ridley Scott was telling a fictional tale set against the backdrop of historical truth, rather like "Titanic" did to seemingly far fewer complaints. This is a pretty common device in storytelling, and to people who have problems with that, I can only say learn to tell the difference between a story and a true story.

The script for this film was sufficiently well performed not to draw too much complaint, and the special effects if a bit comic book were used sparingly and only to create a sense of place quite effectively. I have heard people commenting about being disappointed or unimpressed by the fight sequences. I personally cringed, but to those who found them tame, I point them with a grin to Maximus' remarks after killing several people in the arena "What is the matter, are you not entertained? Is this not what you paid to see?". Indeed the film was also making rather pointed references to us, the viewers in that respect.

A warm, if a tad brutal treatment of notions of "the perfect/clean death". 6/10.

title: Gladiator is a "true" blockbuster!
review: Get ready for a visually stunning movie that will touch your soul, make you cheer, and make you cringe all in one shot.  When the royal highness isn't getting his hand kissed by the people, and when the camera doesn't pan above the Roman Coliseum, and when you aren't truly feeling involved in this simple but wonderful story of a brave general turned slave turned Gladiator, you are cringing every time a sword cuts into a man's flesh.  Even the violence was visually stunning.  This movie (and I won't give away too much), has a battle scene comparable to that of Saving Private Ryan's opening battle.  Although not as long and drawn out, it brilliantly sets the tone for a movie 2 hours and 34 minutes in length which seems like and hour and a half when it's all done.  Kudos on the casting job.  Crowe delivers with a bang and he is proving once again that he belongs here.  Give him a part and he will play it, much like the rest of the LA Confidential alumni. Gladiator is a film of potential epic proportion.  But it won't become an epic unless people make it that way.  It's a wonderful cinematic experience not to be missed by anyone who would appreciate a movie of this caliber.

title: A great film but not quite an epic
review: Think of the Roman Empire and classic films like Sparatacus and Ben Hur spring to mind. Russell Crowe gives a compelling performance, and indeed one that could match Heston or Douglas. They however had the great benefit of a quality script. The special effects are awesome, the fight scenes breathtaking , and the opening battle gives Spielberg a run for his money.If only some of the cash could have been diverted to the script then a true epic ,to be remembered for years, would have been created. All in all, a fantastic film which hits the crossbar of true greatness. I give it a nine

title: Good film worth seeing
review: Gladiator seems to me the first good film of the year 2000. Many of the people I know have compared it to be better than Braveheart. I do not agree although I feel that Gladiator is up in that league of films. It has a great story although not historically accurate. People get into the characters and there is some very good acting here. The only complaint I have of this film is that of the camera views at certain times. They can be extremely close and quick which makes it hard to see what has happened. This is true in many of the action scenes. Still I was amazed by the action and the beauty of the many scenes. This film is very good. Go see it in theater if you can.

title: It's been a long time coming, but finally another gladiator flick hits the big screen!
review: Director Ridley Scott brings this blockbuster epic tale of ancient Rome to a modern audience.  Russell Crowe plays the general to Marcus Aurelius Caesar, Richard Harris is the emperor, who defeats the Germanian army.  In the aftermath, Caesar dies of "mysterious" causes and his son, Joaquin Phoenix, takes the crown.  He orders Crowe to be executed, but Crowe escapes, only to be trained by Oliver Reed as an arena gladiator.  Crowe becomes a favorite of the bloodthirsty crowds by the time that Phoenix learns of his escape. Soon, Phoenix and Crowe will have to come across one another's path. The film has great flavor for the period and solid acting and good computer enhanced effects, but the battle scenes are too often done in a stylized, close-up manner, which makes it difficult to discern exactly what is happening.  Sadly, Reed died during the filming and, thus, this is his final film.

title: Ridley Scot's latest triumph
review: Ridley Scot has done it again. Known for his love of stylish scenery and thought evoking camera effects this film seduces the viewer from the very outset, while the fierce battles are savage It is done in such a way that does not totally shock the viewer or make the whole event seem unpleasant. In fact the story, although a very simple one unfolds at a pace which allows the viewer to empathise with the wronged centurion and has everyone transfixed as revenge draws near (Or Does It?) I believe this is one of Ridley Scots Best Movies. Ben Hur and Spartacus on Steroids!

title: Russel Crowe - Someone you would want on your side in a fight
review: This is the kind of movie that they used to make, with a simple plot and some fantastic performances. What is there to be said of Russel Crowe - well he gives a performance which truly befits  that of a true Gladiator, The viewer of this film could easily see him as 'Rome's Greatest General' and at the same time believe that he is all that he as a gladiator and more. Thoroughly enjoyable, a must-see movie. Expect Oscars maybe not for the acting but definitely for the shear grandeur of it.

title: AWESOME MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!
review:
Gladiator is a truly awesome movie. This is better than Braveheart (and Braveheart was a "10"). Crowe is absolutely convincing as Maximus, and the supporting cast are uniformly excellent. The opening battle scene is worth ten times the price of admission.

GO SEE THIS MOVIE NOW! You will not be disappointed - Gladiator is THE movie to see in 2000. A truly wonderful epic, and accomplishes all its goals, and then some.

title: badass
review: this movie rips some serious laro.  russell crowe is my new hero.  it used to be edward norton (although he is going out with salma hayek).  the chariot scene is epic. basically, all i gotta say is: double sword decapitation. i've seen it twice, and will definitely see it again.

title: Best recommended, less described. Just see it!
review:
I only saw this because I was dragged along. Which wasn't a good start. But I have never been so glad of a good dragging. Not even the ice cream (which was pretty good) could top this film 'experience'.

I was breathless, I was stunned, I couldn't speak, I flinched, I screamed, I bit my thumb off and then I balled my eyes out.

The opening battle scene is so good you think you're watching the end of the film. The storyline was classic, Russell Crowe was fit for the part(in every way!)and 3 hours whizzed by as I watched the most fantastic production I have seen in years.

Its difficult to compare, as its pretty much in its own category amongst modern films. It's not a gore movie, the action is too quick (I didn't see any guts hanging out either). It's not Ben Hur. Its more realistic. It's just one of those films best recommended, less described. Just see it.

Oh and . . . the vast expanse of the scenery and the sheer number of extras (computer generated or not!) mean that this HAS to be seen at the cinema. To put this on a video would be a crime!

title: Ridley Scott finally delivers the goods again
review:
I saw "Gladiator" three weeks ago, but only now I've got the opportunity to write a comment: the opening battle sequence alone is absolutely impressive and perfectly sets the tone for Maximus' story. Russell Crowe was good but with his powerful Jeffrey Wigand (from Michael Manns modern classic "The Insider") still in mind, he didn't impress me as much this time around. Yet, I can't think of another actors to be more suitable for such roles as Russell Crowe and it's clearly to his credit that "Gladiator" is such a fine movie. Joaquoin Phoenix is much less convincing, I actually found him pathetic. But that is as well one of the few minor weak points in an otherwise decent script: they should have come up with a tougher, more dangerous emperor - Commodus never convinced me as a serious nemesis for Maximus. Richard Harris, Connie Nielsen, Oliver Reed (if much of his appearance in the movie had to be computergenerated due to his death during the shoot, then I must say, the result is baffling - it's never obvious, though you might guess where they used CGI) and particularly Derek Jacobi as the senator who strives to dethrone Commodus were so good in their roles that they easily compensated for the shortcomings in the characterization. Visually, "Gladiator" is ravishing to look at and the battle sequences are some of the best I've ever seen (dull remake of Braveheart? Bah! Braveheart is self-indulgent and plain idiotic - eat your heart out, Mel Gibson).

Admittedly, there were some images in the movie similar to those in Leni Riefenstahls NS propaganda movie "Triumph of the Will" but so what? There is no fascist ideology (neither obvious nor hidden) in Ridley Scotts film to worry about. If Scott borrowed images from Riefenstahls propaganda piece then in the intention to establish the sense of epic proportions, to show the power and glory of the Roman Empire, nothing else. "Gladiator" has been compared to "Ben Hur" and "Spartacus" - time will tell if it once will be hailed as a classic. I personally like it more than "Spartacus" (from which maestro Kubrick distanced himself), but it comes nowhere close to Wylers "Ben Hur". But it must be said that it is Ridley Scotts best movie for a long time (though, by no means as good as Alien and Blade Runner), exciting and breathtaking. Bring up "Hannibal"(8,5 out of 10)

title: Not that great
review: The beginning of this movie was just great.  It went downhill from there. It was like they were trying to jam "I Claudius" and "Conan The Barbarian" into two and a half hours.  Save your money and go get a pizza instead of seeing this movie.

title: Summer Blockbuster
review:
I must say that I thought this film was excellent. It had a good story line, good cast (Russel Crowe was superb!!), and excellent special effects, although part of the opening battle scene was filmed in a way which was hard to follow. I saw the film at a media screening and this version contained quite a few scenes of people being decapitated and was also two and a half hours long so it might be edited further, (not too much I hope).

The fight scene where tigers are involved was superb and Ridley Scott was at his best. A must see which is up there with Spartacus and Ben Hur.

title: Thank God for Gladiator
review: I was beginning to think that no one would ever make another Roman epic, which would have been a shame because no other genre can match it.But this is something else.It isn't Spartacus, nor (thank god) is it Braveheart, unlike Braveheart there does remain at least some historical accuracy.Ridley Scott delivers a modern masterpiece in that it is a historical piece without a modern feel.Those first battle scenes really had my blood pumping, and it didn't feel like gratuitous violence, it challenged Saving Private Ryan for the best battle scenes I have ever seen.Thankfully with all the main characters having died at the end there will not be a crappy sequel or franchise made out of it, it stands alone, which is only right.The performances are actually faultless, I mean really faultless.Russell Crowe is totally believable and kicks ass with a vengeance (dare I say, he makes Charlton Heston look like a real pussy.)When he kicks the crap out of Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix, who wisely decides not to do what Christopher Plummer did under similar circumstances and go over the top but emanates twisted villainy so that we really hate his guts)I really felt like cheering.I am so glad he didnt spend half the film moping about his wife and kids, he just gets on with what he does best, kicking ass.In support, Richard Harris looks like death warmed up as the ailing emperor Marcus Aurelius (I hope that was just make up for his sake)but exudes quiet tired dignity as a man who has had enough but cannot die lest Commodus get his slimy hands on the imperial throne.Derek Jacobi is also great as a wily old senator who knows every trick in the book(his first Roman role since he made his name in I Claudius more than 20 years ago)and there is a grotesque cameo from the obese David Hemmings as the master of ceremonies (to think he was once a sex symbol)These three, together with the late Oliver Reed were called by Scott "the four Horsemen of the apocalypse" and it is ironic that it is Reed who died during filming, who looks the best, and he really throws himself at his role as a beefy, experienced Gladiator trainer and is memorably larger than life (ironic as there is at least one of his scenes which is a CGI image of him)Even dead, Reed can act his fellow thesps off the screen.Ten out of ten.

title: Quality epic
review: What a film. The epic is back with a bang. This is a must see film. On the whole the pace is fast, and holds your attention. There are a few areas that are slow, but these are soon forgotten. The acting is excellent, and the sets are wonderful.I will always remember Oliver Reed in this film, a true master.

title: Two thumbs way up but only for second...I wouldn't want to lose them.
review:
I was reassured within the first five minutes of this film that Ridley Scott was present and accounted for. The opening battle scene was almost psychotronic in it's atmospherics...like a Roman version of Alien. Wow! I love this director. Russell Crowe has definitely arrived too. He takes charge immediately as a believable Maximus, a great general with character, courage and the loving loyalty of his men...men of one of history's greatest armies. ("When I give the signal, let loose hell.") This guy's an alpha-male with a capital alpha! The movie follows his destiny as he navigates the twists and turns of Roman politics, greed and power. He is betrayed by a vile dweeb, a dying Marcus Aurelius Ceasar's son, who orders Maximus and Max's wife and son killed. This succeeds for the family but Max escapes and is spun off on a Jean Valjean-like journey of redemption and obscured identity. Except instead of becoming a mayor, he becomes...you guessed it...a Gladiator. Apparently, he is a gifted scrapper and builds quite a reputation. He comes to Rome and settles up the score. Riveting. Engaging. Awesome. The acting is superb. The script is intelligent and marvelously credible considering the difficulty scriptwriters have with historical movies, at least as far as I'm concerned. And it is terrific history! Very accurate. This presupposes that I know some Roman history...well, of course, I do. It had some tragedy which my companion (my wife) always finds intollerable and of course I gave her my standard speech about how film is not always supposed to make you feel warm and fuzzy but rather challenged and sometimes jolted. And as usual, it was hopeless. No way any movie gets an Oscar vote from my wife when kids get killed. However, she made me proud by brightly acknowledging that the violence was not gratuitous, in fact she said "it was necessary to the advancing story arc and was done tastefully." At this point, I felt some pride from how well she had learned her Film 101 lessons. In summary, I was glued to the screen for 150 or so minutes and I believe that I saw the best Ridley Scott has ever done...certainly a must see. This may not be a "chick-friendly-flick" although you never know.

Lary9

title: Great epic!!!
review:
I thought the film experience was awesome. There were times of cheering, crying, laughing, and every emotion in between. The fight scenes were intense, and the story line believable.

On a technical note, the costumes, period sets, and computer aided graphics only added to the realism.

The movie was 2 1/2 hours long but I wanted it to go on even longer.

Superb.

title: MAXIMUS! MAXIMUS!
review:
Epic? Yes. Entertaining? Absolutely. Perfect? Nope, but nitpicking is for ex-girlfriends and IRS agents.

This is the first entry into the 2000 summer block-buster slate for Hollywood. And as such, GLADIATOR delivers on many levels as a satisfying cinematic experience. Russell Crowe is a big-time star. He is the film's center, no doubt. His enthusiam as the film's hero, Maximus, creates a powerful character for the audience to embrace. He is honorable, strong and practically fearless in battle. Alongside his strangth comes a particlarly touching human side, a vulnerability that will make women swoon and men wonder lies within their own hearts as well.

GLADIATOR, like its star, is brutal, menacing, thoughtful and complex. Go see it and cheer.

title: Haven't we seen it already Or a bad case of deja-vu
review:
I have to join the people who are disappointed by this movie. Yes, it's entertaining. Yes, it has some beautifully designed scenes. Yes, my wife was in tears at the end (which is seldom) - so it obviously touches some strings of one's soul. That's good enough. But... the Gladiator is full of cliches (pardon my French). Watching the movie I was constantly comparing it to other films. During the opening battle scene my wife whispered to me - "Well, it's Private Ryan set in ancient Rome". Yes, it is. Same jerky camera movements, same gore. The plot is almost scene to scene copy of Braveheart with overall atmosphere of Spartacus. We see the hero going through the field and touching grass tops - hell, I've seen this in dozens of Soviet movies about collective farms. Gladiators' cubicles are just like a modern prison - do you remember the episode when Maximus and his fellows come to the Colliseum for the first time dressed in blue (denim?!) outfits? Haven't you seen this in many movies like "Lock Up" or "Tango and Cash"? It's indeed a terrible mix of many previously seen movies.

But what disappoints most is the final - as pathetic as the ones from the Soviet Stalin era pictures. Though it is a common feature of most Hollywood products. Being an European I can not understand the love of American directors to endings that leave nothing to one's imagination. The Evil is punished, the Good wins. Well, maybe I'm asking for too much from dream factory (grin). But the problem stays. These endings spoil even the best movies like "Saving Private Ryan". Watching it I was praying "Good Lord, do not let this old Ryan salute Miller's grave". God did not listen to my prayer (another grin). Well, maybe its a punishment for my sins. Nevertheless the "Gladiator" is worth watching - for its sometimes really stunning visual effects, for very good performances of Russel Crowe and Oliver Reed. I've been really missing a good historic (even if pseudo-historic) movie about ancient Rome or Greece. Maybe I was expecting too much.

-six out of ten-

title: Any time you hear the word 'classic' applied after one week, be wary...
review:
"Gladiator" is a good movie, and well worth the price of admission. If you believe the hype surrounding the film, though, you will be disappointed -- this is not a 'classic' now, nor will it ever be. Walk into the theater expecting a fun time, however, and you will be rewarded with one (but as another reviewer stated, please leave the kids at home. This is a film that richly deserves its "R" rating... I will leave it at that).

"Gladiator" tells the story of Maximus, beloved and skillful general of the Roman army and Marcus Aurelius' choice (rather than his own immoral son Commodus) to rule the Roman Empire after his death. The film starts out with a great winter battle scene (although filmed in an annoying and difficult-to-watch hand-held camera style, very similar to the first half hour of "Saving Private Ryan"), moves quickly to the premature death of the Caesar and the order given by Commodus for Maximus' (and his family's) death, Maximus' escape from execution, and his being forced into slavery and the illegal bloodsport of the gladiator. As a battle-tested general, Maximus makes a natural gladiator, and when Commodus reinstates the gladiator games in Rome (to bolster his popularity in an attempt to overthrow and eliminate the pesky Senate), Maximus is given his opportunity to enter Rome and gain his revenge.

Interestingly, at a point where the story should be picking up some serious steam for the home stretch, it runs out of gas, and the film pretty much coasts the rest of the way in. We are given some great action scenes, good performances (notably Phoenix as the slimy Commodus, Reed (in his final role) as gladiator owner Proximus, and of course Crowe, as Maximus), and great effects, but the momentum created during the first hour is not maintained for the rest of the long film.

Give "Gladiator" a try, most will be glad they did. It is a fun movie and a good start to the summer movie rush. Just don't expect an epic classic... expect eye candy that satisfies. These days, can we expect more than that?

title: The year's first blockbuster!
review: This movie was simply awesome! I haven't seen such an enjoyable movie since The Matrix. Russell Crowe was terrific as Maximus, the general turned gladiator. Joaquin Phoenix was excellent as Commodus- that was one character that had absolutely no good side...what a slime! Be warned, though. This is not, I repeat, NOT a movie to bring kids younger than about fifteen to. Why? The absolutely brutal gore! And what an opening scene! While it cannot hold a candle to the opening of Saving Private Ryan, it was nonetheless a terrific start to a great movie! I highly recommend this one...see it at least twice!

title: Do your self a favor see this in the Cinema
review:
I went to the theater to see this movie, not expecting anything but an action flick set in the times of ancient Rome. To my surprise I got much more. This is NOT a movie about a history lesson, this isn't a movie that is trying to make some colossal point. It is a movie that is trying to entertain you. It does that and more.

The feel of the movie is that of Braveheart, but this is much better. The battle scene (just one) is very well done and (for those who want a history lesson) very accurate of battles during that era. The gladiator scenes are excellent. The acting is both moving and believable. I do not show my emotions freely, as a matter of fact I can count on one hand the number of movies that I have been `moved to tears', but this movie was able to do that.

If you want to see a movie that everyone will enjoy (maybe not children under 17), then choose this one. I will add this to my DVD collection and it will get a place of honor among the top 10. Do your self a favor and see this in the Cinema, it is worth the $8.

title: This movie by far is worth the money
review: This movie by far is worth the money I thought I'd like this but not this much I mean Russel Crowe wow what an actor.  He is one of the best actors of the new age he knows how to pick movies.  This is the best movie of the year by far for it's great camera work visual effects and acting I can't praise enough how good Russell Crowe is in this movie go see you'll like it.

title: This is a "must see" for everyone except young children
review:
I wasn't expecting more out of Gladiator than a few good fight scenes. Boy was I pleasantly surprised. This movie was fantastic! In fact, quit reading this review and just go see it, right now.

Well, if you need a little convincingÂ…

Gladiator is the story of the Roman General, Maximus (Russell Crowe), who was charged by dieing emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) with returning the government of Rome to the people. However, before the emperor can announce his wishes publicly, he is betrayed by his son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix). General Maximus becomes hunted and eventually thrown into slavery where he finds himself fighting for survival in the Roman stadiums of Africa.

I can think of nothing to criticize about this film, so I'll borrow a criticism from a friend who thought the movie was too long and was monotonous in some parts (I disagreed).

The battles were quite graphic at times, but trust me, you will enjoy this movie.

title: Return of the Roman Empire
review: Gladiator is a great action movie. It has been a long time since a quality movie about this era has hit the theaters. The details might be altered, but how many people today have even a vague idea of what life in the Roman Empire was like? Enjoy a great movie, and for those who need historical ficton with accuracy read Colleen McCullogh's First Man in Rome series.

title: Greatest Sorta True Story Ever Told; Most GLORIOUS!
review:
Gladiator, is the greatest story ever told. The greatest and most glorious film ever created without a doubt. If you have no appreciation for history, your ancestors, or the course of mankind, your family or yourself, you might not like this film.

Gladiator should serve notice to mankind, of what in fact, mankind is not. No honor, no glory, no wisdom as well as many other faults. Today, commercials, radio, cash and campaign managers determine our leaders. Not for accomplishments or ability but for status and figure head. Gladiator, depicts Rome, and a few leaders in a time of great corruption and mis-guidance of central authority.

Gladiator illustrates the price of Roman restoration, and what it will cost the United States, to restore our leadership in all branchs of government, except possibly the Judicial Branch. Our leaders are immoral, corrupt, and ride on the backs of others. No mater the party affiliation, sex and money(Democrats), or Iran-Contra/Coke/or the ruininous state of Texas(Republicans), all are corrupt, and frankly only SANDBAG the government our people need. Anyone see stats/statistic on Texas, it is the most toxic state in the country! Thank you Gov. Bush. Florida beachs don't smell to good this year either, more like sewage.

Gladiator inspires the mind, even after viewing 4 times, it is still compelling both emotional and morally. If only our leaders would have even 1% of Maximus's morality, loyalty and compassion, we would be a better world, 100 times over....

title: "Mad Maximus"..."The Crowe'd Warrior"
review:
Ahh..."Gladiator"...a movie starring an Australian actor as a battle-scarred loner whose wife and son have been murdered by vicious thugs. This is a guy who's lost everything...even his tattered old dog. He's been reduced to wandering the lands in a daily fight for survival...in search of nothing...living for nothing. Wait a minute...I really liked this story the first time I saw it...in two movies called "Mad Max" and "The Road Warrior". Call this one "Mad Maximus" or "The Crowe'd Warrior".

Kidding aside...this flick is awesome...

title: very much mistakes are there in the "Gladiator"
review: hello, I'm an italian student, I've seen this film and I think it's very great, but it has also very much mistakes... So I think that mistakes make the film not very good... In fact, some of the words in Latin are wrong and invented (!!!!!) by the authors. I think so not because I'm italian and from Rome, but because I think that traditions of a nation are very important and must be respected by other nations...

title: As historically inaccurate as Braveheart
review:
Although it's a fine film, they took huge liberties with "history", in the name of a great story. In reality, although Commodus was indeed Marcus Aurealis' son, and though his father had doubts about his ability to rule, he was only truly insane after his sister & a friend plotted against him, and he found out (and hung them from a tree).

Commodus was supposed to appear at a huge event, dressed as a gladiator, to shock conservatives & senators. This was the last in a long line of jokes that his peers considered in bad taste - so bad they poisoned him (and then strangled him, when the poison didn't work).

Marcus Aurelius died of the plague, while visiting a city, to decide how to improve sanitation in the city - he was considered a true "Philosopher King".

title: There's one thing that elevates this film from standard, schlocky fare and that's Russell Crowe.
review: GLADIATOR is not a new story or an overly deep one, but it does entertain. There's a lot more range and depth to Russell Crowe than most Americans have seen up to this point. I, for one, look forward to watching him again and again. Besides the fantastic art direction the only thing keeping your eyes on the screen is Crowe. He gives a subtle, powerful, honest portrayal in a film that wouldn't have been half as good without him. It's not an easy role to pull off and could have fallen into the realm of the ridiculous. No one has tried to make a roman costume epic since the late 60s and the debacle of CLEOPATRA. However, the actors and the filmmakers take their subject matter and characters very seriously, grounding the action in a time and a place one can only imagine. Actually, thanks to Mr. Scott and some amazing computer facts, we don't have to. Rome is alive and well, rearing it's ugly head at the cineplex.

title: Amazing!
review: I am aware that if a movie makes more than $16.50 at the box office that everyone's supposed to call it corporate Hollywood crap and find fault in it, but I was VERY impressed with this film.  Of course I was amazed with the effects, but I also thought it was extremely well written and acted. Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix portrayed their characters extremely well, with Crowe playing the hero to perfection and Phoenix being the perfect brat with moral issues.  There was a great deal of violence, but I found it to be used well in the story.  Go see it!

title: This is the Best Movie I have ever seen.
review: In 30 years, I have never seen a movie as good as this. I have been browsing this site for years, and have never voted or commented on a movie. Gladiator moved me so, that it prompted me to register, vote, and comment on it. General Maximus is a character with the greatest charisma I have ever seen in a film. Go see it. Don't wait for the video!

title: "He will give them death and they will love him for it."
review:
I did not know movies like this were made anymore -- or even could be made.

The production values go beyond lavish -- this is truly a Hollywood Spectacular.

Somebody really did their homework -- every detail was brilliantly executed. However the Romans of that period in history did not have tempered steel (which made its debut in the 14th Century) but is sure looked better on screen than the iron or bronze weapons the real gladiators would have carried.

There is true genius in this film: costuming, photography, art direction and most of all the acting and direction.

Ridley Scott outdid himself. The sheer size, scope and grandeur are breathtaking.

Russell Crowe heads an incredible international cast that had to truly believe in this film to achieve the greatness that the audience sees on the screen.

Whoever did the matte paintings (no credit given) be they on the traditional glass or CGI deserves a special mention. They transport the viewer to a place that is so unreal it becomes real.

In the credits there is a brief homage to Oliver Reed -- who died the day after the film was released in the United States... I do not know how they worked that credit into the release that I saw but I do appreciate it.

This is an instant classic and will go down in filmatic history as 'A Movie For All Time.'

title: I hate Ridley Scott, ....but I mean that in a nice way.
review:
Warning, Spoilers ahead.









Gladiator might not be the greatest film ever, it might not even be the best this year but it is most certainly the best Hollywood hype film for years. While I was watching this I though of the other Ridley Scott film I had seen, Blade Runner, and the two share similarities. An incredible set design and background, the cities in this film look real, an unbeatable character who is beaten and an evil which must be destroyed. It is also clinical like Blade Runner, yet it had me in tears at the end. The similarities end here and I think Gladiator is a much better film because the supporting cast and the lead actors are allowed to flesh their roles out more. There are also many different moods going on here.

Gladiator is in many ways a tragedy, in the manner of Greek tragedy, where there is double crossing and death at every turn, only it is blasted on to the big screen and comes alive. The end reminds me of Hamlet a bit as well. Russell Crowe yet again shows he is a really good actor, and Oliver Reed had his best part in years, indeed as Proximo he has one of the best speeches in the film about what it is like to fight at the Coliseum, but this film is made in many ways by Ridley Scott and the little details he puts in in the huge crowd scenes, especially the ones at the Amphitheatres. Truly breathtaking in scope yet as very small, all Maximus wants to do is go home, if there has been a better huge budget film since Blade Runner, I don't think I've seen it.

title: Good, but could have been Magnificent
review:
NOTE: Before you read my rating you must be informed that as I was watching this film at the CAROLUS theatre in Nijmegen (Netherlands) at 13.30 on Saturday the 20th of may 2000 there was a constant disturbance by two people in the back, who talked all the time. Except during the break, then they kept quiet, of course. I must also say that I despise thy, thou

companions and thou friends, who spoil other peoples movie experiences, simply because thy don not appreciate the movie or because thy behave in the same way at home, where you watch movies on TV. If it is the first than, please go away and if it concerns the latter, than please, wait 6 or 8 months and rent it, for then thy can speak to thy companion and do anything you like and not spoil it for others as well!!!!!!!!!

This might have affected my final rate for the film!!!

Now for my review, of course Gladiator was good. It had a lot of action, which was brilliantly coreographed and filmed by the way, quite a lot of blood (though the film was not very gore) a great soundtrack, good actors, especially Russell Crowe (as the revenge driven Gladiator), River Phoenix (as the psychopathic ceasar) and Connie Nielsen (as the suppressed and terrorised Lucilla). But I also liked Djimon Hounsou and Ralph Möller a lot. The plot actually was good too there were just 2 bothers if you ask me, first of all there are far too many boring politics involved for this action  revenge pic, plus there are a few visions, Crowe had in this film that I found very unfitting, especially that in the end. Oh yes I almost forgot, I didn't like the ending very much. The basics were good but the was it was carried out was way too melodramatic. Standing there and stumbling for many seconds falling, then of course the FINAL words of the hero!! But there were more good than bad things here besides a lot of blood, sadness, sorrow, depression, madness, it all really made you feel for these people. I even had tears in my eyes at one point or two, just as I had with another epic film I saw, which is another classic in my eyes and funny enough has somehow a similar plot (as for the basic revenge story), Braveheart. These are the two best epic classics of the past 10 years and surely two films that may not be missed.

As you may have noticed I found the ending rather bad, regarding the rest of the film, this is also the reason, why I say, Gladiator was good, when it could have been HUGE, GIGANTIC, EXCELLENT, it could have been TITANIC!!!

But it still is a classic, so stop reading and go see it!

8 out of 10

title: Brilliantly graphic and stunningly beautiful
review:
Ridley Scott's masterful "Gladiator" concerns a, you guessed it, gladiator who's family has been gruesomely butchered and has been thrown out of his position as general by the emperor Commodus. Soon, Maximus fights his way into the harsh world of the gladiator, and begins to defy an empire. Commodus soon realizes that he is becoming the underdog and is literally losing his fame. Soon, he develops a plan. The musical score is extremely beautiful and yet heroic and powerful. I have a gut feeling that will be nominated for Best Original Score.

The director, Ridley Scott, who's previous films include the frightening "Alien" and the action-packed "Bladerunner", does a wonderful job as director in this flick. He knows when to use a tool and when not to, and sometimes he needs to know how explicit a tool can be, and he succeeds in this. The acting is superb. Russell Crowe is an instant Oscar nomination, and the guy (I forget his name) who plays the African gladiator is superb, and he might snag a nomination for Best Supporting Actor. The sister of Commodus puts on an O.K. performance, and while Commodus is a weak and pathetic character and the actor does that well, he is pretty fake. Now, since my review is coming to an end, here is what this will receive: Nomination for: Best Actor Best Sound Best Supporting Actor (Maybe) Best Picture (A chance it will be) All in all, this is a 10 out of 10 movie, even though it has small pieces that are a little off-course, it's still a 10. All hail Gladiator!

title: paint by numbers
review:
Gladiator wants to be rousing entertainment, but it's like a talented painter doing a paint-by-number kit and trying really hard not to go outside the lines. It was such a faithful retelling of standard, cliche gladiator movies that I could mouth most lines before they were uttered. It's probably the most faithful remake in history except for Psycho.

Which is not to say it doesn't manage some entertainment value. Russell Crowe is well cast, Joaquin Phoenix surprised me with his range (by showing he had some), and Connie Nelson gave a subtle performance when I would have expected something more heavy-handed. But the action sequences are choppily edited and filmed through a haze, making it hard to tell whose blood it is spraying across the screen (I could only assume it wasn't Crowe's character's).

I give it a six; anyone giving it higher than a seven is very easily amused.

title: Entertaining...but not a great "Roman Epic."
review:
Russell Crowe - very good performance. Great fight/battle scenes/tiger shots etc and even the special effects worked well - cool shots of the Colosseum. The film however lacks the quality of other Roman epics such as "Spartacus." Apart from Russell Crowe and Richard Harris, the other members of the cast weren't too impressive.(perhaps due to poor dialogue and lack of character development).

Contrast this to Spartacus - Kirk Douglas, Jean Simmons, Laurence Olivier, Tony Curtis, Charles Laughton and of course the fantastic Peter Ustinov (best supporting actor Oscar) - what a cast! Yet again like so many other films - music was unnecessarily included in scenes where silence would have been far better. Especially that early scene in the film (*spoiler alert) where Marcus Aurelius tells his son (the irritating Commodus) that he will not become Emperor. What follows is is a way-over-the-top emotionally charged sobbing scene with highly dramatic music involving two characters we hardly know. Its as if Ridley Scott is shouting at us "You must feel emotion here!" - ridiculous - the viewer doesn't care about Commodus at this stage of the film! - it made me cringe instead. Btw: What was with all those "flashbacks"?

The choice of music was iffy at times and the "incest" overtones - how did that help the film? The character of Commodus was poor - extremely annoying at times (like a brat) and cowardly. Apart from all that it was an entertaining film - it was an epic in terms of duration but not in quality. 7/10.

title: Great movie!
review: This movie was more than I expected.  A lot of my friends were very excited for it, but I was more reserved about how i would feel watching it.  In the past, I have not enjoyed movies with beheadings, and sword violence (13th Warrior), but this movie pleasantly surprised me.   It was very intense, the camera work was different, and Russell Crowe was great.  I would recommend this to anyone who can stomach gory, brutal violence because this movie has a lot of it.

title: I was disappointed
review: I heard and read that this film is a classic, and thus I expected a really great film. But it's not the case. This film has a serious lack of character development despite it lasts 2 and a half hours. Together with the character development, we can see a poor ambient development. We just see a huge coliseum and thousands of people computer-generated. Just that. We don't see closeups, we can't see the feelings involved, and we feel no empathy at all (for a good example of a well done job, see Kubrick´s Spartacus). The camera moves in the fight scenes are acceptable for films like Saving Private Ryan, set in a time where cameras did exist, but not for a Romans' film... They just seem to be used to make us more difficult to find goofs, and that is a dirty trick in a so expensive movie. Another point is the acting. The actors are not bad, but they don't look like people from the 2nd century. OK, nobody knows how they were, but I am sure they weren't like people from the 20th century. I mean, the dialogue, the way they move, the feelings they show. You can use the same acting and the same music in a film set in the Middle Ages and we wouldn't note the change. If we forget that Ridley Scott is the director and Steven Spielberg is the man behind the production company, we just have a mediocre film. I still can't believe that The Sixth Sense got no oscars and American Beauty took them all. Mr. Spielberg, you are rich enough yet, so please let talented people do their thing and stop your 'This is the greatest film ever' propaganda in a Microsoft style! And you, people, please look with your own eyes and don't follow the stream. Dreamworks is making really good products, but not everything is gold...

title: can i get a wide-angle shot please
review:
this movie was definitely entertaining. it was engaging, it had my full attention, and it was a visual feast...well, sometimes. but what is going on here? why does everyone love it exactly? i saw the film at one of the most beautiful theatres, the Cinerama Dome on Sunset Blvd., which added to it a lot. but if i sat up front, i would have ran out of their screaming. people complain about the Blair Witch project? i didn't know what was going on half the time. this was me at about 5 points during the film: "what? he got hit? yeah he did.. but.. he who? WHERE?!"

the recreation of Rome is fantastic, and those shots are excellent, as are the effects and art direction. the fights are fun in all their gore, with the exception of the chaotic camera movements. and certain shots, for example of the fields when Maximus's hands are brushing against the tall grass. beautiful. but not enough to get the praise it's been receiving.

and character development? hello? "Lucilla, you should have been a son." oh really? "Lucilla is a strong woman this, and a forceful soul that." how so? i couldn't tell. and bratty Commodus, played by an excellent Joaquin Phoenix, just was not fully explained in his insanity. Russell Crowe is great (as always) as the vengeful Maximus, but even with his character something seemed lacking. and way to go with the subtle ending. (no, that was not sarcasm).

overall the movie entertained me, but i walked out confused (as to whether i liked it or not). and when i walk out of movies confused i wait for the next day.. and the next day i was not satisfied. some great shots and color, cool costumes, Crowe finally confirming himself as a star, Phoenix confirming himself as an actor, and Nielsen confirming herself as a hottie who can act. it'll do. but it would have been better off had it been done by someone other than ridley scott. (gosh.. he better not butcher Hannibal). it deserves no spot on the IMDb's top 250 much less the top 100.

title: For the Love of Rome! What a disappointment....
review:
Ridley Scott has made a real loser. The first third of the movie was tedious - the one battle at the beginning was so messy you couldn't tell what the hell was going on -- ok the horrors of war show that it's crazy and Ridley Scott was trying to make the viewer feel as disoriented as the film's hero -- guess what? It was done better in "Saving Private Ryan" and at least in that film you can SEE the fellow soldiers falling around the main character. One ripoff from a film. Also check out how close it comes to "Braveheart" in parts --- "Say, William Wallace is visited by the young queen while in a cell in "Braveheart" and that was cool - let's have Maximus visted by the daughter of the king and conspire against her brother just like the young French Queen conspired against King Longshanks in "Braveheart." Plus in "Braveheart" there's cool battle scenes, let's try that too. Not to mention the obvious, Russell Crowe sure as hell sounds like Mel Gibson, the only difference is he is so miserable in this film and there is no real heroic character development like with Gibson. When his family is killed at the end of the first act, the moral is that Hollywood truism, "behind every good man is a dead woman and/or child." It does pick up after that though. The best part in the film was the 2nd act after he's picked up by Oliver Reed and thrown in as a Gladiator - but even here the battle scenes are too messy and you can't tell what the hell is going on - at one point a Legionaire is cut in half by what I thought was only a wooden stick on the chariot - I had to be explained that "it must've been a blade" by my companion who came with me to the film. Now that I think about it, we were asking each other what the hell was going on a number of times, mostly due to the jerky camera shots and the loud noises over whispered dialogue. And I never talk during a film. The ending was ludicrous the "go home Maximus" and the "Lucius is safe" dialogue made me roll my eyes. There was little to no historical value to the film and Rome was pretty damn boring - plus 5 shots of the same part of the "majestic collosium" only verified that it was a CGI-generated shot. Christ, even the CGI birds were splotches on the screen...

Anyway, there are a few things that were ok - Reed and Crowe were pretty good. Phoenix was ok as the "unloved by daddy" emperor. The actress Connie Neilsen who played Lucilla was pretty good and well as Maximus' two "buddy" Gladiators. In short, a lousy script, well-acted but 2-dimensional characters, and messy camera shots made this only another film that disappointed me. A 6.5 out of 10 (D) --- Go watch any bit of "Spartacus," two scenes from "Braveheart," and the first 15 minutes of "Saving Private Ryan." You'll have the same damn movie.

title: Know why you're going to see this movie
review:
Some of the other users commenting on "Gladiator" have complained about its cliched plot and weak dialogue. They are absolutely correct in their complaints. However, everyone who has seen this film agrees that the visual effects and aesthetic value are absolutely stunning. So stunning, in fact, that they alone make the movie worth seeing.

So there you have it -- if you go to see "Gladiator" with high expectations of the plot, script, or characters, you will be disappointed, unless you are about 15 years old or younger. You will be in awe, however, of the incredible cinematography and special effects. The recreation of ancient Rome, the opening battle scenes, and the live action in the Colloseum are just a few examples of the amazing visual effects of this film.

Does a movie have to have an original, unpredictable story with realistic characters to be considered good? It's funny how the great operas in history almost always have very hokey, silly, and predictable stories with cliched characters. We still consider works like "The Marriage of Figaro," and "Carmen" to be artistic masterpieces because of their great musical appeal. Can we not look at a film like "Gladiator" in a similar fashion? Can we not excuse its "Hollyweed" story and characters because of its superb aesthetic appeal? I think we should.

title: In a word: WOW!
review: Stunning visuals and an excellent story make this a must see movie for the summer. This movie felt like a 2 1/2 hour movie, but I didn't care one bit. All in all Gladiator is a superb movie truly belonging in the class of great Roman epics.

title: The first epic of the new millennium.
review:
Well, if you haven't seen it yet, what are you playing at? Make sure that you catch this work of art in the cinemas as it will never have the same impact if you watch on video.

Gladiator has some of the most intense battle sequences I have ever seen as Ridley Scott puts masterfully puts the audience in the middle of the action. However, the movie doesn't just rely on gory battles to interest the reader. A superb script is ably supported by brilliant performances from Crowe, Reed and Phoenix(a revelation in the evil conniving role of Commodus)and Gladiator is actually an intelligent movie with a true action hero with brains as well as brawn.

Up there with American Beauty as the best film of 2000 so far (UK) SEE IT NOW! 10/10.

title: You will either love or hate this movie. I loved it!
review:
That being said, I can honestly say to forget the 'reviews' from those who didn't even sit through the whole movie. That's just whack. But it really is the sort of show that some people just won't like. If you're a history purist, the story and characters just won't add up. But mostly I don't think the negative reviewers see the depth and get annoyed with the violence. The movie does have plenty of violence. But gore? I don't know what Mary Poppins spinoffs they've been feeding on, but there's a whole buncha movies out there that have more gore. Gladiator flashes the 'chop off the arm' or the 'split the skull' scene very quickly. You know it happened but barely see it.

There is much more to this movie than action or gore. All the main actors are good or better. I saw a touching scene here, a real feeling there. And hell, no movie and I mean no movie has ever before given viewers so much of ancient Rome to look at. What a great job of computer rendering!

For those who haven't been watching movies for 40 years, this is the same basic story that was the basis for the 'Fall of the Roman Empire', made in the 60's. Sophia Loren was Lucilla, Stephen Boyd as Maximus, Christopher Plummer as Commodus and Obi Wan Kenobi as Marcus Aurelius. Similar but different, I prefer Gladiator.

title: Braveheart again - with snappier dialogue
review:
Russell Crowe has now proved himself as one of the truly great actors. With nothing less than an inspiring performance, he has managed to make up for the shortcomings of many of the other cast members. Gladiator opens with one of the most creative and entertaining (though bloody) battle scenes. Crowe, playing the most successful of Roman Generals, plays a multi-faceted role, from brutal warrior to loving husband which has been enhanced by the films continuously interesting and original cinematography.

Through this film, Ridley Scott will be able to through of the Sci-Fi master tag that seems to have dogged his career since the 'Aliens' series (irrespective of their acclaim and box office success).

Aside from the continual excitement that this film offers, there is an interesting storyline that goes along with it. Although it will not go down as a classic of all time, 'Gladiator' offers excitement and keeps the audience glued to the screen despite the long viewing time.

All in all a wonderful must see film.

title: A Woman's Movie
review:
Gladiator movies are not high on my list. But Russell Crowe is, and for good reason. He delivers. And what does he deliver? Integrity, intimacy, and most of all, emotional truth.

Sitting there in the darkened theater, uncertain as to what level of violence was soon to assault me, it wasn't until the moment that the great Richard Harris opened his arms (and heart) to embrace his son, Commodus, that I knew this was a film that I could trust.

Beautifully matched with the talented Joaquin Phoenix, who more than held his own against the formidable Crowe, I found Crowe's performance as Maximus one of gravity, sensitivity, and a dignity of character not often found in films today. The relationship between Maximus and Lucilla was both balanced and believable, and as much as I would liked to see some steamy loves scenes with Crowe, the lack of one in Gladiator actually enhanced the films credibility. There was a naturalness and ease also in the relationship between Maximus and the soulful Djmon Hounsou.

Ridley Scott's exciting direction was flawless (as usual) and the action sequences, while violent (it is a Gladiator film after all) were imaginative, visual, and expertly choreographed. The addition of tigers was brilliant, as they aren't acting. The strong combination of all of the above, plus stunning sets, beautiful cinematography, and powerful, yet haunting music brought this film home to it's much deserved success.

I've seen Russell Crowe in only three films; "LA Confidential", "The Insider", and now, "Gladiator". I am astounded by the raw power of his performances, and sense that underneath that raw power there is a fine thread that connects everything that Crowe does, and that thread is his heart. And it's a big one.

title: Wow
review: This is just one of those movies where you walk out of the theater thinking "Hell Yeah!"  There were occasionally crude looking digital effects and the skip-frame photography seemed a little out of place for a movie set in this time period, BUT the performances were all amazing, and "sandal" movie or not, I had a great time.

title: Sorry, Roger, Wrong On This One!
review: OK, Commodus ruled 12 years after the (natural) death of father Marcus Aurelius, and not for the year (or whatever) depicted in Gladiator.  And, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix ) may have been a more daunting foe for Maximus (Russell Crowe) in the ring, judging from what we know of his athletic prowess, even without the "advantage" of his having "insured" himself of victory (no spoiler).  (In fact, a powerful wrestler strangled Commodus to death at the behest of Commodus' trusted advisors in 192). Doesn't matter. Doesn't matter.  The opening scenes of Gladiator alone are worth the price of admission.  How WERE the Romans able to conquer and control almost a quarter of the world's population?  Take in the first 30 minutes of this film.  Then you'll know.  Ridley Scott has a genius for film making (which always begins with the visual).  Reminds me of Kubrick.  He  knows how it must have been, or could be, or should be.  So, you rearrange history a bit to create a first class story.  So what?  The script, the performances, the mood and tempo of action can't disappoint, unless you're so oriented to plots laced with video game inspired characters and disaster scenes that only a third century vintage Freddie Visits Mission Impossible will stir your senses.  Sorry Roger, two point five? (I thought I'd never say this) you are dead wrong.  This is a terrific two plus hours of first class entertainment.

title: Awesome!
review:
Wow! That's all I can say after watching "Gladiator". And you know what? I'm not writing this review immediately after watching the movie like I usually do. I'm writing this review after watching the movie for the SECOND time. Yep, I saw this movie on opening night and then went and saw it again two days later.

Gladiator is about a Roman General who's a hero that becomes a slave, then becomes a gladiator, and finally a hero again. General Maximus (Russell Crowe) refuses to support the young Emperor Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) as he suspects foul play after it is discovered that the current Emperor and father to Commodus is found dead. Maximus becomes an outcast and eventually a slave as he is bought by Proximo, a man who engages in the sport of gladiating by supplying the slaves that will eventually be killed in these gruesome competitions. To Proximo's surprise, Maximus not only survives competition after competition but he becomes the favorite in almost every competition. But there's more to this man's success than skill alone. There's revenge.

Russell Crowe is not one of the better-known actors but he's fast becoming one. I saw him in "Insider" and was blown away with his performance there but when I saw this movie I gained an even deeper respect for this man. He is one talented actor. The rest of the cast is no sack of potatoes either. This is probably one of the most talented group of actors assembled for one film.

Richard Harris, Oliver Reed, Dereck Jacobi, the list goes on and it's hard to find a weak actor in the group. I was particularly impressed with Joaquin Phoenix. I thought he played the young Emperor with a wonderful mix of child-like poutiness and scheming villany that was a good counterpart to Crowe's character. Connie Nielsen's portrayal of Commodus's sister, Lucilla, was equally well done and at times made you feel a bit uncomfortable as the hint of an incestuous relationship between her and Commodus possibly existed.

The good thing about this movie was that there was a good storyline to backup the strong cast. The dialogue was appropriate to the story and unlike many of the other "testosterone" filled movies, this one didn't suffer the fate of cheezy lines.

Overall, a definite must see but I must warn you. There is a tremendous amount of graphic violence so if you're faint of heart this may not be the movie for you. If this sort of thing doesn't bother you, you must go see it. For your information, the real Commodus did participate in gladiating and was rumored to have amassed a record of 1000 wins so he was no slouch in the gladiating ring.

title: Impressive, but best scenes were on the trailer already.
review:
Although quite impressive of a movie in its acting, cinematography, story line, etc., its studio(s) did the movie a disservice by putting the best scenes of the movie onto the trailers. I don't just mean the ones you see in the theatres or on TV, but the clips on talk shows where the actors/actresses plug the movie.

Sadly, this follows the tradition of Disney's Touchstone Pictures (circa late 1980's early 90's) where the crux of the movie was given away in a five-minute trailer (e.g. The Doctor, 1991). The bad news is that word of mouth precluded many others from seeing the movie once word got out. The good news is that the Disney exec's finally wised up and "trimmed" back on the trailers for future films.

In many ways, it truly is a magnificent picture. I just hope that future movies of this great caliber aren't "diluted" by too much foreknowledge.

title: Beautiful,brutal and brilliant
review:
i cannot comment on this film without first saying how this is the first film where I have actually wanted to meet the cinematographer and congratulate him on a job that for myself, made the film. The photography in this film is breathtaking. Every flashback sequence, every battle, every exchange is made in short beautiful to watch. The camera is one minute showing us the most brutal of deaths in a battle sequence that I must say is the most realistic I have ever seen, and the next conveying the audience to the heaven-like sanctuary that is Maximus' home. I don't believe I have ever actually looked forward to the filler shots in between scenes.

However beautiful the film looks, the dialogue is sometimes lacking. The actors make best use of often cliched speeches and emotional one liners (not least Crowe), but the dialogue just never seems to 'fit'. The exchanges between characters seem forced and, well, like you've heard them before. A small fault in an otherwise great film.

Definitely see gladiator. Whether it's just to marvel at the first-class filming or the braveheart style sequences of utter brutality that will forever be etched on your brain, it's a classic story and a classic film.

title: Superb action, poor plot
review:
The opening battle sequence and subsequent fight scenes are superb. They feel realistic, bloody and uncompromising. The film looks great throughout.

Unfortunately the plot is a cliche and completely predictable. The characters lack depth and the dialogue slow and dull. A lot of editing to cut this down to 90 minutes might have been a good idea.

All the actors put in at least reasonable performances and you wish the same cast had been given a decent script to work with.

title: A highly engaging film where acting supercedes SFX
review:
Most people have based their judgment on this film by the quality and nature of its battle scenes. While they are surely integral parts of the movie I believe its real strength lies elsewhere - principally in the high caliber of acting in a film that has no real "star" appeal. Crowe is becoming globally renowned as a class actor (this I knew before his previous work) and he portrays the rugged single-motived determination of a vengeful man that has lost everything perfectly. The real stand out in this film for me was Joaquin Phoenix - an actor who has been lampooned by many for no other imaginable reasons than his famous family name and youth. The way in which the character of Commodus was played defines this movie. He could so easily have been summed up as a simple one dimensional purely villainous antiseptic anti-hero like all those homogeneous characters infesting countless "die-hard" type movies. Or, he could have been an essentially camp figure played as so inept a leader though endless emotional manifestations of his inferiority complex. If it had been the first the movie could well have been demoted from welcome epic to traditional gung-ho flick by-numbers where everyone secretly wants the "bad guy" to win. Joaquin brilliantly finds a type of middle-ground between the two extremes and plays a character equally insane, intelligent, evil and ashamed. There are times when he seems a purely pathetic little spoilt boy (something I think critics believe Joaquin himself is - denting their abilities to truly judge his performance) with, intentionally funny, lines such as "I'm vexed, really vexed". Other times, his own self hatred and sense of inadequacy make him seem more sinister than any type-faced bad guy with the latest nuclear weapon (particularly in scenes with his sister - Connie Nielson, in effectively a bit-part role). By being a 3D character whose motives we feel we can almost understand somehow makes him more evil than otherwise possible - we don't love to hate him we just hate him and pity him in equal measures. He also has the perfect look for the role. I heard Jude Law was auditioned for the part - unsurprising, both have a similar look as pretty boys not destined for battle but capable of displaying a thousand emotions beneath one single expression.

Much about the rest of the movie has been said many times so I shall be brief. The battle scenes are very well done and not enough credit is given to Scott for them (I sadly expected the usual unimaginitive "he copied Spielberg" jibes). Oliver Reed is indeed a commanding and vibrant character on the screen - all the more surprising given that he can be seen to be stumbling through some scenes, guess that Roman vinum was a little too tempting. Yes, the ending is a little annoying - such a face-off is wearingly familiar from those tiresome wrestling fests but the whole movie is not in this vein (many have called it WCW Colliseum Style - a disgraceful simplification). The lack of tension in this final scene, while disappointing in a dramatic sense, links well to the theme of ultimate destiny that underlies this and most Roman epics. Also, the flashy "dream" sequences interspersed throughout are far too pop-culture for such a film and dampen the general flow of realism. Special effects are generally excellent, although occasionally certain Rome shots tend to look a little to CGI'd. Any flaws are merely nit-picks and the problem with mentioning them is that often one feels obligated to do so yet takes up half his critique saying so. This should not be the case - Gladiator is an excellent film that hopefully heralds a return for more epics that triumph in their characterisation at least as much as their technical showmanship.

title: A Tiger of a movie
review:
I'd agree with the reviews- this is not the summer blockbuster that it was billed as. It contains some cracking action setpieces- the gritty opener set in a German forest (imagine Saving Private Ryan with catapaults and more horses) and a chariot scene that is really the high point of the film. Ridley hasn't lost it since G.I. Jane.

Russell Crowe (The Quick and the Dead) is really turning into a proper action hero- maybe a hairier, more australian Keanu Reeves. I'd pay to see them in a gunfight. The scenes between him and Oliver Reed (Oliver!) were the strongest in the film- the old generation and the new, much like in "The Rookie".

One thing I would say against the film is it seems to have skimped on its CGI budget- Rome looked too plastic, not fitting with the parts filmed in the 'real world'- a similar problem to Episode 1. Computers just aren't good enough yet to create whole worlds that make us forget it's all ones and zeros.

title: One of my favourite movies of all time!
review: I think Russell Crowe was outstanding.  I generally am not that impressed by acting roles as I believe a role can win an oscar better than the actor/actess. However, he captivated myself, and to my knowledge, everyone around me.  The movie was well directed with great battle scenes, but Mr. Crowe captured the audience with his portrayal of Maximus.  I cannot possible say anything bad about this movie, and maintain it was splendid. Thank You, Dr. S. Rahman

title: Straight and to the point, as always!
review:
This review may contain spoilers, but not many, they are not plot threatening, because there is not much of a plot.

Gladiator... the posters were most exciting, and the hype was very convincing, but unfortunately for us, the film didn't quite live up to expectations.

The plot was slow and drawn out, and the spectacular views we saw in the trailer were either very short, or didn't happen at all! The acting was very good, apart from the old Caeser when he died, you could still see him breathing which I thought was a bit amateurish. It spoiled the effect for me.

The main thing that was lacking was the empathy for the characters. Maximus obviously had a bit of a bad time, but you didn't get the sense of his pain that a good movie will provide. Well written characters either endear themselves to the audience or make the audience hate their guts. The audience have some emotional response to the heroes or villans, but this film didn't do that.

I didn't hate the new Emperor, just as I didn't care when certain events happened to Maximus in the middle and end of the film.

The fight scenes were the only redeeming feature of the movie, but they could not save this stunningly mediocre offering.

I am disappointed because I thought this would be great, but cut an hour and maybe it would be.

title: Exciting and gripping
review: Ignoring the historical inaccuracies (Commodus was strangled whilst in a drunken stupor) and some plot flaws, this film is engaging, exciting and a visual treat. The armour and sets are nothing short of amazing and anyone with a remote interest in ancient Rome will enjoy this film. My only gripe was the boy didn't look Roman and had an English accent that was a distraction. I find myself thinking about this film days after watching it so it has depth. Watch and enjoy, can't wait for a directors cut on dvd!!

title: Beyond the hype, Russel Crowe and special effects, not much lurks behind Gladiator's shiny armour plating
review:
Ridley Scott strikes again and creates a huge sprawling Roman epic. Forget Alien, the scenery created here is truly stunning and worthy spending money on just to see that alone. Russel Crowe is fantastic and is well supported.

By becoming an epic though, Gladiator falls into the usual pitfalls. It is too long, the story isn't strong enough and in places it is simply (whisper it) dull. The fight scenes are superb, but are spaced out by parts which don't continue the surge of adrenalin. Great epic, almost a classic, flawed, but worth seeing anyway just for Scott's wizardry and Crowe's bloodied face.

title: Wonderful historical fiction.
review:
Wonderful historical fiction! People who have taken Latin will enjoy the sets, scenery, and costumes. While some things are not and cannot be accurate to actual history; it is still a wonderful tour of the ancient world. It really shows how much we lost in the Dark Ages.

Very few bumps in the road from acting, all in all an enjoyable 2.5 hours. Rather bloody, but c'mon, it's a gladiator movie!

title: Bravo Mr. Scott and crew!
review:
I thought this move was stunning. It was even better for me the second time I saw it. If you liked it to any degree, I would recommend seeing it a second time at the theater. You will probably like it even more.

Every once in a while a movie comes along that can inspire you. For me, this was that type of movie. I spoke with two friends of mine and they had similar reactions. One even went as far to say that this film changed his life. Personally, I can say that I now view death (and life) in a whole new understanding. I have a feeling this film will effect men more than women, but I really don't know.

The acting is flawless for the most part. The sets and costumes are impeccable. Ridley Scott, who started out as a set designer, shows his ability to take you into another time and place with fantastic sets. This last fact alone is worth the price of admission. I mean, even a simple documentary with such excellent shots of ancient Rome would be entertaining. Its certainly the closest I'll ever come to seeing a real gladiator fight.

In my opinion the script was good too. Some have commented that the plot and script were lacking, but for me it was not. I found some of the lines to be very powerful.

There were a few shots and other things in the movie that I thought could have been better. I can think of 2 at the moment but don't want to revel them. I had no problem overlooking these flaws in an otherwise superlative film.

I'd like to thank Mr. Scott and crew for reaffirming that film is indeed art.

title: Probably the last of the great Roman epics
review:
We've trodden this route before. Anyone familiar with the Kirk Douglases and Charlton Hestons of the world will recognise what this film is about. It was interesting to note the number of elderly people in the cinema, another indication that this film was a throwback to a bygone era.

Having said that, it was visually stunning, the cinematography added another dimension to this genre. The battle scenes were vivid and exciting and the scenes in the colleseum kept me enthralled. Russell Crowe was a fitting choice for the part of Maximus and generally it was well cast apart from the irritating Lucius. Oliver Reed chose the perfect vehicle for his swansong and filmic epitaph.

Despite enjoying it as a thrilling spectacular and not finding it long at over two and a half hours, at the end of the film I did have a certain sense of deja-vu. Apart from technological advances there was nothing new that would differentiate this film from the the Cecil B de Mille epics. Still, I ask myself is there anything wrong with turning out a good old-fashioned movie with all the tricks that entertained previous generations.

However, there was something about it that left me pondering that as we are now in the year 2000, perhaps we demand a little bit more. Maybe we've spent too many years watching too many films to be surprised, and that's my biggest gripe - there was nothing surprising or unexpected about this film.

Still perhaps I'm over complaining. I felt I got my moneys worth and would certainly recommend it to anyone who was unsure as whether to go or not. There is a lot to enjoy about this movie and I suppose if it happens to be on the box on a Good Friday in a few years time, I'll probably tune in again. So it's a thumbs up from me!

title: pictorial excellence - cultural regression
review:
Okay, so "Spartacus" is 40 years ago and lacked CGI sophistication. At least it was about a basic human theme. It's a shame the superlative acting talents of the entire "Gladiator" cast were used to serve a story of a Roman general seeking revenge against a corrupt emperor. For what? To see who gets to run the massive slave state of Rome for another few years? Whether Rome was Republic or Empire was a moot point to the 50 plus per cent of the population who were enslaved. "Spartacus" on the other hand is based on a real incident involving a real issue: freedom vs. slavery. "Gladiator" is bogus history. It is a fascist work. Ridley Scott's brilliant evocation of Riefenstahl when Joaquin Phoenix enters Rome is no accident. But didn't he realize that the whole plot as well was just an totalitarian wetdream? The movie never challenges the basic assumptions of Roman rule. For all his failings, Kirk Douglas, did that - and profoundly so. I think it's nice that Russel Crowe wanted vengeance for losing his wife, son and luxurious villa. Spartacus just wanted to die a free man.

And an observation about Ridley Scott's pictorial genius. His set design reminds me of pre-Raphaelite painting knock offs, something one might find on the dust jacket of a "historical" novel. Kubrick's Rome and Roman countryside had the spare lean authenticity of archealogical reality. Scott's silvered, coppered and bronze frames, crammed with "stuff" looked just that - crammed.

And an observation about Scott's action: Does anyone notice that the swordplay and much of the fighting occurs in a blur or blizzard of camera-swishing? Very "Batman and Robin." When Russell Crowe is about to be executed, his escape and table- turning is so swish-panned as to be unseeable. This happens again and again. The defeat of the charioteers in the arena: the coverage is askance and oblique. It lacks the simple integrity and graceful genius of a Jackie Chan move or something Bruce Willis might do or... dare I say, the way Kirk Douglas might handle it. I liked "Alien," I liked "Thelma and Louise." I'm beginning to worry now about the upcoming "Hannibal."

title: Hmmm.... Should they have called it Braveheart II?
