Now I have no problem w. styling violence but the type of one- up-manship that has been occuring since SPR and the Matrix ultimately hurts things that really matter. Story and character.

And saying that this movie is about for violence in society is like saying that ID4 is about the SETI Program. Allegory is great but when the movie fails on the surface - the sub text can never save it.

title: A little soon to remake Braveheart, don't you think?
review: Frankly, I was disappointed by this movie, and  I had suspicions that I would be. Before I go into the, why -of-it, it is important that I make an introduction. Ridley Scott permanently captured my imagination, and many others as well, many years ago with "Bladerunner," which still ranks in my top list of science fiction movies, despite recently losing it's number one spot (my own) to "The Matrix." "Bladerunner" had been preceded by the also incredible "Alien," which led me to believe that Mr. Scott would become one of the great directors of all time. "Legend," which followed, though fun to watch Tim Curry,  as Darkness, was a bit childish and thin, and "Someone to Watch Over Me," was a bust. Even the much praised "Thelma and Louise," which was ground breaking in its introduction of leading women characters as hero/anti-hero, (characterizations only previously allowed for men), despite its hype and popularity, did not completely win me over either. I could go on and on and throw a brick at, "Black Rain," or "GI Jane," but that's not the point. I can only say I have not been impressed with any of his work since 1982. Now in all fairness it does take a lot to impress me. And perhaps if I were viewing these films as the work of an aspiring film-maker, I might be less critical. But I expect more from my heroes, and so now I will tell you what I found so lacking in "Gladiator." About an hour into the movie, I turned to my companion and said, "I've seen this movie before..." First of all, to me, talking during a movie, is the first sign of trouble, as her listening to my comment, was the second sign. Any film worth it's salt will go from beginning to end without so much as a peep from me. And this is the way it should be. Now many of you might say, "so what, we 'love' remakes," or in fact,  "everything is a remake,..." and you wouldn't, sadly, be too far from the truth,  (which is perhaps my greatest lament about the mainstream movie industry to begin with.)  Some remakes have not been that bad, and I wont waste any of this time elaborating. The movie I originally had in mind with my comment was, "The Fall of the Roman Empire," which was pretty much the exact same story with Alec Guinness as the dying Marcus Aurelius; Christopher Boyd, as General Livius,(not Maximus), selected by Caesar to be Rome's guardian, while it remakes itself as a republic, (Caesar's dying wish here as well); Sophia Loren, as Lucilla, the princess; and most importantly, Christopher Plummer, as Commodus, Caesar's son and murderer, in a captivating performance, (as opposed to Joaquin Phoenix's listless interpretation of the same character),  in an otherwise tediously long film, (a full 34 minutes longer than "Gladiator." The characters names are mostly all the same, as is the story, and sadly the dullness.  Now I do realize that this movie was made in 1964, and most of you out there have not seen it and could care less, But I expect more from my great directors. Unfortunately, this was not the only movie herein that I had seen before. Also built within Gladiator, and becoming more apparent half of the way through, one noticed desperate story line similarities with "Braveheart," in  the drive behind the hero's plight, and fate. This pathetic resort to imitating plot lines from Oscar winning films, should be relegated to fledgling directors, and not from one of the best. The similarities do go on, I could mention "Spartacus," and several others in the Roman genre as well. All old films perhaps, and once greatly in need to have been remade, though now no longer. All in all, in-between the action packed sequences, the picture moved slowly, begging for more scenes with special effects.  Which it did not ultimately produce. We saw the best of this the film had to offer halfway through. In fairness, I loved a lot of the images, which reminded me that Mr. Scott now has the right to include any images he wants, and will not have to resort years from now from releasing a "director's cut" of this movie. I only wish he could have relied more on his intuition and less on what I perceive as, a catering to the least common denominator of the film going audience. So for the most of you, go see it and enjoy it, and forget everything I say, because you may not be expecting as much more, as I have, and will continue to do, while waiting for one more "Bladerunner," to come forth from this talented film-maker.

title: A man finds an alternate way to achieve his destiny.
review:
Despite being predictable, this movie benefited from a kind of violence discretion - big battles but no torture type scenes, which always make me squirm and which I will always avoid if possible. Battles are another thing altogether.

It was fun to watch the harnessed chariot horses suddenly sprout stirrups (which hadn't been invented at that time, I believe) and for the stirrups on other saddles to be modern steel stirrups with rubber foot treads! It was also fun to see how quickly and scarlessly gladiators heal. This is a goofmaster's delight of a movie.

Nevertheless, I would glad(iator)ly see it again - for Crowe, Harris and for Oliver Reed's last performance.

title: What a Wonderful Movie, (Spartacus 2?)
review:
I saw this movie on Tuesday, it was breathtaking. The opening scene had a battle betwen armies that was so realistic that I imagined myself in the midst of battle. I did not find one error in this movie (concerning production). I saw this movie as a combination of Spartacus, Double-Impact and the Sixth Sense, in a rather beautiful way. Now this movie puts special-effects to good use and you cannot tell reality from computer-induced events. I still can't decide if the aerial views of ancient Rome were an actual city or computer-generated. The plot is good and splendid.

The battles are the most realistic and bloody I've ever seen in any gladiator/fighting movie, you literally see blood sprinkles in the air. You feel as if you are the condemned man going to meet death at the arena. Certaintly this movie is greater than Braveheart and will surpass it at the box office. It's an epic, that's all I can tell you.

title: Great epic - Great film
review:
What a great film!

Ridley Scott of `Alien', `Blade Runner', and `Legend' fame has delivered a wonderful and moving film.

The opening battle scenes between the Roman Legions and the barbarian hordes in Gaul were equivalent to the opening scene in `Saving Private Ryan' and the brutal attack in `Paths of Glory'. Absolute reality  cold, miserable, dirty, dangerous, vicious, - but organized and executed with Roman efficiency and uncompromising courage. I felt I was there and I really didn't want to be there.

Russell Crowe is terrific. The movie Hero with Charisma is back. He is the link that ties the movie together and there are no false steps. No over or under acting  just a performance that makes you believe that Maximus existed and had to do what had to be done.

Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius should get a Oscar nomination for his performance.

Jacquin Phoenix is the psychotic Emperor Commodus and proves the maxim that a great movie with a larger than life hero always needs a great villain.

While the special effects were exciting and important, I didn't think that they dominated the movie or accounted for its success. I give the credit to old fashioned directing, great screen play, wonderful music and cinematography, great sets, editing, and fine acting.

The Games

`Spartacus' was about the training and the revolt of gladiators. `The Gladiator' centers on what it would be like to actually participate as a gladiator in the `Games'. For about seven hundred years  from the Etruscans to the fall of Rome  the Games bound the Roman culture together. On a weekly schedule throughout the Empire - tens, hundreds, and thousands died to entertain the populace. Ridley Scott presents the Games as simply part of the Roman life  no moralizing, no cute scenes, no Christians, - just its brutality and its vicious, addicting, emotional appeal.

Gritty, tough, epic in scope and very moving.

title: What potential! What happened?
review: "Gladiator" was the one film I was really looking forward to seeing this summer (asides from X-Men).  So when I finally got to see it, I was all set up to really enjoy a summer epic-- not blockbuster or action flick, but an epic, because I expected no less from Dreamworks or Ridley Scott.  What I got instead was a film that was stunning and breathtaking in every way, save the script.  The script for "Gladiator" dragged the entire film down.  What essentially happened-- and it's disturbing how easily this pattern applies-- is that the writers broke down the script for "Braveheart" and rewrote it using shallower characters and stilted dialogue.  The actors did a superb job with the pathetic material they were given, particular note being given to the performances of Joaquin Phoenix and Russell Crowe.  The visuals, particularly Scott's stylized way of altering the contrast and film speed during the action scenes to lend it that "unreal" aspect, were amazing.  I have an amazing amount of respect for the SFX people who did the Colisseum-- really good job, guys.  The pacing was also very nice.  They managed to make a very dense movie.  However, the script continually kept the film from hitting true epic greatness-- despite the best efforts of everyone associated with it.  After having read articles about the script problems "Gladiator" was going through, it's easy to see where the problems stemmed from.  Likewise, the only other problem I found with the film was the score, which was a bit heavy-handed and predictable (then again, the predictability comment could be handed over to the script as well).  My friends and I could predict EVERYTHING from opening shot to final scene within about five minutes-- perhaps just because we saw "Braveheart", perhaps because the script didn't take the risks it could have.  Why didn't Proximo have moral problems with being a gladiatorial profiteer even after he KNEW the psychological issues gladiators get?  Or even if he was so caught up with the thrill and the popularity-- why wasn't his character given more depth on this level?  Why didn't the script go into some REALLY difficult places-- like forcing Russell Crowe to combat his friends?  Why wasn't more done with the concept of winning over the mob as creating political power?  There were so many issues that could have been addressed that weren't-- and it was sad. Overall, an impressive piece of cinema-- if you look beyond the script. Congratulations guys-- with a good script in hand, you could have had a legend.  As it stands, you have a fun evening diversion.

title: One of the best movies I've ever seen.
review: As high as my expectations were when I went to see Gladiator, they were met and exceeded. This film rests squarely on the shoulders of Russell Crowe, who gives a performance that is superior even to the one he gave in the Insider. I'll be shocked if he isn't nominated again this year. Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard's score is the best I've heard in years, and Ridley Scott keeps the action moving at a frenetic pace, right up to the last match. While the film may draw comparisons with Spartacus, keep in mind that it is a totally different movie. And Crowe's performance easily outmatches that of Kirk Douglas. The early favorite for Best Picture, go and see Gladiator. I promise you won't ever forget it.

title: spectacular
review: The movie's frenetic fight scenes are balanced by Russell Crowe's intense performance as Maximus and Ridley Scott's rich direction.   Although, Joaquin Phoenix doesn't have Malcolm McDowell's mad edge as Commodus it doesn't matter.  Connie Nielsen is regally sexy as Lucilla and Oliver Reed (who is almost unrecognizable as Proximo) is PHENOMENAL and his presence will be sorely missed.  Character actor, Tommy Flanagan, makes another memorable impression...

title: An intense, well-crafted movie about one man and a fading empire.
review: "Gladiator" ranks high among movies about Roman times, "Spartacus", "Ben-Hur", "Fall of the Roman Empire", "Quo Vadis"  come to mind. The movie maintains its uniqueness among these heroic sagas in the way it affords us a view of those times and men in those times. The panoramic scale the movie maintains to set us up and bring us into the parts of the story is breath-taking. The camera shots of the protagonists makes sure the viewer is held firmly and moved surely  through the plot. The intensity of the final confrontation is brought by sheer force of the way the viewer is brought to this point. For people who enjoy movies, this is an event that must not missed. On a personal note, the opening scenes were a bonus to students of Caesar's Gallic Wars. If you have always wondered, like me, how those battles (strategies & tactics) were fought, this is the answer.

title: A poetic look.
review:
GLADIATOR is like a rush of pure energy moving through you, leaving you in a state of "Aw" and excitment, thirsting for more.

GLADIATOR slams you into it's historical settings making you a Roman at the Coliseum with your arme stretch outward, thumb up or thumb down, deciding the fate of another gladiator.

title: Excellent
review: I have seen it twice, and I have enjoyed it thoroughly.  The acting is great, the battle scenes are spectacular, and the directing is wonderful. All in all, this is a great movie, better than most of the other drivel being put out these days.  As everyone says, Russell Crowe was wonderful, but the real surprise for me was the performance of Joaquin Phoenix, who was perfect as Commodus.

title: Oh...MY....God....
review: If this doesn't launch Russel Crowe into super stardome, I don't know what will. This movie is intense. I felt emotionally tied to the whole situation, especially because all that kind of stuff once went down in real life. You know a movie is amazing when there's not a single thing you can think of to change to make it better. Gladiator is a movie of perfection. It's intense. It's a saga. An Epic. I can now die in peace knowing I have seen the ultimate movie.

title: Epic story and powerful performances. A+!
review:
Gladiator delivers, and I'm not talking pizza. Although there's plenty of red stuff flying around from time to time. This movie is an extremely well-crafted epic with sweeping vistas, spectacular scenics, breathtaking scenes of battle and fighting heroics, strong supporting roles, and a refreshingly cliche-free script which I did not find at all predictable. The tension was gut-gripping, the characters rich and mythic. Can you tell I was enthralled? What a role for Russell Crowe, who shows here just what he can do in a lead role. He has arrived for good, and we're the better off for it.

I heartily recommend this movie. A fulfilling cinematic experience. Please seek out a theater with a great sound system and good projectors. You won't regret it.

title: Speculator!
review: Leave it to Russell Crowe, one of the few actors who actually reads a script for a movie before acting in it.  He has been in two of some of the best movies of the 1990's, L.A. CONFIDENTIAL and THE INSIDER.  Now Crowe proves his marquee star status with his latest film, GLADIATOR.  GLADIATOR is a film in the tradition of BEN HUR, EL CID, and TEN COMMANDMENTS, a classic epic brought into the new millennium. The story is about Maximus (Russell Crowe), a Spanish general fighting for the powerful Roman army.  He is hailed a hero among his soldiers, and admired by his leader, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris).  Marcus adores Maximus so much that he would rather see Max, than his own son, Commodus (Jouquin Phoenix) become the future leader of Rome.  Commodus is both hurt and angered by his father's decision, he kills his father, imprisions Maximus, as well as threatens and torments his beautiful sister Lucilla (Connie Nielsen).  Maximus escapes Commodus soldiers and discovers that his family is killed and his home is destroyed by Commodus' army. Maximus is then captured and is sold into slavery to become a gladiator, under the rule of Proximo (the late Oliver Reed).  Maximus befriends another slave, Juba (Djimon Hounsou), and together along with Lucilla, and Roman senator Gracchus (Derek Jacobi), they try to defeat the evil rule of Commodus. From start to finish, GLADIATOR is a feast to the eyes and brain.  This is the kind of film that snaggs a couple of Oscar nominations.  Ridley Scott not only proves that he can make a fantastic movies that are in the future (ALIEN & BLADE RUNNER) but also the past, with this film.  From start to finish, and over 150 minutes, Scott manages to makes this film entertaining. With the excellent cinematography, editing, and fight scenes, Scott makes this a unique film placed in the history of cinema. And the acting is also great.  Russell Crowe is excellent, as usual, in his leading role as the faithful and honorable Maximus.  Now maybe, Crowe will become a popular star that he deserved to be since QUICK & THE DEAD.  And Jouquin Phoenix is very vicious and cold as the evil Commodus.  He proves that he can live up to the status that his older brother was in.  Connie Nielsen and Richard Harris are both great as the royal family. And in his final role, Oliver Reed is great as Proximo, the former gladiator who fight his way to freedom. GLADIATOR is a film that both the young and old will enjoy. The old will enjoy it since it's in the same formula as the classic epic film is, and with the great acting.  And the young will enjoy it because of it being so bloody and violent.  But anyone who enjoys brain food with thier summer films will enjoy this film.  Don't miss it!  ***** (out of five)

title: very long epic with modern sensibilities
review: I'm surprised that people liked this so much. It was entertaining, but I've seen several movies I thought were better already this year. I found the mismatch between the "realism" of the sets/props/action and the modern sensibilities expressed by the actors to be somewhat jarring. And while I enjoyed the spectacle, the attempt at being serious (which included jerky camera movements and washed out colors) got in the way of that, too. (This is in contrast to Ben-Hur, which is all spectacle.) I thought that the performances were rather good (Crowe was, as always, excellent), but Derek Jacobi was acting in the wrong movie (I think that he thought he was in Spartacus, perhaps), but somehow it all added up to less than the sum of its parts for me.

title: A entertaining movie that will be displaced in weeks.
review:
Gladiator: Having defeated the last pocket of resistance to the Roman Empire General Maximus is determined to return to his life as a farmer. Marcus Aurelius Caesar has other plans; he wants Maximus to succeed him as ruler so that Rome can once again become a republic and be returned to the people. Unfortunately, Aurelius' son Commodus learns of this and sentences Maximus to death. But, the best laid plans

This movie seems to have triggered a round of "Blockbusteritis"- after a spate of mediocre films, it is the first big budget movie of the summer and it is indeed entertaining. But the 62nd best movie of all time (as voted by 3500 members on the Internet Movie Database)? I think not.

The first battle scene is without a doubt my favorite part of the film - an amazing spectacle enhanced by excellent cinematography and painstakingly choreographed, it combines the best elements of "Saving Private Ryan" and "Braveheart". I was in addition duly impressed by the special effects, particularly the recreation of the Coliseum, and the battles between the gladiators (it may be a bit too intense for some people, after all it's not often that you get to see a literal bloodbath). I did however have several problems with the story.

Maximus rides from Germania to Spain, a journey that would surely take weeks if not months and arrives literally moments too late to save his family - a little too convenient for my liking. Also, after all that time his wound is still bleeding - surely he would have become food for the buzzards long before that. Or why did Commodus not have Maximus assassinated when he returns to Rome? But my biggest question was the past between Maximus and Lucilla: without a doubt, the most pivotal relationship in the movie and it is never explained. The acting is similarly unbalanced.

Once again Russel Crowe proves his versatility as an actor: his Maximus is quiet spoken, stoic, straightforward and lives by a code of honor (a concept too few people are familiar with these days). It is impossible not to feel for him. Richard Harris, though onscreen only briefly, is excellent as the omnipotent ruler who knows his time is ending (I hope it was the makeup that made him look that bad) and is determined to do the right thing. I'm still ambivalent over Joaquin Phoenix's take on Commodus, the villain of the piece - I did not hate him for being evil, but for annoying me. I couldn't wait for someone to cleave him in two to put an end to the whining, sniveling, incestuous little weasel.

Although Gladiator does not have the staying power of Spartacus or Ben Hur, it is a good way to wile away an afternoon.

title: I wasted money on this?
review: I went to see the "blockbuster" movie because I was bored and had nothing else to do.  I'm sure that I could have found something else to do for the price of a ticket that I paid.  In my humble opinion, this movie lasted way to long.  After about the first hour of the movie, my mind wandered off of the movie, and on to what was I going to make for dinner.  That's pretty sad when youre supposedly watching one of the summers hottest flicks.  True, I liked the battle scenes, but they were few and far between, and the plot is very slow moving.  I also noticed that people in the theatre made fun of Commodus when he would start to pout.  I can't say that I blame them. Ha! Anyways, I would not reccomend this movie unless you are scheduled for a root canal, and even then, I might say go for the root canal.

title: Grand!
review: It was a sort of a movie a big screen was invented for. The fighting scenes were impressively (a tad too gory for my taste, but oh well) filmed. It was just amazing watching Russel Crowe move. He had so much presence. So awe inspiring that I am thinking about going to see him again! And their recreation of Rome was also impressive. Computer schomputer. It looked big and real enough to me. I could see why people would worship Rome. Only small downside is that the story/plot isn't that great. It is quite predictable and some of the lines are quite corny. But the great thing about this movie is that it doesn't matter. I was so engulfed in the image and awe of Russel Crowe and Rome that weakness in the plot never bothered me at all. I went to a cheap night show and payed CAN$4 for it. And I believe that was a real bargain for such a grand film. I think every one should go see it!!!

title: FUN FUN FUN
review:
The problem with movies today is that they try (and the key word here is "try") to enlighten us. They attempt to push lenghty ten minute monologues on our materialistic existence or the superficiality of mankind down our throats. What these movies and directors and screenwriters behind these movies fail to realize is that 98.9% of the world's population could care less about being enlightened. When I sit through a 3 hour movie, I want it to be entertaining. I don't wanna shell out 8 bucks to be preached at. Gladiator is the perfect example of a movie that the majority of moviegoers want to see.

Gladiator has it all: a villain, a hero, a king, lots of gore, and beautiful cinematography and direction. While not being a breakthrough film or a one of a kind masterpiece, it's got all it needs. People want to see movies like this. They want that adrenaline rush right before a fight scene, they want to root for the hero, and they want that instant feeling of gratification and pure elation when the hero wins, no matter how strong the forces against him are.

The hero in the movie is Russell Crowe, and he's great. The rest of the cast was good, but the one person holding this entire film up is Crowe. And why shouldn't he? The movie is centered around him. This movie is exactly what he needs. He's gonna become a household name.

I give this movie a 10, not because it's one of my favorites, and not because it's a masterpiece (because it isn't), but because it embodies what a film should be. It's not superficial or preachy. It's just a good old-fashioned story delivered to us in a beautiful package. I'd be willing to shell out 8 bucks for the ticket (plus 3 for a Dr Pepper) to see this movie any day.

title: Glad I went to see.
review: Being someone having English as my second language, I do not go very often to see English movies. But today I was glad I went to the Gladiator. The movie is nothing less than a classic. Powerful battle scenes don't loosen the grip of the the director on the movie. The tempo is not very fast, and neither too slow (although it is close to 150 minutes!!). Its a movie anyone will find entertaining.

title: The movie that sucked mightily!
review: This has got to be one of the worst movies I've seen in a long, LONG time. I can't believe that the same Ridley Scott that gave us awesome movies like Alien and Blade Runner directed this dross. The movie is way too long, as this plot could have fit in a 60 minute after school special. Half of the movie consisted of sped-up battle scenes, in which guys hit each other with sticks while the camera operators shook the camera around so you couldn't tell how el-cheapo their special effects were. The other half of the film consisted of one of the characters talking to another one of the characters in very slow speech, with overly dramatic lighting and music finishing up the scene. I counted about three unique expressions coming from Maximus-he looked forlorn, then he looked depressed, then he looked....well, make that two unique expressions. The next time you want to go see a good Ridley Scott movie, rent Blade Runner and save yourself the trouble of having to sit through this mess.

title: Well worth seeing, but misses out on greatness
review: When I first heard about this film, I knew it would either be one of the best films of the year, or one of the worst. There was no middle ground. I'm happy to report that the former is the truth. This film took a very exotic and little used location, and needed to make it convincing to work. It succeeds admirably. The dreary landscapes, ragged populace, and gruesome attention to detail quickly make the viewer forget all the "tits and togas" films of the sixties. The film establishes a strong hold, and never lets up. It seems that ever since the success of the relatively intelligent Titanic, and failure of moron trash like Godzilla, every action film advertizes itself to be "character driven", or "plot centered". This usually means a character will talk about how much he is loved by someone, and proceeds to die an exotic death followed by the self-indulgent tears from the actress playing loved one. Not so here; the plot seems to flow from the personality of the characters, and even though cliches and cheap emotion are plentiful, the film is so earnest and determined, such things are forgiven. The characters also find the right note; Maximus is dignfied and silent, a man of action who leaves words to the politicians. Commodus is cowardly, inexperienced, and stupid, but also dangerously ruthless and ambitious. The sister also strikes the right note, posessing the intelligence and courage her brother lacks, but also develops empathy and a concern for others. The only wrong note is the fellow slave played by Houson. Real gladiators were vicious criminals or rebellious slaves, but Houson is too nice and benign to be convincing as either. There also was no really good villain, like Mesalla in BenHur, or Edward in Braveheart. Commodus is too pathetic to really hate. The plot is effective, but seemed focused on the wrong things. It would be better to tell the film from Maximus' eyes than the omniscient narration that kept pulling us away, into the Senate chamber and Commodus' bedside. Scott also makes a few directing mistakes, such as showing us the coloseum early and a huge procession, diluting the effect of Maximus' first coloseum battle. The dark, brooding photography helped set the mood, but many times made things hard to see. It also seemed to lack the epic sweep and power of Spartacus, BenHur, or Braveheart, and some battles were hard to follow, particularly the charioteer fight, which chariots were wrecked but it was unclear how. Still, this is a pleasant surprise after the meager offerings of Y2K, and while it may not be a classic, it is a good start for a promising summer.

title: As good as Braveheart, but cooler.
review:
When I saw the first trailer for Gladiator(around superbowl time), I thought about how much potential for greatness this film could possess. In a genre that has been ignored for thirty years, it's refreshing to see a movie that will no doubt be a catalyst for a surge of new epics. Russel Crowe = bad hombre. It's one thing to see a hero who displays excellent prowess with a gun - like the protagonists we love from westerns and cop movies; it's something altogether different to see a warrior slay his enemies with primitive weapons like swords, spears, and morning stars. I won't go into detail, but the battles in this movie are phenomenal. One last element of Gladiator that makes it a different type of film than Braveheart is the computer generated imaging that makes the ancient Rome real and possible for the movie. Also, this movie will probably not win Oscars like Braveheart because people viewed Braveheart as one man's(Mel Gibson) vision.

You can't not like this movie.

title: Breathtaking visuals and historically correct
review: This movie is a one of a kind piece of film. To watch it is like enjoying an independant movie with a big hollywood budget. Scott pulled out all the stops to make this one spectacular movie. I had not seen such excellent camera work since "Pulp Fiction." The scenes made you feel like you were right there in the stadium watching the spectacle. Scott also brought in many of the themes that have been left out of other roman based projects. Like the incestual tendencies of the latter Ceasars. The fans showering thier favorite gladiators with rose pedals. Slave camps, and the worldliness of ROME. You could walk down the streets of Rome and see people from all over the empire.

title: Quick notes about the movie.
review:
Gladiator! Great movie, great cast - all in all a must see for anyone. Russell Crowe is very capable of holding this movie together and the supporting cast is just right. Definitely this is the first blockbuster movie of the millennium and as such it will be remembered for generations to come.

Very good work by Director Ridley Scott this would have to be his best work since Blade Runner(1982)!

Go and see the movie, you'll not regret it.

My rating 9.5/10 !!!

title: Short and to the point
review: What an excellent film!!  The first time I watched Russell Crowe in a film, I was impressed.  I knew he would go far.  Well, this film is yet another example of Russell's fine talent.  As for the visuals, the story, the fights, the sound, the actors, the music, the costumes, the editing...all I can say is WOW.

title: Tremendous seamless special effects, not built in a day
review: The mighty Roman Empire is captured exquisitely by `Director Scott' This movie takes believability to the MAX!!. The technological marvels that begun in Phantom Menace are refined and perfected in this movie, where as menace effects took over the movie gladiator has incredible effects that you dont realize are there...you take for granted they rebuilt Rome and Slaughtered hundreds, how else could they do it?

title: Best epic in years
review:
A movie this long and epic cannot be summed up easily, but suffice to say that the movie is a must-see, and that lovers of many genres will find the movie to be quite satisfying. The movie contains a lot of action, and even though the action is often brutal, the director stays away from extreme gore and made-to-shock fight scenes. The plot development is great, with only minor loopholes, and the characters are all believable and easy to get to know. The camera-work is great, as is the script. Ridley Scott has come up with another winner and classic, though not in the same vein of 'Alien' or 'Bladerunner'. Russell Crowe, (who showed us that he could act tough without overacting in 'L.A. Confidential'), shows us again (as the gladiator Maximus) that sometimes the most believable emotions are the ones left to the mind. Sure, there are times when his face gives away what he is thinking, but most of the time you find yourself captivated by his stage presence. And then there is Joquin Phoenix, who convinces you that he truly is a mentally troubled Caesar, loving his position of power, and yet still playing children's games, deadly as they are. Connie Nielsen also convicts the heart with the emotion that she gives to her character, showing us her strong side, as well as her sorrow for her brother Commodus.

Overall, this movie can be compared in length, plot, and character to 'Braveheart', but I would give 'Gladiator' the edge, and two-thumbs up.

title: WOW - Makes the "Phantom Menace" even MORE dissapointing...
review:
Yes Yes Yes!

This movie is fantastic!

All the performances ranged from good/great to great/fantastic.

The story was solid, even though it may not have been the best ever written.

The cinematography was rich and interesting. The sets/CGI are fantastic, You'd think ancient Rome still existed today.

For some reason I kept getting reminders of The Phantom Menace, (in both the visuals, and dialogue/plot). I liked the look of the Phantom Menace, but was dissapointed in the execution slightly. This movie made my opinion towards Episode I even less favourable.

No not everyone will love it, but only the TRUELY cinical will think that it is the worst movie they have ever seen.

My advice is see it...judge it for yourself.

Later,

Lukas

title: MAIN EVENT
review: This is the kind of film made to be seen on the big screen. It's an engaging, adventure tale for adults. The opening battle scene in Germania is on a par with 'Saving Private Ryan'. Crowe is all man, but Phoenix is awful. He's not helped by his script, culminating in the awful line "I'm vexed, I'm truly vexed". There won't be a summer 2000 blockbuster to match this film.

title: An epic movie with dazzling effects!
review:
I had heard all of the hype about Gladiator and I thought that I should go and see it. I was looking forward to see the CGI which I guarantee you is mind blowing and I wanted to see how Russell Crowe would fair against the likes of Charlton Heston and Kirk Douglas.

The movie lived up to all of my expectations and exceeded some of them, the fight scenes are well staged and are often brutal. The movie has a great style about it thanks to it's brilliant director Ridley Scott.

The film opens in Germania with the Roman soldiers about to go to war with the barbarians. This goes on for around ten minutes and you will be astounded by it, shocked, but you will never forget it. It has brutal moments in the battle with heads and arms flying off left, right and centre which may put people off put I implore you to stick with it because it is excellent.

The dying Marcus Aurelius' (Richard Harris) last wish was to have the Roman General Maximus (Russell Crowe) become the new emperor which shocked Maximus as he just wanted to go home to his family. When Marcus Aurelius dies his son Commodus (the outstanding Joaquin Phoneix) wants Maximus dead so he can take over. Maximus escapes and becomes a gladiator.

The acting in the movie is superb and this should win the major awards at the Oscars because all the other movies out this year are sci-fi or action. Joaquin Phoneix is amazing as the devilish Commodus and Russell Crowe is brilliant as Maximus. Connie Nielsen, Derek Jacobi and the late Oliver Reed are excellent in their supporting roles.

This movie is a must see, it lives up to it's hype and I think it is better than Ben Hur and Spartacus. One of the best movies ever made and triumph in every way.

title: Boring movie that goes no where
review: I was so bored with this movie. It had no drive whatsoever, I walked out of the movie saying to myself "Who cares??" Russell Crowe is the only character that is even remotely worth caring about but we really never get to know him. "Gladiator" tries to be Roman "Braveheart" but it fails at all attempts. I also did not care for the high speed shutters used in the battle scenes, the only movie that worked in was "Saving Private Ryan."

title: A disappointment
review: This picture had a lot of buzz, and I went to it with more than a little goodwill.  Ridley Scott has directed THE DUELLISTS, ALIEN, and BLADE RUNNER, among other pictures, and he has one of the best camera eyes in the business.  The first 45 minutes or so are extraordinary, the snow in the German forest, a bunch of guys in leather skirts and bronze armor chopping each other up, flaming arrows flying into the trees, and the cinematography is to die for.  You forgive the weak spots in the characterization, or the laborious way the plot points are laid in.  But then it collapses of its own weight.  It reminded me a little of John Boorman's EXCALIBUR, which was also way over the top, but in the end XCALIBUR's operatic qualities worked. GLADIATOR just ends up being preposterous.  Russell Crowe doesn't embarrass himself, and Oliver Reed is terrific,  but THE LAST OF THE MOHICANS it ain't.  If you're going to make a costume picture, either pay attention to history and character, or do STAR WARS.  GLADIATOR is good for guys between the ages of, say, eight and thirteen (and I'm not putting that audience down, either), but it's basically the same plot as FISTFUL OF DOLLARS.  The hero gets mangled, and then he gets revenge.  But Sergio Leone didn't put you to sleep between the fight scenes.

title: Epic movie masterfully executed
review: I love this movie.  It is the kind of movie that only comes around about once every 10 years.  It is so well written, directed, acted and filmed that it is a masterpiece.  The fight scenes are very well done, some of the filming of this is speeded up a little.  The plot just keeps building-up to a perfect release at the end.

title: Better than I expected
review:
Gladiator is derived from several films yet manages to remain itself and is superb. What I cannot understand is the huge gap in opinion presented by major critics. Some expound on the greatness of the film, likening it to Braveheart and Saving Private Ryan. Others state that it is the "worst movie ever made." How can critics be so diverse?

Gladiator is simple and profound, violent yet beautiful. Could it be that passions aroused by this film are similar to those that drove American Beauty to its position of greatness? The terrible beauty of violence is American as it was Roman. Our violence is generally more gentile but for lust and the passions aroused by that lust are parallel. Gladiator is a great film journey. It also touches profound cords in the viewer that are deeper than some would want to acknowledge. We are the beast and the beauty, noble and savage.

We are all a breath away from being gladiators, or perhaps its just a draft.

title: Excellent
review: I went into this movie thinking Braveheart.  It is not at all like Braveheart, which by the way is one of my favorite movies.  This movie is just as good but totally different.  I thought the casting was excellent and there was plenty of plot and story.  The special effects are amazing.  I would highly recommend seeing this in the theater.  I think seeing it on a TV would lose too much of the splendor of this film.

title: Great Movie
review: This movie was truly amazing. It really captured many aspects of Ancient Rome, from the politics to the way that the romans waged war. This movie has enough to capture any audience from the failed romance of the sister and Maximus to the great action of the gladiator sceens. I highly recommend this movie

title: Go Russell go
review: This film, combining Lear, Macbeth, and Braveheart, will thrill you with a number of amazing action sequences while stirring your emotions with a powerful tale of courage, dedication, and historical revenge.  Throw Russell Crowe into the mix as a guy named Maximus - Great man in Latin - and you've got yourself one great time at the movies

title: Visual Feast of historic beauty and war
review:
Wow! Never have I seen such a lively response of the audience after a movie. The dialogue, cinematography, casting and music were extraordinary. I've seen it twice in two days and it was well worth it. The beautifully detailed beginning battle reminded me of the Saving Private Ryan beginning scene, with the shakey hand held camera and in your face action.

Good Job Ridley Scott!!

title: Uninteresting supporting characters, good Crowe
review: I liked Maximus and Crowe's acting job, but the supporting characters were largely uninteresting and woodenly acted. Lucilla spent most of her time looking scared and crying. Richard Harris did a good job as Marcus Aurelius though. I wasn't impressed much with the cinematography either, too much gray and blue and strange "jumping" in some of the special effects. The plot was interesting enough to follow for the first 2 hours, but the final showdown was too predictable. Better than a lot of period movies, but Braveheart is still top of its class by far.

title: Amazing...but missing something
review: I approached Ridley Scott's Gladiator with an enthusiasm for spectacular visual effects and a testosterone-pumped craving for carnage along the lines of Saving Private Ryan meets Ben-hur. However, upon actually viewing the film, I found that there is much more at work here. Of course, Scott is no Joel Schumacher and Russell Crowe isn't a Schwarzeneggar type, so this came with only a minimal amount of surprise. To address my initial hopes, Gladiator does harbor a variety of extraordinary images. The Roman cityscape is worth the price of admission in itself. Although some shots exhibit that "too bright" look that a lot of cgi effects have, the majority of scenes are composed with convincing authenticity. But forget the settings. Let's talk about satisfying the "I want to see brutal murder and dismemberment" desires of most moviegoers. Don't get too excited. As far as the blood and guts go, it seems that all of the battle sequences were cut in extremely short takes thrown together with shaky-cam perspective(I'm guessing they were trying to avoid an NC-17 rating). The bottom line is: in most shots, you really can't tell what is happening except for traces of red derived from spraying blood and the occasional death scream. I understand some things are in bad taste, but when you are depicting the gladiator "sport", the exploitation of death is the center of entertainment. Points off for that one. Also in poor form is the editing of the film in general. Gladiator is either an edge-of-your-seat roller coaster ride or a soap-opera paced drama and never falls anywhere between these two extremes. There is simply no transition. So what you seem to be left with is two films: a Mad-Max-style, kill 'em all hand to hand combat action flick on one hand and an expensive period piece character-study on the other. It's not that the performances are bad. It's just that there is essentially very little plot, so the actors have no means of developing their characters other than in face-to-face emotional monologues. Which brings me to the overly-dramatic-at-points score. There is a scene in the beginning of the film where Commodus and his father discuss the future of Rome. It entails Commodus communicating great frustration to his father through an emotional out-pour. The scene is acted adequately, but the music is laughably out of place and you feel like laughing at Commodus rather than understanding his plight. Aside from that, and a rather weak ending, Gladiator is, by all means, a must see. It runs over older sword and sandal epics with a 4-horse chariot (ok, that was pretty lame...forgive me).

title: If you see just one movie this summer see Gladiator
review: I saw Gladiator last night and I felt that it was one of the best and most interesting epics I have seen in a very long time.  The movie has something for everyone. If you liked Braveheart, you'll love Gladiator.  I think that this movie has everything....great action and battle scenes.  There hasn't been a roman epic like this since Ben Hur and as we all know, Ben Hur is the record holder for most Academy Awards won.

title: Most enjoyable - Ridley Scott has made a great comeback
review:
After some dissapointments (G.I. Jane wasn't to great, and White Squall was lacking at the end) I'm glad to say Ridley Scott is back in his game. I was looking forward to this film for awhile, it looked to be an impressive piece of cinema and plus, it had Russel Crowe in it. After a few months of waiting for it to come to theaters, I was it opening day with a sold out crowd. Everyone in the theater seemed to have really enjoyed it. Some thought it was to long (drags a lil at the beginning), some thought it was to violent (guess they haven't seen Braveheart), but most of us thought it was excellent.

I'm not gonna give anything away in this review like many have already done. I must say Ridley Scott hasn't had beautiful shots like this since Legend. The cinemtography really pulls you into the story - Rome has never looked this stunning. The acting was oustanding on all counts, everyone was very well casted. Above all, what hit me most about this movie wasn't the cinematography, nor the directing, nor the storyline. It was Russel Crowe. This guy proves himself that he is the Marlon Brando of the new generation. He's wonderful as Maximus, some of the weakest lines in the film he makes them sound amazing. I can only hope him and Edward Nortan, another actor who's amazing, will make a movie sometime together.

As for my dislikes of the movie - the editing. It's nice to see that a lot of people agree about how similar this is to Braveheart. Mel Gibson and Ridley Scott are very different directors and Scott approached this as an in your face kind of thing. For many scenes it dosen't bother you, but the opening battle and the first gladiator battle are very hard to follow because of this. I wish some of the action scenes lasted longer than they did, although the battles in Rome are oustanding. I wish I could have been able to tell what was going on a lot easier in the opening battle (the start of it as thousands of arrows fly through the air is magnificent) since everything happens very fast.

Overall though I expect this to be one of the biggest hits of the summer. Maybe not in profit, but it has already made it on the top 250 so it seems most people love it. This movie will make Russel Crowe standout soon enough as another 20 million dollar actor, and he deserves it more than anyone. If you have the time, and the taste for a good action/drama, see Gladiator. 9/10

title: Fantastic Movie!
review: I really enjoyed the movie.  The Special Effects were fantastic.  The action was gripping, finally was neat to see just how bloody those gladiator fights were.  Oliver Reed and Richard Harris turned in fine performances as well. I cannot wait to see this one again.  I will also get this on DVD. Great Summer Movie!!!

title: A wonderful movie that's about something important!
review:
What can I say, the acting, directing, writing--all hit the mark. Special effects work, but who cares? This is a movie about people and relationships and you really really care what happens. When was the last time a movie made you think about integrity and loyalty and doing the right thing, no matter how much it hurts?

If I were a moveimaker, I would pray that all my movies would star Russel Crowe. And be directed by Ridley Scott. This is heaven (or Elysium) indeed.

title: Long time coming...
review: Wonderful movie, so much in fact it actually prompted me to get out and pay the ridiculous prices for movies these days (we have a dollar house here in Erie that plays month old movies).  I thought it was a very 'thick' story line in which all of the characters held their own -very strong cast. Wonderful job on the special affects (sp?) and costume.  I was pulled in... A must see! 9 out of 10

title: An all time classic in the making
review: This film is undoubtedly the best film of the year, and has to be in the all time top 20. For me it had everything. Russell Crowe is just brilliant and puts in another oscar winning performance. This man can't put a foot wrong at the moment following his huge success in The Insider, although it took me a while to realise it was him as i am sure it will you. A good comeback also by Ridley Scott, who directed it well after a disappointing and not such a great effort with G I Jane. I just couldn't get enough of this film. It wasn't too long or too short, but i can see why the female of the species may not take a liking to it, as there was vast amounts of violence and blood which for me made it better, along with a terrific story line and a heart warming end. I recommend you seeing it but can't guarentee you'll like it as much as i did.

title: an absolutely great movie, an epic with style and the guts to do as it pleases
review:
alright, when i first saw Gladiator all i could say was wow. that movie was the best i've seen in a while. i see a lot of movies, most i must say are decent at best. its only once in awhile where i see a FILM. this is what Gladiator was. after seeing it i cant get it out of my mind. everytime i see a trailor for it i get butterflys in my stomach. most movies that i enjoy are forgetable. not this one, i remember every detail, and thats something considering the vastness of the film. every single scene had power. each was a punch to the groin or a passionate brush on the heart. the characters, while archetypical, were all well rounded. Crowe delivers an awesome performance, worthy of super-star status. in my opinion the up and coming actor should be on the pay roll with Gibson, Cruise and Carrey.

Soem people will complain about the violence. i think that the movie was very violent, but unlike a cheesy slasher film, the violence was tasteful. Like other Dreamworks titles (SPR mainly), the graphic content of Gladiator only added to the power and omnipotence of this piece.

While the idea of a Gladiator movie went out with the battle fires in Sparticus, Scott is daring enough to tackle the epic idea and, while retaining a confident, historic style, the director uses all of todays extras to really bolster the film. while on the topic of speicial effects, i thought they were grand. the stadium, half real half CGI is seamless. any loss of detail wouldn't be noticed because, while watching, your full attention is focused on the characters. lastly, at 1 hour 50 minutes, the movie may seem too grandiose for the fair-weather movie goer. however, you never even feel like its almost thre hours. not at any point in the film can you have time to look at your watch and say "damn, when is this gonna be done?" all i have to say is that Gladiator was an great movie by a stellar director staring a soon-to-be huge actor. you MUST see this film.

title: A grand movie that can only be considered as a "must see".
review:
From the grand battle at the beginning to the final fight at the end, there are 2 1/2 hours of glamorous screenplay and some of the best acting to be seen this year. Russell Crowe as Maximus, Connie Nielson as Lucilla, Oliver Reed as Proximo, Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius, and a host of other supporting actors.

And the top actors are needed as this is a screenplay written by a team, and it lacks a unified vision. Small production errors, like Lucilla wearing a bra, detract from the authenticity. Will the audience care? When character arcs reverse without cause, will anyone notice? There is so much action, and even a weepy scene at the end, perhaps they will not care.

Well worth seeing for what is good, but not for people with faint hearts. This is an action movie, and the violence is sometimes overwhelming, and the cinematic style taken too far. But worthy of a viewing all the same.

title: What, is it autumn already?
review:
"Gladiator" is being hyped as the first blockbuster of the summer movie season, which is rather strange, as it hardly exudes what could be described as a summery feeling. Ridley Scott's sword-clanging historical drama boasts plenty of July-style blood and thunder, but it's powered by a dark, brooding emotional tone that makes it feel more like a serious October release than like summer popcorn fun.

Set in 180 A.D., the film centers around Maximus (Russell Crowe), a powerful Roman general in the army of Caesar Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), who plans to give Maximus control of Rome upon his death so the great city's long-dead republican government may be restored. This infuriates Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), Aurelius' actual son, so he kills his father, as well as Maximus' family, and plans to have the general executed. Maximus escapes, but is caught by slave traders and sold to Proximo (the late Oliver Reed), who trains the former military man as a gladiator. Maximus, not surprisingly, is a prodigious fighter, and he and his fellow gladiators are called to Rome...where Commodus Caesar has ordered five months of games in honor of his dead father. Revenge (along with severed limbs) is soon heavy in the air.

This is a more intricate story than is common for popcorn cinema, and admittedly, it is handled fairly well. However, the story is essentially a framework for some impressive set pieces. I have always considered Ridley Scott a director of primarily visual gifts (his "Blade Runner", my all-time favorite science fiction film, is one of the very rare pictures where visual quality and subtext bear more weight than the plot itself), and here he delivers an immense and intriguing Rome which is always eye-catching and enjoyable to see. Cinematographer John Mathieson, production designer Arthur Max, and costume designer Janty Yates position themselves as early 2001 Oscar favorites with their work here. Unfortunately, the visual impression is marred somewhat by a few instances of ham-fisted editing, as well as a Hans Zimmer / Lisa Gerrard score which is frequently intrusive and ill-suited to the action onscreen.

There are many people, of course, who will be seeing "Gladiator" primarily for the arena battle sequences. Be warned: this is not your typical Teflon action stuff. Though visually striking, these scenes are shockingly gory and gruesome, and are not much fun to watch at all. Anyone who thinks boxing is too barbaric should watch this film, a record of an time in our history when cold-blooded murder was served up as public entertainment.

The screenplay, by David Franzoni, William Nicholson, and John Logan (who tackled modern-day gladiators of a different sort with his football epic "Any Given Sunday"), does not improve on the dialogue of such sword-and-sandal forbears as "Ben-Hur" and "Spartacus"; the characters still express themselves with the same sort of Shakespeare Cliffs Notes verbal style. Fortunately, Scott's cast can out-act an army of Charlton Hestons. Harris and Reed are entertaining in their roles, and Djimon Hounsou exudes his typical effortless menacing charisma as one of Maximus' gladiatorial comrades. Among the supporting cast, Joaquin Phoenix is the major standout, making Commodus a perverted, cowardly man cursed to doom by a herculean inferiority complex. This is not a villain you'll love to hate. You'll just hate him.

Russell Crowe continues to impress as an actor, following his nervous, conflicted whistle blower in "The Insider" (a role which deservedly won him an Oscar nomination) with a convincing and nuanced portrayal of a man of principles trapped in a world of death-for-profit. He is commanding in the action sequences (I wouldn't want him coming at me with a sword) and enough of an actor to convey the strong, direct emotions that customarily drive a narrative of this type. It's nice that Hollywood has wised up to the usefulness of real ACTORS in these types of roles; picture Jean-Claude Van Damme as Maximus if you don't believe me.

I wouldn't exactly call it anyone's idea of summertime fun, "Gladiator" is nevertheless an interesting and well-made film which provides a fair share of good, if not always rousing, entertainment.

title: Like a nice, slightly ill-fitting suit
review: I liked this movie: it had good action, some intrigue, the sets were beautiful, etc. However, it suffered from a few editing problems. For instance, the scene when the senator advises Commodus to imitate the sea-snake: why? Nothing comes of it. Was there a piece of story line that fell to the cutting-room floor? Visual mis-edits abound: gladiators in a tortoise in the center of the arena, then a scene of milling shields, then a faraway scene of the tortoise again. I found it distracting. Overall, I enjoyed the movie, but it left me feeling like I bought a nice suit that doesn't fit quite right. Having seen Ridley Scott's Director's Cut of Blade Runner, and finding it superior to the original, I wonder how satisfied he is with Gladiator as it plays in the theaters now.

title: Action ... and a story, too!
review:
"Gladiator" is a good movie without being a great movie. It's not that it had any huge flaws in it, it's just that it never built upon itself. Instead of getting more and more powerful with each battle and each scene of intrigue, the film just resets itself to its previous level. This effort to keep itself in check is what kept the movie from being "great."

It started with a great battle and, like I said, just cruised along after that. It had no grand climax, just a quiet ending.

The story is intriguing -- a tale of treachery, revenge and triumph -- though I'm told it was lifted from "The Fall of the Roman Empire."

Technically speaking, "Gladiator" is intriguing. Here's why:

>>>Unlike Roger Ebert, who criticized it's muddy tones, I thought the use of two major colors -- blue and brown -- was impressive. It helped bring it together thematicly if you think of it. Blue for the sinister politics and brown for the Maximus' battles.

>>>Another interesting thing was the use of snakes. Just before some of key gladiatorial battles in the film, they always showed people playing and taunting snakes. Perhaps it was director Ridley Scott's way of saying if you mess with Maximus, you get bit.

>>>Particularly pleasing is that Christianity or Judeaism wasn't in the film at all. Why? Because every other film I've seen like this makes a point to show that it was the hero's religion that made them the good guy. In fact, "Gladiator" goes out of its way to show Roman/Greek religion as it was truly embraced by the Romans. It was a nice touch.

And finally one minor criticism: A recent cliche that has surfaced in movies about ancient times is that the villain is always considered sexually deviant. He's a homosexual. He's in love with his mother. He wants to sleep with his sister. He's a sadist.

Why is this? Isn't killing people in cold blood a good enough reason to be a villain? Why do the writers have to continue their "character development" into the sex thing?

May 9, 2000

title: Beautiful
review: How can a movie full of testosterone be beautiful? Come see this one and you will know. Yes, there are many R-rated scenes which are really bloody. However, there are many other scenes that make this movie artistic. That's why I feel beautiful about it.

title: The best movie ever!!
review: This movie was possibly the best movie made in a long time. It has everything, action, drama, romance, everything. Will keep you in your seats from beginning to end. Russell Crowe gives an excellent performance as well as the rest of the cast. A MUST SEE!!!!

title: Major disappointment
review: When I first heard about this movie, I was excited to say the least. Intense gladiator fighting set to the backdrop of the Roman Empire...AND Russell Crowe? An offer I couldn't refuse. So, I went to see and well, to say the least, it was pitiful. The plot was okay but there was far too much of it. Not to say that I was hoping for all bloody battles but it would have been nice to have seen more considering that the movie is about fighting. The acting was okay, Crowe pulls in a fairly good performance but Phoenix as some character whose name I can't remember is the real star of the movie putting in a brilliant performance as Rome's new emperor. (Saying anything else would ruin plot).  But, I think that this movie did have promise. Perhaps I should have waited for it to come out on tape...

title: I really liked this one.
review:
Well, first off, this movie is NOT a historical account, but rather historical fiction set against the backdrop of historical events (compare with A Tale of Two Cities - the story itself is not historical, but the setting takes place at a specific point in history (the French Revolution)). However, the Emperors Marcus Aurelius, who ruled from 161-80 AD, and Commodus, who ruled from 180-92 AD, are both historical figures.

What I liked most about this movie was that it gave a glimpse into what the glory that was Rome must have been like. We see through the character of Commodus how devious and really messed up most of the Emperors of Rome must have been (Caligula, Nero, to name a few), and we get to see that it was a very violent and bloody period in human history. But then, the same can be said for any other period in history when war or conquest played a major factor (Spanish conquest of the Americas, the American Civil War...and so on).

All this to say, so what if the movie is full of historical flaws? Who cares if certain characters did not really exist? People will always nitpick at things without taking the time to just sit back and make a paradigm shift and look at a movie like this from another angle. And for me, that means that the essence of that period in human history was captured and portrayed accurately. If you want to get any more accurate, then go to a library and read a book on Roman history. But for the space of time that was given for the movie, it was a job well done.

There was another review that questioned the existence of glass in Roman times. The setting of the movie is 180 AD, there have been archaeological finds of glass artifacts which date much farther back than that.

I recommend this movie. Even if it may be a cliff note version of history as told through the life of a fictional character.

I give this one a 9 out of 10.

title: Visually Stunning
review: Gladiator may be the best looking movie I've ever seen. The visual effects are simply amazing. Granted, some of the dialogue is overdone in parts, but if you allow yourself to get lost in the moment, it just doesn't matter. The fight scenes were very well done, having the sense of being while still being able to know what was going on. All the actors give fine performances, but it is the visual appeal that really makes this movie.

title: Eye-catching
review:
I have seen Glad twice in 24 hours. After the second viewing, I think I put my finger on the why the film falls short. It is clear that Ridley Scott's forte is the scene with big sets and hundreds of extras. They were, by far, the most fun moments of the film. By contrast any of the dialogue-driven or one-on-one character scenes felt uncomfortable and forced.

The script also falls short because there is no equally brooding and compelling character to challenge Russell Crowe. The most we get is an emperor who we find out is scared to be alone in the dark (Oh Dear!!) This is extremely weak characterization especially with Derek Jacobi whose presence reminds us, from the I Claudius series, how wicked and tyrannical a Roman emperor can be.

title: excellent - what can i say?
review: I knew this movie was incredibly hyped, and I knew it was going to live up to its initial buzz.  It definitely did, but I would have to say I am biased to this historical period.  However, in comparison to Spartacus and Ben-Hur I think this is a better movie - that's just my opinion.  I came in expecting a lot more Gladiator action, but was a tad disappointed by how much I got.  However the action scenes that were present were spectacular and brutally violent.  The plot drags a bit, but it can be overlooked because of Russell Crowe - he holds it all together.  Definitely a must see.

title: A Truly Captivating Experience.
review: Gladiator left me absolutely speechless, it is one of the finest films since the reminiscent days of Ben Hur and Spartacus.  The opening sequence of this epic, featured a realistic display of the battles that occurred during the time of Roman rule.  Ridley Scott's story of the General turned slave turned gladiator-- turned HERO, is truly captivating. The cinematography was seamless, the computer generated Roman Empire ie colosseum was so real, it was like you were there, while the action sequences were "out-of-your-seat" exhilarating.  Russell Crowe's (Maximus) performance, as usual was brilliant, showing he has the ability to add depth to all the character's inwhich he plays (ie The Insider, LA Confidential, The Gladiator). Crowe's presence is felt from start to finish.  As the evil and mad-hatter Caesar, Joaquin Phoenix  plays Commodus the Son of Marcus Aurelius perfectly. Though all three, Crowe, Phoenix, and Nielson (as Lucilla) bring together this epic to make this a truly spellbinding experience. Missing out on two Academy Awards for LA Confidential and The Insider (though much deserved), Crowe hopefully should see a look in for this years nominations -- if not, there must be something seriously wrong.  This is definitely a BIG-SCREEN experience, a must see.  I give it 10/10. Keep up the truly great performances Russell!

title: I loved this movie!
review:
After reading some of the other reviews found here, it appears that you either get this movie, or you don't. Well, I did in a big way, and I feel sorry for those who didn't.

The details have been explained in detail in other reviews, so I won't bother with that. Suffice it to say that I was completely absorbed in this movie, primarily due to Russell Crowe's performance. Crowe is rapidly becoming my favorite actor, and he plays this role perfectly. Others have commented negatively about the historical accuracy, and long running time, but I never noticed, and really did not want this movie to end.

Do yourself a big favor and GO SEE THIS MOVIE!! Unless you're dead set on being critical, or determined not to get it, then stay away so I can have a better seat to see it again.

title: First disappointment of 2000(oh wait... that was Scream3)
review:
Well, at least for the 2000 this is my first thumbs down of the summer.

I hate to use a big critic as a reference but Roger Ebert was right on the money with this one. Too much of Rome looked like Naboo in Phantom Menace. Except I'm more forgiving of Lucas filming a place that doesn't exist. I know, I know Rome is pretty much history but don't even get me started on the historical inaccuracies.

I'll keep this short. Actions sequences are hard to get into because of all the cheap slo-mo(for great slo-mo see john woo's MI-2) AND they don't make much sense. Case in point: there's a battle with like, five dudes all heavily armed against Maximus. When Maxumus defeated the last one(slicing his head off) the guy behind me was like "YEAHHHHHHHH!!!" I'm like, "Oh yeah...it's real hard to kill them if they attack you ONE AT A TIME!" Bogus. The tiger scene, some cool trap doors but nothing speacial.

Most of all, there's really not much of a story. Basically, after a pretty good setup, Maximus is pretty much on this big revenge thing. And that's it. Period.

Keeping it simple? Sure but with a running time over 2 1/2 hours I'd like some more story thank you.

The bad guy: Commadus(SP?) Who cares? He's a whimp with hints of sexual feeling for his sister. Perverted? Sure, but not in the Caligula over-the-edge way. It's more like, we need something terrible about him. I know he's in love with his sister! stupid.

Positives, the opening is nice and dark. Moody to the core. The battle in the opening is decent thought not great. And the first Collesium(SP?) fight is clever. Russell Crowe does what he can with what I've already stated is pretty 2 dimensional.

Again, a major disappointment.

Overall ** mediocre.

title: One of the best movies of the year !!!
review: I went to see this for no reason. I was bored and just got up and made it my choice to see this. I am EXTREMELY happy that I saw this. The movie is by far THE best movie that I have seen this year. Do NOT, I repeat DO NOT let the marketing fool you into thinking this is just some hack em'/slash em' movie. The Marketing for Fight Club, Three Kings, and The Iron Giant killed those movies. Don't let the same happen to this instant classic. The movie itself is beautifully shot, almost as if any one shot could be placed above a mantle. The acting is done perfectly, although most of the credit goes to Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix performed greatly with what little material he had to work with. Last, but not least, some people might complain about how the battle scenes are too hard to understand. The point of the battles were not to entertain, but rather to show how a real battle is like. Your friend and mine, this is Teenratboy signing off.

title: It was pretty good, with only a few flaws.
review:
This is one of the best movies I have seen in a while, it has everything too (Good story, pretty good dialoge, good acting, superb visuals, pretty good physics, and plenty of gore). The characters all had pretty good backstories, and you never really knew what was going to happen.

But I did see a few mistakes...one at the begining, at the battle scene, before anyone had even shot an arrow or swung a sword, they show a close up of the barbarians and they have arrows all around them. Another mistake were the Tigers...now I know I couldn't have been the only one to notice this, but if they were so vicious and so mean why does it show them laying down after he let that other guy live? And another thing wrong with the tigers was that they were on chains held by slaves, now after a while wouldn't you think the tigers would realize that they could go get the slaves?! Hum...I'm not that looks for every error in a movie, but these stood out big time.

Hehe, im getting all off subject here, but this really was a great movie and like I said it have everything and the characters stick in your head, it also had one of the best endings I've seen in my opinion.

Final rating: 9/10

title: I'd like to thank the academy...
review:
This is a serious piece of cinema on the kind of grand scale that makes its ancestors like Spartacus and Ben Hur mighty proud. Let's not waste any time with the other summer (winter, or fall for that matter) dreck and hand out the 2001 academy awards now. Yes, it's that good.

Best Screenplay - Sure. Riveting plot, well executed. A heroic fable in every sense of the word. Acting - Hell yes. Russell Crowe perhaps for Best Actor, but particularly Joaquin Phoenix for his unnerving portrayal of the mad Commodus. Truly an inspired piece of casting. Best Set Design - How can you beat the glory of 'Rome' at it's height. Best Costumes - By far the most beautiful works of art I've seen in a long while. The general's chest piece has got this amazing wolf fur attached to the shoulder pads. The Emperor is absolutely stunning in his intricate vestments. Best Director - Sure, Ridley Scott deserves it, not only for this but also for his early works like Blade Runner, etc. Best Visual Effects - Yep. Best Sound - You will be in the Coliseum. Don't dare see it at any theater but a THX venue. (Sounds a bit silly, but you know what? If you are shelling out 10 bucks a ticket then you should at least get the best sound for your money.) Best Cinematography - This is where the film really shines. Ancient Rome, The Coliseum, thousands of extra's clashing in classic epic battle sequences. Lions and Tigers, ohh My! The gladiator combat sequences make WWF 'matches' look like minor disagreements. It isn't all Gladiator battles though. Long sweeping shots of breathtaking panorama's pervade this incredible film. Best Editing - No one really cares about this award anyway, but since we are in a giving mood. Best Picture - Nothing will be its equal this year.

title: high on style, low on substance
review:
The first half of this movie you can throw in the garbage, it's slow moving and well, flat out boring. It's the second half where the interesting stuff starts to happpen. Even the acting gets noticeably better the farther into the film we go; it's almost as if the cast is getting better as they go along - although, russel crowe was good throughout (but you'd expect that much.) Basically, the core components at work in this film are its _fight_ scenes, which range from ok to pretty good, but the direction often gets on ones nerves - the camera never really holds on to any one image for more than a split second and instead switches or flashes all over the places and what we get are dozens of little stabs and jabs, flipped quickly in front of us like cheap cartoons drawn on a deck of cards. The overall plot was also very predictable. You could see things coming at you a mile away and then cringed when the characters acted so surprised to learn the news. As I say, the last half is the films saving grace and even that could be stripped down to a much shorter version of the key gladiator fight scenes.

The best thing I can say about this film is its cinematography and the Roman backdrops are very cool. Otherwise, the film is an overhyped, predictable soap opera, with some good fight scenes filled in with a whole lot of pretty filler.

title: Intense is too mild a word for this movie.
review:
I went into this movie with the realization that there would be no middle ground. It would either be amazing or horrible. I was right.

This movie borders on the epic. Russell Crowe was expertly cast as General Maximus. Joaquin Phoenix turns in an excellent performance as the emperor you love to hate, Commodus. The supporting cast, including the late Oliver Reed as Proximo are outstanding. The sets, costumes and armor are incredibly detailed.

Go see this movie on the biggest screen you can find. The opening battle sequence alone is worth the price of admission.

A word of caution: This movie is not for the squeamish or the young. It is gory, as befits a movie with this subject matter.

title: It Coulda been a Contendah!
review:
Overhyped!

Gladiator is perhaps the most frustrating movie that I have ever seen. Expecting either an action-adventure popcorn movie, or Braveheart 2 I sat down with baited breath. However, the opening battle scene was completely uninteresting except for the special effects firepower. Then the movie slinks into a long series of poorly written scenes that serve no thematic purpose (no matter how much they pretend to) but are only there to forward the plot. I was almost entering REM sleep when the movie shocked me awake with something very strange, a well-written scene. Once Crowe is sold into slavery, we finally get some movie magic working. Oliver Reed and Djimon Honsou enter with well written characters and powerful screen presences. Strangeley Crowe's, Phoenix's, and Nielson's characters suddenly become more interesting as does the plot. The battles begin to have meaning, as does every word. I exstatically awaited the ending... only to see the writing go back to hell and end in a poorly handled, overly simplitic, and flat out bad ending. In 3 hours I saw a bad pseudo-epic turn into the next braveheart, only to give way to an ending only found in a bad action movie. The acting is fine, Crowe is a commanding screen presence and can bring dignity even the most horrible of lines. Reed's performance is gripping and wonderful, as is honsou in a very small role. Nielson is dignified and beautiful, Phoenix's characterization oscillates as much as his role does, but he is effectively complex and twisted. Unfortunately they were all wasted on a Great script wrapped in a horrible beginning and ending. It's worth a peek, but it should not be an Oscar contender.

title: "Veni, Vidi, Vici."
review: Gaius Julius Caesar said this famous quote after conquering all opposing civilizations.  And indeed the movie opens with a excellent battle scene depicting the organized Roman Legions versus the Barbaric Germans.  A battle scene which will take its place next to other great movie battle scenes (i.e. - Braveheart, Private Ryan, Glory, etc...)  The movie follows the rise and fall of Marcus Aurelius' (Caesar-Richard Harris) Greatest General Maximus Meridas (Russell Crowe) and then his rerise to power as not a general but a Gladiator fighting for his life in the Brutally Violent Colliseums of Rome.  While the movie is not historically accurate as far as story goes (the film never states its factual anyhow) its still a great piece of work by director Ridley Scott (Blade Runner).  Great musical score, cinematography, battle scenes and supporting cast.  Djimon Hounsou and Ralph Moeller are fun to watch as Gladiators and Joaquin Phoenix is fun to watch (and laugh at) as Marcus Aurelius' son.  Highly recommended for all fans of Battle Epic Movies.

title: Superb sumptuous sweeping epic
review:
I think this might just be Ridley Scott's best yet.

The story is good, not great, but it's just so well told and in such bold charismatic tones, that you can't help but admire it. Lots of political intrigue, a fair sprinkling of human dignity, much savagery and of course Scott's familiar brooding cinematography.

Crowe has just got this swagger about him, that you would for kill for. All the actors are intoxicating to watch.

Yeah, sure, it's a little cheesy and drawn out in places, but still easily the best movie of the year.

Go see.

title: Restless because of Maximus
review:
I saw "Gladiator" at the late show and then went home and tried to get a good night's sleep. Forget it. First of all, this movie is an adrenaline pump for impressionable viewers. Maximus's world is full of danger through the whole film and the viewer shares those fears and thrills, the battles, the gladiator bouts, the secret conspirings. Secondly, this movie fills your heart with sadness and you are drained and upset when you walk out of there.

DON'T try tell anyone that this movie lacks emotion....give me a break! Not since "Braveheart" have I had such a love of a main character.
