This dude is a hero in the true sense of the word, totally fearless and driven to achieve his goals no matter what. Russell Crowe plays him with a modest, almost shy demeanor that is very engaging, considering the character's physical attributes and skills.

The photography is spectacular. The long sweeps of scenery (again reminiscent of the scenes of Scotland in "Braveheart") are breathtaking and the depiction of life during those times and especially what Rome was like was one of the best aspects of the movie.

I gave this a 9 out of 10, only because some of the dialogue was a little lame and the acting was OK across the board, but not brilliant. GO SEE IT!

title: The first Epic picture of the new Century - A MUST see
review:
I took my 11 year old daughter to this picture and both of us were speechless after it was over.You MUST see this on the big screen.. It will lose so much on a tiny TV when it is out on video!

This movie is Star Wars ..with real people.. in a galaxy near near and a time not so long ago. The audience (very sparse I might add) applauded wildly at the end of this picture.

My daughter said she liked it because she likes blood & gore (and there is a LOT of it).. but that is the way history paints these times. She did not grasp all the dialogue (you need to know a little about Roman times).. and was a little bored in the beginning.... but the plot grabbed her and after she refused to leave her seat even to get up to get a soda refill for fear she might miss something... Unusual!

The acting superb, script, action.. This movie is SO big you do have to see it twice..as I will... the second time to just sit back and relax.. and enjoy a first rate piece of movie making.... 9 stars out of 10...

title: It's no Ben Hur, but not bad.
review: The beginning of this movie really had me worried. I'm used to gladiator type films being lavish, with warm earth tones, lots of red cloaks and reddish dirt and dust kicked up by horses' hooves. This is really dark and blue, and the MTV style editing and grainy film stock make the battle sequences obscure and confusing. I'm also used to Charleston Heston or Kirk Douglas bellowing to his comrades, leading them to heroic acts of vengeance. Russell Crowe is much more subdued, I'm not saying that's bad, he does a remarkable job and is the best part of the film. Once I got used to the stark contrasts and the story gathered momentum I began to enjoy the film much more. It was also the first time The Coliseum was filmed historically accurate, complete with the overhead shades.

title: And the Oscar Goes To......
review: WOW! What an incredible movie.  Tremendously rich in character development. The score by Hans Zimmer and the Cinematography was incredible.  YOU MUST SEE THIS MOVIE.  BEST PICTURE OF THE YEAR, NO DOUBT.  This nearly 3 hour EPIC captured your interest from the first scene and held you captive with wonder and suspense throughout the entire movie.  Joaquin Phoenix and Russell Crowe deserve OSCAR nominations for their performance.  WOW, WOW, WOW.  I LOVED THIS MOVIE.

title: Brilliant epic
review:
I saw an advance screening of Gladiator and was for the most part blown away. Russel Crowe's versatility radiates in this picture, compared with The Insider. He is the ulitmate Roman hero, vanquished by political enemies. His challenge will not only be to survive his predicament, but to restore the values, hopes and dreams of a forlorn nation torn by greed, economics, and evil.

The cinematography is awesome- Kurosawa-esque in it's grandeur, magnatude, and graceful treatment of the action. There are many smaller hand to hand encounters that are also exciting.

The true power of this film lies in the brilliant performances of Crowe as a magnetic hero, and Joaquin Phoenix as the tortured heir of the Roman kindgom.

title: A hero, denied his rightful reward, is cast out of society, and makes his way back to his rightful place.
review: The Roman Empire is back, in all its glory and filth.  The plot is simple and mythic:  A hero is denied his rightful reward, is cast out of society, and makes his way back to his rightful place.  Russell Crowe's Maximum oozes honor and dignity, even when all he knows is destroyed around him. Joaquin Phoenix's Commodus is his antithesis -- an insecure, scared, and malevolent ruler.  You know good will triumph in the end (it always does in such blockbuster films), but the hows and wherefores are worth watching nonetheless.  Ridley Scott has created a visual masterpiece in his recreation of ancient Rome (the cityscapes reminded me, oddly, of Naboo in the Phantom Menace; surely my imagination was running overtime?). Depicting the Roman circus in all its gore (although most of the truly awful stuff is just off camera, leaving too much to the imagination), this movie deserves its R rating.  But I enjoyed it, overall.

title: Spectacular, but shallow
review:
There's no doubt that Gladiator looks great, and it's a fun movie to watch. Don't expect too much from the story though; there's nothing here that hasn't been done a hundred times (see Titus for a movie that does it better), played here in a way that was more reminiscent of professional wrestling than of Shakespeare.

They should have cut out most of the dialogue and focused on the action, for a tighter, more exciting, package.

title: great action, no heart. (SPOILERS)
review: I came into this movie hearing rave reviews about it, but afterwards, I must say I was rather disappointed. To be fair, the CGI shots of the crowds at The Colluseum were gorgeous, and the fight scenes were top notch. However Gladiator was missing something that other historical epics had, and that was emotion. In Spartacus, we see the horrible conditions that Spartacus and the slaves lived in, and we rooted for them to fight for their freedom. In Braveheart, the film spends a great deal of time developing the romance between Wallace and his wife, and when she's killed by the English, there is a greater emotional response when Wallace fights the English. There was none of that in Gladiator. Although, we see Maximus' wife and son murdered, I felt nothing, since practically no time time was spent fleshing out their relationship. And also Maximus' goal is to overthrow Commodus as emperor and bring control of the Roman Empire to the Senate. I don't know about you, but government restructuring pales in comparison to trying to topple a kingdom. By the time the movie ended, I really didn't care who won or lost. I give Gladiator a 5/10 (5 is for the special effects.)

title: A welcome return to the epic blockbuster
review:
"Gladiator" is a true tour-de-force, a satisfying, thrilling eipc that makes moviegoing fun again. I place it on a level with "Ben-Hur" and "Spartacus."

The cinematography, sound and editing (though I have a few minor complaints with the latter) were superb. The story was engrossing and the performances were first rate.

Russell Crowe is solid as the heroic Roman general who suffers at the hand of Commodus, the ambitious and ruthless emperor's son (Joaquin Pheonix). Richard Harris has a wonderful turn as the dying emperor who loves Maximus as his own. The late Oliver Reed is perfect as the slaver "businessman." But the one performance that may be overlooked in this rich masterpiece is that of Connie Nielsen as the emperor's daughter, Lucilla. Nielsen's use of expressions as well as words to convey her character's moods is excellent.

Some of the violence, though necessary, may be hard to take for the squeamish, but I thought it was not overdone, as is the case in lesser movies with violent themes.

All in all, "Gladiator" is an instant classic, a movie long overdue and one I recommend highly.

title: "Gladiator" Is A Perfect Ten
review: "Gladiator" is a film that should suit all tastes. It is expertly mounted and an eye-filling event; the blood and gore, delivered in split-second imagery (allowing your head to fill in the rest) should satisfy the most blood-thirsty movie goer; and the story is a superb tale of good vs. evil, power vs. honor, and "Might for Right". I was reminded of "Camelot" many times during this film, especially by the almost unrecognizable appearance of Richard Harris as the wise and noble Marcus Aurelis. But the sole weight of this overwhelming piece rests on the shoulders of the magnificent Russell Crowe. If one doesn't believe in him, then one doesn't believe in this epic costume drama. Kudos to the rest of the cast as well, and hand over heart for the late Oliver Reed. But back to Crowe--he is an actor to contend with. My one worry is that this film will reinvent him from "gifted actor" to the next "Hollywood Hunk". I've watched other mercurial, vastly talented actors, like Mel Gilbson and Alec Baldwin, sell out to beefcake roles, and I'm praying Crowe doesn't fall under the same spell. Although his work in "Gladiator" is a tour de force performance, he very nearly sprays testosterone from the screen. It's what was exactly demanded from him in this role, and he exceeded expectations in that regard. My hope is that he continues adding to his extraordinary body of work, rather than "selling out". Take my word for it, he'll be the next "Mel Gibson/Alec Baldwin/"People" Magazine's Sexiest Man on Earth if he isn't careful. Want to take a trip along side a great actor? Watch "The Sum of Us", or even "The Insider", and then immediately go out to see "Gladiator". In all cases you'll witness a great actor doing his job extremely well.

title: A historical epic of such proportions unseen since Spielberg's 'Amistad'
review:
Gladiator is an extremely well done, though flawed, epic that is very deserving of it's box office success. Ridley Scott's best film since Alien is a terrific blend of action, drama, and worldwide appeal that is sure to make Russell Crowe a star.

Much of the film is wonderfully entertaining, one of the best films yet this year, but somehow I don't think it lived up to the praise it's getting from critics and audiences alike. Nearly every scene in 'Gladiator' is overly stylized, with Scott going way too far overboard with the camera effects, fast cuts, camera movement, and over baked atmospheres. Still, in the era of technology this is becoming more and more common, especially in films made by Dreamworks. Because of this the film is strangely devoid of any sort of emotion, even with the deaths being one of the main aspects of the story.

The other problem I had with 'Gladiator' was the opening scene, which had Maximus (Crowe) and his army fighting a group that opposed the Roman rule. The scene (though it set a good pace for the rest to follow) had absolutely nothing to do with the central story, and was never explained or even referred to later on.

Still, it commands first rate performances from Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix (Return to Paradise), and Scott handles it quite well. The music by Hans Zimmer is also outstanding, though it ends up sounding a lot like his score for the recent 'The Thin Red Line'. The movie should not be missed, and the giant budget allows it to rise above the mediocrity that plagued several recent epics attempting to emulate 'Titanic'. Dreamworks deserves a hit, and they're getting one here.

7.5/10

title: Maximus Rules!
review:
Combining elements pioneered in "Blade Runner" with battle scenes depicted in a way reminiscent of "Saving Private Ryan", director Ridley Scott has successfully revived the long dead genre of movies about ancient Rome. Yes, there have been attempts to cinematically resurrect Rome since the epics of the 50s and early 60s, but none have come close to the historic-artistic integration that Scott has pulled off in "Gladiator". This movie is so beautiful, that a slide show of selected stills could stand on its own as a work of art.

An excellent cast is headed by Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix, the latter being the first actor to succeed at portraying one of the "bad" Roman emperors as something more than a one-dimensional villain. Even evil Emperors deserve better depiction than Hollywood has given them over the years. Connie Nielsen, absolutely ravishing in Roman finery, also carries her role very well. Richard Harris, as Marcus Aurelius, is so good that he really does look like a dying man (I sure hope it's just good acting and makeup!), and of course, it's always great to see Derek Jacobi in a show about ancient Rome. Oliver Reed was excellent in his last film; he will be missed.

I predict that "Gladiator" will catalyze a revival of public interest in ancient Rome, which is a long time coming. I hope also that this film heralds a renaissance in Ridley Scott's career. It had been way too long since "Alien" and "Blade Runner".

title: Ridley Scott is back...!!!
review:
After a few sleeper hits and a few bombs (speaking from a box office point of view) Ridley Scott is well back on form with Gladiator. This is not, as some people might think, a no brain action flick. It actually has a story and the gladiator fights, which are superbly done by the way, don't play as big a part in the movie as you might think. All of Scotts visual flare is still very much apparant and adds some great atmosphere to the movie as do the CGI panoramas of the cities of Rome. The opening battle is breathtaking and actually shows what it's like in the roman trenches as it were, before a battle. Something you don't often see in a roman type movie. All the acting is brilliant especially Russel Crowe who deserves to go places and of course Oliver Reed and although he died during filming you really can't see the join were they filled in with computer graphics.

The musical score is also excellent and very emotive. Running a 150 minutes this movie asks a lot of your time but you wont be dissapointed.

title: Strong story and a bit of historical fiction
review: This was a strong movie.  It held my attention and kept a quick pace, building a few characters and spicing things up with admirable special effects. Although it is not based too strongly in historical fact, most people will not figure that out unless they do some research on Roman Emperors.

title: The first true epic in a while
review:
Wow.

I went into this film pretty sure I would hate it. Wow. I was pretty impressed. It has been a long time since I have seen a film that had an epic feel to it in the same way that Lawrence of Arabia or Ben Hur did.. Not that it is a perfect film or anything. It is great escapism. Russell Crowe is fantastic - MAXIMUS. How can you go wrong with Ancient Rome and all those great latin names?

The art direction was very good - thank god they covered the actors in dirt. It always sucks to see clean and pristine 20th century actors portraying characters from the middle ages or ancient times.

I thought also that this was one of the first big budget films to really pull off using some surreal effects. Often they stick out like a sore thumb, but I felt they were very effective in this film.

The only problem I had with the film I think was that when Maximus was taken to the desert and made a gladiator, the whole sequence of events was too short. He's taken away, he is sold into gladiator slavery, he rises to the top of the gladiators, and then he is sent back to Rome to fight for the emperor. It needed to be spread out just a little. I know it was a long film, but another few minutes in that part of the film would have done wonders.

I particularly liked the camera work during the fight sequences. Very nice.

title: A welcome return to the Roman epic!
review:
'Gladiator' has been hailed as the triumphant return to the era of the big Hollywood Roman epic and that it was to rank alongide such cinematic monuments as 'Ben Hur' and 'Spartacus'. Russell Crowe plays Roman General Maximus who leads his war-worn troops to victory in Germania only to find that his emperor has been murdered by his son, Commodus (Jacquin Phoenix). Maximus becomes a condemned man, his family is butchered and he becomes a gladiator, intent on striking revenge on the evil emperor.

'Gladiator' is an enjoyable blockbuster boasting splendid performances especially from Crowe and Phoenix. However, the action sequences are wasted through modern trickery camera effects and therefore are unsuspenseful. The computer graphics of the colosseum are impressive and the photography is visually striking.

It is great to know that this is a big summer blockbuster which is more intelligent than what we have experienced lately (remember 'Wild Wild West' last year?). It is an impressive movie, but at the same time contains no memorable moments which must mean that it can not be in the same stable as 'Ben-Hur or 'Spartacus'. It is simply unfit to untie their Roman sandals!!!!

title: The cinematic highlight of 2000
review: In Gladiator, Ridley Scott has most probably fashioned devised the cinematic highlight of the year and revived the beloved genre of Biblical/Roman epics in hi-tech, '90's style.  However, there is no Biblical references in this one and it is much darker than the classics (in particularly Spartacus) which it has been moulded around.  Like those films it is truly spectacular (special effects are at their best when you can hardly notice them) and has perfect actors playing memorable actors.  There are some truly touching scenes (especially the last one) and others are fast, furious and blood-wrenched. All in all, Gladiator is a hugely impressive film which brings an old genre back to life and gives it an added dimension.  It will probably spawn a few imitators but this original will end up a classic.

title: Awe-inspiring
review:
I was SO surprised by this movie. I saw commercials for it on tv, and just passed it off as another no-brains-all-brawn-popcorn-action flick. Not that I dont enjoy them once in a while, its just the commercials and ads and stuff didnt intrigue me, nor did it make me raise an eyebrow. BUT, my friend dragged me along to see it anyway, and I was pleasantly surprised.

I wont bore you with the plot of the film, but let me just say - this movie has brains AND brawn. Everything was nearly perfect. from the visuals, to the acting, to the filming locations - nearly everything.

The characters were interesting, which was a breath of fresh air in these types of movies.

Maximus -- dear lord, I've never cheered somebody on so loud. He 's a sympathetic figure, as well as a noble one. Russel Crowe deserves an Oscar for this.

Commodus -- did anyone else wanna rip this man's head off? Especially after that "squealed like a girl" comment... but Joaquain Phoenix created a three-demensional villain.

Lucilla -- another sympathetic figure. Connie Neilson did good with her character, a lesser actress would've made her seem like a downright wimp.

Proximo -- Oliver Reed was indeed a great actor, and I'm glad to see this was his final role.

All in all, Gladiator was a fantastic film. --But, this movie is NOT for the squeemish. The battle and arena scenes are high in gore and blood, as well as sword play. In fact, in the opening battle, I dont think I've ever seen so much blood on film.

title: The Star Wars of the Gladiator Movie.
review:
This excellent film succeeds on many levels. All of the other comments already deal with it's many attributes. But I think the film also may be ultimately seen as a beginning of an entirely new approach on historical movies from this age.

Just as Star Wars redefined how we saw futuristic films, this film may do the same for the gladiator film.

title: A Mixed Bag But Ultimately Worth Seeing
review: The Gladiator was a disappointment to me personally. I wanted the story to be more believable and I wanted to care more for the characters. This is not to say that this effort is not worth seeing. Richard Harris and Russell Crow give excellent performances. The overall look of the period was captured well however the battle scenes, while intense, were so chopped up, one would think the editor, Pietro DiGiamimo had drank too much coffee. The quick camera work along with chopped editing actually made me dizzy. A mixed bag for me but this film should  appeal to those who like epic, action thrillers. Though a bit too long, there is enough action to make it bearable.

title: If only Star Wars was half as good...
review: I just saw the movie, and I expected about two hours of good, fun entertainment, with plenty of action, breathtaking fight scenes and special effects. It certainly delivered.  But, what was surprising was that it was actually a touching movie.  Russell Crowe really shows his chops, and I actually believed that Maximus was the most noble man on earth.  Phoenix also gave a good protrayal of a very flawed man, not just a one dimensional evil villain. Last, but not least, I am in awe of Ridley Scotts expert direction, his attention to detail and extremely stylish touch.

title: An amazing journey
review:
I have seen near-perfection, and it is "Gladiator".

Others have said more eloquently what I could here, so I will not go into any detail. In summary:

Russel Crowe: The 'rising star' who deserved a little gold statue for "The Insider" had better nab one for this role. Maximus is a typical soldier - powerful presence, quiet confidence, emotional yet controlled (especially when Commodus tells him his son "squealed like a girl") and ultimately, dignified in victory.

Oliver Reed: A classic as always. We will miss his screen presence. The CGI used to recreate his face for some scenes is faultless.

Joaquin Pheonix: Develops a character we can really learn to hate. Others have said there was not enough screen time for Commodus, but I thought there was nearly too much!

Connie Neilson: Suitably whimsical as a princess in the beginning, we see her develop into a strong mother figure, discarding all for her son's safety

Fight scenes: Not the best I've seen, but they would have to come close. The first battle against the Germanian horde contrasts sharply with the gladiatorial arena. The skip frame effect serves to enhance the confusion of real battle, while the slower, more elegant shots of the arena display the game of death fought between essentially large men wearing silly hats. :)

Costume, Sets, Design: Faultless - there are more gold statues up for grabs here.

CGI for scenery: At points it was just a tiny bit fake (especially when they put birds into the frame), but overall the effect was superb.

Some people have criticised the film for not being historically accurate, but what is it you people want? Truly there is no way to satisfy some of you, and you've lost the ability to just enjoy a movie for what it is. If you want to see history, watch a documentary.

Personally, I shall be very interested to watch the Oscars next year and see if, once again, a movie gets snubbed because one of Hollywood's darlings isn't at the helm. We know Australian actors can grab the gold (Geoffrey Rush for "Shine"), but how long before we get another?

10 out of 10, but it was worth at least 12...

title: A Beautifully Realized Film
review:
We had grown used to Ridley Scott missing in action when it came to story concept, plotline and story elements. He seems to have gotten away with these shortcomings because his taste for visual aesthetics is peerless. He is one of the few working directors whose grasp of visual beauty is constant and always gratifying.

In Gladiator, we are once again surprised because the grapevine said that the script was not really finished at the start and it kept changing with more than one writer in the pot mix. Indeed, the Gladiator story is superficial and the concept as old as the hills of Rome, but one can delight in the hearing of an old song once more, finely rendered.

Unquestionably, this is a beautifully realized film. It has all the elements, atmospheric musical score and a fine lead player with a solid supporting cast. It did not get an overall excelent vote from me due to the current in-style dark lensing and film processing, apparently to look realistic or just to copy an awful dark style we first noticed on television, copied now by nearly everyone and as such will immediately lock the film into a quickly dated style as in the overuse of zoom lenses in the early 70s and similarly, with the Steadicam a few years later. Heavy style like this serves only to date a film and cut its legs. This brooding, dark style would have worked fine in the north country scenes, the Germanium campaign, but when it continues into sunny Rome and then, worst of all, becomes even darker in the depiction of the Astral Plane in the final scenes, we had to wince. The Astral Plane, for those who have been fotunate enough to visit it during meditation, if anything, is gloriously luminescent.

Here, we also bid good-bye to Oliver Reed, who died with three his scenes left undone. The scenes are not missed, but some of us will miss Reed.

This is one I will be purchasing in wide screen DVD when it comes out. Thanks to an extraordinary filmmaker and company, it is a keeper.

title: This movie rocked!!!
review: This is already the best movie of the year!!  The story, action, and acting were all great!!  If you only watch one movie this year, make it GLADIATOR!! Russell Crowe has proven that he is a versatile actor, and Joaquin Phoenix delivers a commanding performance as a ruthless emperor.

title: When In Rome...
review:
The tag line for this film is `A Hero Will Rise.' Ain't that the truth. Make no mistake, Dreamworks' promotion for Gladiator has the principle purpose of launching this guy to the top of the Hollywood A-list. `Can we get Russell Crowe?' will soon be the number one question asked in production offices across Tinseltown. Looks like filmmakers have finally found a performer who is the Real Deal as it were. I mean, the intensity of his performances evoke true toughness: you feel like you'd trust the guy with your life. Can you now or could you ever say that about Costner? Cage? Keanu? Arnold? Crowe is here to stay and puts the hero back into movie heroics.

His new film is another good story in the vein of "Braveheart"-not a bad blueprint to follow. The reservations I have about "Gladiator" all come from the familiarity of some of the scenes. The whole hero of the people' thing it's got going; the retelling of the ages-old story of the struggle against totalitarianism. Here is another one, a good one, set in a time and place we haven't seen depicted in cinema for quite some time. The film uses its height-of-the-Roman Empire setting well and delivers on the promise of action and adventure. Set in the last days of the good Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), the film takes on the familiar subject of a World Power worrying a little too much about its neighbors and not tending to its own growing problems at home.

In the opening scene, Marcus watches his powerful Roman army, led by his general and respected friend Maximus (Crowe), tear into a rebelling army of Germanic barbarians. This opening scene is a huge, loud, impressive spectacle that the movie never really tops. The Emperor would like to pass along rule of the Empire to Maximus, which comes as disturbing news to Marcus' disgraceful son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix). Commodus sees to it that his father's dying wish is not carried out, and promptly orders Maximus executed. From here on, bad things happen to Maximus and to Rome, with the evil nervous wreck Commodus behind it all.

Maximus, thought dead by the new Emperor, is sold into slavery and trained to fight in the gladiator' games, the entertainment choice of the times until they were abolished by Marcus Aurelius. Commodus, however, brings the games back. In the past, gladiators who could win over the crowds in the Colosseum would earn their freedom. Maximus has something else to fight for-revenge. Director Ridley Scott ("Alien," "Blade Runner," "Thelma and Louise," "G.I. Jane") stages the arena scenes with pure entertainment in mind, just as the real things were. The whole idea of the games was to re-enact in a way, great wars fought and won by Rome. So here is Maximus, as a gladiator, pretending to be a soldier in an army he had likely conquered as a general in real life. This is when Maximus' character really gets under our skin. A lesser person might wallow in the obvious humiliation of his situation, but Maximus doesn't. He finds every opportunity to use it for the benefit of himself and his estranged countrymen. The story is so strong that these arena scenes become simply pieces of the whole that help to propel things forward. Scott never succumbs to the temptation of showing any more brutality than is necessary.

Joaquin Phoenix creates a truly loathsome human being in Commodus. This is the kind of twitchy, insecure kid a father would keep his daughter miles away from and here he is in charge of the world's greatest empire. The casting of Phoenix; along with Connie Nielsen, Richard Harris, Derek Jacobi, Djimon Hounsou, Oliver Reed, and of course Crowe, shows that Gladiator's creators preferred substance over style.

The casting, the photography, the writing-all of these things seem to have been given great care. The result is what will probably end up being one of the year's best films.

Grade: B

title: George Lucas take note
review:
Marvelously directed and spectacularly shot, "Gladiator" is an aural and visual feast from beginning to end. But it's more than that. It's a powerfully moving story which, despite the 154 minute running time, is economically written and very simply told. I've seen it three times and it just keeps getting better.

George Lucas should see this film about three hundred times before he shoots the first frame of "Episode 2". "Gladiator" is everything his disastrous "Episode 1" should have been: a great political story with lots of sword play, that still manages to be big on family values and which, most importantly, uses special effects FOR A NARRATIVE PURPOSE and not for their own sake. From the extraordinary opening battle sequence, to the spectacular recreations of Rome - and what looks suspiciously like a digitally-resurrected Oliver Reed in one or two shots - Ridley Scott deploys the special effects with sensitivity, purpose and elan. He uses them to TELL the story. With Lucas, they ARE the story.

If I were Lucas I'd be handing over the "Episode 2" writing duties to Messrs Franzoni, Logan and Nicholson, and only keeping the director's chair warm until Mr Scott wraps on "Hannibal".

Welcome back, Ridley. You're a master.

title: I AM MAXIMUS!
review: Wow, what a stellar piece of film-making! Ridley Scott has done it again with attention to detail that won him such acclaim for BladeRunner and Alien.  This movie is lush, atmospheric, full of action (mmmmmmmm, action) and enough gore to satisfy even those who thought Saving Private Ryan didn't go far enough.  The opening twenty minutes of Galdiator should satisfy most action fans and the gladiatorial sequences are phenomenal. Even Oliver Reed, who died during production, looks good in the CGi used here! 5 out of 5!

title: EXCELLENT MOVIE!!!!
review: I can sum up the experience of Gladiator in one word, AWESOME!!!!! My friend and I went to see it recently and both of us being refined movie critics gave it two big thumbs up, if I could, I'd have voted a 11+ for Gladiator. The action sequences and the visual effects were second to none and there wasn't a point in the movie where I wasn't urning for the next scene to find out what was going to happen! It also leaves us with an important message; It shows us that if an extraordinary man such as Russel Crowe's character (the general) can be humble, kind, unselfish, and save the world (in this case Rome), than there is hope for everyone to do good in their own lives and help the world in some way. Very well done indeed overall and I'd definitely recommend this to any moviegoer looking to wisely spend 2 1/2 hours of his/her time.

title: Adrenaline pumping action but not ancient Rome
review:
I have been waiting for this movie for some time and was not disappointed. I thought that Phoenix played a great part as Commodus giving the role a certain amount of believability compared to some of the derranged depictions of Roman Emporers that have gone before. Russell Crowe also makes his character come to life holding the whole movie together. On the accuracy side the film gives a very accurate depiction of the colliseum but the other shots of Rome in the background are fanciful to say the least.

The first gladiatorial sequence gives a real feel for the total lack of value placed on human life by the Romans however I don't think the true horror of the collisseum comes through in this picture. The typical day at the colliseum was split in three with the first part of the day belonging to the beast hunts. Where up to a hundred lions, bears, bulls elephants etc would be made to fight each other and teams of besterai(beast fighters) also convicted criminals and slaves would be lead into the ring in chains, the chains would be removed and the person striped naked and forced to meet the lions etc by poding with red hot branding irons often the people would be hung from different types of contraptions to make it more difficult for the animals to get a clean kill. Death by a lion was considered a clean kill as the animal would kill its victim in short order, smaller carnivores where often used and the victim would be hardly recognisable as a human before the death blow was finally administered by the staff to enable the later shows to continue. Midday brought out the slightly more favoured criminals who where made to fight each other to the death the winner staying on until he meet his death. Once again the application of branding irons to reluctant victims ensure entertainment for the masses. The afternoon brought the Gladiatorial fights as depicted in the movie. The bodies of the victims where branded to ensure death. If any life was left a blow was applied to the cranium to finish the job, a hook was then stuck in the carcasses gut and a horse was used to drag out the body and was thrown into large pits near the colliseum kept for such purposes.

I am not sure that this sort of horror could be depicted in a modern movie as not only would it be censored but it is so outrageous that a modern audience would think it lacked credulity. Commodus also as depicted in the movie was a more loveable character than the one described in the histories of the times but yet again his depravities would not suit the censors.

All in all great entertainment though.

title: Good but can use a bit more intricacy in story
review:
Historical movies based in ancient Rome are few these years and fewer still are those worth watching. Fortunately, the latest Gladiator came as a pleasant surprise. A good, although not perfect way to spend a weekend afternoon.

Throughout the movie I was astonished by the epic scale of the sceneries. From the epic battle in Germania to the computer recreation of the city of Rome, to the great battle arena, each scene are magnificent and beautiful. The actions are fast and furious; they are somehow bloody for a PG13 movie so parents please be warned.

The story is ordinary but functional enough to keep me interested for ~3 hours. No major logical flaws in the plot although the ending is a little cheesy. In many parts of the movie I was emotionally tugged by the powerful applications of music and imagery. The themes of loyalty, love, jealousy, and despair are very well conveyed to the audience.

The characters are well developed with many memorable and interesting casts, although I think it is somehow of an overkill to portray wickedness of Caesar. Overall the acting is good and small details like Maximus padding a fellow soldier on the shoulder really add depth to their personalities.

If you are a fan of movies like Braveheart or Saving Private Ryan, you should enjoy this one. I give this movie only 7/10, because there could be a better story, a more logical ending, and more believable villain.

title: A pretty good flick, but with some glaring errors :(
review:
Ok, I saw Gladiator last night, and on the whole I was impressed. The acting was good and there were some interesting in-jokes. However, historically it left much to be desired.

First, the good parts: Marcus Aurelius' Meditations reveal that he did not much care for the public life, and longed to return to his quiet life on the farm back in the country. Sound familiar? Also, there had been a revolt by a senator named Cassius shortly before Aurelius' death, and he shows up in the movie, yay! I also liked the fight scenes, yes that makes me no better than the mob, but I thought it was interesting how the actual killings tended to be displayed either sped up or slowed down, in either case making them seem unreal. In regard to the mish-mash of accents, I thought it added charm to the movie, after all, Rome was a mish-mash of people, no?

** There are some spoilers in the following section. You have been warned **

As far as the history goes, I have heard some complaints from friends about Aurelius actually being in Germania (he did go out on the road with his armies) and Commodus entering the gladiatorial ring (which he also did). My major issue is the fact that Commodus enjoyed(?) a 12 year reign! He was not, repeat not, killed in the Coliseum by anyone, he was drugged and murdered the night before he was to accept a consulship. (Dressed as a gladiator, no less) For me, that brought this movie down a couple notches. Historical license is one thing, but killing emporers less than 6 months into their reign is too much for me.

Final analysis: 6/10

title: Awesome...
review:
If you are looking for an exciting, fast paced, action packed, violent, visually captivating movie with an actual plot. Then don't wait another day to see this movie. I'm already plotting to see it again in the theater even though I know it'll be around for a while. At one point in the movie, I took a glimpse at my watch and was elated to find out I had another hour and half to go...

I can't fathom how someone could vote this movie a '1' out of '10', they must have expected a boring, tear jerker with bad acting because anyone that likes action films HAS to enjoy this movie. Maybe not as much as me, but GLADIATOR doesn't rate a '1' in any aspect, especially not overall... So Buy your popcorn and your soda, and make sure you go to the bathroom before you get your seat, because you won't want to leave after the reels start rolling. ENJOY!!!

title: Incredibly awesome!!
review: A definite must-see.  Best Picture, 2000: Gladiator; Best Actor: Russell Crowe.  It was packed with action, extremely touching and moving as well as super intense!  Russell Crowe is about to become a HUGE star, much to his ambiguity. From this point on, I'll go see ANY MOVIE with him in it.

title: Lions, and Romans, and Gladiators, Oh my!
review: I have to admit that I was one of the few who were not totally anticipating this release.  I am a die-hard Braveheart fan and have been disappointed by all epics since it's release.  Although this movie is still no Braveheart in my opinion, it is definitely a movie to see.  The beginning fight scene along with some of the shots of Rome shows why this movie is truly an epic. The total grandeur of the picture along with some excellent acting help make this movie one of the top 100 of all time despite some obvious slow points in the plot.  This movie clearly could have been 3+ hours had they fully developed the main characters and the plot.  The special effects are blended in nicely without taking away from the movie and it's realism.  One of Russell Crowe's best works if not the best of his career.  I highly suggest viewing this movie on the big screen.

title: Definite thumb up!
review: This is the kind of movie that people mean when they say "They don't make them like that anymore"...  A true "Wow" film, transports you to a different world long turned to ruins and dust.  Russell Crowe answers the age old question "what do women want"...  a man of honor, strength, integrity, intelligence, with a light in his eyes and passion in his heart. The violence is real enough to be taken seriously, but the film does not linger or wallow over it. While much has been made by some critics about how audiences cheer the violence in the Coliseum, they/we are also cheering the clear underdogs, fighting for survival in a world not of their own making. When Maximus wins against the odds, and still shows honor and mercy, he is a hero well worth cheering.  I was struck by the similarities to a hero in our own day.  Over the weekend I saw Cal Ripken Jr get a standing ovation...at Yankee Stadium!  Proof that a true hero is still recognized.

title: Ye gods! Spare me from a sequel....
review: What a disappointment. Although I'm sure that the handicapped kid in the front row with the speak and spell board who typed repeatedly throughout the movie "I need a hug" and "I want more" added somewhat to my lack of movie-going enjoyment--I did not like this movie at all. Now I understand what scriptwriting courses mean when they say to avoid "talking heads," and boy, this movie has exposition a-plenty. Long, draggy, incomprehensible exposition---anytime there isn't a fight onscreen. Plus, all of that exposition is done by predictable, cliched characters possessing as much depth as a sheet of paper. Not that the acting is bad---it wasn't. But if you've seen any entry in the "they-killed-the-family-of-the-noble-hero-and-now-it's-payback-time" genre, then you've already seen this movie. What's sad is that Russell Crowe is a fantastic actor, and "Gladiator" would have benefitted greatly from having a flawed anti-hero like his role in "L.A. Confidential."  And while this $100 million movie IS pretty (if a bit vertigo-inducing with rapid-fire jump cuts and camera angles), it seems to possess a lot more style than substance. Wait for the video.

title: Too long
review:
This 2.5 hour film was, easily, half-an-hour too long. There are several spots where boredom sets in during oh-so-excessively-too-long scenes. Yet, Ridley Scott opted to use rapid jump cuts during the battle scenes, leaving me almost dizzy, and not totally certain of what I had just seen.

At 2 hours, this would be a much better film. As is, I gave it a "fair" "6".

title: What a film
review: I havent seen anyhting like this. EVER. This movie is totally unique. Upon entering the movie (which sadly i was late for) i thought that it would be good, but your typically empty action movie. I was filled with emotion during every battle and death. But i have to pay homage to Ridley Scott, one of the most incredible directors out there. This is an epic film. This film is a spectacle. This film is a gift to the audience. This film is flawless. Absolutely flawless.

title: Hollywood finally tells a good story again!
review:
Gladiator is really a sweeping epic of a film! It is truly something else. I've been waiting for this type of film to be made again. It's a lot like the great big films of the late fifties. There's no sex, no foul language, and no nudity - instead they tell a gritty, fantastically engrossing story that kept me white knuckled throughout most of it.

The acting is superb and the casting is dynamite. I really despised Phoenix's character - just what I was supposed to feel. I had never thought much of this younger brother to River Phoenix, but now I see that he really can deliver. And Crowe, well, let's just say I've been waiting for the U.S. to realize what a great actor this man is.

Gladiator and U-571 are two of the finest films Hollywood has cranked out in decades. They've really told stories and stories that don't need the "F" word peppered throughout it (tell me where the difficulty there is for screenwriters to come up with that word?) I'm very liberal and not much bothers me, but I'm sick to death of cursing in movies when it doesn't add to the film and it just seems to be in there for shock value.

So, now I can really say, "Hurray for Hollywood!"

title: See this in the theatre
review: See this one in the theatre. I haven't seen an audience react so collectively to a movie in a I don't know how long. Gladiator is the stirring story of Maximus and his fight against the Roman emperor. The previews hardly give justice to the bone crushing, decapitating, roaring battle scenes. The cinematography is almost perfect, transporting one to the wilds of Germania and bowels of the coliseum equally well. I know it's early but I wouldn't be surprised to see an Oscar or two come out of this movieRussel Crowe's carries this movie well. If were to compare this to Braveheart I would say Gladiator has Braveheart beat hands down. If you like a good old-fashioned action flick, definitely see Gladiator.

title: See it on the Big Screen!!!
review: The first battle scene alone made this movie worth seeing again.  Russell Crowe is great and the combat scenes are intense.  I would have been happier with a few more of them, but the story is good and balanced out the fighting.

title: BEST MOVIE OF THE YEAR!
review: Gladiator rocked!  After the opening scene was over I found that my jaw had been open the entire time.  Talk about action.  Gladiator is in the same caliber as Saving Private Ryan and Braveheart.  If you don't mind a few severed heads this movie is for you!

title: Cecil B. would be proud...
review:
Great movie! I would see it again if only for the well realized environments. Ridley Scott has done for Rome what he had done for the L.A. of the future in Blade Runner. The battles are intense and sweeping. The arena contests are brutal and well staged. Many nice little cinematic touches.

Russell Crowe is again exceptional and believable in this role. He conveys his feelings with a subtlety where there could have been much scenery chewing and gnashing of teeth. He allowed me to care about Maximus. A lesser actor would have been lost in this production, there is so much going on. To be honest there is some heavy melodrama but that would seem to be inherent within this genre. And in spite of some slow and indulgent stretches there is actually some injection of sly humor. Joaquin Phoenix actually humanizes his evil character who is nonetheless in the end, evil.

Gladiator is a spectacle, larger than life and this is why we go to movies. Isn't it? See it.

title: Crowe continues to amaze and impress
review:
A lot of the favourable comments already listed here I concur with. I agree that GLADIATOR is the best Ridley-Scott effort since BLADE RUNNER and that Russell Crowe in addition takes this movie to a whole new level. I was very impressed with the CG work in this movie and the strong gripping storyline to boot.

Be glad world - you now know what we "Aussies" have known since ROMPER STOMPER back in 1992 - that Russell Crowe is one heck of an Actor and surely will be an A-List one after this mountainous performance!

title: Realistic settings.
review: Superb photography, intense battle scenes with realistic settings, good storyline but dialogues a little lengthy and repetitive. The editing could have shaved off a good five minutes of over-sentimentality.The afterlife glimpse and the sincerity of prayer in the context of a pre-Christian faith is a refreshing novelty.

title: Disappointing.....
review:
The fight scenes and such were spectacular. It was a visually lush movie. The acting, especially on Russell Crowe's part, was excellent but if they are going to spend 100M on a movie couldn't they have channelled some of those funds into a decent script with believable characters.

And I am always willing to suspend my disbelief but when it comes to historical movies I appreciate a little more accuracy. For instance: Marcus Aurelius DID with the last of his strength (supposedly) declare Commodus to be his heir in front of the army. And Commodus did quite often enter the arena as a gladiator but, it wasn't until about 10 or 11 years after he became Emperor that he was poisoned by his mistress and died. Though perhaps not as truly depraved as Caligula, Commodus' true history seems to have been interesting enough to have fledged a much more well rounded script, with a greater depth of plot.

I went to the theatre expecting the kind of feeling experienced from viewing BraveHeart I was definitely disappointed.

title: The first truly grand movie this year
review: During the first five monthes of 2000, I sat through loads of dreck, waiting for some film to live up to the annus mirabilis that was 1999.  I went to Erin Brockovich, and was repulsed by the manipulation of the audience in that film, not to mention the deification of Julia Roberts and passed through the film.  I decided not to look for a good movie, just an entertaining one, and I went to U-571.  Instead of giving solid action, it tried to build characters into a story that couldn't handle characters. They piled cliches on an unsturdy frame, and the all film colapsed.  I really wanted Gladiator to be the film that I would love, and I truly did love it.  The opening has echoes of Saving Private RYan in style, but goes beyond that film because it truly ties us in to Russell Crowe's character, instantly.  We know who he is, we identify with him, and we are instantly willing to follow him through to the end of the film. All of the fight scenes are on a grand scale, perfectly mounted and expertly executed.  But there is more to this film than action.  Russell Crowe had better become a movie star with this movie, because after The Insider, he truyly deserves it.  He is a romantic, heroic, nobleman in the grandest sense of the word. Joaquin Phoenix is suitably over the top at times, yet there is depth to his characters.  He is a human villain, and yet a hissable one none the less. That is great movie making.  The political aspects of the film are also magnificent, adding a sociological dimension to the film that at no time feels like the film is teaching the audience.  It is worked into the story organically.  It also manages to work this massive scope into the context of a conventional, though thoroughly compelling and engrossing, revenge story. All in all, this is extraordinary, majestic, wonderful work.  Now that I've listed everything I can think of that is great about this movie, allow me to take this opportunity to curse the name of Hans Zimmer.  His score is, until the last twenty or thirty minutes of the movie, horrible, and should be excised from the film and replaced with something else in later incarnations of this film.  Hopefully this is less than 1,000 words.

title: An epic disappointment
review:
I was prepared to be enthralled by "Gladiator", but I ended up being bored. It was about a half hour too long. My wife found it tedious enough that she went out for candy in the middle of it, and didn't feel she missed anything while she was gone.

I know that I was supposed to be viscerally excited by the graphic violence, but I ended up being turned off. There was just too much of it. And as Maximus's improbable victory piled on improbable victory, I became more removed from the movie. My willing suspension of disbelief was stretched to the limit.

The real story of this movie belonged to Commodus, and I applaud Phoenix's performance. His character was the most interesting and complex, from his profound disappointment at his father's disapproval to his befuddlement as to why the people of Rome didn't love or respect him. An epic hero traditionally has a fatal flaw, and Commodus' was his ambition. In this story, Commodus isn't likeable, but he is certainly the most human.

Maximus was driven solely by his revenge and his sadness. There wasn't much more to his character, except his prowess in battle. I was supposed to root for him, but I felt little connection to him. Except for the opening battle scene (which IS intense and riveting), his victories seemed as believable as watching a bare-chested Sly Stallone scale a vertical cliff in the middle of a snow storm.

At the start of the 21st century, I had hoped that a movie of this magnitude would transcend the sandal epics of the mid-20th century. I was sorry to be disappointed.

title: Poor Man's Braveheart
review: Billed as the biggest onscreen epic produced in years, Gladiator shines in the action department but, ultimately, its cliched and shallow storyline makes the film fall flat.  On paper, Gladiator looks phenomenal, directed by a master of 'smart' action film (Ridley Scott) and starring some uniquely talented tough-guy actors (Crowe and Oliver Reed).  And the action is intense, from the opening scenes of large-scale warfare to the battles in the arena.  Yet peel away the impressive battle scenes, and you will find that the remaining scenes tell a tired story that has been done over and over again.  Gladiator is basically a reworked version of Braveheart without the detail, depth of the characters, and emotional response.  You really won't love Crowe's Maximus all that much, and you really won't ever be scared by Joaquin Phoenix's Commodus.  You won't really get upset when the bad things happen, and you won't really feel inspired at the end.  In Braveheart, you feel terrible when Wallace's first wife is killed; how can you be expected to feel terrible when the same happens in Gladiator, when Maximus' wife doesn't even speak or appear for more than 2 seconds in the film?  Gladiator shares a million parallels with Braveheart (I'd be surprised if the mimicry wasn't intentional), and falls short in every category.

title: One of the 10 most awe inspiring films ever
review: I do believe this film is the most intense I've ever seen.  I was plastered to my seat the entire 2 hrs and 40 minutes.  The cinematography was awesome. The acting was all solid to excellent...I really could not imagine anyone doing a better job as Maximus than Cameron Crowe - he is the next Mel Gibson. Phoenix is very good as the complex Caesar. Despite what others have said (Roger Ebert), the computer generated city was as good as those of Episode One, in my opinion.  I could find no real thing to complain about in this film - I left with the same feeling as I did from Braveheart and Saving Private Ryan - that I had just seen brilliance.

title: Laughable...
review:
No, not the film, but the few of you out there that actually decided to pay money to go and pick this movie apart, then whine about the silliest thing on some website. Suggestion? First, find a life, then start to go to the theater and realize you are watching a movie, not a metaphor for life. There are so many ludicrous comments here, I have to get a 10 lb bag of salt so I can take them a grain at a time.

Why do we insist on comparing every movie made to every other movie ever made? Why is it necessary to say this movie is like 'Braveheart' or '13th Warrior' or 'Ben-Hur' or 'Sparticus' etc, etc, etc.... This movie is just like one movie I have ever seen: 'Gladiator.' It is huge in scale, plenty of great action, wonderful actors, very followable storyline-wise. You see the grandeur of the Roman Coloseum and then complain because Maximus wasn't a real person? If you want reality, save your money and watch the History Channel for free. See this movie for what it is.

So the movie is 2 and a half hours. Pay $8 and see a 90 minute movie and then pay the same price for a 150 minute movie. I say you got a bargain. I was entertained from minute one to minute 150. Anyone who says "the action was great, but the dialogue was lacking...." you obviously went to see the movie *just* for the action. Too many Commodous whining scenes? Reinforcement. You hated him didn't you? Desired effect achieved. Crowe was brooding and dark? Wouldn't you be if you desired nothing but revenge on your family's murderer? Mysteriously gained a sense of humor mid-way through the movie? The closer he got to his goal, the more at-one he felt with his desired fate. One person here actually said "Phoenix tries to play crazy, but ends up coming off as bitter." *imagine yelling:* His father gave an entire empire to someone other than him. *imagine all-out screaming:* Wouldn't you be bitter too?

I digress....See this film. If you have half a brain, you'll like it. If you insist on following the exact healing time of a scrubbed-off tattoo and feel the need to post here that the production quality lacked because you left the theater disappointed because you didn't see the stages of scabbing/scarring in its biological context, blah blah blah....stay the hell home and flip on the tube.

title: Wow! can you say "Braveheart meets Spartacus"?
review: I thought that this film was one of the best movies that I have ever seen. Very much like titanic, it was an epic, which combined great special effects, with a great moving story. I could just imagine going into the Roman coleseum in front of 50,000 spectators. It was amazing, and everyone in the theatre got into the movie. When Maximus turned around to say "I am Maximus Aurelius, Commander of the armies of the north, father of a murdered son, husband of a murdered wife, and i will have my vengence" the entire theatre started to cheer. It is a rare thing to have such a historical epic, which we have not had for a long time, and i expect to see this movie up for best picture at the oscars next year.

title: Scott's fast editing is artistically valid.
review: Ridley Scott broke away from the 50's and 60's style of watching the gladiators' battles within the arena by-way-of a relatively static widescreen POV.  His rapid paced editing of mostly more intimate widescreen POV shots brought something new to the Ancient World Epic genre.  Some have likened this to pandering to the MTV-watching crowd, but I reject that notion. Fast editing for no apparent reason (as in ARMEGEDDON, for example) is MTV-like, and quickly results in both confusion and boredom for the viewer; but a fast-cutting style, sparingly used to immerse the audience into the center of a sudden storm of life-and-death violence, is artistically valid and effective in conveying the adrenaline surge, terror, and sense of chaos that such combatants would likely experience.

title: Extremely well done epic
review:
Well this movie does have a few problems with it but its a great epic. Scott captures that sense of awe with Gladiator. The locations, sets, effects, extras, costumes, and action all leads to a huge epic.

The plot is fairly standard stuff. The ruler is killed by his son who wants to rule Rome.The ruler he wanted to follow him is imprisoned by the son. Son kills the rulers picks loved ones and man get angry...and what not. Its the good old revenge tale but told as an epic. The acting is good especially Crowe as Maximus.

The film is visually very cool. From Rome to the fight scenes all well done. The worst scene is the begining battle. Its ruined because it was filmed in the dark, its edited to fast so you cant see whats happening, and the camera doesnt keep still. Also the ending is rather anti climatic. It leads you to believe that there is going to be a huge battle in Rome but alsa all we get is the hero and the villain dueling it out in the Colussem.

Another problem that is too long. It could have a used another brawl or two its seems much longer then 2 hours and 30 mins. I never was really interested in epics of battle but i really enjoyed this one.Its got well done action and good acting thats leads to a well worth trip to the theater

7 out of 10

title: Outstanding!
review:
Russel Crowe delivered probably the best work of his career beating out his performance as Bud White in L.A. Confidential in an epic movie worthing of being in the same category as Braveheart. GLADIATOR captures so much in its plot and the special effects used to create the Colloseum and ancient Rome in the prime of the Roman Empire and kept my attention until credits rolled.

Although the film contains a somewhat sad ending, good still triumphs over evil which only one aspect of what makes GLADIATOR a must see. The brutality of the film, although hard to watch at times, accurately captured what the society of ancient Rome was like.

GLADIATOR puts all of the science-fiction movies with special effects and huge budgets that just seem to eliminate a story line to shame with its simpleness and the power to keep the watcher deeply interested throughout the whole two and a half hours. As the movie opens with a battle scene in Germania, the watcher knows that they are in for something special as the sky just seems to be on fire with arrows and balls of fire.

Russel Crowe should definitely be nominated for an Oscar for Best Actor as being "the general who became a slave, the slave who became a gladiator, and the the gladiator who defied an emperor." His quiet and modest demeanor in the movie causes him to be a great leader on the battlefield and in the Colloseum. He uses his leadership skills to help he and his fellow gladiators survive in what is almost certain death.

With an all-star cast in which every actor plays their part fantastically and a story that can't miss, GLADIATOR should be a best picture candidate. GLADIATOR shows how important loyalty is and presents the question "Is blood thicker that water." Trust me, you won't be disappointed.

title: What can I say, its great!
review: I saw this with my dad a couple days ago, it is so good! It has enough action for action fans, and enough drama for drama fans! This may not be a family film, but you will be suprised, it is not one of those Dirty Harry kind of characters who kills anyone who gets in his way and never gets hurt, its completely different, I have to say it is as realistic as it can get, so you might not want to bring the youngest kids to see this movie because there are some bloody scenes, but you will be suprised at its drama, action sequences, and its authenticity

title: The first blockbuster of the year
review: Gladiator is in the top 3 best "Roman" movies I have seen--and I have seen them all--along with Ben Hur and Spartacus.  Many people talk about the opening battle in Germania, but to me the highlight was the Carthage gladiator battle in the middle.  Russell Crowe is going to be hotter than those flaming balls of oil.  The production values were superb, and I just cannot conceive of any film coming up this year beating Gladiator in all the technical aspects--Art Direction, Cinematography, Costumes, Score (I HAVE to get that CD!!), Film Editing, Visual Effects, and Sound.  Anyone who doesn't see it in the theatre is nuts (and I have a vested interest in hoping this does well so we get some more blood and sand epics like this one!).  Long live Gladiator!

title: A rousing, vastly entertaining big-budget winner
review: While hardly the most original of stories (you can have a great time coming up with all the films that influenced it), "Gladiator" is a mega-budget Hollywood summertime entertainment that works magnificently. Ridley Scott's directing is solid, the screenplay has some nicely developed character shadings and the acting is superb. Russell Crowe turns in yet another great acting role, Joaquin Phoenix also turns in a winning performance as Commodus, while Richard Harris, Connie Nielsen, Djimon Hounsou and the late Oliver Reed all offer great support. Technically, the film is near-perfect and of course, those fight scenes are truly exciting. A great, entertaining, fun time at the flicks.

title: Incredible movie
review: I don't see how anyone could not like this movie, unless they are sensitive to violence.  I personally thought the acting was top notch, and I didn't find the plot to be thin, or dull.  Sure, it wasn't the best plot, but it was still above average.  The fight scenes, the blood and gore, made me question how civil I really am.  The ending was very awesome, and made me tear up.  Maybe in comparison to other Roman movies, or if you're only concerned about the historical accuracies, it might not be the best movie, but I don't watch a movie for it's historical (in)accuracies.  I thought it was an incredible movie, and I gave it a 10/10.

title: What a disappointment.
review: I was really hyped up to see this movie and man was it a disappointment. Basically the only thing this movie has going for it is the cool fight scenes and action sequences involving gladiators. I'll admit that the fight scenes are pretty exciting and visually well made. But they are too few and far between. The movie is two and a half hours long and there are so many boring parts involving Joaquin Pheonix and really boring and uninspired dialogue between him and his sister. I literally fell asleep. I don't care about political power plays between Roman senators and Emperors, it's boring. And the dialogue gets pretty cheesy at times, I can understand why Russell Crowe had such a problem with some of his lines... they are pretty poorly written. And the English accent that everyone has confused me. I thought I was watching Braveheart. One guy even had a Scottish accent. Gladiator is basically a Braveheart clone set in ancient Rome and is very unhistorical and unrealistic. Especially the thumbs up, thumbs down, which Romans didn't actually use. There was no thumbs up, there was only a fist enclosing the thumb to spare the fighter's life (indicating a sheathed sword) or a thumbs down, meaning kill the fighter. The action sequences were awesome but might not be worth putting up with the rest of the boring plot that this long movie requires the viewer to sit through. Gladiator is not a very inspiring epic, which it tries too hard to be.

title: No Roman Holiday
review:
If you are looking for a movie to compare with the Roman spectacles of yore such as Spartacus, Ben Hur, or Fall of the Roman Empire, you're not going to find it here. And I mean that on several different levels...

As a huge fan of Roman history, I was extremely eager to see how artist-cum-director Ridley Scott would handle my favorite period in world history. I knew from my past experience with historical filmaking that it wouldn't come close to accuracy but as a fan of his work I was hoping with my heart of hearts that it would be Mr. Scott's triumphant return to fine form (ALIEN, BLADERUNNER, THELMA AND LOUISE) instead of something akin to his more recent flops (WHITE SQUALL or the overly mediocre 1492). His latest effort is somewhere in between, a Pyhrric victory: He won the little battles but lost the entire war. The one question I asked myself after leaving the theatre was "How can the same movie shine so brightly one moment then be as dull as rusted iron the next?" The answer...Blame it primarily on the script, blame it somewhat on the director, BUT don't blame it on the actors. Maximus we hardly knew you.

All of Ridley Scott's trademark talents are in full glorious force in GLADIATOR. The editing and cinematography are phenomenal and only add to the already vast panorama of the locations where the film was shot. The CGI effects were a mixed blessing, like the film itself. At once they recreate the splendid decadence and squalor that ancient Rome was but they also could prove unrealistic and distracting at times.

The frequently (and wrongly) criticized opening sequence is astounding and hints at a promising, richly textured classic that never emerges. This is not PRIVATE RYAN or BRAVEHEART. The final battle for Germania owes more to Kurosawa than to Spielberg or any other action director in recent years (except John Woo).

It also asks the questions that resound throughout the entire film: Were the Romans really more civilized than the barbarians they sought to conquer and subdue? Are we any different today? (Replace the blazing forests of Germany with the scorched jungles of Vietnam or gladiator games with boxing, football, and auto racing) The answer is as close as your television, our version of bread and circuses.It was an oddly ironic experience sitting in a theatre full of my fellow citizens while they cheered on Maximus along with the those "depraved" Romans in the Colosseum.I don't believe that Ridley Scott meant this to happen by chance and it is where the film is most effective.

Also effective was Hans Zimmer's haunting score and the brilliant cast of actors.Russell Crowe does his damndest with a character that is at best a rough draft outline. You can see where he wants to take Maximus but he's just not quite given the chance by the script.Joaquin Phoenix is outstanding as the debauched emperor Commodus who somehow manages to come across in a tragic manner. Backing up these fine performances are Richard Harris, Derek Jacobi, and best of all, the late Oliver Reed. These old guard actors lend an air of authority and legitimacy to the classical setting.But again their performances are merely hangers, albeit steady ones, for the limp storyline.Even at 2 1/2 hours most of the main characters remain tragically underused and unexplored.None of them stand a chance because in the third act, the Colisseum swallows them all up and becomes the main actor on the stage. End of story.

Instead of exploring one or two strong issues and developing Maximus further, the story seems to be content to jump from one fight sequence to another with moments of half-hearted debate about (inaccurate) Roman politics thrown in for filler. Who cares if Rome returns to a Republic (as if it could have after 200 years of imperial totalitarianism)? The Roman people certainly didn't seem to and that's one of the reasons Rome eventually fell. Why should we?

GLADIATOR is worth seeing primarily because this is not your grandparent's kind of epic with all of the preaching and preening of 50's Hollywood. It still has its moments of real drama that could move even an old stodge like me. This was not a horrible film as a minority have suggested. I urge any one who's a Russell Crowe or Ridley Scott fan to go see this movie on the big screen, along with all of you history buffs. This was an average to good film that could have been great. What a Roman tragedy.

title: WOW! WOW! WOW! WOW! WOW!
review:
WOW! I cannot remember the last time I was so engrossed in a film! From the opening battle sequence as gripping as the WWII landings in Saving Private Ryan, through the political intrigue to the gladitorial action in the colussium I was transfixed.

Do not wait till this film comes out on video as epics of this nature do not come around too often so see them where they were made to be seen.

Russell Crowe really has lifted his career into superstardom with this marvellous performance as Maximus, former Roman General, sentanced to death but only to return as Gladitorial hero of the Empire.

Backed up by a very strong cast, including Oliver Reed in his best, and last performance, Richard Harris, and Joaquin Pheonix, as snivelling Emperor Commodus.

Ridley Scott has lifted his talents to a new level.

A film I will remember where I was when I first saw it!

title: Awe inspiring
review: My God.  You people with your endless yammering about this movie's not being historically accurate need to pull the iron rod out of your kazoo.  Nowhere in the great lexicon of literature, be it print or film, does it say that a story needs to be historically accurate to be good.  Braveheart wasn't historically accurate, but it was good.  I'm reasonably sure that Star Wars wasn't historically accurate, but most people seem to enjoy that movie. Gladiator isn't a story about the history of Rome.  Gladiator is a story about the methods in which people are entertained, and the hypocrisy that said entertainment can breed.  More simply it is a story about a man who seeks one thing.  Before death or after, Maximus seeks only vengeance. Both the story and the lesson are beautifully told.  The scale of this movie is both grand and epic, to my mind, very reminiscent of Cecil B. DeMille.  The acting is stellar, especially good were Joaquin Phoenix and Oliver Reed. The reviewer I read in my local paper said that the Colesium looked bigger than it should, but I don't care.  It was awe inspiring, and so was this movie.

title: Disappointing
review:
As a work of fiction, this would be a truly great film. However, this is based on actual events and twists them beyond recognition. Commodus had been co-emperor with his father for 3 years prior to his death, not the actions of a man who planned to hand the empire to another. And no, Rome did not become a Republic again after Commodus was assassinated.

Though his sister Lucilla did indeed plot against him in 182, her plot failed and she was executed. Commodus was Caesar for 12 years (from 180 to 192) but was finally assassinated by a combination of poisoning and strangling.

If it is to be fiction, then use fictional characters. This is the worst adaptation of history that I have seen since El Cid. This film only contributes to the ignorance of history that already plagues America.

However, if you are one of those who don't know history, you might find this to be a great epic.

title: 21st century CB deMille
review:
What Jurassic Park did for cgi creatures, this one does for cgi sets. It looks like they put cast, crew, cranes, and a helicopter into a time machine and filmed it in ancient Rome. The aerial views of the ancient city and Coliseum, complete with crowds, are truly dazzling.

Russell Crowe is most impressive as "the general who becomes a slave who becomes a gladiator who defies an emperor." Emperor Commodus is suitably smarmy - you want to reach up to the screen and whack him yourself!

A bit slow at times, but who cares? The visuals are breathtaking and the combat scenes are unequalled in any movie. Very realistic violence - might want to leave the youngsters at home.

Came home to find Ben-Hur showing on PBS. It looked terribly dated. During the chariot race, I wanted to hear the crowd chant, "Maximus! Maximus!

title: Great movie! Haven't seen a true "epic" in a while.
review:
When I first saw the previews for this movie, I thought someone had colorized a Richard Burton film. Then, of course, I realized that I was looking at Russell Crowe in a Ridley Scott movie, and I was even more intrigued. After seeing it last night, I have to say I was not disappointed in the least; all the performances were top-notch (I always love watching Oliver Reed in anything, and Richard Harris is as good as ever), the use of special effects was very efffective, and the battle scenes were realistic enough to make me wince but not so over-the-top that it felt cartoonish.

And Mr. Crowe was, to put it succinctly, understated perfection. I was a little worried about scenery-chewing (and, in an almost-three-hour movie, that gets old really fast!), but his Maximus was the epitome of soldierly restraint. And, let's face it, he looks great in a tunic. Joaquin Phoenix, as the young emperor Commodus, was appropriately dramatic and miserable.

What I realized most after seeing this movie was how nice it is to see a film about a truly noble individual, someone you'd like to try to emulate (in nobility, not perhaps in career choice), and how rarely one gets to see those sorts of characters in today's world. It's also refreshing to see an unromanticized version of Roman history; it wasn't pleasant to live in those times, no matter who you were, and the film captures the uneasiness of the time quite well.

I'm rating it a nine out of ten just because it could have been edited a little better (this did not need to be 2 hours and 45 minutes long!), but, truthfully, I was surprised to look at my watch and see that 2 hours had passed. It goes by very quickly. Go see it! You won't be disappointed.

title: remake of Fall of the Roman Empire
review: What nobody's noticed is that this is basically a remake of the 60s epic 'Fall of the Roman Empire', with Alec Guiness, Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer and Stephen Boyd. While 'Gladiator' has great acting and a surprisingly involving story, not to mention amazing action scenes, the older film beats it in one very important area: producer Samuel Bronston rebuilt the Roman Forum in Spain, so the sets are real. 'Gladiator' is all digital and looks it. There's probably not one bit of natural light in the entire film. That's too bad, because otherwise it's very entertaining. As for 'Fall of the Roman Empire', it's pretty dated, but it's also one of the most visually stunning films ever made and has a GREAT Dimitri Tiomkin score. Try to see it letterboxed if you can.

title: Stirrups stirrups stirrups
review: *sigh*  It's strange to see Ridley Scott fail.  Which I think he did.  This is one of the only movies I've ever seen where historical accuracy would have actually *improved* the script tremendously.  If you had known that historically Commodus was well loved by the Army, fought as a gladiator, and even won over most of the Senate it would have been much more believable. The only real chemistry in the film was between Joaquin Phoenix as the mad Emperor and Lucilla as his sister.  Every other supporting character appeared to have motivations along the lines of "because the script said so."  Although it was visually amazing, the last scene is abruptly and completely different from the entire rest of the movie, which destroys what little (and it was little) emotional commitment you had to the film.  I give it a 5.

title: Better than expected...
review: I know this movie was set in 150AD but the Roman Empire was not yet Christianised.  But of course Hollywood is pitching at a Christian audience who are unable to understand the idea of true self-sacrifice without a consequent rebirth.  So unfortunately the film opens and closes with the tackiest vision of a Christianised-Hollwooodised-quasi-Romanised Elysian Field where all good people get to prance about in endless cornfields.  But these elements were a minor distraction from an otherwise thoroughly entertaining retelling of a traditional heroic story.  The digital reconstruction of Rome was a feast for the eyes and the combat sequences (apart from the thoroughly annoying strobing due to the lack of motion blurring) were well put together.  Joaquin Phoenix is perfectly cast as the snivelling pathetically evil emperor and Oliver Reed is great as the gladiator owner.  Not a classic like Blade Runner or Alien, but fine nonetheless.

title: Great movie by Ridley Scott. Russell Crowe is outstanding.
review:
This is a movie well worth seeing. Ridley Scott has made a movie that is believable and brutal but not gory. It has fine editing. You get the impact but not lingering gruesome shots of bloody battle. It is undoubtedly the most realistic portrayal of Roman life that has ever been in the movies.

Russell Crowe is a revelation. In a sea of wonderful actors, he carries the movie. Any army would follow his Maximus into battle. I will now have to go back and look up his previous work and see what I have missed. All of the actors including Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, Richard Harris and Connie Nielsen are wonderful.

The photography is flawless and you can hardly notice the effects.

The ending is a minor flaw in the movie. It is satisfying but you can see it coming from a long way off. They spent a lot of money to make this movie and it was well spent. See it.

title: No moral value
review:
We have become stimulus junkies.

I remember when I first saw Bonnie and Clyde and how shaken I was by one of the final scenes in which a storm of machine gun bullets shook their bodies as if they were puppets. It was emotionally upsetting, overwhelming. Yet that movie's presentation of violence was mild compared to that seen in Gladiator.
