However, don't mistake this movie for Great Cinema. It isn't. This is a Hollywood-spawned crowd-pleaser, a "Roller coaster of a movie" that will "have you on the edge of your seat." While the plot was non-trivial as I said, it had few surprises and is not particularly interesting, though it did its job of wrapping the action scenes extremely well. The characters also do their jobs; unfortunately, without much flair. I would rate the thinness of the characters as this movie's worst flaw; the bad guy is wholly bad (they even make him a sexual deviant to drive the point home). The good guy is wholly good - plenty of reinforcing the "loves his family" angle to show what a wholesome fellow he is. The other slaves are eloquent, good-natured, stoic, and dignified. If you were sold into slavery, beaten, starved and then told to be hacked into little pieces for the amusement of others, would you be so likeable? Me neither. The wise emperor, the faithful servant, and anyone else you care to name, are cardboard cutouts.

So, don't miss this one at the cinema. A most pleasing way to while away a couple of hours. I just wouldn't expect to see anyone quoting it in a year's time.

title: I own three movies ... this is one of them!
review: Intense and captivating!  The struggles of Marcus and the anguish that he faces are truly captured in this great picture.  There was just enough of all elements of a good movie to make this a masterpiece.  Action, adventure, SFX, and the ever so slight romance.  Although I would not consider this by any means a "chick" flick.

title: A flashy, action-driven piece of cinematic trash.
review: While I'll be the first to admit that this movie has spectacular action sequences, depicting horrifying terrible combat and beheadings and arrow strikings, I must say that I am really perplexed as to why so many people find this movie so good.  It never deserved any awards, save maybe a "gruesomest bloodbath" award.  People are harping on and on about how Russell Crowe is this great actor, but all he did, the entire movie was either look p***ed off or look about to cry.  His character had no depth, no faults, he was brave, gallant, honorable, and completely too perfect to be human.  His nemesis, Commode-ius or whatever toilet-sounding Greek name he had was as shallow and one-dimensional a villain I have seen since Titanic.  He had no redeeming traits, even when you thought he might show one... oh, it was eclipsed because he either killed his father or molested his sister.  Plus the story line?  Utter trash!  When will movie writers see that the audiences of America (at least the ones that can think for themselves) want something more than the standard by the book epic of "Great novel superior Good" vs. the "Deep dark despicable Evil" that killed his wife and kids and other people too?  When will we get more than a simple piece of re-hashed, re-charactered, and ever-so-slightly-re-written cinematic garbage to feast our intellects on?  Obviously not as long as the tasteless hoards gush to see the epic about people getting chopped up, that was produced by no-talent scene-stealing unimaginative hacks.  Ridley Scott, I'm very disappointed in you...

title: Great movie, despite what others say.
review: The acting in this fim was in my opinion very good. Russell Crowe's performance was outstanding. You get the sense that his men respected him, you get to see how proficient he is at fighting, you get to see a tender side. The one thing that I never hear or read is the fact that for quite a lengthy period of time Crowe doesn't speak. He gets his emotions across without words. And it works. Ridley Scott is a great director. Some may say the first battle is full of fast cuts, but to me it gives you the feeling of being in battle. There are lots of things going on and you have to try and get it all in. The rest of the cast is fantastic. Joaquin Phoenix did a marvelous job. Finally the score. As with many great films the music just enhances the enjoyment of the film. Hans Zimmer gets high marks for the music in the both the first battle & its reprise in the Barbarian Horde scene. All in all was it the best film of 2000? I won't say outright yes, but considering what else was out it had to be right up there.

title: Fantastic sound visual and drama
review: This has to be one of my all time favourite movies. It shines in the quality of the story, the photography and the sound editing. A must have action packed show, from beginning to end, I strongly recommend it!

title: Spectacular!
review: Ridley Scott has breathed new life into the sword and sandal epic with Gladiator.  Using modern visual effects, Gladiator shows us a Rome that hasn't been seen since, well Roman times.  There is a thriving metropolis and at the center of this mass of humanity is the coloseium.  Ridley Scott's films are wonders of art direction and costume design and Gladiator is no exception. The sumptuousness of Rome in its heyday is wonderful to look at.  With all of the eye candy that Scott gives you, you almost forget that there is a story unfolding, and it's quite a story.  Russell Crowe gives a strong performance as Maximus, the disgraced Roman general. Juaquin Phoenix is perfectly sniveling and underhanded as the newly crowned emperor Commodus. There are scenes of quiet treachery and intrigue and then there are scenes of blood stirring combat in the arena. Gladiator is an epic that spares no expense in giving you thrills from ancient Rome.

title: very thought provoking
review:
I found this movie to be not just a guy's movie, but I really liked it. It demonstrated the indomitable human spirit. I was so moved by the strength and never do something that you dont take pride in attitude.

The camera action in the death scenes were so poignant and effective. I truly admire the transition sequences. It was a powerful story. Never say die.

title: A great action movie, but underneath a powerful story..
review:
The film is well made, well acted and a fantastically fluid yarn. I have seen this film over ten times, yet still feel an overwhelming sense of sadness and discomfort after doing so.

That is why I cannot consolidate or agree with lines like "edge of your seat fun". Lets face it, the guys son is murdered, his wife is raped and butchered, both are burned. The hero gives up a life of comfort as a General in the Legion over his principles and beliefs, and this is how he is repayed?

Almost everyone in the film end up dead, there are long scenes of dreamscapes and wind rushed grass, yet still I find myself drawn to this story.

Whether its Crowes masterful performance(aided ably by a skilled cast), or Scott's knowing direction, the film strikes me as a classic-now, and for years to come, albeit a depressive one.

MCR

title: A Classic!!!
review: This movie is destined to be a classic as it has all the required elements...a realistic historical setting, a message of courage from an underdog hero, great acting (Russell Crow is GREAT in this type of role), and the timeless message that freedom isn't free and through sacrifice can come great things.  This movie is one of the few movies that I can watch repeatedly without getting bored and every time I see it I feel both moved and inspired.  Anyways...I loved this movie...!!!

title: Best big budget film in a while (Spoilers)
review: I really enjoyed this film. It looked great, the story was good, a few cliches but what can you expect in a big budget film. I found Russell Crowe dying to be something not often found in big budget movies, the hero almost never dies. I thought the acting was great from everyone, well Crowe's wife (who has no speaking part) kinda annoyed me, but that's a small fault. All in all a very solid film, worth seeing. 8/10

title: Simply Amazing!!
review:
Gladiator is quite simply one of the best movies ever made, and it deserved each of the 5 Academy Awards that it won. The story is brilliant, the acting is outstanding, and the soundtrack is perfect.

All of the acting performances are outstanding, but the most memorable performance is that of Russell Crowe. His performance here put him at the top of the Hollywood A-list, and he deserved the Best Actor award. He is riveting as Maximus, the Roman General who was betrayed. He was forced to become a slave, and then a gladiator. Some of the most memorable quotes come from the character of Maximus, such as 'My name is Gladiator'.

Another outstanding performance is that of Connie Nielsen as Lucilla.

The action scenes are well done, and extremely bloody, but this makes them more authentic.

If you haven't seen this movie yet, you are missing out on one of the best movies ever made.

Definately 10/10!

title: This is my second fave movie of all time!
review:
I have seen this movie fifteen times now, and it gets better every time. I liked this movie so much, I went out and got the special edition DVD. But there is something I must say. Joaquin Phoenix was the best by far! He's the one who should've

played Maximus! But he was cool as the villain anyway. I will always consider this Joaquin's best role! Anyhow, it was an overall good movie, kind of gross, but who gives a damn! This is a 10/10 for me. See it if you love action/Dramatic movies that keep you happy until the end.

title: Nice Tale of the Roman Empire
review: This is yet another successful film starring Russell Crowe, who has turned in some of the most versatile acting performances in the past decade, including "A Beautiful Mind", "The Insider", and "L.A. Confidential". This film is a well-paced, action-packed (if not always realistic) film. What my wife liked about it (of which I'd have to agree) is that it is simple in its plot, very easy to follow, yet is never lacking in the right amount of action or momentum. It is a summer-movie but a well-made summer movie. I'm not sure that I would have voted this for the Best Picture Oscar it received ("Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" had more depth and "Almost Famous" was very witty), but I certainly can't say it was a bad choice. This is definitely worth a look at least once.

title: A respectable and fairly engaging Roman epic.
review: A respectable and fairly Roman epic about a much beloved Roman general, Maximus (Russell Crowe), who instead becoming the next emperor of Rome is forced to be in the gladiator fights, which were fierce and...a bit on the bloody side.  The strongest parts of this Ridley Scott film are the excellent fight scenes and the performances of veteran actors Richard Harris, Derek Jacobi, and Oliver Reed (who died during the filming).  Only the appearence and design of Rome look very grainy and unpleasant.  I have some doubt why this movie received some Oscars that included Best Actor (Crowe, no offense) and Best Picture.  The only nominations that this film should deserve are Best Supporting Actor for Reed and Djimon Hounsou instead of Joaquin Phoenix (brother of the late River Phoenix).

title: Not just good but a Great film!
review: Gladiator was an Awesome film.  the acting was perfect and i loved all of the gore and combat.  Russel Crowe played the perfect part as the Gladiator and nobody could replace him in the role. The beginning of the movie was perfect and it also had a nice depressing ending.  I give "Gladiator" 8.3 out of 10 stars

title: Terrific film, interesting portrait of Roman empire...
review:
As a history buff, I had a lot of fun with "Gladiator."

The actual plot for Gladiator was nothing new. As a matter of fact, it "borrows" a lot from "Macbeth", "King Lear", and "The Odyssey." And some of the dialogue was trite...

On the other hand, it's probably the most realistic depiction of the middle Roman Empire in film to date. The use of CGI was outstanding, specially the reconstruction of the Colisseum.

I enjoyed the minor details a whole lot: the dresses in the Roman empire had more to do with how people actually dressed in the Middle Ages, than the greco-roman "toga and sandal" vision that Hollywood created. Also, notice how the nobility wears blue colors: it was the most expensive color for fabrics, since very few things in nature have that pigmentation.

I enjoyed seeing the palaces with actual furniture, (unlike in classic Hollywood), and the nobility using glasses and glass utensils. Romans were incredibly skillful at glassworks. Unfortunately, only a few pieces have lasted until today.

It was also quite impressive how the movie starts by showing you why the Roman Empire was so powerful and lasted so long: their technology and war machinery was ages ahead of the rest of the known world. Most of Europe was still living in tribal societies. As we can see in the opening scenes, the tribes of Germania barely entered the bronze age when they got beaten by Roman war machinery.

And of course, I appreciated that the main character, Maximus, is not from the Laetium (Rome), but from Spain, one of the provinces of the Roman Empire since about 100BC. Spain, Portugal and Southern France (Hispania, Lusitania, and Galia) were the second most important provinces of Rome.

Spain was kind-of like their "Cambridge, Mass": they sent their future Caesars, senators and Emperors to the many Roman universities in Spain (Salamanca, Complutum, Caceres) and military academies. Even Julius Caesar, for instance, was educated in Spain.

With its minor flaws, "Gladiator" was definitely a great show, highly entertaining as well as educative.

title: History
review: While the actual scenario concerned with Gladiator did not exist, the presentation of Rome gorgeously brilliant and accurate.  This was a refreshing improvement on Spartacus and "Heston Biblical classics" that tend to suck in the accuracy department.  Praise be to the god of film and fun, Ridley Scott.

title: Powerhouse of a film
review: Rarely does a film leave me with a sense of awe.  I am not easily impressed. As a rare person who is easily affected by violence I found this film to be exceptional.  Everything about it was choreographed so well, Not just the fight scenes.  All of the character interactions were done so well. Russell Crowe was, as always outstanding.  I have yet to see him not be a full character.  Totally absorbing as Maximus. His emotion and depth were enough to convince me that this is truly one of the finest actors this decade. He can truly be anybody.  The music was incredible, but then it was Hans Zimmer. I listen to the soundtrack and it transports back into the film. Incredible film viewing opportunity.

title: Academy was right!
review:
-The Best: Russell Crowe, Connie Nielsen, the evil River Phoenix, the directing, plot, music, cinematography, the outstanding battle scenes which lead this film to be one of the best of all time. Synopsis: the whole movie. -The Worst:????????????????? -Rating: 9/10

Roman General Maximus (Russell Crowe) is chosen to be the new emperor of Rome after Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) instead of his son Commodus (River Phoenix), which becomes a corrupt prince by killing his father and claiming himself has the new emperor of Rome. As soon as Commodus has his hands on the power he orders the army to kill General Maximus and his family. It happens that Maximus survives the attack, but not does the family that is burned and crucified alive. Maximus is found unconscious on the ground by a group of nomads who turn himself in a gladiator called Spaniard specially known for his combat skills and are these very skills that take him to Rome to fight in the Colosseum as a Gladiator. Also in Rome Maximus calls everyone's attention once more by his combat skills which moves the emperor to know who that Spaniard Gladiator is. It is in this moment that appears one of the movie's best lines:  My name is Maximus Decimus Meridius, commander of the armies of the north, general of the Felix legions, loyal to the true emperor, Marcus Aurelius, father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife, and now I will have my vengeance, in this life or in the next.'. Commodus is now frightened to see that his control of the empire is dropping and the people's love for him is each time dropping as well arranges some plan to make the new hero of Rome be forgotten in less than nothing

Once more, revealing the rest of the movie's plot would certainly be really boring and somehow useless because there's almost no one who haven't seen this masterpiece already. Regarding to the movie's evident quality there aren't needed anymore words uttered by another viewer like me, as this year's Oscar nominations speak for themselves. Start running to the Oscar ceremony as the clear favourite, Gladiator's final number of Oscars ended up being somewhat like a big disappointment (there were only five). However the awards delivered to the movie were all fair besides the Visual Effects one. I can tell that I am one of the biggest defenders of this movie, but if the recreation of one big city would have been done in some other movie it would certainly be forgotten or ignored by the academy to the nominations list, in my opinion what led to the big astonishment regarding to this effects was the fact that no one have seen the city of Rome in good old times of the empire so fully created before. It is clear to everyone's eyes that the Special Visual Effects are quite more flawless and astonishing in one of the other nominees Hollow Man. Due to it's acceptance to the big audience it is now a matter of opinion but you can't surely disagree that the effects were eye candy and all the work developed by the computer wise men should have been rewarded by the Academy (see for example the scene were Kevin Bacon disappears, only that about- five minutes scene will show all of you how right I am). Regarding to the other Oscars unfortunately Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon stole almost all the awards that should have been given to Gladiator. It seems that critics and now the Academy are completely going nuts by those poor Tiger and Dragon that don't even appear on the movie But now getting back to the centre of the arena where movies like this one are considered minor when compared to movies that show a cheesy and ordinary love story that should have been water down along with the boat, we have to consider ourselves' lucky to have (only) five Oscars when we should have had 11 (Special Effects out  explained before-) Well, right now when there is lesser space for writing, before I will go back to my resting place, I should (of Course) congratulate all the ones that were responsible of bringing back Roman empire: Ridley Scott's aggressive and reachable vision, Russell Crowe's power which was capable of filling even more the Coliseum, an other powerful artist named Connie Nielsen, who by one single look meaned not what a thousand words could. See it, enjoy it, it might be tragic and get 5 Oscars instead of 11, but at least it is not tragic, ridiculous winning 11 Oscars when it should have been 5.

Strength and Honour 9 out of 10.

title: A triumphant and magnificant story about loyality and love, good over evil, and heroism
review: Gladiator is a film about loyality and love, good over evil, and heroism, and one of the best i've ever seen. It's  truly an inspirational film, and the best film of 2000. This IS Russell Crowe's most memorable performance in his career, and also Joaquin Phoenix. This movie is amazing from beginning to end and has lots of special stunts and very cool fights. When i saw this movie i was blown away, i give it **** out of *****

title: The Best Film of 2000
review:
Ridley scott shows off his magical visual style of director with Gladiator. A tale of honor and revenge. Great unique cinematography and beautiful art direction the major stand outs. The acting is superb also. Russell Crowe gives one of his best performances and puts him among the top actors of today. Hans Zimmer's score is perfectly composed for the film. Winner of five academy awards including Best Picture and Best Actor. Probably should have won Best Art Direction, Cinematography, and Score.

**** out of **** stars

title: BEST EPIC SINCE CONAN:THE BARBARIAN AND BRAVE HEART!
review: GLADIATOR***1/2[3 1/2 STARS]-Best epic since ''Conan: The Barbarian (***1/2) and ''Brave Heart" (***1/2). There's an excellent story and the acting is great despite theres not a huge cast except for Russell Crowe. There's an awesome battle scene at the beginning of the movie plus some awesome sword fights and some great bloody action in the arena. The ending was also pretty awesome. This is a nice comeback for Russell Crowe since ''The Insider" (**) which also made kind of a mess for Al Pacino who made his comeback in ''Any Given Sunday (***1/2). I've never been into Russell Crowe but he was awesome in this movie and I hope to follow up on more of his movies. If you want to see a great epic go see ''Gladiator''.

title: Rumble in the Collosseum
review:
With a cast that includes the late, great Oliver Reed, you know you are in for a treat. Add the direction of Ridley Scott, amazing sets and some of the most seamless CG seen thus far, you only need a decent plot to make a classic movie.

Thankfully, the plot is very good (if a little historically inaccurate), and in Russell Crowe, you have a physically believable gladiator.

The fall and rise of Crowe's character gathers momentum as the story moves on and along the way we are treated to some stunning visuals, accompanied by one of the most vibrant soundtracks I have ever heard.

The fight scenes too look real, I can bet a few bruises were collected along the way. It's a novelty to see such combat in modern movies - no ballet-like stuff here - all blood and guts and hard work.

The characters are also so believable - and the dirty, gritty images of pre-firearm combat really do make battles in other movies seem like a bit of a joke.

I have no hesitation at all recommending this one - especially on DVD where you get a plethora of extra features and commentery.

10 out of 10 for this one - a movie I have watched time and time again, and will continue to do so.

title: A grim and gritty classic
review:
I love a good melodrama, and this is a grim and gritty classic, full of vengeful tooth-gnashing and visceral battles. Crowe's performance is moody and believable (his Richard Burton impression is very impressive), and he's backed by some great acting from Phoenix and Nielson. Veterans Richard Harris and Oliver Reed make the whole affair that bit classier, and it's a fine swan song for the latter.

So what if the plot is an old chestnut, we haven't seen this kind of film for a while, and it's done very well. Protestations of historical inaccuracies should be ignored  it's a sad day when we can't enjoy a spirited yarn without being force-fed a history lesson, for no other reason than to keep the pedants happy.

Mention should be made of the effective CGI utilised to bring ancient Rome to life, and the impressive (if vaguely familiar) score. Lots of little touches combine to make this superb entertainment, the best film Scott has given us in some time. It's very much a movie that should have been seen at the cinema, but if you missed it there the DVD version is great and reasonably stocked with extras. Pull the chair closer to the TV and enjoy.

title: great acting, excellent directing, lovely script and wonderful movie
review: I think it was a great great idea to finally make a big movie about Rome and the Gladiators's life. In the latest 20 years, I think this is obviously the best epic movie. Director Ridley Scott proved one more time his versatility. One more great movie he made. This movie has great acting, wonderful directing, and the story is simply fabulous. Perhaps we could say much more about this great movie, but the ones who didn't see it yet dont't know what they are really missing. This movie is maybe the best movie of the 90's (well, actually it only came in theatres in 2000), and it's worth viewing. Nobody can detect weak points in this movie, you know why? Because it has no weak points. Ridley Scott and the rest of the crew members made an wonderful job. And, besides, the story is original. Great, great movie. Have a seat and enjoy it, and then have a seat and enjoy it again. Yes, because I really believe you won't see this movie only one time, but several times.

title: Hit, hit, miss...hit
review:
This movie reaches out and offers you many things, as if on a large, golden platter, and I enjoyed all of the fare that I could actually swallow. The visuals were grand and satisfying, almost haunting - particularly the opening battle with the Germanic tribe(s) in the forest (which was stunning), and first historic recreational battle in the Big Ring. The costumes were very good. Oliver Reed stood out as thoroughly enjoyable and believable; and it was nice to have a face that was fresh (to me) in the starring role of a budget monster, instead of, say, Mel Gibson's.

But though Crowe was good, I don't think he was better than Geoffrey Rush in Quills, who also had the nomination. Crowe showed depth but no remarkable vulnerability; Rush had both. Joaquin Phoenix put good effort into his role as the naughty Commodus, with just that precisely awful affect that you could see his effort to do so. He engaged in some intense acting that looked like that - intense acting (a bit like Angus MacFadyen as Robert the Bruce in Braveheart, but more obvious). Commodus' emotions looked drummed up from the actor, not flooding up from the natural depravity of the man who brought back the Games.

Nevertheless the movie still has a sum greater than its parts (no easy feat in the whirlwind of filmmaking's many disjointed pieces). I've seen it twice and would see it again.

title: Great Movie
review: This was a good movie. I Enjoyed every bit of it. It had a great start with a battle, then it dwindled down to many conversations and murder. But then the pace was picked up again and the movie was good from then on. I did expect to see more fight scenes in this movie, but what could I expect from a Drama-Action movie right? Overall I enjoyed this movie over the countless times I have seen it.

title: Good Film but Very Derivative of Braveheart
review:
Think a minute & tell me what film I'm describing: It's an historical drama which is only loosely based on history. Its hero is a strong-willed man who only wants to live his own life but whose wife is killed by an evil ruler & who vows revenge. In later portions of the film, he dreams of being together with his wife in an idyllic setting. He has a loyal Irish sidekick & the film features airy music & large & violent battle scenes. The hero of the film is fighting for freedom and against tyranny & in the end, although he dies, he succeeds in bringing freedom to his people. Sound like any movie you know? Maybe...Braveheart? Well, all those features also apply to the new film Gladiator, a shallow but entertaining Braveheart rip-off set in the Roman Empire c. 180 A.D.

Maximus is a popular general of the Roman legions for whom the Emperor Marcus Aurelius has just bypassed his son, the incompetent Commodus, as his successor. Marcus wants Maximus to bring power to the Roman senate & bring freedom to the Roman people who have been living under the yoke of the Emperors. Unfortunately, when Commodus learns of Marcus' plan, he kills the old man, kills Maximus' family, & tries to kill Maximus himself. But Maximus escapes & winds up a slave in North Africa where he is trained as a gladiator.

Eventually, the gladiators are brought to perform in Rome where Commodus has ordered a lengthy series of games to improve his popularity. Various schemes ensue until there is a big showdown in the gladiatorial ring between Commodus & Maximus.

The film at least has the honesty to admit (in a blurb at the end) that, while it contains historical characters, the story it tells is fictional. It is an entertaining movie but it's not as good as it could have been. The opening battle scene, while suitably noisy & crowded, is not up to any of the battles in Braveheart (the Romans' German opponents look like a bunch of poorly armed old men--the sort of soldiers who, centuries later, would have been guarding the Fuhrerbunker in 1945 & not a formidable opponent for the Roman legions). The gladiator scenes are mostly good, although like most of the film they lack the feel of authentic history. However, while the action is pretty good, the whole bit about Maximus' desire for revenge & his goal of freeing the senate is uninvolving & the plotting between Commodus' sister Drusilla, the senators, Commodus, & various others seems to be there mostly to fill screen time between gladiator matches.

There are a few good bits in the film. In particular, the scenes of the gladiators seeing & then entering the Colosseum for the first time are impressive & the battle scenes of the legions have their moments. But the numerous & often weird & gratuitous `borrowings' from Braveheart (both films even have the hero voice an aphorism about death-`Every man dies, not every man really lives'-Braveheart vs. `Death smiles at all men, but some of them smile back'-Gladiator) leave a bad taste in one's mouth & make one wish that the `creative' forces behind Dreamworks had used a little bit more of their *own* creativity on this film & not relied so extensively on the creativity of others. I'd give it two stars out of four, but add a star if you didn't see Braveheart.

title: A remarkable story
review: Gladiator is a movie which inspires people not to lose faith in themselves, no matter what adversary may come. Although a little more gory than what probably would have been okay, the action scenes were truly grand. Russell Crowe did a great job but at times he seemed a little bit emotionless. May be that's how the character itself was created.

title: The Gladiator Who Defied an Empire
review:
This is an excellent movie. Russell Crowe is awesome as Maximus, the Roman General turned slave, who than becomes the Gladiator that defies an empire. It's tastefully violent, there are good action scenes, but the acting was why I liked this movie. Russell Crowe was convincing as a vengeful gladiator who wants revenge from the new emperor Commodus, who kills anyone who stands in his way of being Rome's greatest emperor.

Joaquin Phoenix was a good villain as Commodus, and Connie Nielsen was also good as Commodus' terrified sister, Lucilla. There are great special effects, great costumes, great acting, and a great story.

This is a good and exciting movie that you can watch for the action or drama. I found it was funner to watch it as an action/drama, which made it all the more enjoyable. This is one of my favorite movies, and I recommend it to anyone who like the above description, because I know I do. Besides, how many other award winning movies can you see a guy get his head cut off with a large sword (not including Braveheart, because that wasn't a sword)! 9/10

title: I only found the fight scenes and the sets to be decent; nothing more
review:
If it weren't so damn overlong and overly-wholesome, GLADIATOR would have been a winner in my book. The film overstays its welcome because of all the hype, and that's what I didn't get. Most of the performances (especially by the star, Russell Crowe) weren't that good as I

expected, plus the extremely long time length of the film was a

downer, and this movie won the best picture of 2000?? The Oscar

committee was far too generous for GLADIATOR, that's for sure.

I thought the only saving graces in the film were the intense action sequences in the battlefields and the arena, plus the costumes and landscapes were fantastic. But sometimes the minor details are indeed minor; they didn't help to buoy GLADIATOR from sinking.

title: Fantastic Moviemaking
review: This was the best picture of 2000, by far in my opinion.  The first time I saw it in the theatre I was awestruck by the film's tremendous suspense, drama and depth of character.  One scene in particular, the moment that Maximus has to finally go into the arena to fight, is extremely intense.  The sounds of clanging metal echoing under the belly of the arena give you a feeling of the terror and tremendous fear these men had live through.  The second time I saw the film confirmed for me that this was one of the finest films I have ever seen. One reviewer wrote it was not quite as good as Spartacus, I disagree.  I'm am a big fan of Hollywood Epic movies.  I think Spartacus ranks up there as one of the best.  Gladiator is a very different picture and just as good.  Overall it's a sad film, but a film that has hope.  Russel Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix are both excellent.  They give fresh in-depth performances without giving us cliche Roman era characters.  The script is powerful, and the story compelling without ever seeming to sentimental or pious.  It's so refreshing to see a character like Maximus with the highest of principals come to life on screen without looking like a cartoon character in a bad script.  The sountrack is a perfect compliment to the look and feel of the movie and brings it up to another level.  Ridley Scott has given us a magnificent picture that I am sure will be looked upon as a masterpiece for years to come.

title: A great story.
review:
The story is about Maximus who was a general in the emperors army,but after his friend Commodus betrayed him,he became a slave and had to fight for his freedom.

This movie got lots of action,great story and of course great actors.(what more can you want.) I hadn't seen to many movies about the Roman empire so this one just blew me away. The fighting scenes is awesome,especially the ones in Coloseum.

This movie is absoulutely among my top ten movies,and I would recommend it to everyone.

9 out of 10

********* of **********

I loved it from beginning to end.

title: Excessively impressed half a year lately!
review:
Its extremly rare that one watches a movie that grabs your attention so much that over half a year later it is what you consider to be the best film you have seen recently. Gladiator certainly has had this effect on me! Where so many other films which, at the time of viewing I considered to be really stand-out have faded in impact over the march of time, Gladiator soldiers on.

In all departments Gladiator is one of the undeniable best. Its casting is perfect. Russell Crowe as 'Maximus' is a sight to behold. Having read the screenplay, the concept of his battlefield prowess and presence which is allured to is instantly recognisable on the screen. One see's Maximus as a man of honour, integrity, dignity and courage. By contrast Jouqain Phoneix as 'Commudus' epitomises a classic villain. Yet he rises above this and plays his character with such conviction one starts to believe he really exists. I gauge this by the fact that in seeing films in years to come with Phoenix, I will regard him still as not that character but Commudus. Connie Nielsen is also excellent in her role as 'Lucilla'. Richard Harris and the late Oliver Reed also support skillfully.

Cast aside, the two areas that impressed me above all in Gladiator were the score and the visuals. Ridley Scott is truly an awesome director and Hans Zimmer in my opinion beyond even John Williams. The seamless, and I do mean seamless, transitions between CGI and conventional film is a sight to behold. As I watched the film on the big screen, the sight of Rome and the Colleseum was awe-inspiring. It is extraordinarily immersive. Zimmers score with vocals by Lisa Gerrard is close to perfect amd easily his most accomplished yet. It is stirring at the right moments and sensetive when the mood dictates it. EVERYONE SHOULD OWN A COPY OF THE SCORE!!!

If one had to pick a weak point, I would have to opt for the script, which although brilliant was probably the least polished of the componets. However what really makes Gladiator stand head and shoulders above the rest is the manner in which it is epic, enthralling and exciting. It's a Hollywood blockbuster that manages to succesfully negotiate all the pitfalls that that conventionally entails. I highly recommend it!

title: Just OK. (warning mild spoiler)
review:
As a fan of Ridley Scott's previous movies "Alien" and "Blade Runner" I awaited "Gladiator" with great anticipation. I really wanted to like this movie, but was sorely disappointed for several reasons.

Firstly, the Gladitorial battle sequences are all fairly short lasting maybe a minute or two at the most. They are shot in such a fragmented, jerky and close up way that often it's very difficult to make out what exactly is going on. I hate to say this, but Ridley needs to take a few lessons from Mel Gibson on how to shoot a battle sequence. The look Scott uses here just doesn't work. Really, the only battle sequence that I enjoyed watching was the Chariot one and that did give me goosebumps, it was so good. Unfortunately, that does not make the movie.

The rest of the movie contains political intrigue which is quite mediocre.

A little too much here is similar to "Braveheart". Against great odds, Our hero wishes to avenge the death of loved ones. He carries a symbolic token of his wife and son. He dies in the end.

All in all this is a decent movie, but not as great as all the reviews are saying. This goes in the wait until it's out on video category. Sorry, it wouldn't have taken much to make me like this movie, but it just doesn't follow through.

title: Very good but overrated.
review: Gladiator is a very good movie. Russel Crow and Jaquin Pheonix both give quality performances and the movie is exciting and fun. The gladiator scenes in this movie were done well and interesting to watch, even though I have no idea how realistic they are. Still this movie is definatly not best picture quality. The screenplay is good, not great, and the story is really only slightly better than average. This movie has many similarities to another movie I felt was overrated, Braveheart. It's still very good, just not great. I give Gladiator an 8 out of 10.

title: I've watched it again and again
review: It gets better each time you watch it.  Overall, a fantastic movie that has everything - war, love, jealousy, betrayal... all of the Roman virtues. There's nothing like a Kiwi to spice up the main character; Russell Crowe makes the movie.  You can't help but to cheer him on in the arena, even if you don't like violence.

title: Pure, exciting, old-fashioned entertainment
review:
Every now and then, a film comes along with adrenaline-pumped action, first-class acting, delicious cinematography and with warm, old-fashioned storytelling charm. I believe that Gladiator is one of those films. Russell Crowe gives a memorable performance as the heroic Maximus Decimus Meridius, Joaquin Phoenix is sensually evil as the embittered, power-hungry Commodus and the late Oliver Reed gives one of his career-best turns as Maximus' idealistic trainer.

The story had enough depth to compliment the action sequences and the score to the film was just sensational. One of Han Zimmer's most accomplished compositions, and one to remember with nostalgic sentiment. Connie Nielsen was also credible as Lucilla, the troubled sister of Commodus, repressed of hope by her brother's dark affections towards her. The sheer magnitude of Rome, the fight sequences in the wilderness and the battles in the amphitheatre elevate this film from the run-of-the-mill Hollywood crowd of films, and witholds a historic value to boost its credibility.

I don't think its one of the best films of all time, because some of the subplots are not given the depth I would have liked, and some were given too much. The incestual relationship between Lucilla and Commodus lacked subtlety. The ending though, is very special. I think about Maximus' ideal of heaven and I wonder how close he is to the truth.

title: A perfect hero defined through a perfect story.
review: It is almost as sad to read the bad reviews here of "Gladiator" as it was to view the ending of the movie. I watched the movie as a human being in search of a wonderful story and visual experience, not as a wannabe critic as many reviewers here seem to have done.  I could find no fault with this movie: it had me choking back tears (in concealment from my girlfriend, of course) during many scenes; the battles where great; many actors/supporting actors gave awesome performances; the music inspired me to search music stores for Lisa Gerrard (what a beautiful voice, she melodically DEFINES the sadness in many tough scenes); etc--for sure! For those of you who write that this movie does not deserve the praise/honors it has received, I could only guess that this is because you're all unaccustomed or uncomfortable with seeing a movie about a hero doing well.  Or, some other bias holds you back. In any case, many more people with professional experience in the movie industry voted contrary to your tastes/opinions by placing this spectacular movie among the archives of the greats through their granting of awards. This may sound corny, but, there are some things in life that I'm thankful for having done or experienced or seen before I die: seeing "Gladiator" was one of them.  It was otherworldly; I got to escape from some of the dumber beasts of modern-day society for 3 hours and idolize a hero.

title: Good, but a poor man's Spartacus
review: "Gladiator" is a good action movie, but it's overrated. The battle sequences in the Colisseum are excellent, but outside of those scenes the film moves too slowly and is too long. I rate it 7. Russell Crowe's character is fighting for an ideal that is never really explained (what - a slightly less oppressive Roman Empire?), and so some of the drama seemed thin to me. Basically, Stanley Kubrick's "Spartacus" (1960) does everything "Gladiator" wants to do, and does it much better (including the fact that Spartacus is fighting for the more noble cause of ending slavery).

title: The only realistic movie about ancient Rome history
review:
The producers of this movie must know well ancient history, and, in the same time, they know well how to add fantastic elements to transform a simple movie into an awesome one...

Surprisingly, this movie shows high class elements in scripting, direction, acting, photography and action scenes.

The opening is epic; it represents a battle between Romans and ancient Germans. Never a movie on ancient history has shown a battle scene so well realised; not only it is highly exciting and dramatic but also, there is a historic realism in representation, battle technics, nomenclature. Apart classic elements, like an exciting show of the Roman phalanx in action covered with shields repelling German's arrows, You will see a series of innovative realistic historic features: very good costumes, war dogs, catapults and so long. The battle shown in "Spartacus", although good, was less realistic, and surely was far less enjoying and thrilling.

Another important thing is that this movie, unlike all other of its genre, shows the real religion of ancient Romans (substantially, the adoration of ancestors) with realism, respect and seriousness, not like old movies of this type, where this religion was considered only "paganism" and never showed.

And then, after this, You have wonderful actors and fantastic plot, perhaps a free variation on the real story of the despotic Commodus (in the reality, Commodus was killed in 192 a.c. by an ambush of a gladiator, Narcissus, hired by his sister and the Senate).

It is really the case to say: thumb up!

title: Are you not entertained?
review: Gladiator deserves immense praise. Ridley Scott directed a great film that helps people understand the Roman era's magnificence and it's horrors. Granted, Gladiator is very violent but the violence and gore never seems glorified or stylized to be gory just to gross out the audience. Gladiator is, in my opinion, one of the best war-drama films alongside Saving Private Ryan, and Braveheart. Gladiator has a sweep and style that is rare in Hollywood these days.

title: Good but Oscar worthy???
review: Ok is it oscar worthy yes and no.  It is a very good movie and should get awards for the Visual effects as they were absalutly wonderful but best picture??? I think Not.  For one yes it did have good directing but Ang Lee was better in Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon.  Acting.  Ok it did have good acting but sorry Tom Hanks Did a better job then Russell Crowe.  Other then that yes it was a good movie it had a ok storyline and for the acting that was good but lacked a few things as did the story line.  For one the story was the same throughout the whole movie you knew what was going to happen before it happened.  Fight after Fight.  Sorry he wouldn't have lasted but maybe 3 fights not as many as he did.  So people say it's a movie it dosn't have to be accurate.  Well I think it should be somewhat accurate.  other then that it did hold my attention and the music was totally good.  Richard harris did a good job.  It's a good movie and it's worth watching but it really didn't earn best picture in my opinion.  That would go to crouching Tiger hidden Dragan. (own both on DVD) I'd Give it a 8/10

title: Oscars aside...
review: I have heard debate over this film's Oscar-worthiness, and it may have not been the greatest film of the year. But disregarding that, it is a fine film, and one of those cases where you can't let all the hype  fool you into thinking it's over-hyped. Great direction, cinematograpy, score, etc, etc. A friend of mine (also a teen) bashed it for its "MTV-style direction ," perhaps referring to the frantic pacing in the battle scenes and the surreal dream sequences. I didn't see those as flaws. I think that if there's one that that this film has more than anything, it's feeling. Pain, anger, sitting through the whole film wanting to see Commodus dead. And that final scene - I can't find the word to describe it, but it simply left me awestruck. Or something like that. I once thought that if this film had any flaws, it would be its title, which seemed simplistic and stupidly obvious, sort of like "Titanic." But I eventually realized that this film isn't just a film about a gladiator in Ancient Rome, and I think some people have yet to see that.

title: Pretty good, but this overrated historical epic lacks heart.
review: "Gladiator" has a lot to commend it: Awesome fight scenes in the Coliseum, haunting images, and fine (albeit brief) supporting turns by Oliver Reed and Derek Jacobi.  But it's ultimately a three-character movie (Maximus, Lucilla, and Commodfus)and none of those three characters are all that interesting. The ending should be devastating in terms of emotional content, but it just lacks the heart of earlier Roman epics like "Spartacus" and even "Quo Vadis".  And, despite the lavish computer-generated effects, the film is sorely missing an epic scope.  Contrast Commodus's arrival in Rome with Cleo's spectacular entrance in the '63 "Cleopatra".  Maybe the latter film wasn't all that great either, but it captured the scale and pagentry that "Gladiator" misses.

title: Good, if you like Roman history
review:
2 remarks:

1. This is the first time I saw such a great scene about a Roman battle against Germans. You can see the Roman war methods in action.

2. I found the buildings at Forum Romanum a bit different from what you can see there as tourist. The real Senat seemed to me (a) much smaller than in movie (b) and the real entry into Senat did not lead towards the Coloseum, as it is in the movie.

title: MAXIMUS IS MAXIMUM ENTERTAINMENT
review:
A truly epic film of brutal proportions. Magnificent from start to finish. The opening battle displays the sheer military might of the Rome war machine. A glorious film worthy of my namesake God Mars.

VALE OLIVER REED.

title: Ridley delivers again.
review:
Gladiator. It conjures up images of honor, bravery, courage strength, and stoicism. One would think that a Hollywood movie would not be able to capture such qualities on film, sacrificing realism for the fluff, sex scenes, gratuitous violence and stilted weak plots.

Ridley Scott doesn't make that kind of movie. He brings to the screen a very realistic seeming portrayal of life as a Gladiator in the Roman Empire. Russell Crowe gave one of the most amazing performances of his career, bringing the title character to life, and managing to make Maximus real in just a few short hours.

Definitely a movie to see. It has subtlety for those who like to think in movies, but it also has action and betrayal for those who don't.

All I can say is, Thank you Mr. Scott. Keep 'em coming.

title: A great epic that I hope will not spawn others...
review:
I was surprised opening night at my local cinemas only attracted 50 or so people to the 9pm screening, but I never use that to guage anything.

Visually the film is awe inspiring, with a visual feast that never lets up. In some earlier scenes gore was cut down (to receive its M15 rating here in Australia no doubt) with fast film cuts and close down action. Still, it managed to put the action scenes in Braveheart to shame. Various film effects were used, the most noticable being the blue tinge of night (or cold), or the rich red warmth of daytime (or warm).

Aurally I've never heard a better sound mix. You can literally follow a horse galloping from one side of the screen to the other with your eyes closed. The rear speakers get heavy use, with crowds and sometimes some very curious noises during battle.

The acting by all parties was well above par, apart from some extras who got a bit glued to the camera. You may notice from the start no accents are played up, so Crowe speaks in his Australian accent, Phoenix has his USA accent intact. This DOES NOT make the movie worse! Instead, it relaxes you, and also saves you from the rehearsed and sometimes awful attempts at accents that actors really burden themselves with.

Phoenix (who is finally past being "River's brother") is despicably evil as Commodus, so much so that I believe if you had ever met this character you might not think twice of punching him right in the face. Crowe however is now hot property thanks to this film, to which he deserves every minute.

The length of the film is not a problem (2 1/2 hours) as the pace of the film is fast, and could quite easily had taken 3-4 hours if the powers that be chose to do so.

This brings me to another point, the 'sequel' factor. Please Hollywood, don't give us even one more movie in this vein, as this has done for Roman Empires what Saving Private Ryan did for War movies.

Watch it on the big screen? Yea, unless you can wait and have a huge TV. Ridley Scott (of Alien fame) will have a great year, as Hannibal is set for release this year also...

Overall, A great movie, with some decent plot twists, that keeps you enthralled from the beginning to the end!

-----------------------------------------

Chris Gray is an avid Film watcher, DVD reviewer, webmaster, and most importantly an Aussie. You can see his Australian DVD site DVD-MAX, at this address: www.dvd-max.8m.com

----------------------------------------- Copyright 2000+

title: Incredible
review: The first time I saw the preview for Gladiator I thought that it would be nothing more than an excellent summer action film in the vein of Men In Black or Die Hard or something like that.  But after seeing this movie I realized I was completely wrong.  This movie is near-epic.  It's actually smart.  The directing is nearly flawless and the dialogue is amazing too. I just can't believe this is the same guy who did "1492".  That is amazing. Scott uses some excellent time-lapse photography and surreal dream shots that seem out of place for a time but in the end fit right into place.  The action sequences just add to the film.  Scott puts you right into the battle at the beginning as well as in the Roman Coliseum for the gladiator fights. The characters are rich and colorful and the ending is incredible.  I would compare it to Braveheart and also add that it is almost as perfect.  See this movie.  It will be the best of the summer.

title: Fresh story line and cool but predictable
review:
The opening battle scenes are terrific, and the story rolls from there.

Aside from a serious problem with predictable plot lines, the movie was one of the most entertaining ones I saw all year.

The acting is terrific, and the film is clean and crisp. Phoenix is delightfully hateful, and in the theatre where I was watching, evoked a sarcastic "aww" from the crowd at one point, as he was whining to sis about getting no respect.

Oliver Read was the true star of the film. A fitting epitath to a fine actor of the classic roles.

title: Overrated and derivative
review:
To give Gladiator its due, the music is good and aspects of the filming are also much above average. Unfortunately, there is little to either the story line or the acting to understand the ridiculous comments regarding the quality of this movie. The antagonist is reminiscent of Caligula with over-acting and a twisted personality that defies understanding where his political strength came from. The protagonist is wooden and compares poorly to all the prior "heroes" of this genre. Russell Crowe manages to make Victor Mature look good which is quite an accomplishment.

When you start a movie by having the aging caesar far removed from the political center of Rome decide that he will confront his perverted son and announce that the son is getting the shaft and the general is getting the glory, credibility drops like a stone. No one but Maximus, the son and the daughter know of the plans for succession. Oh, surprise! son kills father. Son kills Maximus' family. Maximus spends the movies going through slavery, remote gladiator contests, Rome and final confrontation. If there was one clever plot element along the way, I missed it. Gladiator=glad it was over.

title: Great Site, Visit all the Time
review: In This Oscar Winning Triumph, Russell Crowe stars as Maximus, a roman general who is favoured highly but Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), but when Marcus chooses Maximus as his successor, his greedy son Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) is jealous and kills his father and sentences Maximus to Death. He Escapes, and becomes a Gladiator, leading to a nasty showdown with Commodus, now emperor. This Film is beautifully filmed, features excellent performances (most notably, Oliver Reed's last performance as slave driver Proximo), and is an entertaining and riveting epic, that mustn't be missed. 10/10 x Infinity

title: Comments to show how wonderful the movie is.
review: I really loved this movie! It is now my favorite movie of all time. I wish I had gone to see it at the theatres, but I didn't know much about it. My mom rented the movie and it stole my heart. It has a great story with all the good characteristics you want in a movie.

title: A window on the past
review: For the first time ever we have seen what it was really like to be among the Roman army as they do battle.  The opening scenes of Gladiator are jaw-dropping, as we witness not the clean and  clinical Roman war machine that history describes, but a rough, dirty and brutal killing force. Russell Crowe is perfect as Maximus (among his other names - The Spaniard, The General, or just plain Gladiator).  Great performances too from the rest of the cast. The fight scenes are excellent, the gladiator costumes are brilliant. Ridley Scott has done it again, this film should do well at the next oscars. Hail Maximus!

title: Absolutely stunning; an instant classic.
review:
Gladiator is a film that will be remembered for a long time. A four-star masterpiece and an instant classic, the film will not only solidify Russell Crowe as one of the best actors of his generation, it should also reacquaint the world with the sometimes unfortunately forgotten genius of Ridley Scott.

The film follows Crowe as a Roman general named Maximus; a man feared by his enemies and revered by his men. Gladiator opens with a crawl reminding the audience of the might of ancient Rome, and the breadth of its power -- at one time, "one quarter of the world lived and died" under the rule of the Caesars.

The picture begins with the last battle between Rome and the "barbarians" in then-Germania -- a stunning sequence which not only sets the tone for the dazzling spectacle the movie becomes, but also shows the viewer how exactly skilled the Romans were in the art of war.

Without revealing too much of the plot, a new emperor (an amazing Joaquin Phoenix) takes power, and Maximus is sent into slavery. As a slave he soon becomes a gladiator -- as was the practice under some of the Caesars, and his skill on the battlefield translates well to the arena. Soon thousands flock to the Coliseum -- flawlessly created with the help of computer-generated shots -- to see Maximus fight. By winning the crowd, Maxiumus hopes to get a chance to seek his revenge on Commodus, the unjust ruler who ruined his life.

The film is stunning in every respect -- from acting, to action, to direction, to set design, and should become an instant classic.

title: true to the past with all the brilliance of present technology
review: Although there might be spots where cutting would improve, there are so many truly stirring scenes that it is hard to fault the final package.  My friend who studied Vergil with me and has taught Latin confirmed my impression that they had all the important historical details right.  The hommage to Leni Riefenstal when Commodus returns to Rome is killer. The scenes when Maximus prays to his portable Lares and Penates just blew me away. Anyone with a drop of testosterone should get quite a kick out of the "end" of the Germania war.  Must see.

title: **** 1/2 Excellent return to sword-and-sandal epics
review: Ridley Scott's best film in years is this astonishing epic of Roman proportions about a great general (Russell Crowe) who is demoted to gladiator slave when the kindhearted emperor (Richard Harris) dies and his selfish and callous son (Joaquin Phoenix) takes over. The plot moves smoothly over its vast size without stopping for a second, climaxing in excellent fight scenes that combine state of the art sound effects with Scott's unbeatable visual flair. Crowe gives a star making performance as the lead, and Connie Nielsen stands out in a pretty ineffective role as the princess who must watch her brother destroy everything her beloved father worked so hard for. One of the most exciting films of the year.

title: How did this movie win!? Doesn't anyone else remember that this is a genre pic?
review: Doesn't anyone else remember that gladiator movies are a genre? If not, allow me to educate. Gladiator movies (like the old steve reeves hercules pictures) were companions to the old spaghetti westerns or the errol flynn style swashbuckling pictures. The movies were successful because they were fun and simple, but that was it. They were sometimes grand in that they had a lot of extras (even when the occasional roman soldier can be seen wearing a gold watch), but that was really it. The plots were nothing special. They were all pretty much the same, actually. Element one, larger than life hero who just wants to be left alone to live his life has been stripped of everything by the evil villain. Element two, said villain. Element three, a girl. Put all three together, let the hero triumph over insurmountable odds, cut and print, and you've got your picture. Sound familiar? Now, it's great to see this genre picked up again for fun, even if it did take itself a little too seriously, but PLEASE, don't go around saying it was a great movie. It was just a gladiator movie, nothing special. Don't get your idea of ancient roman civilization from the movie either, spend some time in the library for christsake.

title: Absolute Perfection and Class
review:
i have to say this movie is literally perfect. From acting to story, from music to cinematography and from special effects to anything else a film can be judged on it is just brilliant. it is a pure epic. This is not your cheapo action summer flick like X-men. Everything has been thought out so well, and choice for all the actors and actresses were spot on, since i think nobody could have pulled it off as well as the main man Russell Crowe, which i like to say "well done" for receiving his oscar. From the opening scene of the wheat field, you know its a film which is going to be emotional and deep, and when the first battle appears, you know its going to be loud and fast moving. This film has just one of the best endings i have ever seen (i won't say just incase you haven't seen it)

Believe me it has it all, you will not be disappointed.

"What we do in life, echoes in eternity"...so go and watch and enjoy!

title: Stunning! Re-watchable.
review:
I'm sure most people who like this movie, do it because of its strong orientation on one's feelings. It's quite the same thing as Titanic (although I didn't like Titanic), that simply attracts so many people who actually might have very different taste.

Furthermore, it has something for everyone: action, intrigue, love (not merely between a man and a woman) and even history (only visual, though) - fantastic battles, costumes, and decorations. As these kind of movies are often considered to be just bare money-machines by a lot of critics, Gladiator goes far beyond that level. There are very few categories about the film that I wouldn't like to rate as perfect. The way Scott has managed to create an atmosphere of the time of Roman Empire, the pain you can see in Crowe's eyes almost all throughout the movie as the betrayed general Maximus, incredibly powerful soundtrack composed by H. Zimmer - these are the first thoughts that come in mind.

Personally, I always get carried away by the anger and oppression that I feel together with Maximus. So even if there were more scenes that wouldn't remind me of his pain, it wouldn't really matter because the tension simply is already high enough, until the end. And the end is much more than a classic "happy end" would be, it is beautiful! So is the film itself, too.

I simply had to give it 10/10, because of the effect it has to me everytime I watch it. Otherwise I wouldn't be fair.

title: Excellent!!!
review:
One of the best movies I've ever seen.

Nice acting of Russell Crowe - he absolutely deserved the Oscar!

Makes you feel you're part of battle - pretty scary and realistic.

title: Why does no one see that this movie has no story.
review:
I did not like this film at all. Ridley Scott has sold out to the Hollywood Studio System and he is rewarded for it. This is a smaller reworking of "The Fall Of the Roman Empire."

Story...what story, with the exception of the cinematography this is an artless movie, how it won Best Picture is way beyond me.

The production qualities were definitely high, the acting was very good, the directing was excellent, yet the story is something everyone seems to miss, the entire body of the story is summed up in it's Tagline.

Why, why, why are people letting American Cinema become so artless, the script was obviously approved because it follows the Hollywood formula to a "T."

Anymore people go to a movie to be "entertained" not to learn, not to "think" and sure who doesn't just like going to a movie to not have to think, but I would like to expect a Best Picture Winner to have just 2 qualities, 1...Make it Original, and 2...Make people think.

title: Ben Hur resurrected!
review: Finally we are back to films that have everything: Great actors (you just love to hate Joaquin Phoenix!), Brilliant music, moving storylines and all the action you could possibly want.  From the historical accuracy to the marvellous recreation of Rome I cannot fault Gladiator.  I have never before seen such a movie that almost (note ALMOST) puts Ben Hur and Spartacus to shame. Russell Crowe deserved his Oscar and it's a shame that Joaquin Pheonix missed out. Brilliantly entertaining and marvellously accurate.

title: This was clearly the best movie of 2000
review: This was clearly the best movie of 2000. From a well written script to near perfect direction by Ridley Scott who understood the genre in which he was working in. The music as scored by Hans Zimmer can and does stand alone. Every one was ideally suited for their roles from Joaquin Phoenix as the deliciously wicked Commodus to Derek Jacobi's senator. But the film belongs to Russell Crowe who is quickly becoming one of the finest actors of his time. Crowe simply excels as Maximus as man who only wanted to go home.

title: This was clearly the best movie of 2000
review: This was clearly the best movie of 2000. From a well written script to near perfect direction by Ridley Scott who understood the genre in which he was working in. The music as scored by Hans Zimmer can and does stand alone. Every one was ideally suited for their roles from Joaquin Phoenix as the deliciously wicked Commodus to Derek Jacobi's senator. But the film belongs to Russell Crowe who is quickly becoming one of the finest actors of his time. Crowe simple excels as Maximus as man who only wanted to go home and go home he did. All hail Maximus !

title: Absolutely the best of 2000!
review: It's been a year today since I first saw "Gladiator" at the movies and it's beyond me why it took me so long to write a review for it but here it is now. Russell Crowe plays the title role (Maximus) to perfection and makes it impossible to imagine anyone else in the role. Winning an Oscar as Best Actor (it was really a consolation prize for his loss last year for "The Insider") made me VERY happy and he was very humble and dignified while making his acceptance speech at the Oscars in March. Joaquin Phoenix made an incredible breakthrough as the villain Commodus and should have won the supporting actor Oscar for his performance, while Miss Connie Nielsen is convincing as Lucilla, Commodus' sister and Maximus' love interest (but only as a lukewarm love interest since he has eyes really for his late wife). The sets which also should have won (they lost to "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", but the brilliant costumes won so there is some consolation in that) and the score as well. The Academy is just getting more and more benevolent in regards to splitting the awards evenly between several different movies. But "Gladiator" by far is the winner of the year. Viva la Crowe!!!

title: Gripping from first to last fight
review:
Ridley Scott has certainly banished the demons of White Squall and GI Jane with this fantastic offering. Crowe is superb as the determined Maximus, but he is matched by fight choreography and the rich CG visuals of Rome at its height. The opening battle sequence betters anything in Braveheart, although the slow motion was overused. The standout feature of the film was the depiction of Rome; from the streets, to the emperial palace to the Colloseum. It equalls anything presented in Bladerunner or one of Lucas' offerings (with the use of CG birds being on a par with the Ewoks)

This is the film of the year. It does not deserve the tag "event film" as it is not a shody piece of work held together by some shiny computer code but a heart-pumping, sword-swinging, sweat and blood soaked masterpiece with superb visuals, intellegent script and flawless performances from the leads.

see it, then put aside another 3 hours to see it again

title: EXCELLENT
review:
This film is absolutely incredible, it is 3 hours of some of the best direction and choerography I have seen.

The fight scenes are amazing and I would strongly recommend that you watch this on the feature-packed DVD.

title: Great movie? Yes! Best picture? Hmmmm...
review:
I saw Gladiator last May and really enjoyed it. I have never seen a movie of this scope and dealing with this subject, so I thought that it was original for today's types of movies. I am a big fan of Russell Crowe and thought that he did a great job in the title role of Maximus. He is a very strong character who follows his own path and ideas, but shows a tender side in his desire to be with his family. The majority of the cast was great, especially Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus. He has a very strong talent and will be sure to make an impact in movies in the future. However, I thought that Connie Neilsen's Lucilla was a bit weak and while she did display some independence in her actions and thoughts, she still held true to the standards of typical women's roles. While I did think that the movie was great, it was hardly the best picture of 2000... but I'm not sure what would be instead. It was a fairly weak year for the movies in comparison with recent years, especially 1999. It was nice to see Russell Crowe win the Oscar for best actor, but he should have received it LAST year for his stirring portrayal of Jeffrey Wigand instead of Maximus. His performance in Gladiator was excellent, but somehow it did not measure up to his former role. I still believe that Tom Hanks was robbed for not getting an Oscar instead!

7/10

title: Best Gladiator movie ever, Best movie of the year!
review:
Yes, it's without a doubt the best Gladiator movie ever, not only because it's excellent, but because it's the only one since "Spartacus". It's won Best Picture so obviously it's the best movie of the year! The fight scenes are breathtaking but ,although it has a well developed plot, it does tend to get a bit dull at times. Nevertheless, THIS MOVIE ROCKS! And it'll BLOW YOU AWAY!!!! Thumbs up 'Nuff said.

**********************9/10******************

title: Well done but overrated !
review: I was a little disappointed in this movie, what with all its Academy Award hype.  This was a good movie, well worth your time but this was not a great movie.  The story line was borrowed from a half dozen different movies depicting gladiators.  The acting was professional  but the only Academy Award performance I saw was Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius and that part was so small it had no impact on the film.  Definitely not family fare as it is very bloody from start to finish.  Preview this movie but it would become very tiring in any film library.  I rated this a 7.

title: Symbolism in Gladiator (warning: potential spoiler)
review: The film Gladiator, directed by Ridley Scott, contains many elements of symbolic nature. This becomes evident in the story very quickly. Although most Ridley Scott films seem completely pointless, this film is surprisingly deep. The first obvious symbol that is shown in this movie is the wheat field that Maximus is walking through several times throughout the movie. This field symbolizes his view of paradise. We know that this is the ideal place that he wants to be, because there is a scene where he describes his home, and the way he describes it shows plainly that he prefers that place over any other. Another symbol in the movie is Maximus' habit of rubbing his hands in the soil before battle. This symbolizes his ability to know his enemy; also to know the battlefield. A third symbol in Gladiator is the child and mother dolls, which are physical representations of Maximus' family in the afterlife. These dolls are used very effectively in the denouement of the story, where Juba buries the dolls in the center of the Coliseum. This represents the closure that Maximus has attained through his death. Fourthly, we see another symbol in the wooden sword of the character Proximo. This sword represents not only the freedom of Proximo, but also foreshadows the freedom that Maximus is to attain. Unfortunately, Maximus dies just as he achieves his freedom, which is a slightly ironic but very necessary plot twist. Gladiator is a multi-faceted film that contains all the elements of a true epic, and is quite a masterpiece. Symbolism is well used in this movie, and the instances where it is used, both obvious and not so obvious, show evidence of much creative thought.

title: Very Entertaining, if Slightly Overrated, Epic
review:
`Gladiator' is a splendid, action-packed throwback to sandal epics such as `Spartacus'. Russell Crowe is Maximus, a general in the Roman army. After crushing an army of Gauls, Maximus meets with the Emperor of Rome, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris). Marcus Aurelius tells Maximus that he wishes Rome to become a Republic once more, after his death . . . and that he would like Maximus to help create this new Republic. Afterwards, Aurelius goes to see his spoiled son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), and tells him that he does not feel Rome should have another Emperor. In a fit of rage, Commodus kills Aurelius and becomes emperor, and then promptly orders the execution of Maximus. Maximus manages to escape his own death . . . . but his wife and son, alas, do not. Fast forward a few years (exactly how the following transpires is never clear), and Maximus is a slave, a gladiator forced to kill in order to entertain the Roman people. As his popularity as a gladiator grows, Maximus begins to see how he can exact his vengeance upon Commodus.

For the most part, `Gladiator' is well-acted. Russell Crowe is quietly intense as the former general Maximus, and manages to effortlessly pull off a memorable performance in what could've been a wooden role in other hands. Richard Harris is good as the wise and weary Marcus Aurelius, and the late Oliver Reed is excellent in his final role as Proximo, the cunning gladiator trainer. The weak link of the cast is Joaquin Phoenix, who I still can't believe was nominated for Best Supporting Actor for his stiff, awkward portrayal of Commodus. I found him annoying instead of terrifying  Commodus needed to be a fearful tyrant, and instead he was little more a petulant child. This might have been more how the role was written instead of Joachim Phoenix's acting skill, but the character of Commodus still brought the movie down. Ridley Scott's direction is superb  the battle scenes and the gladiator fights are wonderfully done, and the movie has a grand, epic feel that's been missing from the big screen for far too long. The use of CGI to recreate Rome is incredible as well. Where the film falls apart to a certain extent is the story  there are a few plot holes that are just big enough to be distracting. For example, the audience watching `Gladiator' in the theater or at home on their DVD player are given plenty of reasons to hate the vile Commodus . . . but it's never made clear why the Roman people would hate him. The Emperor puts on lots of gladiator tournaments, gives out free bread, free wine  hey, the average Roman should love Commodus! So why isn't he? Little points like this drag `Gladiator' down slightly  and while these detractions certainly don't make `Gladiator' a bad film, I think they're enough to pull it down off the masterpiece mantel. Personally, while I really liked `Gladiator', I think even nominating it for Best Picture of 2000 was a stretch, and as for actually winning the Best Picture Oscar . . . no. It's good, but not that good.

Still, an intense epic worth watching. A-

title: Good, sure. Great? No, uh-uh. Overall a 6.75 out of 10
review: I should preface this review by stating that I'm something of an expert in the area of weapons and armament. Most folks aren't going to notice or care about the many things I found wrong with the film, but the HUGE number of historical inaccuracies were distracting to me. For the sake of the readers, I won't go into a lot of detail and will only point out two examples. In one of the scenes Crowe and his fellow gladiators approach a table filled with helmets. Each gladiator picks a helm and moves on. Two helmets were 9th-10th century Norse and two(?) helmets were most likely 12th century Turkish. If someone is going to drop a ton of dough making an "epic" (such as Gladiator is alleged to be), wouldn't you think they'd spend a couple of bucks on a military or historical advisor with, perhaps a high school knowledge of history? In this great "film" a senator states Rome was originally founded as a Republic. Yes, and I'm the Easter Bunny. The storyline itself wasn't terribly objectionable, as long as you don't expect a lesson in history. What I did find redeemable about this film is what many left-wing reviewers found the most upsetting and that is the objective portayal of a man who was patriotic and loyal to the idea of a concept and entity larger than himself. Whether some pseudo intellectual bed-wetting types want to accept it or not, Roman military types were often motivated by feelings of nationalism. Fascistic, maybe, but that is the way many thought. The makers of the film obviously never intended to propogandize, they merely showed things the way they were. It's amusing how the far left and the far right are outraged at the truth when it doesn't fit their preconceived notions of reality. If you merely want a film to entertain and don't give a hoot about history, go for it! The combat scenes are fun and there's enough of a sentimental subplot to make this an enjoyable flick for romantic types of either sex. The acting wasn't great, but it wasn't bad either. Oscar material, I think not. Entertainment, you bet!

title: Flesh, blood and brains.
review: The gladiator shown in this movie is a man of flesh, blood and brains, not only integer, will-powered and physically dominant, but also intelligent and sensitive. A real difference from previous movies on similar themes. Further on the whole film is breathtaking by acting achievements, special effects and sound-track. Very lucky I saw it, because mostly I am not so interested in big show-pieces.

title: Well done, Russell Crowe!
review:
The film seems to be symptomatic: an empire turns out a film about an empire. So what do the audiences get? On the one hand, the scriptwriter will obviously not set the Thames on fire. The plot is very predictable, the action (especially in the first part of the film) dragged out, dialogue anaemic. There is a "politically correct" Juba and the optimistic end. Good guys go home, the evil emperor is punished, Commodus's sister makes another stilted speech. The drawbacks are numerous: first, I doubt that Marcus Aurelius looked so old (he died when he was 59), second, the child Lucius looks like a typical American kid with strange outfit on, Commodus was killed after he had reigned in Rome for 12 years.

So what keeps this film from being a tedious pseudo-Roman stuff? First of all, Russell Crowe. He managed to convey that sense of inborn dignity which can't be taken from a real Man. He did a very good job of his character bordering on magic (taking the poor stuff he had to work with into consideration). Second, it's the sound-track. And third, it's the work of the cameramen. The magnificent landscapes, the huge moon, the glimpses of the other world, the silver cypresses moving in the wind. I believe the film is hardly a new word in cinema, BUT it's a story of a Man, a human being at last, not a story of mundane violence. I think people are getting pretty tired of drugs and addicts, cops and mobsters, tearful soap operas. It's a "fairy tale" of course, too, but not a bad one.

I'd like to mention that an imdb-user Aleona said it was implausible that a Roman emperor had fought a gladiator. An encyclopedia says about Commodus that he took part in gladiator fights.

title: A cliché that's not...
review:
Let's get one thing straight. Gladiator is a clichéd movie. From its battle-scene beginnings to its battle-scene endings, Gladiator is predictable.

Ish. And that's where the excitement comes in.
