And about gladiators they were not only slaves.Many of them were free man who were searching for glory,fame and most of all money. Why does Hollywood have to ridicule history?And what a false praise to Republics.The Roman Empire survived with its original capital between 27 Bc and 476 AD and continued to survive without it.What Rebublic ever survived 503 years?This movie is a disgrace considering it's plot and it's messages.

title: Hounsou and old actors made the film
review:
I think this is a fairly overhyped project,judging by the nominations and awards it got.Russell Crowe's performance was solid,but no way big enough for an AA(academy award).Connie Nielsen overplayed her part and fluked it for most of the film.Phoenix was ok at first,but became more and more tense and uncomfortable in his role.

No,the biggest credit should be given to the wonderful work of Djimon Hounsou and old british actors Oliver Reed and Richard Harris.They made me enjoy the film,much more than any battle scene or interplay between Crowe and Nielsen.Reed specially should have been given an oscar,posthumously that is.Djimon Hounsou has made a reputation with this film which will last long.And this is a marvel he has to look proud at.So,my 7 goes to him.

title: Food for the easily pleased
review: This movie is by far the most overrated 2 and a half hours in Hollywood history. Riddley Scott, best known for his grand imagery in films, falls short with this movie. There is virtually not character development as well as cheesy, super fake looking special effects. The movie is a spectacle though. And as I bash it I must also say that I own it on DVD. Worth seeing but not worth the best movie Oscar.

title: Have you looked at it twice?
review:
I used to be a big Ridley Scott fan, when masterpieces like Alien and Blade Runner made me think he was almost Kubrick's peer.

Since 1492, yet, I wonder who is actually this guy. I just can't believe someone can change so much from artistic craftmanship to commercial fast mediocre production.

All of his movies since 1492 has been merely average Hollywood productions, with solid scenery and photography I agree, but nothing more than Roland JoffÃ© or some other directors. And his movies then respected all of Holywood's codification, would it be for the music, the editing etc... CLICHES!!

And Scott was almost forgotten by the cinephiles...

With Gladiator, suddenly, Scott makes a "come-back", with a lot of advertising... Then what is it?

Well, to me, it's the same Ridley Scott who made 1492.

While Gladiator has a brillant photography, the poor psychology, the mediocre scenery and the bad editing turns the whole thing into an average peplum with lots of visual effects to compensate the lack of substance.

Sure, some scenes are very good, Ridley has a lot of savoir-faire then is able to make some very good shots just because he's fundamentally talented.

But I simply can't understand how so many people just can't see the vacuity of this film, and the mediocrity of its production!

So my question to all the people who rated this film with reverential "10" is: Have you actually looked at it twice, and AFTER all the hype?

title: HUGE let-down
review:
Gladiator was a very very lucky movie, having been released in the awful year 2000 there is nothing in this mundane movie to fetch it 5 (!!) oscars.

Sure, Russell Crowe was very good, the casting and costume was great. The music was out of the world but the rest just fade in oblivion. The biggest disappointment for me was the poor character sketching. Where are the complex characters? Throughout the movie every character is just a good guy or the bad guy. Black or white. Where are the shades of grey? those mysterious characters that elevate drama to the next stage.

I would call this an average movie that has been over-rated because of the mediocrity that it surrounded itself with. Instead of Aussie Russell Crowe, watch his fellow A Mel Gibson in the classic "Braveheart" for a truly complex and heart-rending epic.

An average 5 (mostly for the music and technical wizardy)

title: am I the only one?
review:
good film, of that i've no doubt. but to receive the heralded fanfare that gladiator got, i'd have expected it to be the best thing i've ever seen.

what you do get is a wonderful looking film, russell crowe growling his way through a meaty part (nowhere near as well as in l.a. confidential however) and some well choreographed fighting and action sequences.

my major beef with this film was the cheesy script and the acting from the supporting cast. the plot was lofted directly from that of braveheart and it was too damn long.

i know i'm in the minority here, but what the heck - each to their own. i've seen better in the past, and i'm 100% sure i'll see much, much better again.

title: My cousin loves this movie.
review: Gladiator isn't such a bad movie, nor a good movie.  The storyline is interesting, and so is the acting.  One thing it lacks is the setting.  It's always dark, especially in the beginning.  One other characteristic that it lacks is a good ending.  I don't want to reveal it, but it was typical. Gotta make something new.  My cousin loved this movie, however.

title: overrated
review: I've seen this twice. Once in the theater and again on video. Each time was a disappointment. Judging from the look of the film it truly desires to be great, but ultimately it fails. Talk about woeful miscasting - Mr. Phoenix is atrocious (he is so much better in Clay Pigeons, and U-Turn). I can hardly watch him anytime he is on the screen. And what's with Lucilla's son? He looks like a pre-pubescent Adrian Lyne circa "Fatal Attraction". I disliked the score by Hans Zimmer - yet another component of a film that yearns to be epic, but isn't. Disappointing also in it's outright theft of Gustav Holst's "The Planets". Lisa Gerrard's beautiful voice is unquestionably suited for a vast, cinematic opus. This isn't it. This film suffered from too much explaining of it's special effects. Knowing how fake the Coliseum is with it's liberal use of CGI robbed me of any awe it could have produced. I didn't like the slow-motion effects in the opening battle scenes. And the dog jumping through fire? Please. A film that should have been great, but is just another over-hyped (but I did love the Kid Rock trailer-music promo), poorly executed waste of two hours.

title: disappointing
review:
Gladiator was not a bad movie, but I must say that I was disappointed with it. Maybe my expectations were too high (hard to believe with most of the movies coming out now a days). But I came out of the movie feeling a bit ripped off.

The acting was solid. Russell Crowe made a good brooding hero. But my main grievance with the movie would be the total lack of originality in the story. Basically change Maximus to a NY city cop, Rome to NY and the Emporer to a corrupt politician and you would have pretty much every other action film to come out of Hollywood. They billed it as a throw back to the epic Roman Empire era movies like a Sparticus or Ben Hur, but it just wasn't. Basically it was the same ole, same ole with some good acting.

title: Looking Back...
review: I just watched "Gladiator" the other day, and to be honest, it's not as great as I remember.  Sure the fight scenes are great, but at some points it becomes boring and uninteresting.  The acting is okay, except I found Joaquin Phoenix to get a bit annoying.  It's not quite on the same level as "Braveheart".  Watch that one instead.  6/10

title: boring
review: I did not hate this movie, but I can't see why everybody else loves it. It's an everyday movie about revenge. It's just an regular old adventure movie. At some points I even found it to be incredibly boring. Sure the fight sequences are amazing I'll give you that. But other than that this movie isn't special at all. 6/10

title: I Really Like Russell Crowe!
review:
He is a truly skilled actor, very intense and dramatic, and his style is magnificent. I am starting to watch him in all of his movies, and he has made a true fan of me! His performance in Gladiator was exquisite. He was just so believable. His accent, though try as he may to mask it still projected itself into the movie and this I truly loved and found so fascinating about him. I love to hear this man speak. He does give a solid strong performance in this role. I have always been a fan of Oliver Reed and he will be missed. What a wonderful performer he has been and a wonderful addition to the ranks of all the wonderful actors their have been in hollywood. This movie is one that will be added to my collection. With the awesome good looks this man has, I am certain their are many plans to utilize him in many more projects to come. I look forward to see what is fresh and new in the coming time for Russell Crowe.

Peace Sandy

title: B-O-R-I-N-G
review: I went in with the greatest of expectations.  I left highly disappointed. This film takes forever to get going, and when it does, the going is SLOW!!! Does it have stunning visuals?  Yes.  Is the cast okay?  Yes.  Does one care?  NOPE.  The film commits the cardinal sin of action epics ... it's B-O-R-I-N-G.  My suggestion?  Save a couple of bucks and rent the Cuba Gooding, Jr. version instead.

title: Groan a minute
review:
After finally getting to see this film, I wondered what all the fuss was about. By the end I was bored to death by the trite story and corny dialogue. The special effects are terrible (as bad as any film of the 1950s about ancient Rome), and it is only saved somewhat by the fact that the actors (if a little camp) seemed to believe that this was real life. And who chose the terrible music that burdened the film with meaning it did not possess? Has anyone noticed that when millions of dollars are spent on a film (Titanic, Pearl Harbor, Gladiator), very little of that is channelled into the dialogue? In the end the only thing that holds these films together are the actors (not all, but usually just enough of them).

As my parents used to say, they don't make films like they used to. Well, they do still make good films, but only if there is a very strict budget.

So, thumbs down.

title: Excellent!
review: This movie was brilliant.  Breathtaking and wonderful.  Very detailed, and it left me on the edge of my seat.  It was sad, but an excellent movie. (the best ever!) I recommend everyone to check it out, it's a wonderful movie that has great fight scenes as well as great acting.  This is without a doubt Russell Crowe's best movie I have scene yet.  I would definetly buy it, and see it again.

title: A disappointment
review:
I've seen this movie a couple of times, and I still don't understand why so many people love it so much. I so wanted to love this movie, but I just don't get it. I really liked the authenticity of the sets and props and such, and the initial fight scene was very good, but the movie bored me to tears! Perhaps I just don't enjoy revenge fantasies. Anyway, I couldn't help watching this and thinking "Russell Crowe really deserved the Oscar for 'The Insider', not this piece of Hollywood pap." But the rest of my roommates absolutely love this movie, so maybe it's just me.

I've got to file this movie under "Movies that were WAY too overhyped". I may have enjoyed it more if I hadn't been told how incredibly fantastic it was.

title: I can't believe this film won Best Picture
review:
This movie winning best picture is an example of how corrupt the Academy Oscar Award system must be, even Russell Crowe should not have won best actor (or even have gotten nominated period). Tom Hank's performance in Cast Away was far better even if he has two oscars already and Cast Away itself wasn't that great. Don't get me wrong though I believe that Crowe is a good actor and I would have given him a nomination for his role in L.A. Confidential. Gladiator is a summer movie and that is all it was. This movie was incomplete and full of cliches, and then out of no where the film ends abruptly, with of course a show down between Crowe and Phoenix. I believe that Roger Ebert is a great critic, and have no problem with the rating he gave this film (one and a half stars), but I don't agree with how he rates certain films such as summer movies. When a filmmaker makes a film such as a summer movie they usually aren't going after best picture, they're more going after giving you a ride, and if this is the case you should critique the film on this basis, and not judge it as though it was meant to be some kind of masterpiece in the art of film, however even on this basis Gladiator still somewhat fails. I was given this film on DVD and I sold it without even watching it. In order for a film to be worthy of beset picture or even good, the film must be tied up and have no loose ends, all issues should be dealt with and after the movie being almost 3 hours it actually has no story. When I first (the only time I watched it) watched Gladiator I thought that there was going to be some kind of inventive story line and then out of no where the film turns into a senseless basher movie. And if the Academy is going to allow films like this to continue to get nominations, some other film festival should be deemed more prestigious. This kind of thing is just scary, the next thing you know Pearl Harbour will get a nomination or probably even win. Here's how it is, Gladiator is an alright (two stars) summer movie, but for a well made movie of Best picture quality watch something like Chocolat or Enemy at the Gates instead.

PS. Just for the record, I have no problem with summer movies winning Best Picture as long as they're made properly, up to now the "Empire Strikes Back" is still my favourite film and I would have given it BP, and "Star Wars" also got a nomination because they were great and well made!

title: Over-Hyped Hollywood Idiocy
review:
Everything about Gladiator was completely *wrong*. Everything--every single thing about this movie--was handled in the wrong way. An excellent example is the gore and violence in this film--while the director made sure to include huge amounts of blood and guts in the fight scenes for no discernable reason, he weasled out in the one scene where such a graphic display might have made an emotional impact on the viewer (the murder of Maximus' wife and son). Why? Because it would have added a tiny smidgen of controversy to the film, and everyone knows that controversial films *never* get Oscars.

And speaking of which, the number of Oscar nominations this film received is a joke, exceeded only by the number of Oscars it actually won. I'm not saying that Joaquin Phoenix and Russel Crowe aren't good actors it's just that they were given so little to work with that their lack of conviction was inevitable. I was especially surprised with Russel Crowe's victory over Geoffrey Rush, who I thought had given an exceptional performance in Quills.

Well, at least Best Director went to Steven Soderbergh. Seeing that evil scowl on Ridley Scott's face when they presented the award almost made the whole rest of the evening worth it.

title: Ben Hur Lite
review:
Gladiator is an infuriating movie, an immensely overrated Ben Hur light that is clearly a graduate of the Armageddon school of filmmaking. Nevertheless, it does some things very well. And this is the problem perhaps. The combat sequences are a sight to behold, as exhilarating in their beautiful bloodshed as anything Ridley Scott has ever done (and he is the American master of beautiful bloodshed). But the drama that connects these sequences seem only filler, existing only to move us (sometimes in a most incoherent way geographically speaking) to the next moment Russell Crowe gets to bear his teeth and fight another battle.

But how is this a good movie? If anything Gladiator is more of a punched up, swords a blazing series of dance numbers. The drama rests on the shoulders of a one note performance by Russell Crowe, whose core emotion seems to be one of grimace and pout. He is a character who has one desire and one desire only: revenge. Many critics loved the intensity of the performance but why? A complex, interesting character should have complexity to them. But this character has no complexity, no range of emotions: he is a Stallone character trapped in an art film.

Joaquim Phoenix, on the other hand, was a delight, an over the top sociopath who brings a few precious moments of levity to an otherwise drab, ugly, and humorless film.

title: I Don't Get It
review:
What a dud of a movie!

Don't get me wrong. This movie had some amazing scenes, but I didn't think Russell Crowe's performance was anything spectacular (he was much better in "The Insider", and should've won best actor for that, but that's another story.)

The story was too predictable. We've seen this epic type movie many times over, and quite frankly, it's hard to come up with new material...I understand that. But to totally rip off scenes from it's predecesors...what's up with that?

I guess this movie just ranks up there with all of the other over-hyped movies (Titanic, There's Something About Mary, ANYTHING starring Julia Roberts!)

To be honest, I thought that Gladiator was almost boring. There was not enough action to keep the movie rolling.

As for Best Picture? I know that the Academy loves the epic, but there were a few movies in 2000 that deserved the awards more than Gladiator. (Almost Famous, Traffic, Crouching Tiger...)

Overall, I guess I just expected more from this movie. I guess I just have friends who hype movies too much. Maybe I should tell them to shut up.

title: Hopelessly Overrated
review:
I cannot believe this picture won the Best Picture Oscar. Now I am completely convinced that the OSCAR is given for political/economic reasons than artistic/merit reasons.

The film does a poor job of telling a dumb story. Yeah a slave gladiator takes over the greatest empire on earth by Killing Caesar in a duel front of spectators. How likely is that? The film tries its best to try to convince that it is plausible, but that's what makes this film hilariously bad.

The fighting scenes were poorly choreographed. The Tigers lounges out, it seems, only when the director wants them to, not when the gladiator should be trounced by it.

The special effects in this movie were not special. In fact, it has ALL been done before much BETTER in other films. What is so spectacular about developing a virtual colisum when we can create a virtual dinosaurs, cities, creatures, etc etc???

title: The best movie for 2000
review: I really enjoyed this movie so much that it's my best picture for the year 2000. I thought the start was quite brutal and wondered since they started fighting in the first minute of the movie, then what else is there for the duration. Well it will surprise you since there are good and evil characters in this movie. Once revenge was set in Crow then watch out for the excitement. It was exceptionally exciting. I have to give it a 10.

title: Why I prefer Spartacus
review:
I found this film to be massively overhyped, and was unbearably derivative, particularly of Spartacus.

Spartacus, on he other hand, is one of my all time favourite films. And given the immense similarities, I should have at least found Gladiator ntertaining. And I figured out why I didnt today - characters. Gladiator has none. Maximus the Gladiator is deliberately played by Crowe as a walking Zombie throughout the film, the Emperor is barking mad, and only Oliver Reed's part has any sort of substance, and even then is a carbon-copy of Peter Ustinov in Spartacus.

And speaking of carbon-copies, the emperor bears a strong resemblance to John Hurt as Caligula in the classic tv series I, Claudius (incidentally, Derek Jacobi, Claudius in that series, crops up in a small role here). However, Hurt's character had far more depth and believabilitly, and most importantly, was better played.

None of the other characters here really got anything to do, so that rules them out as well.

At least the emperor was fairly enjoyable to watch. Joaquim Phoenix has a lot of potential, he should go far.

And another thing. The score was dreadful. God knows why it sold so well. And God knows how come this film got so any Oscars. Russell Crowe as best actor? How difficult is it to look grim and stand still a lot? Dear oh dear.

The best scene was the opening battle. That, at least, was brilliantly filmed and very powerful. If only the rest could have lived up to it.

If you liked this, you should vastly prefer Spartacus and I, Claudius. If you havent seen this, dont bother and watch those instead.

title: Brilliant
review: I thoroughly enjoyed Gladiator. It was full of action, great acting and great costumes, all gripping the viewer. I watched it 20 times.( i'm sad) The action sequences are particularly good with the great music. coooool

title: Maybe It's Better On The Big Screen
review: I have probably missed out on a good part of this film's appeal by only seeing it on video, which medium doesn't really preserve the grandeur of big battle scenes and scenic vistas. Still, I can't imagine the acting or dialogue would be much improved by seeing it in the theatre, and watching it at home allowed the viewing audience to guiltlessly engage in an ongoing game of Spot-The-Cliche. That interactivity and Joaquin Phoenix's OTT performance actually kept us more-or-less tuned in for the full two and a half hours, which puts this ahead of quite a few blockbusters and/or Oscar winners in my personal top ten thousand.

title: Not worth going to the movies to see but worth renting.OK movie.
review:
I don't really think of this move as "historically sound"thats for sure! But once again movies have shown us that war isn't funny and should be avoided at all times.

I enjoyed this movie but I wouldn't spend 6 bucks to go see it at the movie theater.But if you have a rainy day with nothing to do go out and rent it and see what you think for yourself.And I do believe this movie is worth 2 1/2 hours of your time.

The movie was tragic and sad all the way through to the saddest ending since Romeo and Juliet-almost.So be prepared.

title: Overblown! As Shakespeare wrote -"Much ado about nothing!"
review: This movie was really quite silly.  Blurry photography, and oh so obvious special effects (I think they should have asked for some of their money back, you could see the computer enhanced crowds, buildings etc. but maybe this matched the movie as everything was so damn obvious and excessive and fake).  I liked Commodius (or whatever his name was) thought the Phoenix one played his role well, you could say he "rose above" the others.  Russell Crowe was talking in a lower register (what this is supposed to be sexy?) and mumbling.  Blood and guts and about as much feeling and emotion as a dead log.  This really is Hollywood Big Budget gone mad.  Give me good storyline and small budget any day.  Just colour and movement.  Much ado about nothin'. It seems a case of "The Emperor's New Clothes" the old children's fairy tale where cunning tailors fool the pompous Emperor that he is actually clothed in fine garments they have "made" when he is really naked.  It takes a couple of children to laugh and "expose" the truth when the Emperor parades in his "birthday suit"  Same thing here.  Everyone is saying it's huge and fabulous so it must be true.  It ain't.  Rome wasn't built in a day and neither is a good movie.  Hollywood quit the overblown effects and get back to the basics.  A rivetting good story with a beginning, a middle and an end.  Solid and honest acting, true to the character, with actors daring to put themselves on the line, and "real" settings - not computerland fakes!  Gladiator Smadiator - there's something rotten with this Rome - and it sure as hell stinks!

title: What the HELL this is the Best Picture?
review: I like this movie dont get me wrong.  It has some great action and an above average movie plot.  But the BEST picture of the year?...and the Best Actor? did these people watch the movie before voting for it?  Russ struts around puffing his chest out and he speaks a little more than Wilson from Cast Away.  And for this he brings home an Oscar?  I was busy trying to figure out how he got his nomination when blam...he wins.  I would rather have seen Tom Arnold win an Oscar for is roll in "Car Pool". Well maybe its not THAT bad.

title: Yawwwwwwwn
review:
A great movie when it came to blood and guts. But very typical and done many, many times before.

The ending is what really did it for me. I thought it truly sucked.

After all the fighting and pain, Maximus ends up like that.

I was just so pi**ed off that I wasted 2 hours and 45 minutes of my life watching this film, for it to end just like that.

title: There have been much better films on this theme
review:
Firstly, I was able to tell what was going to happen from one scene to the next. no suspense or real drama Next: The poorest use of CGI - I cant believe that I was able to spot all the computer effects (crowd scenes mainly & the entry to Rome. How this one any academy awards is beyond me.This is 2 years in a row that an an undeserving Dreamworks film won an oscar. I cant believe everyone is so in awe of Spielburg they honor anything he is associated with. For better movies of about a Gladiator Or this period of time see

SPARTACUS OR THE FALL OF THE ROMAN EMPIRE OR EVE QUO VADIS Fall of the Roman Empire was not that great a film but it sure surpasses this mess. & believe or not was more truthful in the story of the Emperor Commodus & Marcus Aurelius. Commodus was a trained expert wrestler & fought many times in the games, obviously he always won, except the final time. Besides having a yen for his sister he liked the boys also & that was completely left out.

as always

jay harris

title: WAY overhyped movie
review: Seen "Braveheart"?  Seen "West Side Story"?  Mix em together, you have "Gladiator".  This was supposed to be the most original, amazing film of the year.  What it really was was crap thrown together with a hot lead actor (who was totally undeserving of his Academy Award, as it should have gone to Ed Harris for "Pollock"), a bunch of special effect tigers, and an ending you could have seen from a mile away.  Want to see a good Russell Crowe movie?  Watch "LA Confidential" or "The Insider".  This gets a dismal 3/10.

title: Great fun! Russell Crowe is terrific!
review: This is one of the best war movies that I have ever seen. Russell Crowe is amazing! Loved it! Very good! This movie had a good mix of action, drama, romance,and war. This movie is a little graphic, but it is very good! Rent this and see for your self! It is great! I give it an A+!!

title: The best film of 2000, hands down.
review:
A film of incredible vision, brought to life by the best talent in all fields of filmmaking. The wonderful performances, the masterful cinematography, the god-like directing by Ridley Scott, and the best score of Hans Zimmer's career make this picture one for the ages. It was robbed of quite a few Oscars (Director, Score, Cinematography, Editing, Sound FX), but hey that's the silly Academy for ya. This is my #6 favorite film of all-time and I gave it a 96 on my rating scale. Now if only they'd give Ridley's brother Tony Scott a chance at such an epic...

Strength + Honor! Roma Victor!

title: Ready to go to ancient Rome.
review: Russell Crowe as Roman general Maximus leaves viewers amazed with his performance which won Crowe a best actor Oscar. Maximus winds up a gladiator after he refuses to pledge loyalty to the son of the dying Aurelius. Orders then come for Maximus to be executed only to lead to many great battles some of the most violent in film history that's just the way it was in ancient Rome times. Gladiator is a great movie to see if you like the historical/drama type and enjoy great battle scenes.

title: Cool special effects, but...
review:
Kinda like a poor remake of the '60s Fall of the Roman Empire" with a bit of "Ben Hur" mixed in.

With a poor story line.

Historically foolish.

O.K. great special effects...

It'll look VERY tired in a few years.

Watch it, it's fun (but best on big screen).

title: boring... boring... boring...
review: i cannot understand why this film got so many oscars. the story is really boring... nothing happens that is not expected. you know exactly what's coming next. the fighting scenes are dusgusting, and i cannot understand why one of the darkest chapter of roman history is celebrated as if it was great. the "panem et circenses - bread and games"-mentality of this period was really awful, but in this film you do not learn about the cruelty of people who spend their sparetime watching slaves killing each other - no, the fights are shown like great spectacles, and nobody cares for the poor lifes of the abused slaves. for the spectators of the film the fights are the same like for the historical roman spectators - just fun and entertainment. i would have expected more social interest for the incredible treatment of people. i must confess that i liked russel crowe, but i think most of the women do so. the scene when he found his wife and his boy crucified was really touching. but the rest of the film he spent with being brave, brave, brave... and over all hans zimmers music... i like zimmer, but i hate it, when every scene, every breath is commented with music. it's like a musical curtain all over the film, and i would sometimes prefer completely silent scenes. if a sad scene is written, acted and filmed brilliantly, then i don't need weeping violins in the background to learn: ah, this should be sad now! and the computer animations! did they cost more than 10, 99? if yes: you don't notice that! all in all: you don't miss a thing if you don't see the gladiator.

title: Overly rated but good action/drama...
review: 1st watched 5/7/2001 - 6 out of 10(Dir-Ridley Scott): Overly rated but good action/drama from director Ridley Scott.  The cinematography was great, and Joaquin Phoenix as the Caesar was excellent(which should have won him an Oscar), but of course Crowe won for an ok performance as best actor.  The film was directed well by Scott, but our appeal to the characters was lacking as opposed to a similar Oscar winner in "Braveheart" in that it had a lot of violence but Gibson was wonderfully captivating where Crowe was again just ok.  It seems like Oscar always tends to like a overly-produced epic know matter how good it is these days.  I hope that it returns to simple storytelling for it's best picture winners (aka. Chariots of Fire, Driving Miss Daisy etc...) in the future.

title: Best Movie!!?? Gimmie a break!
review: I can't say that I was really surprised when this movie won best picture. Hollywood long ago stopped awarding films that have any merit and only award films that make them money. Even saying that, to give this insipid junk any kind of recognition proves beyond a shadow of a doubt, that the academy awards are a pathetic farce. As far as battle scenes go, they weren't bad, but the rest of the film is a total bore, did the writers really think they were being clever by naming the title character Maximus!!?? Wow! How clever! Skip this movie. It stinks.

title: No big deal.
review: This is a good movie for watching on TV if there are no Star Trek reruns on. Heck, I've even seen some infomercials that were more entertaining than this. It sure wasn't "Best Picture" material.

title: A "Sorry" to Russell Crowe's "Insider"
review:
The only reason that Russell Crowe received the best actor award at the Oscars is for "Gladiator" is to make up for not giving him the award for his performance in The Insider the year before. A charismatic actor, Russell Crowe was the only reason to watch this overrated movie. I've lost faith in the Academy for their past choices when it comes to their "Best Picture Award". "American Beauty" and "Unforgiven" were the only winners that truly deserved the award.

Though supposedly historically correct, the story does not offer anything to be impressed about. Russell Crowe's character "Maximus" is unbelievably noble (Spaniard with Australian accent?) throughout this 3 hour movie. Even his brutal killings (to prove what point?) are designed to be admired. All the characters are one-dimensional and dialogue is clichèd to the point of being ridiculously fun (not a good thing).

*POSSIBLE SPOILER*A general wins a battle, loses everything (position as general and family) and climbs up the ladder of success to face the evil emperor to a predictable end... Death.

The story is the least of this movie's problems when compared to the battle scenes. The camera moves too quickly and misses it's aim most of the time (horrible, even if it was intentional). This is what you get when you pace the camera for a gunfight instead of a swordfight. Editing is even worse than the cinematography if you examine it closely enough. A scene in which a sword is taken by Maximus from an opponent is unbelievably screwed up. After all of that, we are exposed to a rollercoaster ride in which the rails have loose screws.

Yet, after all it's flaws, majority of the people like this movie. Why? Add it's box-office competition when it was first released with a barrage of more horrible movies plus advertising and promotion plus DVD with special features designed to make people admire it even more plus Russell Crowe with Meg Ryan equals "Movie of the Year". It's difficult to disagree with majority but this is very overrated.

title: i liked it better, when it was called...
review: ...BRAVEHEART!  the only difference is that Mel Gibson isn't in the movie. how can you say that it is even somewhat original.  it is an okay movie, but to say that it deserves special recognition is out of the question.  it is good to watch if you liked Braveheart, because it is pretty much the same movie.  have a nice day.

title: a clanker
review: Whether this is the worst movie ever to be given Best Picture Oscar is a tricky question, when one thinks of, for example, "Dances With Wolves," "Titanic," and "Forrest Gump"...  For Most Money and Research Used to Least Effect, the sinking of the White Star liner and the Roman Empire are just about a tie, but for contrived situations and dialogue that clanks worse than the armour (not to mention cheesy special effects), "Gladiator" is in a class of its own.  The film's popularity, and its garland of ill-earned awards are a distressing instance of substituted reality (the late, unlamented Dr Paul Goebbels would have understood this very well), of hype feeding on itself: the movie, as a movie rather than a sales-campaign, is a dud.

title: Good, but not worthy of Best Picture Oscar
review:
To tell you the truth, when I first saw this movie, I was kind of supprised that it was nominated for best picture. However, considering the years batch of movies, I can see why. 2000 had a lot of good movies, but only two of them (Traffic and Crouching Tiger) were worthy of winning best picture. Previous years have had movies of even higher calibur (American Beauty, Saving Private Ryan, Schindler's List, Forrest Gump, The Shawshank Redemption). If it wasn't for the ending I probably would have not even considered Gladiator for Best Picture at the Oscars. Gladiator is a movie with good acting, decent special effects, exciting gladiator scenes, and a solid, but a times drab screenplay. In certain parts of the movie the dialogue seems kind of cheesy, but these errors are not glaring. Those who are looking for an intelligent, mentally stimulating screenplay should look look elsewhere. However if you are willing to compromise a little, then Gladiator should not disappoint. Russell Crowe does give a solid performance, but I think his performance in last years drama The Insider was far superior. Crowe's vocal tone is good, but at times his New Zealander's accent seeps through in Gladiator. Joaquin Pheonix gives a Performance that just barely qualifies as worthy enough for an Oscar nomination.

When compared to the other movies of this year, Gladiator's acting is on the level with Traffic, Crouching Tiger, Almost Famous, Erin Brockavich and various movies heavily considered by the academy for nomination. As far as screenplay goes, Gladiator gets smacked by movies such as Crouching Tiger, Traffic, and Almost Famous, among others. As far as the other categories go, Crouching Tiger's Cinematography and Traffic's film editing do more for their respective movies than did Gladiator's excellent sound and decent, but flawed visual effects.

I would highly recommend this movie to just about anyone, but I'm afraid the Gold Guy for best picture should have gone elsewhere.

title: Worst "Best Picture Oscar" since "The Last Emporer"
review:
This movie is just such a mess, that last year must have been a worse year for movies than I'd realized. That said, Traffic is head and shoulders in quality beyond this silly toga movie.

There are little scenes in this movie that do not relate to ANYTHING - most notably, the scene near the end where someone puts a poisonous snake in a bed. The viewers are lead to believe that a certain traitor was being killed; the set-up about Cleopatra had been made in the previous scene. But nothing happens - the character is clearly alive later.

The scenes involving war crib from the best - Rashoman and Henry V, with music stolen from Holsts' The Planets. The gladiator scenes steal from Spartacus (with more gore, of course; Spartacus, made over 40 years ago, is a vastly superior movie despite Tony Curtis' problems with acting). The Collesium scenes use many shots from Ben Hur.

The performances are all over the place. Richard Harris and Oliver Reed (whose ruminations on death in the movie are all the more eerie since he died during the filming) are terrific. Russell Crowe is pretty good, but not great. His best scenes are during his general days early in the movie. But Juanquin Phoenix and, to a degree, Connie Nielsen feel like they are in a completely different movie.

Some of the photography and most of the CGI work (except when they attempted to animate a tiger) is quite good. The animated tigers intercut with real tigers showed the CGI isn't perfect because the perspective is extremely flat when the animated tigers are used.

This movie is an ambitious disappointment. It is very much like Ben Hur in that it has flashes of brilliance but is undercut by a surprisingly awkward script. On the whole, I'll take Ben Hur and Spartacus for great cinema about Rome.

title: HOW COULD THAT HAPPEN?!
review:
Initially, I didn't want to comment on Gladiator` at all, but now, as it won so many Oscars, I think I should:

How could that happen?! How could Hollywood sink so low and nominate this monstrous combination of pure commercial thinking and perverse blood lust for twelve Academy Awards, especially Best Actor and Supporting Actor (???), Best Writing, Best Director, Best Music and  Best Picture? Or is the Best Picture nomination only a result of the number of other nominations?

It really hurts seeing how the American audience ignored the terrible way history is treated in Hollywood. Ridley Scott commercialized the Ancient Rome so obviously that one might believe he meant it ironically. But the movie is deadly serious (as is Oscar-winning actor` Russell Crowe who moves his face I think three times during the whole film!), so we are really supposed to believe that Maximus the Gladiator was Christian and hoped to meet his family again in the Hereafter. The whole story is so dumb that even eight-year old children should say they are too old for such nonsense.

It is no argument pro Ridley Scott that he gave a second birth to the genre of the sandal movie`. The real Roman movies were historically more accurate, more intelligent and not so overloaded with glaring computer-animated visual backgrounds. Those were movies. Gladiator` is more like a videogame. An absolute disgrace happened on March 25th. It showed how poor in quality pictures the year 2000 was.

title: No I am not entertained.
review: No I am not entertained.  I went to this movie expecting little and receiving less.  I could single out certain individuals to point the finger at for this artistic failure of a film, but can't seem to see the point in it, this film was bad in so many areas that it really is a collaborative debacle.  Even the general audience failed, because in accepting this film the standards for what will be honored as a great film have been lowered dramatically.  The dialogue was stupid, the characters were completely overdrawn, the performances were typical, the plot was as formulaic as it gets, not one moment in this film left me anticipating the next, not one character was original or intriguing, and the cinematography was unimaginative and monotonous.  On top of this they kill off Richard Harris the best actor in the film at the beginning of this movie which crawls on its belly to the end.  To its credit the film does a decent job of creating the coliseum which unfortunately is not as impressive given the fact that Spartacus the original gladiator film was done four decades before this release and was just as successful if not more in this aspect.  This film never comes close to achieving the success of similar films made long ago. At best Gladiator is a watered down flat derivative of Spartacus.  The film is as dead as the time period it was supposed to depict, and perhaps just as dead is the general public's knowledge of a good film.  As a side note when one asks why it is important to have an appreciation and understanding of history in regards to art or a lexicon in the language of film I can think of no better reason than 'without a perspective of a variety of great works one will never fully be able to appreciate or understand what a great work truly is.'  In short this film lacked everything that constitutes a great film.  What is that?  Great filmmaking.

title: Best Picture? Huh?!
review:
Probably the worst movie to ever win the best picture Oscar (certainly the worst I've seen.)

Sure, the action is fun, the acting and directing are solid and the special effects are nice, but 'best picture'? The script for Gladiator leaves so much to be desired that everything the movie has going for it was not enough to keep me interested with the characters and the story.

A 'fun' popcorn movie, but no way does it deserve the best picture Oscar (even with the dearth of good movies in 2000.)just another overhyped, big budget Hollywood movie.

(6/10 )

title: Best Actor? Best Picture?
review:
The fact that the immortal Cary Grant never got the nod from the Academy should clue us all in as to their thought process. Gladiator was an entertaining film, but its characters (yes, every one of them) had all the depth of department store mannequins.

Worth watching? Sure. Worth all the accolades it received? Hardly.

Crowe or Grant? Uh huh.

title: great on the eye, awful on the ear
review:
oooohhh it looks just lovely, Rome is awesome and the set pieces, the opening fight scene and the gladatorial combat are fantastic to look at. But then it is spoiled by people opening their mouths. Not because they all have really bad teeth, but because someone should have taken the time to come up with a good script for Ridly Scott to do something with.

As ever Mr. Scott proves what a gifted director he is with great visual flair, but again he is poorly served with material that is all mouth and no trousers. And as for the performance by Joauqin Phoenix, well to say he was overacting his role as a madman would be to insult the undisputed title holder of overacting madmen, the one, the only Brad Pitt.

It's not bad, but how anybody could say that this is a better film than the simply sublime 'Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon' proves how little taste there is in the world and how unfortunately good guys so often don't get what they deserve.

title: I Weep For American Cinema
review:
Everything there is to be said about this movie has already been said, so I will keep my comments brief. "Gladiator"'s musical score is breathtaking; the rest of the movie, in all other facets, is garbage. If you generally like what the majority of the American population likes, you will enjoy this movie. If you usually prefer films with competent direction (including action scenes where you might actually *GASP* be able to see the action), intelligent dialogue (it took three people to write this?!), professional acting (brilliant death scene Russell...you really deserved that Oscar), or special effects that seem even remotely realistic, you may wish to look elsewhere. The latest in a long string of inane Best Picture choices, this is by far the worst in the history of the Academy Awards.

The only consolation for myself and those who share my opinion is that in twenty years, "Gladiator" will come to rest in the same category as "Rocky" and "Kramer vs Kramer"--not that there were any "Taxi Driver"s or "Apocalypse Now"s released in 2000. If this is a sign of things to come, the future of cinema in the United States will be very grim indeed.

title: Disappointimus Maximus
review:
Gladiator is quite possibly one of the least rousing, most underwhelming films to ever win a Best Picture Oscar.

This is the tale of Maximus (played with spirit by Russell Crowe in one of the film's few interesting performances), the Roman Empire's best general, who is betrayed by a vengeful emperor-to-be, and eventually enslaved to serve as a centerpiece for entertainment in the arenas of the gladiator. Robbed of his power as a citizen and a general, Maximus finds new power in the admiration of a crowd who adores him.

The interesting premise for this film is poorly executed, plodding along for much of the exposition before getting to any real development in traditional Ridley Scott fashion. With the exception of Crowe, most of the other main performances are uninspiring, and in the case of Joaquin Phoenix, downright dreadful. Phoenix's characterization has as much bite and energy as flat week-old beer, and he creates a villain who is so textbook that he is not formidable in the least.

The fight sequences are entertaining, but shot with such unsteadiness that we are robbed of seeing much of the action. The visual effects are surprisingly bad, looking inappropriately hazy and low-res, with many details ignored.

All in all, Gladiator fails to entertain on many points, and stands, in my opinion, as the most egregiously overrated film in the history of film.

title: Best picture? Please.
review: Both "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and "Traffic" were far superior movies, and both will be hailed as enduring classics.  Glandiator will continue to make money in rentals and retail purchases, as its star has undeniable appeal to women, and the action is certainly watchable, so it hits both sectors of the market.  But Best Picture of 2001?  Pleeease.

title: Watch Braveheart!
review: I got this film a long time ago on DVD but wasn't sure if it was even worth a look. I wanted to see this film before the oscars to see if it is worth the 12 nominees. It isn't...which means it will get them all. Some of the fighting scenes were great. And Russell Crowe was a good choice for the part. But thats all good to say about this film. It doesn't come even near Braveheart.

title: Only a flesh wound
review:
Gladiator isn't a great film by any means, but it isn't nearly as bad as some reviews would suggest. Sure, it depends mainly on big budget spectacle and production design to achieve its effect, but it's surprising how far big budget spectacle can take you.

I disagree with those who say that Russell Crowe was more or less interchangeable with any other Hollywood action star in the main role. I thought his basic persona - the strong yet vulnerable man carrying deep hurts - was quite well used in this film, and his performance and Connie Nielsen's lent a semblance of human interest to a script that didn't give them much to work with. The film's ability to build human drama isn't helped by its failure to provide a credible villain: it's obvious from the beginning that Commodus is no more going to be a match for Maximus than Frank Burns was for Hawkeye and B.J.

Some people have also criticized the film for its gratuitous violence, but I'm not sure if I go along with that either. If you are going to make a gladiator movie, you might as well go for broke. As a number of commentators have pointed out, we go to gladiator movies for pretty much the same reason as the Romans went to the Colosseum. To see blood.

Having said all that, I don't think the film was particularly well made. The film seems if anything to get less spectacular as it goes along, and what should be a series of climactic sequences at the end come across as hurried and confused. There are also rather too many places where the film is unintentionally comic. There's the film's odd notion that the Roman ruling classes all spoke in upper-class British accents. Then there are what look like odd borrowings from, or maybe misplaced tributes to, other films: the American Beauty-style falling petals, or the slow-motion battle sequences, which looked elegiacal in Kurosawa but seem Pythonesque here. Actually, even Maximus' name struck me as Pythonesque - I kept wondering whether his first name was Naughtius, and whether he had a friend called Biggus. Perhaps Naughtius Maximus would be an apt nickname for Russell Crowe in real life.

Once or twice the film does hint at higher ambitions. It touches on the theme of Commodus', Gracchus' and Maximus' relationships with the public, and the potential was there for the film to be a very original type of political thriller - something that would have given point to all those crowd scenes and all those power plays. But that theme isn't developed. In the end, Gladiator is not that kind of film.

title: Undecided
review:
This movie undoubtedly works on a frivolous, popcorn munching level. It seldom penetrates through the barrier that would make it a true classic with a resonant theme. I came out thinking it was nothing more than Death Wish B.C.

It is brilliant technically with astonishing visuals, and it is competently directed for such a massive exercise. The performances are good too, adding a contemporary dimension. Crowe is commanding as are each of the supporting players. I do not think they will rate the same way 20 years from now they will get lost in the extravagence of the film.

Gladiator probably ranks so high this year(2000) because everything else is pap. As usual there are stronger films in the indie and foreign circles, but if the mainstream dominates this could very well be the best picture......depressing!

title: A good film being confused as a great film
review: This movie basically came off as I expected, a good film, fun to watch with a lot of eye candy. However, a great film it is not nor will it ever be (let's see what history has to say). The script is horrid and predictable. Crowe does his job, maintain a dark and quiet intensity throughout the film (much like L.A Confidential, a projection that he did even better in that film than in Gladiator). The character of Commodus, with all of his flaws, was perhaps the most inept bit of scriptwriting I have seen (in a film that is supposed to be of high quality with great writing). Some have said that he lets down his guard and shows us a pitiable side (and a depth of character). There is nothing that comes across as pitiable. He wallows in self-pity, and when combined with his depravity as a human being, there is nothing there to like, nevermind find sympathy for. The script took an easy way out by giving us an antagonist that is far too easy to hate. If there was anyone deserving of a "best supporting actor" oscar nomination, it was Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius and not Joaquin Phoenix. All in all, it was a good film, fun to watch, not quite as nice on the tv screen as the movie screen, and definitely not deserving of a best picture nomination (take off chocolat and gladiator (saw all 5 nominated) and put up Almost Famous and Billy Elliot for the award...now those are great films and worthy of the honor).

title: Maximus waste of effort
review:
Those who applaud this movie do so for it's excitement and action. Those who denounce this film focus on the derivative plot, lack of character development, campy special effects, and sub-par acting. I choose to be with the latter group.

This film is worth seeing, in the theater alone, but please don't expect a masterpiece. Gladiator's massive decor is entertaining viewed on a large screen, but that's where the film's success ends. The plot took quite a few ideas from BraveHeart, Spartacus, and other epic period pieces of the past, but in this case, had nothing new to add. I would like to stay away from the comparison's to BraveHeart, but the similarities between this film and the former Oscar winner is too common. Another highlight of the film is Phoenix's character, Commodus. If you don't already know, the commode's namesake was this Caesar, so you can basically conjure up the outcome of this evil emporer.

I highly recommenend this movie if you enjoy 'neat' fighting scenes and 'cool' special effects. But I am still baffled from the fact that this picture is receiving so much attention from the Acadamy Awards. This film, like Titanic, will not stand the test of time.

title: Good movie, but a great one?
review:
"Gladiator", the movie favored to win the Oscar for Best Picture this coming March 25, is an epic movie that I found to be just good. I didn't think it was a great one like most people thought it was. Certainly not as great as "Ben-Hur" and "Spartacus", which "Gladiator" is no doubt inspired from. The good things about this movie are the two main performances by Russell Crowe (Maximus) and Joaquin Phoenix (Commodus), the action scenes in the Roman Colosseum, and the beautiful film score. All those elements get high marks. The cinematography, editing, and production design are very good as well. But if there's one element that keeps this movie from being a great film is the lackluster special effects. The effects aren't all that great here. Even though they're not bad at all times, there were some effect shots that looked obviously phony. That shouldn't happen in a film like this. Nevertheless, if you like historical epic movies, then you'll probably like "Gladiator". I was just a little disappointed that it wasn't the great film I thought it would be.

*** (out of four)

title: Well recorded sound on DVD, little else
review:
I rented Gladiator (1) to try out my new home theater speakers (upgraded from "2.1" to "5.1") are any good and (2) to see if Roger Ebert is right, whether this could be the worst movie ever to win the "best picture" academy award. The answer to both my questions is "yes."

Wow, this flick really sounded great on my stereo, dts encoding a special treat! Even the perfunctory and unremarkable "epic music" sounded good. I was able to tune up all 5.1 of my speakers, so don't touch my levels, I got them set just the way I want 'em. And now, the bad news.

Gladiator is overlong, overdirected, underscripted, and totally forgettable (aside from a being DVD showcase). It's hard to make a good epic. Spartacus this ain't. Moreover, as good as the sound was, the visual effects looked artificial. The tigers in one of the fight scenes were particularly cheesy. In the action sequences, it looked like the actors were filmed as they moved slowly, and then were restored to real speed through mechanical/digital means... this makes everything well focused, but ironically, a perfectly focused swinging forearm w/broadsword looks more like claymation than reality.

The acclaim of this movie doesn't astound me--people like gladiator movies. Indeed, all I kept thinking of as I watched was Peter Graves' line from "Airplane": "Joey, do you like movies about gladiators?" Hey, at least I got a laugh when I thought about this... 2.5 hours of total humorlessness is tough on a viewer. "Saving Private Ryan" had more laughs than Gladiator. Oh wait... the exploding firebombs in the opening fight scene had me howling. I love anachronism.

Such an oh-so-serious tone should be saved for the likes of Schindler's List or Judgment at Nuremberg. Gladiator fails at profundity. In trying to be an action flick, it fails worse--it's an hour too long. As an ode to history, I have no idea--I have problems identifying, much less cheering for, the "good Romans" of the reign of the Caesars.

title: Best picture?!?!
review: I would never say that the Acadamy Awards mean anything, but still I must say that I take a perverse pleasure out of watching the whole affair. Ridley Scott's Gladiator will most definitely go down in history as one of the most gaudy, inept pieces of commercial pap to come down the tube in a long time.  In terms of films that have been nominated for Best Picture, it will rank right up there with Cimarron (and that won!).  Have a little perspective, people--there were some great films made this year, and this is an ugly little movie.  With barely the inclination to turn its own lens on the idea of our modern audiencing of violence (a theme that would seem pretty obvious, and fairly easy to follow up on), Gladiator is another example of our movie going cultures' willingness to be spoon-fed every little detail, and unwillingness to be the least bit reflective. Did anyone see Hannibal (another Scott crap-sterpiece)?  Is there anything left for the imagination these days?

title: Ho hum
review:
The lead reviewer, who thinks this is one of the two greatest films ever made, must not have seen many films. Crowe, a sort of uninteresting Richard Burton, is Shane--the little good guy who beats up and kills all the bad guys. The film itself, designed for teens, is a mixture of pro wrestling and sentimentality. The religious aspect is laughable. The political correctness is boring.

Better to see The Robe, with the real Richard Burton.

title: Too Long And Not Very Good
review:
In German there is a good expression for movies such as Gladiator (G): "Historienfilm" -- it means that it is a movie which has a historic backdrop, but is not a movie ABOUT history. What worries me is that many people will think that G is realistic, that the historic context of it or even the entire story are accurate, which is not the case.

I found the movie definitely too long -- it would be much better if it had been cut by 45 or 60 minutes. The story line was too pompous, without much suspense, and ordinary. The "look and feel" (camerawork, lighting, sound track, decoration, casting, etc.) is high quality, though too glossy and commercial - like for my taste. As for believability -- oh well. Maybe seen from America ancient Germany is just a quick horse ride away from Rome and right next to a gladiator training center in the middle of the desert, but trust me -- it is not. And I do understand that there has to be a bad guy, but did it have to be a hare - lipped, father - killing, sister - fancying, paedophile dictator? And did the good guy have to be such a sickly - sweet mixture of George Washington, Rambo and Walt Whitman? And -- on a slightly jingoistic note -- if the ancient Germans were such club - swinging barbarians ("hunh? cavalry attack from back, that no fair"), how come the Romans never did capture the territory?

Conclusion: if the movie had been shortened, I would have found it OK to watch on the small screen (rental or free TV). As it is, I did not like it. And I find it depressing that such a great director as Ridley Scott seems to have dedicated himself to producing glossy, mind numbing garbage.

title: Mortal Kombat wins
review:
The plot, being old as the hills, is nothing to write home about.

And the lines about "win the mob", "give them blood" seemed more than a little ironic. Talk about a movie aimed at the Mortal Kombat crowd.

The cinematography was amazing. His long shots constantly reminded me of Maxwell Parrish; the quick Koyonasquaatsie-like "nature moving fast" shots were effective, and scene after scene of indoor opulence and/or mood-setting were meticulously lit.

Shame that such a talent as Scott's must be burned creating such a mundane barn-burner.

title: Its a joke that this film is up for an Oscar
review: Oscar material? Hardly.  Gladiator is at best a "B" level action flick. This film is filled with endless scenes of gore and mayhem, which hardly constitute acting.  It is the typical B level flick with tension building to the inevitable encounter of good guy and bad guy, which good guy obviously wins. Crowe walks around for 2 hours and 35 minutes with a semi-pained expression, but not saying much and certainly not acting. A further disservice of this movie is the way it warps history.  Marcus Aurelius died of the plague. His son, Commodus, ruled for 12 years and although he was insane and  did enter the arena, he was murdered elsewhere.  The final Germanic wars of Marcus Aurelius were fought on the Danube frontier and I don't know how you go from the Danube to Italy via a desert, unless you're miserably lost.  Which is sort of the theme of this movie.  People see this and think they're getting a history lesson rather than just junk.  I can easily think of ten movies this past year which had more meaning, intellectual content and stronger acting than Gladiator.

title: Do they come any better?
review: Ridley Scott may have a up & dn past; this time he hit the 'bullseye'. This movie is just getting better each time I see it; the first time was not enough. This is probably (so far) the best movie I've ever seen; but it takes a 50-60 inch screen with a really good sound system to appreciate all the work that has gone into this film! THANKYOU Ridley!

title: Russell Crowe should have passed this one up!
review:
Slow, dark & dreary. Action too gory. Battle scenes too fast-paced with jerky camera--thought I was watching war movies while on acid!

Spartacus on A&E Biography was much more interesting and entertaining.

title: Guy's movie compliment to Titanic.
review:
Why this movie is so critically acclaimed is beyond me. It is a boring a movie as its name. The characters are bland and one-dimensional. It is a B-movie in comparison to great Roman movies like Ben Hur and Sparticus. The only saving graces are the special effects, and Russell Crowe's big name. Russell Crowe wasn't even that great in this movie, he only carried the monicker of 'Next big actor'; the Hollywood flavor of the month.

So now, just like Titanic, it has road it success all the way to the Oscars and will probably win when other quality movies like Almost Famous, Wonder Boys and State and Main get snubbed. Once again the Academy screws up.

title: Like a cheap chocolate Easter Bunny: pretty package, but hollow
review:
There is a scene in Gladiator where Maximus is eating with a couple other gladiators. One is Juba, the man he befriends almost immediately after getting captured; and the other is the really big man (I'll call him Big Guy), I am not sure of the name, who Maximus refused to fight earlier, while the gladiators were, I presume, getting evaluated on their skills. In the scene Big Guy asks Maximus about his days as being a general. He asks if he fought in Germania, and Maximus responds, and I apologize for not having the exact quote, "I've fought in lots of countries." Something to that effect. When the question was asked, I thought to myself how interesting it would be if Big Guy had lost family in Germania. When you think about it it was a terribly odd question for Big Guy to ask. It became a distraction. I kept waiting for the great climax of the film, when Rome is safe and secure with Maximus finally being able to retire, when along comes Big Guy to do what none of the Romans could do: kill Maximus. And why not, I figured. After all, there were families killed in Germania too, right. Unfortunately nothing came of it, and I don't think I am giving anything away when I say that Big Guy eventually gets shot with arrows (despite the obviously apparent safety vest underneath his tunic). O.k. So I am giving something away, but he is a very minor character, as it turned out.

I only mention this delusion of mine because I think it says something about how hollow the script was, and what could have been. I mean, we had already been given a possible subplot during the "evaluation scene" when the two men give each other very serious looks, to put it mildly. I thought that this subplot would have given the film what it dearly lacked: something worth saying--perhaps a comment on violence in our society, how the brutality of war effects people on both sides of the battlefield. Frankly I would have liked to have had it happen. It would have made the experience much more enjoyable. Of course, the F/X still would have looked kind of cheesey, and the battle scenes would have been confusing and, quite frankly, poorly executed; but what a turn it would have made. Only a handful of people (possibly those who had long since gone bonkers) would have seen it coming. Instead of this we get nothing really. Just an especially brutal film that has nothing serious to say about anything.

title: Only Crowe was any good.
review: Take a great actor (Russell Crowe), a thin, predictable plot, some one-dimensional characters (e.g. Commodus), a TERRIBLE musical score and throw in some computer-generated graphics, and you've got a Hollywood blockbuster.  I guess it just goes to prove the old saying: no one ever lost money underestimating the taste of the American public.

title: Way too drawn out
review: Gladiator was a severe disappointment to me.  Firstly, it was too long, at least 45 minutes too long; 2h45m total.  But length alone doesn't make a movie seem long.  In fact, some movies that are very long don't seem very long at all, such as the Lawrence of Arabia, the Godfather movies and Braveheart, all riveting throughout.  No, Gladiator's problem was that it was obviously going for the look and feel of an epic.  It got the look just right.  No question, this movie looked fantastic; can't possibly give an argument there.  Unfortunately, the film didn't have enough story for an epic.  Solution?  To have long stretches of dialogue and to have long pauses between each line of dialogue which, by the way, was very, very bad.  The acting, therefore, was understandably average as no actor could possibly seem that convincing behind such overblown dialogue.

title: best movie of 2000
review:
Despite what some critics think of this movie, i think this movie deserves to be best picture of the year. I was blown away by this movie. I watch it five times and I am still not bored with it.

I heard alot of people dissing this movie because the movie is too predictable and the character are shallow. I admit the story is predictable but I didn't care. When I watch it, i wasn't thinking what is going to happen next because it wouldn't be enjoying. I don't think the characters are shallow. There were parts in the movie that was very moving in Russel character.

Overall, the story is great, the music is powerful, and outstanding acting.

title: Excellent impact!
review: What a role model, that Maximus! Excellent plot, cinematography, not over-rated a bit. I also appreciated that the plot wasn't distracted with heavy romance/sex... that would have depreciated the flik. Not as gory as I was led to believe, still - there was gore, but the film was not a horror movie and it was realistic and fast. It contained all the right elements. Great acting, great audience response, an excellent "one man's" epic!

title: Entertaining.
review: Gladiator started out with a bang: an intense battle scene, followed by some nice interaction between the characters. After that, the movie devolves into a comic book level romp through the ancient world -- the characters become cartoonish, and the plot becomes predictable. Entertaining yes, but no more so than Conan the Barbarian (which is arguably the better picture).

title: For pure adventure makes Castaways look like childs play
review:
From a person who is normally cynical of almost all movies seen in the past few years, and one who rarely sees a film with brutal violence, I still have to rate this film outstanding. Although not historically accurate from a biographical point of view - it is extremely accurate from the poor gladiators point of view. Yes it happened exactly as the film depicted. The untold slaughter of these poor souls was carried on with Super Bowl style hype for generations for the amusement of the general non-slave citizenry and its patrician class.

The acting is good, the plot sound, and the scenes displaying the ancient way of life accurate. Though the results are inevitable, the film is powerful. For anyone whoever wondered what life was like in ancient Rome this movie is a must. Oh yes, do not be late for the opening scenes, they are terrifyingly real.

title: Watch it for the mise-en-scene
review:
First, the good things about this movie: costumes, set, decorations, and locations, and an excellent beginning fight sequence.

Otherwise, I have to agree with others that this is a poor movie with a weak story. Every character was one-dimensioned and shallow: Russel Crowe as a honorable warrior-family man who who cannot be corrupted by power, Richard Harris as an aged ruler who realizes his legacy should not be about the size of his empire but about the people, Joaquin Phoenix as a conflicted boy who feels unloved by his father, so on and so forth.

Ridley Scott is contrived and conventional. *Possibler spoiler* Case in point: on a deleted scene on the DVD where Lucilla admits that Commodus may have to die to save the Roman Empire. Scott says this was the first time Lucilla expressed her ambivalence regarding her brother and Scott decided to delete the scene say so he can stretch the ambiguity. Hello - was that ambiguity not painfully obvious after we see them together for 10 minutes!?

Hans Zimmer music does not help other - the score sounded like `Lion King' plus `The Prince of Egypt' without the musical numbers.

Overall, the film is problematic and a disappointment. I rank it a 5 out of 10. Watch it for the mise-en-scene.

title: Absolutely brilliant movie!!!!
review: For the people who say this film was not as good as hyped, or was not entertaining, i think you are totally wrong.  This film was brilliant and is the best movie of the year.  The camera work, script and storyline were absolutly perfect and although the history wasn't exact you don't go to the cinema to watch a documentary.

title: fiction better than reality; the mindset of Rome
review:
*Warning: spoilers.

Recently, a kind person out there notified me of an historical mistake in my previous commentary, pointing out to me that it was Lucius Verus who co-ruled with Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris' character in the film) and not Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix). I have to thank that person, because to be honest, I have not read much about the later years of the Roman Empire in many years, and had forgotten many details concerning the end of the Pax Romana. Nonetheless, and I may be wrong about this as it comes off the top of my head, I do believe that Marcus Aurelius did in fact approve of the choice of his son Commodus, which was not the case in "Gladiator". But I have to say, in this matter, I prefer the fictional account of the events over the reality. And to me, "Gladiator" does capture the essence of a broader Roman history in microcosm. In particular I found it strikingly interesting that at one of the gladiating tournaments in the film, the commentator spoke of the ancient Roman enemy of mighty Carthage as something out of "hallowed antiquity"... it seems unbelievable to imagine that the Roman empire lasted nearly a thousand years, and its citizens would probably have never been able to imagine it ending (doesn't it LOOK in the film as though the colosseum was built to last forever? And they do call Rome "the Eternal City", after all) or that a dark age would follow, with a thousand more years of ignorance and illiteracy until our modern age. It's hard to imagine that by the time in which "Gladiator" takes place, the Punic wars against Carthage which they use to stage gladiator battles in "Gladiator" had been over for around four hundred years! It kind of puts it into perspective how short-lived our own modern era is thus far. And just how long will we prosper before our "empire" begins to decline? When I think of this and put myself in Marcus Aurelius' shoes, who, in "Gladiator", could foresee that under his son Commodus, the empire would be heading into disaster (it IS nice to think that Marcus Aurelius would have foreseen this), I can understand why he was so determined to choose Maximus as his successor in order to return Rome to a republic (arguably something better). "Gladiator" is on one level a satisfying film because it not only asks what might have been possible to save the Roman Empire from collapsing but tempts us with a possible answer! As it turned out, nothing could save Rome; though the strength of Maximus' character is such that you begin to believe that he can save Rome from itself. To sum it up: if you enjoy a thought-provoking film that will leave you with more questions long after the film is over, you'll enjoy "Gladiator".

title: The Narcissistic Exploits of Capitalist-Pig Producers In the Hunt for a Quick Buck!
review: In this film, laughingly called Gladiator, there's all the glitz and glamour, the sets and costumes, the special effects, and actors necessary to make a decent film, but they completely miss the mark.  Well, you've probably seen this movie and you're thinking to yourself, I don't see how someone could say that...  And on the surface, the film does have two redeeming aspects...  the cinematography, which I must admit is awesome, and Russell Crowe in a little blue dress.  However, this beautiful, big-budget movie lacks one seemingly minor, but key element: a substantive plot. Although excessive violence, a forced hero, a sexy heroine, and a stint with incest may look like the makings of a great film, Gladiator would only measure approximately twenty-five minutes if you removed all the fight scenes.  You could probably get more plot from watching the Superbowl than watching this film.  In the first ten minutes of the film you know exactly what will happen in this movie and how it will end.  We've all seen this movie before with a better leading man, a smarter heroine, a crueler and more tyrannical ruler, and an actual plot.  It's called BRAVEHEART and it won five, count 'em FIVE Oscars!  This piece of trash that calls itself a movie is not even fit to be considered Braveheart's little sister.  First of all, Maximus Decimus Meridius (Russell Crowe) is not there to save his people.  He's there simply to get revenge on Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), a ruler who's only concern is lifting the skirt of his babalicious sister, a woman who just happens to be madly in love with Maximus (shocker there). Why does Maximus want revenge?  Hmm, because his beloved wife and son, people who are barely in the movie and hence receive little pity from the audience, are savagely butchered.  Haven't we seen this before?  So Maximus is forced to fight for his life.  Yada yada yada.  This lasts about two hours.  He does the usual stuff...  He kicks ass, makes adversaries into friends, and shows off his shapely legs in a little powder blue dress... most fetching.  Then obviously, he faces the odious Commodus in a final fight scene so that he may unleash his terrible wrath.  Woo.  And he is, much like William Wallace, killed and reunited with his dearly departed. Filmmakers today think that they can pass off a movie that everyone's already seen as something new by dazzling them with sparkly lights and flashy special effects.  I'd like to point out that basically everything from Braveheart, even the Australian-accented Russell Crowe trying to be Mel Gibson, has been replicated but as with most copies, it ain't as good as the original.  And yes, this year's movie-pickings have been slim, but that doesn't make it good by default.

title: Entertaining, yet flawed
review:
Gladiator, though entertaining, is one of the most overrated movies of the year.

The biggest problem with this movie is the direction during the battle and fight sequences. The camera is too close to the action. This closeness causes many problems. First of all, the close camera work during the fight scenes left me feeling cheated. The close camera work puts us into the action a little too much, and some of the fight sequences weren't as exciting as they could have been if there were a few wide shots put in there. This closeness also made the "special effects" of the Colosseum look hokey. The people siting in the nosebleed sections of the stadium looked fake (granted, they WERE computer generated, but shouldn't they at least appear real?).

Other problems with this movie include cliches ("On my signal, unleash hell"), anachronisms (Maximus says something in Italian, though the language doesn't appear until much later) and historical inaccuracies (Marcus Aurelius didn't die that way the last time I checked)

Other than that, this movie is an entertaining one. The acting is excellent, especially by Joaquin Phoenix as the evil twit Commodus. All in all, I would recommend this movie simply for entertainment purposes. As for Best Picture of the year...I think not.

**1/2 out of ****

title: THE WORST FILM I HAVE EVER SCENE
review:
I watched this film after everyone i know said "It is the best movie ever"..... BOY WERE THEY WRONG. From the first battle I thought "Well this movie is not going to fly along fast". Instead it was was the slowest film with the worst rip offs ever.

Now you want a good Gladiator film Kubricks "Spartacus." And now Crowe (Who was good in Sum of Us, Romper stomper, Virtuosity, LA confidential) has won a Critics award for his Acting in this film.... MY GOD..... I think if he wins the oscar we should get in the bat mobile and kill every film maker and studio execs and every Film Critic because our society is getting dumber.

SO if you want a good film get out "FIGHT CLUB" OR "BODY SHOTS". Get a movie which the filmmakers actually want to make a good film.

But I shall forgive Russell after making Proof Of Life.... What a movie that was..... But Gladiator... God damn this world

title: Pure entertainment
review:
A fun, pretty shiny thing. The almost braveheart, or Ben-Hur/Spartacus redux. Ridley Scott does it again, he really does create an immersive beautiful, obviously faked world. The acting...well, not much to work with, so hell, Scott always has scenery chewing, so what. They're not the show, the Roman world, a very specific silly version of the Roman world is. Its a well-balanced movie, with nothing being especially good.

Speaking of which, for a budget that big, the effects were pretty, but they clearly weren't that impressive. You can tell where they are, which is too bad. In a year with better movies (hardly a bold statement, and its not like they get much better), this wouldn't be considered for anything. Hell, even Titanic might have had more merits. ...

Nevermind.

title: impressive spectacle (some minor spoilers)
review:
Hindsight is 20/20 - and in the world of movies that is as true of surprise box office successes as it is of unexpected box office failures.
